title: celebrity update - Wayne Brady OF LET'S MAKE A DEAL ON CBS
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
celebrity update - Wayne Brady OF LET'S MAKE A DEAL ON CBS

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 10A | Section: News 
 
 288
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Q: How long has Wayne Brady been hosting "Let's Make a Deal"?A: Ever since CBS' current daytime version began in 2009. Its premiere there made it a rare series to run on three different broadcast networks, since the original show - hosted by Monty Hall, also (along with business partner Stefan Hatos) a creator and producer of it - ran on NBC from 1963 to 1966, then moved to ABC, where it continued until 1976.There also were other editions before the Brady-hosted revival premiered, with NBC attempting it again twice, in daytime with Bob Hilton and (very briefly) in prime time with Bush.Brady has earned two of his five Emmy Awards for his work on "Let's Make a Deal," and by the time he started that job, the idea of comedians becoming gameshow hosts had been accepted. Among examples, Drew Carey assumed the hosting spot on "The Price Is Right" in 2007, and Louie Anderson had guided "Family Feud" from 1999 to 2002 (Steve Harvey started in the latter show in 2010).In interviews, Brady has maintained that he never wanted to be just one thing in the entertainment world not exclusively an actor nor a comic (a skill he has displayed plentifully on the improvisation-oriented "Whose Line Is It Anyway?") nor a singer (he was nominated for a 2009 Grammy Award for his cover of Sam Cooke's "A Change Is Gonna Come"). He also has appeared on Broadway in "Chicago," "Freestyle Love Supreme" and "Kinky Boots." Along with "The Price Is Right," extra episodes of "Let's Make a Deal" have been made expressly for CBS' prime time lineup. That will continue for both shows during the upcoming television season, when they are slated to be seen on Friday nights starting in November.

title: "The Apartment" remains well worth visiting
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
"The Apartment" remains well worth visiting

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 16A | Section: News 
 
 178
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Still one of movie history's greatest comedies, though it has its share of pathos as well, "The Apartment" claimed the Oscar as the best picture of 1960. An MGM+ Drive-In attraction on Monday, Oct. 9, and Tuesday, Oct. 10, director and co-writer Billy Wilder's tale casts Jack Lemmon as an office drone who's quite popular with much of the management at his workplace thanks to his relatively tiny apartment, which he loans out to the bosses so that they can have romantic trysts there.The company's main chief (Fred MacMurray) discovers what's going on and cuts himself in, but his affair is with the office building's elevator operator (Shirley MacLaine) - who is greatly liked by Lemmon's character, forcing him to develop more of a conscience about what he's been facilitating. This simply is a great film that not only has held up on its own over 60-plus years, it also inspired the hit stage musical "Promises, Promises." The excellent cast also includes Ray Walston, Jack Kruschen and Edie Adams.

title: Beyond time and space: 'Loki' returns with uncontrollable powers
author: Sarah Passingham
content:
Beyond time and space: 'Loki' returns with uncontrollable powers

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sarah Passingham | Page: 9A | Section: News 
 
 436
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We've all done the time warp and explored the multiverse, but it's high time to sort out the timeline. A brand-new season of "Loki" premieres Friday, Oct. 6, on Disney+. Tom Hiddleston ("The Essex Serpent") returns as the God of Mischief, everyone's favorite troublemaker, Loki, who has developed a mysterious problem this season.Owen Wilson ("Haunted Mansion," 2023) is back as Mobius M. Mobius, the Time Variance Authority agent tasked with helping Loki right his wrongs across the multiverse. The first season of "Loki" saw the Norse God meet his match in an alternate version of himself. Sophia Di Martino ("The Electrical Life of Louis Wain," 2021) is Sylvie, a variant of Loki who interrupts the Sacred Timeline. After coming together to set things right across space and time, Loki returned to what he thought would be the TVA headquarters he left before his mission, but something still wasn't right.In the official trailer for the upcoming season, Mobius brings Loki to a repair shop of sorts, manned by TVA repair guy OB, portrayed by Ke Huy Quan ("American Born Chinese"). Before the pair have time to explain what's brought them there, Loki suddenly, uncontrollably disappears in a timeslip, leaving Mobius looking to OB for an answer. "It's impossible to timeslip in the TVA," is all he can say, though they just watched it happen."Loki" executive producer Kevin Wright told Entertainment Weekly in September that "[OB's] job is basically every piece of tech, every computer, every thing that is running at the TVA. [[---]] He either designed it or he fixes it and keeps it running." Having recently picked up an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor in 2022's "Everything Everywhere All At Once," Quan is well suited to help repair another multiverse.While Quan's character is the latest to join Loki's crew as he chases chaos across the multiverse, several cast members return for the new season, including Gugu Mbatha-Raw ("Surface") as Ravonna Renslayer, an ambitious judge in the TVA who oversees Loki's case. Literally backing up Loki at one point in the season's trailer alongside Mobius, Sylvie and OB is Wunmi Mosaku ("We Own This City") as Hunter B-15. Eugene Cordero ("Star Trek: Lower Decks") returns as Hunter K-5E, former TVA receptionist.The upcoming seasons also star Neil Ellice ("Halo 4: Forward Unto Dawn") as Hunter D-90, Jonathan Majors ("Creed III," 2023) as He Who Remains and Tara Strong ("Teen Titans Go!") as the voice of Miss Minutes. Rafael Casal ("Blindspotting"), Kate Dickie ("Annika") and Liz Carr ("Silent Witness") all join the cast this season in as-yet-unnamed roles. 
 
 Caption: Owen Wilson and Tom Hiddleston in "Loki"

title: Michael Caine is spy Harry Palmer in a TCM double feature
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Michael Caine is spy Harry Palmer in a TCM double feature

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 12A | Section: News 
 
 333
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Many secret agents came to the screen during the spy craze of the 1960s, but Harry Palmer made his mind his main weapon.Played by Michael Caine, novelist Len Deighton's brainy character sparked three theatrical features, released over three consecutive years and two of them form a double bill Sunday, Oct. 8, on Turner Classic Movies. Logically scheduled first is the character's initial film, "The Ipcress File" (1965), then the lineup skips the second picture in the series (1966's "Funeral in Berlin") to proceed directly to the third, "Billion Dollar Brain" (1967).Harry Saltzman, who was one of the original producers of the James Bond movies along with Albert R. Broccoli), bought the film rights to the Palmer books from Deighton during the latter's brief involvement with the Bond franchise. Interestingly, each of the '60s Palmer capers was released by a different studio: "The Ipcress File" by Universal, "Funeral in Berlin" by Paramount, and "Billion Dollar Brain" by United Artists.Such key players in the 007 series as composer John Barry, editor Peter R. Hunt and composer John Barry were brought over by Saltzman for "The Ipcress File." The movie that made later two-time Oscar winner Caine a star, it finds ex-military man Palmer enlisted to find a kidnapped scientist.complications involving British Intelligence and the CIA arise as the case proceeds, with Palmer eventually captured and subjected to brainwashing in a classic sequence designed for maximum tension by Hunt and director Sidney J. Furie.While "The Ipcress File" is deliberately low in gadgetry, "Billion Dollar Brain" leans more into the technology that became such a part of the spy genre during that era. An early work by director Ken Russell, later of "Women in Love" and "Tommy" fame, it pits Palmer against a computer-obsessed tycoon (Ed Begley) who schemes to incite World War III by dispatching his own private army. Karl Malden, who would reunite with Caine in 1979's "Beyond the Poseidon Adventure," plays a presumed friend of Palmer. 
 
 Caption: Michael Caine and Nigel Green in "The Ipcress File"

title: Boo at the Zoo returns this month at the Smithsonian - HALLOWEEN
content:
Boo at the Zoo returns this month at the Smithsonian - HALLOWEEN

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 7A | Section: News 
 
 455
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It is no trick, only the sweetest treat: Boo at the Zoo, sponsored by Mars Wrigley Confectionery, is back at the Smithsonian's National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute in Washington, D.C.On Oct. 20, 21 and 22 from 6 to 8 p.m., the zoo will be brimming with festive displays and spook-tacular trick-or-treating for this special ticketed event. As an added treat, Smithsonian National Zoo members can enjoy early admission from 5 to 6 p.m. all three nights.Boo at the Zoo offers families a safe atmosphere to trick-or-treat while enjoying festive Halloween decorations in the wild and not-so-spooky setting of the zoo.Tickets include afterhours access to popular zoo exhibits, including the Small Mammal House, Elephant Community Center and Reptile Discovery Center.Guests can feast their eyes on spellbinding habitats decorated with jack-o'-lanterns, spooky enrichment and tasty treats for the animals.Each trick-or-treater will receive one recyclable bag to fill up with sweets, snacks and other fun surprises at around 30 booths stationed throughout the park. Fiendishly fun vignettes featuring frolicking skeletons and fantastical creatures will liven up the zoo's main pathway, Olmsted Walk.Tickets are on sale for $35 or for $25 for zoo members.Each attendee, including any children over the age of 2, will need a ticket.In addition to early access to the event, zoo member benefits include discounted parking, which is available for pre-purchase online at $20 per vehicle for zoo members and $30 per vehicle for non-members.Only guests with a parking pass will be permitted to enter the zoo's Connecticut Avenue entrance with their vehicle.Guests using ride share vehicles will be dropped off and picked up at the designated ride share zones near the Connecticut Avenue and Harvard Street entrances. Zoo staff will scan tickets at both the Connecticut Avenue entrance and lower entrance near the Kids' Farm. Metro Bus (L1 and L2) and Metro Rail (Woodley Park-Zoo and Cleveland Park) have stops within walking distance of the zoo's main pedestrian entrance on Connecticut Avenue.Guests of all ages are invited to dress up in creative costumes. Adult guests are not permitted to wear masks that fully cover the face or obstruct the wearer's vision.Additionally, costumes may not contain any props or accessories that resemble or could easily be mistaken for an actual weapon.Boo at the Zoo is an extremely popular event with Washington area families who celebrate Halloween.Due to limited capacity, tickets and parking passes tend to sell out quickly. Guests are encouraged to plan ahead and purchase both tickets and parking passes early. All proceeds from Boo at the Zoo support animal care and conservation science at the zoo.This event will be held rain or shine. For more information, visit the zoo's website at https://nationalzoo.si.edu/events/boo-zoo. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Creepy confections: 'The Big Bake' returns with a Halloween-themed season
content:
Creepy confections: 'The Big Bake' returns with a Halloween-themed season

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 14A | Section: News 
 
 375
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Dig into some deadly delights as a new episode of "The Big Bake: Halloween" airs Monday, Oct. 9, on Food Network.The series, hosted by Brad Smith ("Eddsworld"), welcomes returning "Big Bake" champions and veterans, each looking to redeem themselves in this larger-than-life, "Halloween"-themed event.Food Network describes: "In each episode, three professional baking teams have five hours to design, bake and decorate a grandscale cake creation based on a particular theme. These bakers need to think big and bold, blowing up their designs to gigantic proportions and thinking outside the (bakery) box." As "Big Bake" competitions take place throughout the year, this iteration celebrates the spookiest and scariest season of them all, tasking bakers with eye-popping and downright dreary challenges that feature spooky Halloween treats, creepy clown cakes, fa-boolous shrieks, scares and costumes galore.So far this season, the teams have been asked to create cakes of the best "boo-ticians" in town, decorated with their creepy clientele, and then made their way to the carnival, where funhouse screams were on the menu as Smith asked the baking teams to create some spine-chilling desserts.But fear not. The scariest snacks are still to come.During this upcoming episode, Food Network promises that witches will be the "talk of the town," as a description for the challenge shares that "Brad Smith asks the baking teams to wave their magic whisks to create cakes featuring the queens of Halloween." In the following weeks, the competition continues, as bakers serve some "big bog bakes" with swamp-themed cakes and later tackle their fears by making creations that feature thrill-seeking monsters.As tension rises and suspense builds, bakers must do their best to impress this season's judges - pastry chef Ron Ben-Israel ("Cake Wars"), cornerback-turned-chef Eddie Jackson ("Outchef 'd") and internet personality/cookbook author Danni Rose ("Danni's Juke Joint Comfort Food Cookbook: Modern-Day Recipes, Ole Skool Flavas," releasing in November 2023) - and avoid elimination, making it to the end of the competition, where the most ambitious (and terrifying) baker will go home with a $10,000 prize.Jam-packed with creepy confections, taunting treats and bizarre baked goods, new episodes of "The Big Bake: Halloween" air Mondays through October on Food Network.

title: more retro rewinds
content:
more retro rewinds

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 16A | Section: News 
 
 243
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "Murder on the Orient Express" (Paramount+, streaming): Director Sidney Lumet's wonderfully stylish 1974 version of the Agatha Christie mystery is - just as the ads promised - "the who's who in the whodunit," encompassing everyone from Albert Finney (as master sleuth Hercule Poirot) and Sean Connery to Lauren Bacall and Oscar winner Ingrid Bergman. The story has been told in other screen versions as well, but the sheer style and elegance of this rendering is hard to top."How the West Was Won" (Turner Classic Movies, Monday, Oct. 9): Launching a two-night "National Parks and Landmarks" event that concludes the following Monday, this 1962 epic handled by multiple directors (John Ford among them) originally used the Cinerama process to tell several stories of the Old West, underscored by truly majestic settings. Spencer Tracy narrates the picture, whose huge cast includes James Stewart, John Wayne, Henry Fonda, Debbie Reynolds, Karl Malden, Robert Preston, Gregory Peck, Carroll Baker, Richard Widmark, Carolyn Jones and George Peppard."Frasier" (Cozi TV, Tuesday, Oct. 10): In the week when a revival of the "Cheers" spinoff begins on Paramount+, the first episode of the original version gets a repeat. Kelsey Grammer relocates his character, Dr. Frasier Crane, from Boston back to his hometown of Seattle - where his reunions with his brother Niles (David Hyde Pierce) and their father Martin (John Mahoney) aren't exactly conventional.Griffin Dunne and Linda Hamilton were the first actors to provide guest voices as callers to Frasier's radio show.

title: Bridge - Wisely employ your big gun
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Wisely employ your big gun

 October 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 21 | Section: News 
 
 269
 Words 

 Read News Document

 What does the word "punch" suggest to you? To a pugilist, it is a means to an end: the end of his opponent's resistance. (Why does anyone inflict physical pain on another, human or animal?) An Englishman might think of the humorous Punch magazine, long deceased. One of its former editors, Malcolm Muggeridge, defended his tenure by writing: "Good taste and humor are a contradiction in terms." However, to a bridge player, "punch" is forcing declarer to ruff and lose trump control -- as in today's deal.After a straightforward auction, West has to choose a lead. Some would misguidedly select the singleton heart. They would argue that partner might have the ace (unlikely on this auction) or that partner might have the club jack as an entry and either the dummy or declarer might hold only a singleton club. However, if the latter is the position, there are only three defensive tricks: the spade ace, the club jack and one heart ruff.Much more sensible is to lead a top club and to continue leading club winners. After ruffing the third round, South plays a spade. Suppose West ducks this trick, to check South's spade length, and wins the next round with his ace. He forces declarer a second time with another club. This leaves the dummy and South with one spade each while West retains two. Whatever South does now, West must score a second trump trick -- and his fourth in all -- to defeat the contract.I suppose, if I weren't above that level of humor, I'd add that West had clubbed South to death.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Talbot Interfaith Shelter stages Showdown
content:
Talbot Interfaith Shelter stages Showdown

 October 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 419
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Talbot Interfaith Shelter's (TIS) S4 program - Shelter, Stability, Support, Success - is designed to guide families and individuals from homelessness to self-sufficiency. On Oct. 21, the community is invited to help these neighbors overcome the obstacle of homelessness at the inaugural Shelter Showdown & Hoedown.The Showdown "goes down" at Tardigrade Obstacle Course and Fitness Facility in Cordova, where participants will get the chance to prove that they are "TIS tough." Families and children can join the non-competitive Family Fun Waves from noon to 2 p.m. Registration for this wave is $25 for adults, $15 for children over 5 and free for children under 5.The Competitive Waves begin at 3 p.m. Participants can compete solo or in teams and can sign up to raise additional funds in support of TIS' mission. Registration for the Competitive Waves is $40 per person.The competition is already heating up. The Talbot County Sherriff's Office will be putting a team together to compete and has laid down the challenge for other local first responders to do the same.Sheriff Joe Gamble shares his excitement for this new local event, saying, "Talbot Interfaith Shelter is such an important part of our community, and the Talbot County Sheriff's Office is excited to join them for this fantastic new event. We look forward to meeting our fellow local first responders on the Shelter Showdown starting line, although, we fully expect to be waiting for them at the finish. In all seriousness, I hope to see our whole community out on October 21st having fun together while supporting TIS and its vital mission."All Showdown registrations include admission to the Hoedown, which takes place next door to Tardigrade at Triple Creek Winery from 1 to 6 p.m. The Hoedown celebration is open to the whole community. Admission for non-Showdown attendees is $10 per person, with children under 12 entering for free.Join in the fun for food, beer, wine and entertainment for the whole family. Kids will have a blast on the giant inflatable play course, along with other games and a craft corner. For the big kids, there will be adult axe throwing and archery games. Everyone will enjoy live music by local favorite Justin Ryan from 2 to 5 p.m.Showdown registration and Hoedown tickets are available at talbotinterfaithshelter.org/showdown.The Shelter Showdown & Hoedown offers many advertising opportunities for local businesses. To learn more about becoming a Shelter Showdown & Hoedown sponsor, contact Development Director Laura Richeson at 443-786-6962 or lauraricheson@talbotinterfaithshelter.org. Visit talbotinterfaithshelter.org to learn more about Talbot Interfaith Shelter and how you can help.

title: Taste of Cambridge returns - Ten restaurants will be there along with distilleries and wineries
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Taste of Cambridge returns - Ten restaurants will be there along with distilleries and wineries

 October 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 574
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - After four years, Taste of Cambridge is back.On Saturday, from noon to 6 p.m. in downtown Cambridge, residents and visitors will have the opportunity to taste the flavors of Dorchester County and the Eastern Shore.Ten restaurants have committed to the event, as well as a mix of distilleries and wineries - so that event-goers can sip while they taste.And for its first year back since 2019, Taste of Cambridge has expanded its tasting categories. Margaret Knudsen, executive director of Cambridge Main Street, which hosts the event, said that in previous years, the taste category was often crab and one "fun bonus" taste. However, this year the categories are crab, seasonal soup and stew, mac and cheese, apple and pumpkin."So everyone who has a tasting ticket will be able to get a little bit of savory as well as sweet," Knudsen said.A cooking contest, which will go until 4 p.m., will determine the winners of each of these different food categories.Entry to the festival is free and those who want to eat and drink can purchase tickets.This year, there will are a variety of ticket types to choose from, including food only tickets, general admission tickets and VIP tickets. The VIP ticket will give ticket holders the opportunity to taste and sip during a VIP hour from noon to 1 p.m."So if you would like to taste and sip early, you can buy a VIP ticket," Knudsen said. "And that allows you the opportunity to get the food while it's fresh out of the oven and ditch the lines."Compostable silverware will be handed out to ticket holders at check in."We have been told that there was a lot of plastic waste, in previous years, from the event," Knudsen said. "So we were trying to come up with creative solutions to reduce our waste."Although tasting and sipping are the festival's main draws, there are plenty of other things for attendees to do. People can peruse a vendors market full of independent businesses or listen to live performances at one of the festival's two stages.On the main stage in the Blue Ruin Plaza off Gay Street, there will be performances from tranzfusion, the Eastern Shore Dance Academy, Anna Burgess music and SoulCrackers.On the secondary stage at the corner Race and Muir streets, there will be performances from The Folk Villains, Island Fusion with Nancy and Jody and The Terry Koger Duo.Mike Elzey's Guitar Studio will be playing in the Main Street Gallery from 1 to 3 p.m.There will also be a kids' zone complete with costumed princesses, a bubble studio and bounces houses, pending the weather."We will have Belle, Elsa and Mirabel making appearances," Knudsen said.With rain in the forecast, Knudsen said the rain could have a large effect on the event."But thankfully we've been able to be flexible with how we're situating our musicians," she said. "And the restaurants have all been more than accommodating and willing to come out in the rain and support Cambridge Main Street."Knudsen said people should come to the event if they are looking for family fun with different entertainment options."So if you want to come shopping, you can," she said. "If you want to eat, you can. And if you just want to get a picture with Elsa, she'll be there in the kids' zone." 
 
 Caption: FlLE PHOTO/
 
RAR Brewing's crab cake won the judges' choice and people's choice awards at the 2018 Taste of Cambridge.

title: Bridge - The obvious ought to be clear
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The obvious ought to be clear

 October 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 268
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There should be no need to state the obvious, but we occasionally do. At the edge of the Sinai desert, with sand and stones stretching as far as the eye can see, there is a sign announcing "Free Parking." In today's deal, I would point out that the six-spade contract appears to depend on the heart finesse, but that is too obvious. Ideally, one would like to make the contract even if that finesse is losing. However, you knew that already. How did the declarer play after West had led the club queen?North's sequence, a transfer bid of two hearts followed by a jump to four diamonds, showed a slam-try with at least six spades and at most one diamond (a splinter bid).South bid what he thought he could make.Declarer won the opening lead with dummy's club ace, cashed the spade ace, played a club to his king and ruffed a club high in the dummy.After a spade to South's king had removed the opponents' trumps, declarer ruffed his last club.I know you've seen the key play coming for some time, but just in case, now declarer called for dummy's diamond and finessed his jack.West won with the queen but was endplayed. He had to concede three side-suit tricks: either two hearts and one diamond on a heart return into declarer's A-Q tenace; or one heart and two diamonds on a diamond return into declarer's A-10 tenace.The transfer bid did its job. If North declares in six spades, East will surely lead the heart jack, which kills the contract.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Bridge - 'Always' may mean most of the time
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - 'Always' may mean most of the time

 October 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 286
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A guideline is something to be followed all of the time - except when it is wrong!Also, as you are aware, bridge is full of guidelines. One of the most reliable is that if one side is playing on a suit, it is wrong for the other side to play on it too.Today's deal is a straightforward example.West leads his fourthhighest heart against three no-trump. This gives declarer seven top tricks: two spades, one heart, three diamonds and one club. Assuming no 4-0 diamond split, two more tricks are readily available in diamonds. Or are they? Look at the spots. If the diamonds break 3-1, declarer will have to win the fourth round in his hand. With no dummy entry, the fifth diamond trick shrivels and dies like an earthworm on a hot pavement.However, South spotted a possibility. After winning the first trick with dummy's heart nine, he cashed the diamond queen and ace.West's club discard was a blow, but now declarer led the heart king.You see the idea behind this play. South knew West had started with at most five hearts, because West had led the five and declarer could see the three and four. South hoped that West would cash at least one more heart trick, on which the declarer would discard the blocking diamond seven or nine.However, West knew that if South thought it was right for North-South to play on hearts, it had to be wrong for East-West to do so too. West won with the heart ace and immediately switched to a spade.This condemned the contract. When declarer lost a trick in another suit, the defenders cashed their hearts. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bridge - The exception to the rule
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The exception to the rule

 October 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 231
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Yesterday I pointed out that if one side thinks it is right to play on a suit, it isn't right for the other side to play on the same suit - but, as you knew, not always!Today's unusual deal is an example.North's slightly optimistic sequence showed four spades and gameinvitational values.(Normally, don't look for game when your combined maximum count is 25.)Then South bid three notrump because he liked the idea of trying to score up a vulnerable game.The apparently hopeless contract was kept alive by a fourth-highest heart lead around to South's nine.Mentally shrugging his shoulders, declarer played a low club: nine, 10, jack.To defeat the game, East needed to cash one or both of his top clubs, but following the principle mentioned above, East returned a heart. West took declarer's jack with his queen and exited with a spade, won by South's king.Declarer cashed the diamond king-queen and spade queen before playing a spade to dummy's ace.After taking the 13th spade and the diamond ace, South exited with dummy's last diamond. West won with the nine and cashed the heart ace, but he had to concede the last trick - declarer's ninth - to the heart king.Bridge is a tough game!Receive daily instructive and entertaining quizzes from Phillip by subscribing for only $10 per month at www.bridgeforeveryone.com. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Simon Cowell - celebrityupdate
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Simon Cowell - celebrityupdate

 October 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 10A | Section: News 
 
 253
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Q: Was Simon Cowell one of the original judges on "America's Got Talent"?A: No, but he still played a major part in the NBC series from the start, since he created it. (He also has been an executive producer of the show from the beginning.)Piers Morgan, Brandy Norwood and David Hasselhoff made up the judging panel for the first season in 2006, with Regis Philbin as the host.At the time, Cowell was intending to make a similar contest for British television, but some complications ultimately held that up and he turned his attention to making a U.S. version. The result was a summer hit for NBC, and it also jump-started the originally planned British edition, which premiered in 2007 and also continues. From there, the concept expanded even more, with versions still being done in Canada, Cambodia, France, India and Spain (among other locations).A judge on the British version from the start, Cowell became an on-air "America's Got Talent" presence beginning with the 11th season - this year has marked its 18th round - but he wasn't present for the live episodes during Season 15, due to a back injury. Substitute judges were enlisted initially, but the number of judges then was reduced from four to three in Cowell's absence, with Howie Mandel (who has been with the show since Season 5), Heidi Klum and Sofia Vergara holding forth with those duties.Actually, Klum also missed some of Season 15 due to illness, with Vergara's fellow "Modern Family" alum Eric Stonestreet filling in for her.

title: Viewers still can love 'Lucy' every weekday
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Viewers still can love 'Lucy' every weekday

 October 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 16A | Section: News 
 
 153
 Words 

 Read News Document

 One of the most popular sitcoms in television history dates back to the early years of the medium, and it basically hasn't been off the air since then. "I Love Lucy" is now shown weekdays by Catchy Comedy, and no matter how many times one has seen the antics of Lucille Ball's Lucy Ricardo - wife of bandleader Ricky Ricardo (Desi Arnaz, also Ball's real-life husband at the time) - they remain greatly amusing.William Frawley and Vivian Vance, who reportedly did not get along when the cameras were off them, also were essential to the show as married neighbors Fred and Ethel Mertz. So many episodes of the series are classics in their own right, if you asked five people which one was their favorite, you'd likely get five different answers. In any event, the world continues to love "Lucy."

title: Welcome to Miami: A young artist dreams of making it big in 'Neon'
author: Sarah Passingham
content:
Welcome to Miami: A young artist dreams of making it big in 'Neon'

 October 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sarah Passingham | Page: 12A | Section: News 
 
 294
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There may be a chill in the air, but a new comedy series brings the heat from Miami beaches and dance floors to your screen. "Neon" premieres on the streamer Thursday, Oct. 19, dropping all eight episodes and immersing audiences in the world of up-and-coming reggaeton artist Santi (Tyler Dean Flores "Miguel Wants to Fight," 2023) as he tries to make it to the big time in Magic City.Packing their lives up into a 2009 Toyota Corolla, Santi and his friends Ness (Emma Ferreira "Unstable") and Felix (Jordan Mendoza "Kaleidoscope") leave small-town Florida behind and hit the road that leads to Miami. The three best friends have a lot of inroads to make once they arrive in the big city, but their hopes of stardom for Santi keep them afloat.In a teaser trailer for "Neon" released by Netflix, the trio's temporary Miami lodgings are parked within view of the more comfortably cramped suites of a Sheraton hotel. Humble beginnings for sure, but the trailer also sees the dreamers working hard, making connections and taking to the stage, enjoying the nightlife they hope to become fixtures of soon.Though they're starting from the bottom and sleeping in their car to start, the "Neon" trailer teases some pretty glamorous upgrades afforded to the crew. Santi shoots a music video, lays down a track in the studio, embraces his friends backstage of a very important performance, gets invites to swanky house parties and tosses cash in the air. "You are a star," Ness proclaims in the trailer before further declaring, "We have to show them we're not loser wannabes." Whether Santi is on the rise or a wannabe, the music fanatics of Miami decide his fate - he'll either get set off to stardom or back to his hometown. 
 
 Caption: Tyler Dean Flores in "Neon"

title: More Retro Rewinds
content:

 "Rawhide" (Heroes & Icons, weekdays): By the time Clint Eastwood attained international stardom in "A Fistful of Dollars," TV viewers were used to seeing him in a Western milieu, thanks to this series. From producers including "Gunsmoke" veteran Charles Marquis Warren, it casts the actor as Rowdy Yates, a trail hand assisting with cattle drives. The legendary theme song is performed by Frankie Laine, and cast regulars also include Eric Fleming, Sheb Wooley and Paul Brinegar."Saboteur" (Peacock, streaming; Turner Classic Movies, Monday, Oct. 16): Alfred Hitchcock was establishing his Hollywood cred when the director made this terrific 1942 melodrama, hugely memorable for its use of the Statue of Liberty in its finale. That iconic New York site is where an alleged traitor's (Robert Cummings) pursuit of the actual culprit (Norman Lloyd) reaches its superbly tense climax."From Russia With Love" (MGM+, Saturday, Oct. 21): Though its gadgetry is relatively limited, many James Bond aficionados consider this 1963 adventure one of the best adventures in the series. Sean Connery's second turn as Agent 007 finds the spy sent to retrieve a decoding device also wanted by Russian rivals, who dispatch an alluring associate (Daniela Bianchi) to seduce and discredit him. The great villains include vicious Red Grant (played by an incredibly fit Robert Shaw) and sneering Rosa Klebb (Lotte Lenya), who wields a very lethal shoe.

title: Monster munchies: Duff Goldman and Rosanna Pansino host creepy cookie contest
author: Caroline Collacutt
content:
Monster munchies: Duff Goldman and Rosanna Pansino host creepy cookie contest

 October 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Caroline Collacutt | Page: 14A | Section: News 
 
 386
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sugar, spice and everything spooky: Season 2 of "Halloween Cookie Challenge" airs Mondays through October on Food Network."Celebrity pastry chef Duff Goldman and social media sensation Rosanna Pansino celebrate the wildest and most colorful holiday of the year!," Food Network describes."They'll bring together the best cookie makers in the country to compete in two challenges and create the creepiest, spookiest and tastiest Halloween cookies ever made! The winner takes home a trick-or-treat bag filled with $10,000!" And that's $10,000 every episode.New contestants park their brooms at the kitchen door and take on Goldman and Pansino's cookie challenge every week, showcasing talent from far and wide.So far this season, the competing cookie confectioners have faced monsters big and small, exploring what would happen if our favorite Halloween treats had a taste for us, too. Bakers have been asked to: make two-sided trick-or-treat bags - with one side being light and fun while the other is dark and spooky - out of lemon candies, black licorice and peach rings; decorate cookies with scary self-portraits; craft life-size oozing zombie parts out of cookies, overflowing with gooey marmalades and jams; and create creepy, 3D haunted mirrors - each old and cracked with crunchy treats like kettle chips, pretzels and corn chips.This week, "Edible stained glass is one of the most colorful and bewitching trends in the cookie world, and four cookie experts make glowing Halloween stainedglass cookies," the network promises."After one cookier is eliminated, the remaining three masters build giant, elaborate Halloween fun houses that would thrill any Halloween carnival-goer. The judges will really feel like they are at a carnival as the bakers must incorporate fun fair flavors like caramel apples, grilled corn, popcorn balls and deep-fried sandwich cookies." In the season's final episode, the final four competing cookie makers hope to scare the pants off hosts Goldman and Pansino by making edible, three-story haunted houses. Then, in the last round, Food Network has shared that, "The three remaining cookiers host a séance by making playable spirit boards. To make sure there is maximum 'spirit' in their boards, they will include spirits like apple brandy, cinnamon whiskey, coffee rum and black currant liqueur." A rambunctious carnival filled with delicious treats, Season 2 of Food Network's "Halloween Cookie Challenge" airs new episodes Mondays through October. 
 
 Caption: Rosanna Pansino co-hosts "Halloween Cookie Challenge"

title: Millington native to take stage at FallFest
author: Bob Ford; Special To The Kent County News Star Democrat
content:
Millington native to take stage at FallFest

 October 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bob Ford; Special To The Kent County News Star Democrat | Page: 2A | Section: News 
 
 839
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL - When guitarist Blake Thompson takes the stage at Rock Hall FallFest on Sat.Oct. 14, it will mark more than just a homecoming for the Millington native, it will be a virtual family reunion, picnic, and jam session all rolled into one.FallFest, the annual street fair that features nonstop live music on Main Street during the 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. event, will host the Blake Thompson Family Band on the Mainstay Stage at 2 p.m. Accompanying Thompson, the lead guitarist, will be his wife, four of his children, and a drummer who snuck into the family act somehow."Everybody's got to work. We're just poor musicians," Thompson said, with a laugh." The band is a hard-rocking ensemble, reflecting Thompson's guitar-driven passions that are heavily influenced by Stevie Ray Vaughn, Eric Clapton, Jimmy Page, Alvin Lee, and Billy Gibbons.When the family is together, however, the selections also drift all over the musical map."The littlest girl (vocalist daughter Rachel) will do some Dolly Parton and Linda Rondstadt, and we'll throw in some Monkees, like "Daydream Believer," Beatles, and kind of go from Dire Straits to Johnny Cash to 60's rock. In an event like that, you really want to mix it up a lot," Thompson said.Thompson's wife Kate plays keyboards and electric violin; his son, Blake Jr., plays keyboards and drums; daughter, Sarah, is a rhythm guitarist and vocalist, along with Rachel; daughter, Josie, is a bass guitar player; and Russ Reinacher will be sitting in on the drums.During his long career, the 57-year-old Thompson, who is also an accomplished recording engineer and mixer, has played regularly with his own band and with Bit O Jane and the Elliots. He's also toured in conjunction with the Steve Miller Band, Dave Matthews Band, The Gin Blossoms, David Crosby, Little Feat, and others.It is a career that got its start when he bought his first guitar at Dixon's Auction in Crumpton when he was a 15-year-old freshman at Kent County High School."I played ninth-grade football and I met a guy on the team who I talked music with all the time, and he played guitar, and I said, 'I'll get a guitar, too,'" Thompson said. "I bought a cheap guitar at Crumpton and it only had four strings and I played it like that for about three months. It just went from there. I worked and practiced and got some books, and I watched other local bands, and wrote down what they were doing, and ran home and practiced." By the end of high school, he had his own band with other musicians from the Massey area, where his family had relocated. And, as he said, his career went from there."It was wild. The whole band was from about a one-mile radius," Thompson said."In that band, and others after that, we played all over the area before I started traveling the country.I think I'm related to half of Kent County. I've got relatives in Chestertown, Rock Hall, Worton.This show at FallFest is like coming home, big-time. The whole event has a great vibe to it." While the Thompson Family show is can't-miss, it has some company on Main Street during FallFest. Also keeping things lively is Wicked Sycamore, an all-female acoustic Americana trio that recently won a Wammie Award, presented by the Washington Area Music Association; The High and Wides, a traditional bluegrass group that has long been a local favorite; Pat Wictor and Bob Beach, who play dobro, slide guitar, and harmonica to turn out haunting bluesbased rock; and The Good Stuff, a new country-tinged band led by Phil Dutton, who also fronts the Cajun-flavored group, The Alligators.And, of course, no FallFest is complete without an appearance by the Catonsville High School Steel Band, which plays the traditional tuned pans from Trinidad and Tobago.The group has been an annual FallFest highlight since 1999, and the band comes back bigger and better than ever this year.That's a great day of music, but FallFest is about more than music.In celebrating the opening of the commercial oyster season, approximately 6,000 oysters will be shucked onsite, and there is all manner of other street fair food, including fried oyster platters, burgers, dogs, tacos, fries, ice cream and, all the rest.Main Street becomes a pedestrian thoroughfare for visitors to stroll and explore our shops and take a look at the offerings of dozens of artisan vendors. There is also Kids Kourt at The Village at the foot of Main Street with games, prizes, animals, painting, clowns and much more for the younger set and all of it free.Admission and nearby parking is also free. So, come join us for a great day of music, food, and fun that benefits our local community projects. Some proceeds from our non-profit event support the Kent County Waterman's Association scholarship fund, and we also help fund improvements for The Mainstay, the iconic music venue at the heart of Main Street.See you on Oct. 14 at 10 a.m. for all the festivities. Bring your appetite and bring your dancing shoes.It's a family affair, especially for Blake Thompson. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF FALLFEST
 
Blake Thomspon 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a local music festival with live performances, highlighting musicians and family entertainment, which aligns best with the Entertainment category.

title: Tides of crime: Secrets and murder abound in Season 2 of 'Annika'
author: Dana Simpson
content:
Tides of crime: Secrets and murder abound in Season 2 of 'Annika'

 October 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Dana Simpson | Page: 9A | Section: News 
 
 421
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's Scottish crime with a Scandinavian twist this autumn as Season 2 of the BBC series "Annika" premieres on PBS Masterpiece, Sunday, Oct. 15. An interesting clash of northern European cultures, the two worlds meet seamlessly due to the titular character's Norwegian roots and the often-folkloric nature of the crimes she encounters at work.The series' main character, DI Annika Strandhed, has been a hit with audiences across the pond since the original radio series premiered in early January 2017 on the U.K.'s BBC Radio 4. The radio series, titled "Annika Stranded," wrapped Sept. 4, 2020, but for lovers of the series, the story continues on television, complete with Nicola Walker ("MI-5") in the role of Annika - no doubt a familiar voice for fans who jumped over from the radio play.Both series follow Strandhed, a former Oslo-based "murder squad" police officer, as she relocates to a remote region of Scotland to head up the country's first-ever Marine Homicide Unit. Given her dedication to the job and a lifelong love of fast-moving boats, Strandhed seems poised as the perfect fit to lead the new team. That said, her cohort DS Michael McAndrews (Jamie Sives, "Guilt") has other opinions.McAndrews attended police college with Strandhed, but the two detectives selected career paths that took them in opposite directions, causing them to drift apart. While McAndrews is clearly supportive of Strandhed and finds her to be a very intelligent leader, he still believes himself to have been a better candidate for her position as leader of the MHU. Nevertheless, the pair must find a way to work together - thankfully McAndrews' duties as head diver keep him busy and away from Strandhed much of the time.Working alongside the two team leads are DC Blair Ferguson (Katie Leung, "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire," 2005), who provides data analysis and tech support for the team; DS Tyrone Clarke (Ukweli Roach, "Blindspot"), a former drug unit investigator who prefers to work alone; and DCI Diane Oban (Kate Dickie, "The Green Knight," 2021), who oversees all police proceedings within the precinct and often has the final say on how the MHU operates.Joining the MHU this season is DC Harper Weston (played by Varada Sethu, "Jurassic World Dominion," 2022), a motorcycle-riding trainee who, given her youth, may act as a second person to provide Strandhed a bit of insight regarding her daughter, Morgan (Sylvie Furneaux, "Red Rose"). This guiding role has previously only been played by Ferguson, who is of a similar age to Weston and only a few years older than Morgan herself.

title: Bridge - The multicolored moods of bridge
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The multicolored moods of bridge

 October 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 266
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It has been said that variety is the spice of life.But variety comes in many forms. Outside Shop Abbey in Cumbria, northern England, was a sign reading, "Admission free. Special terms for parties." In bridge, one deal can provide variety. The opening lead may be pivotal. For example, in today's deal, how would you plan the play in six spades if West has led either a club or a trump?Two no-trump was the Jacoby Forcing Raise. South's three-no-trump rebid showed 15-17 points but denied a singleton or void.North control-bid the club ace. South used Blackwood twice, learning that two kings were missing.After a club lead, declarer is in trouble. He must draw trumps, cash the heart king and take a heart finesse. If it loses, the contract dies.However, if the finesse wins, South cashes dummy's heart ace. If the suit breaks 3-3, declarer's club loser disappears on the 13th heart, and he tries the diamond finesse for an overtrick. If the hearts are 4-2, the diamond finesse must win.On a trump lead, though, South has some flexibility.After drawing trumps, it is right to take an immediate diamond finesse. If it loses, declarer must bring in four heart tricks, playing West for queen-third. But if, as in the given layout, the diamond finesse wins, South needs only three heart tricks for his contract. It is time for a safety play. Declarer cashes dummy's heart ace, plays a heart to his king and leads a heart back toward dummy's jack. This maximizes the chance of three heart tricks.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Easton Beer Fest features over 100 different brews
author: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com
content:
Easton Beer Fest features over 100 different brews

 October 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 597
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Over 1,000 beer drinkers came together at the Easton Beer Fest on Oct. 7 at the Volunteer Fire House, where more than 40 breweries, wineries and distilleries brought their products.The locals came to this firehouse fundraiser with pretzel necklaces to clear their palettes from a barrage of IPAs, lagers and porters. There was even rocking funk music from G Method to make spirits high."The Jellyfish Apocalypse is amazing. It is so flavorful. It still tastes like a beer, but with a yummy kick. We saw the name and said, 'Let's give it a go.' You have to be truly adventurous,'" said Jackie Sadler, who is part of Three Roads Brewing Company in Virginia."To be a good beer taster you have to be open minded about trying different types of beer. So being open to trying the IPA or the blonde or the pilsner or the lager - I think that is what makes the best beer taster," said Emily Sadler, who is Jackie's daughter in law.Chris Hash, the treasurer of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, has been organizing the October beer festival for eight years."It's a huge fundraiser. We have over 1,000 in attendance. Its a big financial impact. General admission tickets are $45. VIPs are $75," he said.While the money is great, Hash said another part of the event is enlisting new firefighters."We have a recruitment and retention table over here. We guys talking about what we do and hopefully recruit some new younger members. Volunteering has become a bit of dying breed in the last few years," said Hash."Firefighting has a lot of excitement.There is a lot of training, but it is rewarding. You get to do something a normal person doesn't get to do. You are running into burning building when others are running out." He said all the food, like crab dip on top of fries, was cooked by firemen.You could also find brats, pulled pork and hot dogs.The festival featured 46 brewers, a couple of wineries and distilleries, and 120 different drink options.Tim Miller of Easton started making National Premium beer in 2012."We have some old fans and we hope to make some new ones, but this is kind of the rewards of the beer business. It is just a fun day for everybody. It is in our backyard and it is the best run beer festival I've done. And I have done a lot. I don't have to lug ice or equipment. I can just come and pour," said Miller.There was even some art to be found at the beer fest. One lady is the "Queen of Bottlecaps." She color coordinates beer caps and puts them into designs on a wooden board."It takes several hours to make one. It is therapeutic. I have been here at least four times. More men are willing to make this purchase.The crab design is the most popular," said Hillary Wright of Salisbury. the event, which is sponsored by Easton Liquors and Discover Easton, helped lead to the pouring of ciders, seltzers, craft beers, wines and spirits all day long. 
 
 Caption: TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Tim Miller, left, bought the National Premium beer franchise in 2012. He is pictured with his team - Kelley McDonald, Ned McDonald and Diana Locke.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Hillary Wright, at left, creates art out of bottle caps. At right is Lisa Davis.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Crabby fries consist of crab dip placed on top of hot fries. The volunteer fire company cooked all the food at this fundraiser.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Organizers said Beer Fest is the biggest fundraiser of the year for the Easton Volunteer Fire Department.

title: Bridge - You may be the judge and jury
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - You may be the judge and jury

 October 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 21 | Section: News 
 
 281
 Words 

 Read News Document

 P.G. Wodehouse wrote, "Judges, as a class, display, in the matter of arranging alimony, that reckless generosity which is found only in men who are giving away someone else's cash." Well, on today's deal, you be the judge. South was the husband, North his wife - and, yes, they are still married.After an auction in which neither side knew who could make what, South ended in four spades doubled. West led a heart to his partner's king. East switched to the club six. Declarer won with his ace, unblocked the diamond king, ruffed a heart in the dummy and discarded a club on dummy's diamond ace. He then cashed the club king and ruffed the club four in hand. However, disaster struck when West overruffed.A moment later, when East got in with the spade ace, another club lead promoted West's spade queen as the setting trick."How unlucky can I be?" asked South. "Why should East have five clubs and only one spadeft" "You misplayed," replied North. "There is no hurry to discard your club loser. After winning trick two with the club ace, ruff a heart in the dummy, play a diamond to your king and ruff your last heart. Then lead dummy's third trump." South judged his wife was right. With her line, everything is as much under control as it can be. If East plays low on the trump, South puts up the king, East being marked with the ace from the auction. Here, though, East wins with the ace and returns a club to dummy's king. South discards his remaining club on the diamond ace and loses only one more trump trick. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bridge - The penalty was quite a shock
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The penalty was quite a shock

 October 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 273
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Here is another sign sent by a reader to The Guardian newspaper in England. Attached to a high-tension electricity pylon in Massachusetts was a board stating: "To climb this structure means instant death. Anyone found doing so will be prosecuted." In bridge you can commit suicide but remain alive and unprosecuted - except perhaps by your partner. It is your contract that dies.South is in three no-trump.West leads the heart five: two, queen, king. How should South continue?When in no-trump, declarer must count his top tricks first. Here he has seven: two spades, three diamonds, one club and one heart (given the lead). He needs two more tricks, which can obviously come from the clubs. However, taking the club finesse at trick two electrocutes South. East wins with the king and returns his remaining heart - down one.Better is to lead the club queen to tempt a cover, but then to win with dummy's ace. Maybe East has the singleton club king. Also, if the club finesse is working, you don't need to take it because West cannot hurt you.However, here, whichever line you choose, the contract dies. Let's go back to trick one. Assuming West's heart five is his fourth highest, when East plays the queen, you can place the ace with West. So, the only risk to your contract is the given layout. As you are never getting more than one heart trick, just play low from your hand at trick one. Give East the trick with his queen. The defenders' communications are cut, and your contract is safe. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bridge - Be sure to measure your trick line
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Be sure to measure your trick line

 October 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 282
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Rodeo riders are hooked on an eight-second ride. Bridge players are hooked on a 13-trick deal. However, both are aware that they might not last that long. Rodeo riders often fall off in under eight seconds. The bridge player might have lost too many tricks before the last one has been played. Still, both always set out with the best of intentions.In today's deal, South was on the three-no-trump bronco. Upon opening the gate, he saw that the lead was the diamond king. How should he have tried to ride to success?During the first buck, South noticed that he had seven top tricks: one spade, one heart, one diamond and four clubs.Looking at those lovely diamonds in the dummy, South won the first trick with his diamond ace and fired back the diamond three.However, West went in with the queen (East discarded the club three) and switched immediately to the heart two. South sailed off the bull and landed face first in the dirt. He couldn't avoid losing five tricks.However tempting those diamonds looked, there was a better source of tricks available: spades. South should win the first trick, play a club to dummy's queen and take a spade finesse by, say, running the queen. West wins with the king and switches to hearts, but South, after ducking one round, wins with his heart ace, plays a club to dummy's ace and runs the spade nine.When that finesse wins, he repeats it and cashes the spade ace and club king-jack for nine tricks: three spades, one heart, one diamond and four clubs.Did you tame the bucking broncoft ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bridge - A marriage of bridge tricks
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - A marriage of bridge tricks

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 275
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Comedians make jokes about wives. Comediennes make quips about husbands. We can relate to them because they are so close to the truth.Zsa Zsa Gabor lent her own style when she said, "I'm a marvelous housekeeper.Every time I leave a man, I keep his house." In bridge, you have to be careful to keep your tricks.If you have a winner in one hand, you must have an entry to that hand - or be able to force an opponent to lead the suit for you.Today's auction was tricky.What should North do over West's three-spade opening? Pass is cowardly.Three no-trump is brilliant or foolhardy, depending on the result. Four clubs is one-dimensional. Double is the most flexible action, but dangerous.Over the double, South might pass for penalties, but that is risky with such poor spades. (He can get 800 for down three.) He could try three no-trump, but that suffers from the same drawback. Four hearts is the normal bid.West starts with three rounds of spades, declarer ruffing the last high in the dummy. East discards three diamonds. South draws trumps, reducing the deal to no-trump. Now it looks superficially attractive to continue with the club ace and another club. However, against the bad break, the contract dies. East wins two club tricks to go with the two spade tricks already in the defenders' bag.The correct play is a low club to dummy's jack. (If West has the singleton king, tough!) The ace must be kept as the entry to the spade jack. Declarer's 10 tricks are one spade, four hearts, two diamonds, two clubs and one spade ruff in the dummy. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

author: Caroline Collacutt
content:

 Author/Byline: Caroline Collacutt | Page: 14 | Section: News

 Calling all aspiring chefs! It's time to sharpen your knives and prepare your mise-en-scène, as "Mary Makes it Easy" airs an all-new episode, Sunday, Oct. 22, on Food Network.Hosted by Canadian television host, cookbook author and chef Mary Berg (winner of "MasterChef Canada" Season 3), this how-to series follows as Berg gives step-by-step instructions to follow recipes that are guaranteed to impress even the pickiest of eaters, as the chef hopes to teach culinary novices and cooks alike how to expand their recipe book without any of the stress.With multiple seasons now under her belt, Berg has focused episodes on a myriad of topics, including: how to make multiple recipes all utilizing the same base ingredients - like coleslaw used both in golden brown Japanese Okonomi-yaki-inspired pancakes and store-bought rotisserie chicken, turned into a nearly unrecognizable, quick and easy Coq au Vin; upgrading store-bought cookie doughs and pie crusts to make impressive desserts; using your kitchen tools - cast iron included - to their fullest potential; and even making the correct wine and alcohol pairings, in an episode in which Berg "shakes things up with Wine Can Chicken that's cooked with a cocktail of dry white wine, lemon and herbs" (Food Network).In episodes to come, Food Network shares that Berg shares her love for cooking outside, detailing recipes that "take grill night to the next level.""Brie and Pancetta Burgers are topped with chunky grilled red onion and gooey Brie cheese," they describe. "For a vegetarian grill-friendly main, Mary's Grilled Soy Maple Mushrooms caramelize beautifully, and on the lighter side, Grilled Scallops with Minty Pea Salad are flavored with garlic, lemon and herbs on a peppery arugula base. Finally, Mary does some barbecue baking with decadent Cheese Stuffed Grilled Garlic Flatbreads."And - taking her creative approach, as always - Berg even shares her own, unique "mash-up" recipes throughout the series, melding common dishes like Caesar Salad and Roast Chicken, even crafting a Taco Meatball skillet.Delving into the best tips, tricks and tools necessary for any cook, Mary Berg impresses in every episode of "Mary Makes it Easy," airing Sundays on Food Network.

title: Celebrity update - Bruce Willis
author: Jay Bobbin

Celebrity update - Bruce Willis

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 10 | Section: News

 Words

 Q: Did Bruce Willlis ever do another series after "Moonlighting"?A: Not in terms of being a regular cast member, but he did have another significant TV role afterward and it's on display often, given how frequently the series in question is still shown. He guest-starred on "Friends" for three episodes in 2000 as Paul, the disapproving father of Ross's (David Schwimmer) considerably younger girlfriend Elizabeth (Alexandra Holden), and the two men eventually came to a meeting of the minds thanks to certain information Ross had about Paul (which the latter man didn't want revealed).Willis earned a Primetime Emmy Award for the portrayal, marking the second one he won, his first having come for his work as wisecracking sleuth David Addison on "Moonlighting." He also did guest shots on such shows as "Ally McBeal" and "Mad About You," but movies had the bulk of his creative attention after he scored an enormous hit with the original "Die Hard" in 1988.That being said, the actor also hosted "Saturday Night Live" a couple of times, and he was the good-natured target of a "Comedy Central Roast" in 2018, with his ex-wife Demi Moore and "Moonlighting" leading lady Cybill Shepherd among those who took humorous shots at him. As is traditional for such events, though, Willis got to even the score with his own remarks at the end of that show. Joseph Gordon-Levitt, who played Willis' younger self in the 2012 movie "Looper," was the host of the "Roast."

title: 'Fear' the undead: 'Fear the Walking Dead' returns with final episodes
author: Sarah Passingham
content:
'Fear' the undead: 'Fear the Walking Dead' returns with final episodes

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sarah Passingham | Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 466
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's the beginning of the end of the trail for some apocalypse survivors in the return of the final season of "Fear the Walking Dead." The "Walking Dead" spinoff series' midseason premiere airs on AMC Sunday, Oct. 22, just in time for an early celebration of the eeriest holiday of the year. Kim Dickens ("Friday Night Lights") stars as Madison Clark, a high school guidance counsellor before the outbreak who now oversees the reconstruction of a survivors' island colony."Fear the Walking Dead" closes out an impressive eight-season run with six episodes to go before the big, two-part series finale set to air Sunday, Nov. 19. The first of now six spinoffs of the original series, "Fear the Walking Dead" premiered in 2015 and followed an extended family as they tried to survive in post-apocalyptic Los Angeles. The series detailed the survivors' journey as they travelled and settled in California, Mexico and now an island off the Georgia coast.The island, known as PADRE, was constructed after the walker outbreak as a military operation intended to distribute supplies to new communities of survivors. A tragic walker invasion decimated PADRE, and since then, desperate survivors have used the island's resources that once represented a more hopeful future.In the first half of the final season of "Fear the Walking Dead," Madison landed on PADRE after a hard-fought journey to find the island with Morgan Jones (Lennie James, "Save Me"). The pair reunited Morgan with his daughter, Mo (Zoey Merchant, "The Price of Fame"), by force at PADRE before the show leaps seven years into the future. Madison is imprisoned on PADRE while Morgan spends most of the first six episodes of the season on his own mission, trying to save Grace Mukherjee (Karen David, "Legacies") from radiation sickness before sadly losing her and setting off to Alexandria.With the dangerous former co-leaders of PADRE no longer a problem, Madison attempts to reinvigorate the spirit of PADRE and the island with the remaining resources available to them. While the final episodes of "Fear the Walking Dead" could certainly detail the establishment of a post-apocalyptic paradise, this is the Walking Dead universe after all, so there will undoubtedly be danger lurking in the shadows of PADRE.This season also stars Rubén Blades ("The Counselor," 2013) as resistance leader Daniel Salazar; Colman Domingo ("Sing Sing," 2023) as antihero Victor Strand; Danay Garcia ("Prison Break") as survivor Luciana Galvez; Austin Amelio ("Hit Man," 2023) as PADRE member Dwight; Christine Evangelista ("Mrs. Fletcher") as Dwight's wife, Sherry; Jenna Elfman ("The Twilight Zone") as nurse June Dorie, who is on the run from PADRE; and one former cast member whose appearance in a trailer for the upcoming return of the series may have come as a surprise to "Fear the Walking Dead" fans.

title: The 'Legacy, continues: 'Bosch' is back - On Tap
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
The 'Legacy, continues: 'Bosch' is back - On Tap

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 12 | Section: News

 Read News Document

 The title of a returning series is accurate, since the character Bosch is continuing to build his legacy.After six seasons of the original mystery series that centered on best-selling novelist Michael Connelly's character Bosch, the detective character returned in the Prime Video sequel; "Bosch: Legacy," which starts its second season Friday, Oct. 20. Played by Titus Welliver, Harry Bosch - a homicide detective turned private eye - has a deeply personal case to handle this time, since he searches for his kidnapped rookie-cop daughter Maddie (Madison Lintz). The drama is based largely on Connelly's book "The Crossing," and Connelly and Welliver are both among its executive producers.Interestingly, "The Crossing" is the 18 th book in the Bosch franchise, while Season 1 of "Bosch: Legacy" was inspired by two of the novels that came later, "The Wrong Side of Goodbye" (the 19th book) and "The Night Fire" (the 22nd book). The first season ended with a cliffhanger that suggested the abduction of Maddie, who seemed likely to have to testify in a wrongful-death shooting case, for which her police body camera had captured evidence.Maddie works out of the same Los Angeles police station where her father was based during his days as a cop. His frequent employer, attorney Honey "Money" Chandler (Mimi Rogers), trades on her own contacts to try to help him find Maddie before time runs out. Bosch and Chandler have other problems as the saga unfolds, with federal agents taking an interest in them and definitely not for the purposes of professional camaraderie and cooperation.New cast members in the sophomore round of "Bosch: Legacy" include Anthony Michael Hall ("The Breakfast Club") as one of the FBI investigators, as well as Jessica Camacho ("All Rise"), Max Martini ("The Unit"), David Denman ('The Office") and veteran actor Bruce Davison ("Willard"). Among other co-stars returning to the "Bosch" world are Jamie Hector, Gregory Scott Cummins, Troy Evans, Denise Sanchez, Stephen A. Chang, Jacqueline Obradors and David Marciano. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Charlton Heston's "Soylent Green" offers food for thought - classic corner
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Charlton Heston's "Soylent Green" offers food for thought - classic corner

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 158
 Words 

 Read News Document

 One of the best movies of Charlton Heston's later career, the 1973 sci-fidrama "Soylent Green" leads off the final night of Turner Classic Movies' Star of the Month tribute to the actor Wednesday, Oct. 25. Since it's set in 2022, some viewers may get a rueful chuckle out of its portrait of a densely polluted, overpopulated New York but there's also something quite moving about its rumination of the world the way it used to be.Heston plays a policeman whose investigation of a tycoon's (Joseph Cotten) murder exposes him to the good life the slain man lived. That encompasses such then-novelties as fresh beef and strawberries, some of which the cop spirits away to share with his friend and assistant - or "book," in the parlance of this tale. That role marks the final performance of Edward G. Robinson, who's thoroughly moving and simply wonderful here. Leigh Taylor-Young, Chuck Connors and Brock Peters are among other familiar faces on hand.

title: More Retro Rewinds
content:
More Retro Rewinds

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 239
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "Adventures of Superman" (Heroes & Icons, Sunday, Oct. 22): The show added a major element - color - to its fourth season, which opened with the story "Joey." The Man of Steel's outfit previously had been seen in black-and-white in live action, but series star George Reeves displayed the official Superman colors for the first time as the hero came to the aid of Joey, a promising, Daily Planet-owned racehorse with a special and continuing connection to its previous owner (Janine Perreau)."Law & Order: Criminal Intent" (Charge, Sunday, Oct. 22): Now part of the lineup on this channel, the series presents the fourth-season episode "Keep," pitting detective partners Goren and Eames (Vincent D'Onfrio, Kathryn Erbe) on the trail of a serial killer who is keeping the bodies of the women he targets. The sleuths eventually suspect a shy fellow (played by guest star Neil Patrick Harris), assessing that he might not want to be challenged by anyone he chooses to keep company with."Final Destination" (AMC, Sunday, Oct. 22, and Thursday, Oct. 26): A successful horror franchise was launched by this cleverly plotted 2000 melodrama, casting Devon Sawa as a student who foresees the destruction of an airplane he's supposed to fly on. After he's thrown off the jet, his vision becomes reality, and he and those who left with him try to prevent the Grim Reaper from catching up to them. Co-stars include Ali Larter, Seann William Scott and the ever-fearsome Tony Todd ("Candyman"). 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Fun Dog Show was a howling success - Second year for event at American Legion
content:
Fun Dog Show was a howling success - Second year for event at American Legion

 October 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 315
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - This year's Fun Dog Show at Christ Episcopal Church in Cambridge was a howling success.Parade grand marshal was George Wham and his pup, Oscar, a wire-haired terrier. Best in show was Jax, escorted by Anna Catherine.This was the second year the event was held at the American Legion on Sunburst Highway.The rainy day provided the perfect venue for puppies and people to enjoy the day indoors. Chili, hot dogs and baked goods were available and many, many raffle gifts and prizes.Highlights of the day included Master of Ceremonies Addie Eckardt, who did the honors of announcing the participants and supplying running commentary that entertained the crowd all afternoon. There was a ring master this year, Jane Flowers, who kept things running smoothly, and DJ James Thompson kept the music going in the background.Pet handlers and ring master assistants kept the event running smoothly. Pets on Wheels and Baywater Animal Rescue, which will receive a portion of the proceeds from the dog show, were on hand to educate about rescue dogs.Mystery dog, Pinky, Cheryl Phillips, also created an atmosphere of smiles and fun. Photographer Janice Orlik, JanniMak Photography, took photos of the event and her online site has dog pictures for sale of puppy participants.Category winners included: Best Small: Kathy Dawson, Princess Grace.Best Medium: Jenny Budd, Frank.Best Large: Anna Catherine, Jax.Best Costume, Small: Katelin Collins, Sadie.Best Costume, Medium: Cindy Burton, Molly.Best Costume, Large: Jacob Mitchum, Allie.Best Pair: Roy Drassal, Tara and Kala.Best Heinz 57: Linda Aaron, Jax.Best Senior: Emory Tamplin, Angel.Cutest, Small: Kathy Dawson, Princess Grace.Cutest, Medium: Jack Saum, Missy.Cutest, Large: Nevin Bunnell, Henry.BestTrick: Roy Drassal, Kala.Best Facial Characteristic: Anna Catherine, Jax.Dog that likes the judges: Nevin Bunnell, Henry.Best Special Needs: Rachel Natoli, Hanson Best in Show: Anna Catherine, Jax.

title: The black cat under the ladder
author: Phillip Alder
content:
The black cat under the ladder

 October 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 21 | Section: News 
 
 297
 Words 

 Read News Document

 How do you view luck? As an integral part of life? Or like Jean Cocteau, who said, "We must believe in luck.For how else can we explain the success of those we don't like?" In today's deal, if you play well, you will win 10 tricks.If you don't, you won't!Against your contract of four hearts, West leads the club four: queen, eight, five.How would you continue?North's bid of three hearts was questionable. With such a good club suit, he should have raised to three no-trump. If he had, South probably would have gone down!In four hearts, declarer won the first trick and naively assumed that West had led from the 4-3 doubleton. At trick two, South finessed the heart queen. Then he cashed the ace, luckily dropping East's king. Declarer drew West's last trump and led his remaining club. When West discarded a spade, South let out an audible groan. There was no way to recover and win 10 tricks.At another table, South started the same way: club queen, heart to the queen, heart ace. However, now he led his remaining club. West wasn't fooled. South could have drawn the last trump, so it couldn't be right to ruff.West discarded a spade; once more, down one.As West had surely led a singleton, the right play at trick two was a low spade from the dummy, planning to insert the nine. Declarer must organize a spade ruff in the dummy as his 10th trick. (If East plays an honor, South wins with his ace and continues with the spade 10, hoping that West must win the trick.) Later, when the heart king tumbles in two rounds, declarer receives a coconut - not a cigar today! ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
