title: To cash or not to cash - Bridge
author: Phillip Alder
content:
To cash or not to cash - Bridge

 October 23, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 270
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Noam Chomsky, a renowned linguist and philosopher, said, "As soon as questions of will or decision or reason or choice of action arise, human science is at a loss." Perhaps, but the science of bridge is a big winner.Suppose you are defending against a suit contract. You lead from an ace-king holding. Instantly it is clear that you can take a second trick in the suit. However, if you do, you will establish dummy's queen as a winner for the declarer. Do you take the second trick before the rodents get at it, or do you wait, hoping the trick doesn't evaporate?Although one example proves little, usually the right play is the one that worked on this deal from a team match.Defending against four spades, both Wests led the heart ace. For the losing team, West cashed his second heart winner, hoping his partner had started with a singleton. At trick three, he switched to a low diamond, when a club would have been much more successful. The declarer won with dummy's ace and, in case East had all three trumps, led the heart queen. East ruffed, and South overruffed. Declarer drew two rounds of trumps ending on the board and discarded one club loser on the heart jack: plus 620.At the other table, West switched to a low diamond at trick two. (I wonder if he considered leading the king.) The declarer misguessed. He won with dummy's ace and played for West to have the club ace: minus 100.In general, don't establish tricks for the opponents. Try to establish your own. first.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATEDISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATIONFOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Should we test new players? - Bridge
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Should we test new players? - Bridge

 October 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 257
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In the Netherlands, you are not allowed to play on an 18-hole golf course unless you have a Golf Ability Card. You must pass a fairly easy test of your driving, chipping and putting.Should we do the same in bridge, setting players leaving beginners' classes a few simple bidding, declarerplay and defense problems?If so, do you think today's deal would be slightly too difficult for the test, or just right? West leads the club queen against your four-heart contract. How would you plan the play?There are three passes and South opens one heart. Should West pass, double or bid two clubs?Most inexperienced players bid two clubs. However, I think that is the third-best choice. With such soft values opposite a partner who couldn't even open in third position, there is a good case for passing. Especially in a pair event, though, you should strive to contest the partscore. Note that a takeout double gives you three chances to find a fit, whereas two clubs will probably lock you into that suit.Playing in four hearts, South must not win trick one with dummy's club king and lead a trump. With this layout, the contract can then be defeated, South losing one spade, two hearts and one diamond. It is right to win in hand with the club ace and immediately lead the diamond jack. If West wins with the ace and continues clubs, you discard two spade losers on dummy's diamond royals, play a trump to the ace and another trump.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Country music concert returns to American Corner Nov. 18
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Country music concert returns to American Corner Nov. 18

 October 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: A3 | Section: News 
 
 392
 Words 

 Read News Document

 AMERICAN CORNER- Following a five-year hiatus because of the COVID pandemic, a popular concert and top country and bluegrass stars will return Saturday, Nov. 18, to the Curtis Andrew Auction Facility in American Corner.Billed as a "Bluegrass Country Concert," three acts will be featured, with Rhonda Vincent and the Rage headlining. Vincent is a Grammy Award winner, a member of the Grand Ole Opry and the "Queen of Bluegrass.""We love the Andrew family, and I've been performing there over 20 years, so it's like coming home," Vincent said."We've had a good relationship from day one, and the public really loves her," auctioneer and owner Curtis Andrew said of Vincent. "She's an easy person to please when she comes here. What you see - that's the real Rhonda."The opening act will be Wilson Fairchild, billed as the "Ambassadors of Country Music." Wil Reid's father is Harold Reid, and his cousin Langdon Reid's dad is Don Reid of the legendary Statler Brothers.As the Fairfax Trio, U.S. Navy Band musician Haley Stiltner, Matthew Songmaker Ziesing and his wife Sally Sandker create close harmonies and craveable bluegrass Gospel music.Andrew and his family have hosted the family-friendly country and bluegrass music concerts at the auction facility since 1997.He values the opportunity to give back to the community and bring smiles to the faces of friends, neighbors and those as far away as Kansas and Canada who comprise the toe-tapping audience.Despite the enormous amount of hard work and coordination the concerts require of him and his family and staff, Andrew said he enjoys "watching the fans having a good time and an enjoyable evening."The musicians and singers he's met through the years prompt fond memories. Artists like Hank Williams III, John Anderson, Marty Stuart have graced the stage of the large auction building, which is completely emptied of auction tables and transformed into a concert hall with professional stage, lighting, sound system and curtains.Tickets are $60 each. Call 410754-8826 or email info@acurtisan-drewauction.com for ticket availability.Plenty of parking is available and RVs are welcome, but with no hook-ups. Recordings and videotaping are prohibited.The facility's restaurant and staff will serve reasonably priced dinners and lighter fare. The restaurant will open at 4 p.m.The Curtis Andrew Auction Facility is located at 25631 Auction Road, Federalsburg. The website is www.acurtisandrewauction.com.

title: Operatic opposition: HBO period drama lifts curtain on Season 2
author: Dana Simpson; David Furr and Louisa Jacobson in "The Gilded Age"
content:
Operatic opposition: HBO period drama lifts curtain on Season 2

 October 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Dana Simpson; David Furr and Louisa Jacobson in "The Gilded Age" | Page: 29 | Section: News 
 
 475
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Whether first heard as a quippy one-liner from famous New York humorist Fran Leb-owitz ("Pretend It's a City") or read in Esther Crain's book "The Gilded Age in New York, 1870-1910," there is little doubt you've heard about New York City's penchant for change. Per Crain's aforementioned book, released in 2016 and available through most major booksellers, "the most common observation about New York is that it never stops evolving."This is especially true in the HBO series "The Gilded Age," premiering Season 2 on its home network and the Max streaming service Sunday, Oct. 29. Starring Carrie Coon ("Gone Girl," 2014), Cynthia Nixon ("Sex and the City") and Christine Baranski ("Mamma Mia!," 2008) as some of New York's finest wealthy gossips, the series follows a group of business moguls and socialites as they work hard to make a name for themselves and build an empire in New York City during the turn of the 20th century.Coon stars as Bertha Russell, a "new money heiress" who caused some major waves in Season 1 alongside her husband, railroad tycoon George Russell (Morgan Spector, "The Plot Against America"), and her fellow socialite Mrs. Caroline Astor (Donna Murphy, "The Nanny Diaries," 2007), the leader of aristocratic social society called The Four Hundred. With her own societal standing foremost in her sights, Bertha often stirs up more trouble than is necessary to get what she wants.Also to blame for her fair bit of trouble is Marian Brook (new talent Louisa Jacobson), who fell on hard times when her father died in the series premiere and began Season 1 by moving into her estranged aunts' house for a bit of a lifestyle makeover in the Big Apple. Marian's aunts, Ada Brook (Nixon) and Agnes Van Rhijn (Baranski), both belong to the old-money world and thus have very particular views on how things should be done among New York's finest. While Marian does her best to please her aunts, she has also learned that not everyone subscribes to her family's conservative school of thought.Returning alongside Coon, Murphy, Jacobson, Nixon and Baranski for Season 2 is Denee Benton ("UnREAL"), who plays highly motivated writer Peggy Scott, who moved from Pennsylvania to New York City with Marian. Despite holding down a job as Agnes' secretary, Peggy is of respectable societal standing herself and has come to enjoy the company of her old friend in a new city. She also enjoys testing the boundaries set in place by those in high-up positions, often complicating matters for herself and those closest to her.Headed into the show's second season, the Primetime Emmy-winning series follows more of the petticoat-clad drama that comes along with Gilded-era expansion. This time, according to the official HBO trailer, it seems that the bulk of the hullabaloo centers on the world of the operatic arts. More specifically, it likely revolves around the 1886 closing of the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Melissa Joan Hart is privy to a murder in true Lifetime drama - On Tap
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Melissa Joan Hart is privy to a murder in true Lifetime drama - On Tap

 October 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 32 | Section: News 
 
 322
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Melissa Joan Hart has enjoyed switching things up in her career, and she clearly enjoys continuing to do so.The actress who established herself as a young star in the series "Clarissa Explains It All" and "Sabrina the Teenage Witch" has moved regularly between comedy and drama, and also between performing and directing (sometimes doing both at once). Her yen for trying different sorts of projects is clear again as she stars in the fact-inspired Lifetime movie "Would You Kill for Me? The Mary Bailey Story," debuting Saturday, Oct. 28.As she has done on many of her projects, Hart also serves as an executive producer on the film, in which she plays the matriarch of a family whose women suffer the alcohol-fueled abuse of an outsider. Hart's character Ella sees her daughter Veronica (played by Olivia Scriven) marry Willard (Connor McMahon), whose behavior gets steadily worse - one major indication being his affair with Veronica's best friend, who becomes pregnant by him. Ella's young granddaughter Mary (Presley Allard) also is subjected to the turmoil, until one night that ends fatally."Would You Kill for Me? The Mary Bailey Story" takes a "Ra-shomon"-like approach, showing the events from the perspective of each of the female relatives. As the story unfolds, the audience is invited to guess who committed the killing, with that person's identity revealed at the end of the movie.Obviously, this is heavy territory for Hart, but she's been tackling challenging material since the time she was particularly popular with young viewers for her weekly television work. During that period, she portrayed a young woman who manipulated her boyfriend against her parents in "Twisted Desire" (1996), one of several people left at the mercy of the sea by a yacht mishap in "Two Came Back" (1997), and a college journalist probing her best friend's assault in "Silencing Mary" (1998). 
 
 Caption: Melissa Joan Hart and Presley Allard in "Would You Kill for Me? The ManyBailey Story"

author: Jay Bobbin

 Kirstie AlleyQ: I recently saw a repeat of "Cheers" that had Kirstie Alley in it. How long was she on that show?A: The late actress joined the NBC sitcom, set in the Boston bar "where everybody knows your name," in 1992 at the start of the sixth of its 11 seasons. Her character, Rebecca Howe, became the site's manager and effectively assumed the former spot of Diane Chambers (played by Shelley Long) as a romantic interest and verbal sparring partner for bartender Sam Maloine (Ted Danson).Alley already had done a considerable amount of television work by the time she began her "Cheers" tenure, including her stints as a non-celebrity contestant on "Match Game" and "Password Plus." Her first major acting role was TV-based, as Lt. Saavik in "Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan" (1982), though that was a theatrical film. She had a brief mid-1980s run in the ABC espionage series "Masquerade," then gained attention in the ABC miniseries "North and South" and played iconic feminist Gloria Steinem in the ABC movie "A Bunny's Tale.""Cheers" came next for Alley, and most of her extracurricular work during her run on that series leaned toward feature films. She used her hiatus periods from the show to make such movies as "Shoot to Kill" (1988), "Loverboy" (1989), "Sibling Rivalry" (1990) and the three "Look Who's Talking" comedies (1989, 1990, 1993). Alley would make several other series, including "Veronica's Closet" and "Kirstie" (though her character in the latter was named Maddie), later.

 Though it's a potent chiller anytime, there clearly isn't better scheduling for director and co-writer John Carpenter's original 1978 thriller "Halloween" than the week of trick-or-treating itself. AMC gives the scare show a real workout by showing it Sunday, Oct. 29, Monday, Oct. 30, and Tuesday, Oct. 31 - along with several of the sequels, which were guaranteed when the first movie became one of the most profitable independent films of all time.Recent Oscar winner Jamie Lee Curtis secured her "scream queen" label as Laurie Strode, the babysitter who ends up in a battle for survival against Michael Myers (played mainly by Nick Castle), a sanitarium escapee who targets various people in an Illinois town. Donald Pleasence also stars as the masked and highly lethal Michael's psychiatrist, who does what he can to recapture the killer. Carpenter also composed the memorably minimalist music score.

title: Give one out if you can get 10 in - Bridge
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Give one out if you can get 10 in - Bridge

 October 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 10 | Section: News 
 
 278
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Education is recognizing that you have made a mistake. Experience is recognizing that you have made the same mistake for a second time.Of course, ideally we compress education and experience into one, never making the same mistake twice. However, in the real world, it happens; and it is especially frustrating when it occurs at the bridge table.North's two-no-trump response showed at least a limit raise in spades with four or more trumps. (North would have cue-bid three hearts with only three-card spade support.) South, despite being worried about his heart holding, took a shot at the vulnerable game.West started with three rounds of hearts, East echoing to show his doubleton.South, who had seen the high-low also, was in a dilemma. Should he ruff with dummy's spade 10, hoping West had the jack? Or should he ruff with the queen, hoping the spade jack would drop in one or two rounds? Of course, if South had a trump loser, maybe East would have the club queen, so that South's diamond loser could be discarded on dummy's club ace. Which way should South have gone?As the experienced among you will know, declarer shouldn't ruff high or low. He should discard one of dummy's low diamonds. Then, as long as the trumps aren't 4-0, the contract is under control.Suppose West switches to a diamond. Declarer wins with dummy's ace and draws trumps. Then he ruffs his diamond loser in the dummy, when there is no risk of an overruff.As Mark Twain said, "The principle of give and take is the principle of diplomacy - give one and take 10."©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Taste and talent: Peruvian chef Franco Noriega sizzles in 'Hot Dish' - Tasty Tv
author: Caroline Collacutt
content:
Taste and talent: Peruvian chef Franco Noriega sizzles in 'Hot Dish' - Tasty Tv

 October 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Caroline Collacutt | Page: 34 | Section: News 
 
 362
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Good food and good stories - that's what makes a perfect meal. And having tried everything - from acting to modeling to competitive swimming - before becoming a professional restaurateur, this Peruvian chef certainly has both to share. All-new episodes of "Hot Dish With Franco" air Saturdays on Food Network.During this series, "Franco shares personal heartfelt stories of his Peruvian and Italian roots as he prepares delicious dishes with his signature flare for flavor," Food Network describes. "From quick and easy weeknight meals to brunch and classic Latin dishes with a twist, all of Franco's food is easy, accessible and brings people together."Even before the show's premiere, Noriega's enthusiasm for the program was evident. "Delicious food has always been central in my life as some of my favorite memories have been in the kitchen eating and cooking with my family and traveling across the world enjoying fantastic meals. Now, I'm thrilled to share my favorite recipes and lifelong passion for cooking with Food Network viewers," he recently shared.Throughout the series' six half-hour episodes, Food Network promises that "Franco takes viewers on a culinary journey, sprinkling in tidbits of his Latin American and Italian background along with cooking tips and tricks," exploring everything from cheese-covered Arepas with Chorizo and Vegetable Ceviche to Crispy Parmesan Lemon Asparagus, Deconstructed Tiramisu and ooey-gooey Lava Chocolate Chip Cookies in previously aired episodes.During the season's fifth episode, chef Franco invites viewers to taste a Peruvian-inspired feast - what he dubs the perfect comfort food. "Crispy and fluffy Baby Are-pas with melted cheese and chorizo are the perfect appetizer," the episode description promises, "and there's nothing more comforting than juicy Pollo a la Brasa with crispy skin, smothered in a spicy green sauce. Papas Huancaina with a Spicy Cheese Sauce makes for the perfect side, especially when paired with a Pisco Sour."Finally, during the series' upcoming Season 1 finale, Franco tackles brunch, sharing his recipe for piled-high Avocado Toast before crafting an elevated take on Tex-Mex Huevos Rancheros, complete with fried tortilla strips then covered in homemade salsa, refried beans, crema and fried eggs.Bursting with flavor and Franco's signature flair, the Season 1 finale for "Hot Dish With Franco" airs Saturday, Nov. 4, on Food Network.

title: More Retro Rewinds
content:
More Retro Rewinds

 October 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 36 | Section: News 
 
 235
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "The Nightmare Before Christmas"(Freeform, Sunday, Oct. 29): Produced by Tim Burton, this bizarrely and famously unique 1993 story centers around Jack Skellington (voice shared by Chris Sarandon and composer Danny Elfman), the offbeat leader of annual celebrations of trick-or-treating. He also wants to honor Christmas, but others don't know how to separate the spirit of that occasion from the Halloween events they're used to, to the degree that a plot to kidnap Santa Claus is hatched. Catherine O'Hara and Paul Reubens - alias "Pee-wee Herman" - also are in the voice cast."To Catch a Thief"(MGM+, Sunday, Oct. 29): One of director Alfred Hitchcock's most stylish and lushy filmed pictures, this 1955 treat teams Cary Grant and Grace Kelly - and, quite notably and noticeably, the French Riviera - in the tale of a former jewel thief (Grant) who has a hard time convincing others that he's gotten out of that line of work. Jessie Royce Landis, who played Grant's mother in Hitchcock's "North by Northwest" several years later, co-stars."The Beverly Hillbillies"(MeTV, Tuesday, Oct. 31): The nostalgic channel marks Halloween with relatively eerie episodes of some classic series, but there's still room for laughs here in the appropriately titled story "Trick or Treat." Jed (Buddy Ebsen), Granny (Irene Ryan) and the other Clampetts decide it's time to meet their neighbors in Beverly Hills but they choose Halloween to do that, resulting in encounters that are interesting, to say the least.

title: Dad couldn't change bad attitude
content:
Dad couldn't change bad attitude

 October 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 17 | Section: News 
 
 300
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DEAR HARRIETTE: I am a 23-year-old who just moved to San Francisco. My dad recently came to visit me, and I was excited because I hadn't seen him in six months.My excitement was dampened once he got here and had nothing positive to say, just complaints the entire time.He hated my apartment, thought it was too exhausting to walk up the hills in the city and didn't like how expensive the city was.I was really frustrated because I've been loving my life here. I found a small apartment that's in a great location and have been really good at budgeting.Despite his complaints, I decided to try and keep a positive attitude and continue to tour him around the city. I don't want our relationship to be strained, and I want him to see that I'm doing well here.How can I address my dad's negativity and help him see the positive side of my new life in San Franciscoft - Crack a Smile DEAR CRACK A SMILE: Choose the positive.Thank your Dad for coming to visit you and spending time together. Tell him how much you appreciate his effort. Then move on to recapping what you like about your life as you are establishing independence as a young adult.You can leave it at that, or, if you feel so inclined, you can remind him that you are budgeting well in an expensive city. You are enjoying the beauty that the city has to offer, meeting new people and building your life.Your father does not have to love your city, your home or anything else about your life. Just know that his complaints probably are based on his love for you and his knee-jerk reaction to protect you. He may only see that he would find it hard to live there. You can see the potential. 
 
 Caption: HARRIETTE COLE

title: Bridge - The weak can win tricks also
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The weak can win tricks also

 October 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 269
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We all know the story of David and Goliath, when little David used a stone thrown from a sling to down giant Goliath. Today's deal reminds me of this. It is one of my favorite teaching deals because inexperienced players have trouble believing that "length before strength" is valid. They would much prefer to bid an A-K-Q suit than a 6-5-4-3-2 suit.After a predictable first round to the auction, many Souths would pass, refusing to bid a suit as weak as 5-4-3-2. This South, though, knew that any four-card suit is biddable.West applied some pressure with a preemptive raise to three hearts, but he should have bid four hearts with a known 10-card fit. Vulnerability is for children! However, North had sufficient distribution to justify his three-spade bid. Now South showed true courage, raising himself to game. Note that four spades is the only game contract with any chance of success.South won the heart lead (luckily not the club 10!) with his ace and immediately played a trump. East won and led a top heart, forcing the dummy to ruff. However, declarer happily played another round of spades.When they broke 3-2, the contract was under control.Declarer played on diamonds until an opponent ruffed in, losing only three trump tricks.True, it is easier on the nerves to have longer and stronger trumps than these. Still, if you enjoy a three-card majority and the opponents' trumps are dividing 3-2, which they will more than two-thirds of the time, the contract will usually be playable. The many dwarfs will overpower the few giants. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Said before, but rarely
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Said before, but rarely

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 10A | Section: News 
 
 254
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Who wrote: "Nothing has yet been said that's not been said before."?Today's critical suit combination has appeared in print before, but only rarely. Most players get it wrong. Without peeking at the East-West hands, how would you play the club suit for at most one loser in notrump?North's sequence showed four hearts, at least five clubs and game-going values or more. He announced the "or more" when leaping to six no-trump on round three.South starts with 10 top tricks: two spades, four hearts, two diamonds and two clubs. Clearly, he can afford one club loser but not two. All plays work if the missing clubs are divided 3-2. So you must maximize your chances against a 4-1 break.It looks normal to play the club king and another club, winning when East has the singleton nine, jack or queen.However, there is a better play. You should win the diamond lead with dummy's ace and immediately call for the club 10! If East plays the two or three, you play low. If East plays the nine or an honor, you win with the king and return a club, planning to cover West's card.This line works whenever East has the singleton nine, jack or queen, and when West has the singleton nine.The opening sentence was penned by Terence, a second-century B.C.Roman comic poet who wrote in remarkably pure Latin. What I would like to know is: Who said it before Terence? ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

 DENTON - More than 800 people from Caroline and surrounding counties poured into the schoolyard of the Caroline Culinary Arts Center to partake in the Halloween festivities last weekend.This free community event, the Spooktacular Fall Festival, featured treats prepared by the culinary arts students, a bouncy house, popcorn, fun Halloween activities and "tent or treating." "The spooktacular event was spectacular, said Beth Brewster, the Chesapeake Culinary Center's founder and executive director."It was a great family event, bringing children, parents, grandparents to enjoy a fun night. The costumes were incredible.The community organizations present to give out treats show a true commitment to our residents. The culinary center team, led by Angel (Perez) on this event did an incredible job and truly brought to fruition what the culinary center is, a community space to bring people together." Community businesses and agencies decorated their tents and handed out candy and information to those participating."It's always great to see new faces at the Culinary Center. title: 'It's like a burlesque show for acrobats' - Paranormal Cirque bring seductive performance under the big top to Maryland
content:
'It's like a burlesque show for acrobats' - Paranormal Cirque bring seductive performance under the big top to Maryland

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 7A | Section: News 
 
 501
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Paranormal Cirque III arrives in Maryland this month for shows in Hanover and Waldorf.The shows are for mature audiences with provocative performances with aerialists and contortionists displaying their skills in a sensual manner.The Hanover shows run Nov. 2 to Nov. 5 at Arundel Mills Mall and and Nov. 9 to Nov. 12 at St. Charles Towne Center. Tickets are $20 to $60.The Cirque Italia's Paranormal Cirque III has seductive, hypnotic, sultry acts not associated with the family circus that many onlookers might recall from their childhood. Children under 13 are not allowed and kids 13 to 17 must be accompanied by an adult.Roxana Midi, a native of Romania who will perform as an aerialist in the upcoming shows, is eager to display her talents in an event that the producers readily boast will feature a wide range of performances that circus goers would clearly not view as normal, including acts featuring exotic witches, gruesome ghouls, sexy witches and zombies."For me, they main reward comes from the applause that I receive from the audience after a performance," Midi said. "It's hearing the crowd clap and cheer during the show and at the end that really makes all the hard work worthwhile. Paranormal Cirque is not like anything else that is associated with Cirque Italia. It's very dark, it's sensual and it takes people into a dream world." Developed by entrepreneur Manuel Rebecchi, the Paranormal Cirque III features the usual array of spectacles associated with the premier circuses in the world, including breathtaking visuals, first-class artists and the latest technological advances in theatrical productions.But it also focuses on the sultry and the terrifying and will not be suitable to younger audiences."We're excited to bring this unique and thrilling show to Waldorf," said Luisa Nelson, Cirque Italia's marketing and public relations manager in an interview with the Southern Maryland News. "We've assembled an incredible cast of performers, and we can't wait to showcase their talent to our audiences. This show is perfect for anyone looking for a night of entertainment and scares." Midi, who has been performing with the Cirque Italia for eight years after previously honing her talents as a ballroom dancer, likened much of the show to dancing in the air, something that she will do while performing as an aerialist as "The Dark Angel," a character seeking love and compassion."We have a lot of good dancers and some of them will be dressed as vampires and others as zombies," Midi said. "Anyone who sees this show will be impressed with the dancing and displays of talent. It's like a burlesque show for acrobats. It's scary and creepy, but at the same time it is also very sexy." For more information or to purchase tickets, which cost $20-$60, go to paranormalcirque.com.

title: Bridge - It's a sungular honor, you snob
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - It's a sungular honor, you snob

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 271
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A man is introduced to a well-known snob - that is, the snob is a well-known person, not that he is well known for being a snob."This is a singular honor for me," says the man as they shake hands."Yes, it must be," the snob replies.There are deals in which a singular honor - sorry, a singleton honor - plays a key role. Today's is, of course, one of them. It is another of those deals on which many players would go down because they wouldn't carry out sufficient analysis.After a Stayman auction in which North upgraded his hand because of the singleton, West led the spade jack. Declarer, deciding, reasonably enough, that West wouldn't lead away from the king-jack into a no-trump opening, played low from the dummy. Up popped the king from East.Delightedly, South won with the ace and led a trump.However, West shot in with the ace and returned the spade 10. Declarer covered with dummy's queen, but East ruffed, of course. Back came a trump, and South couldn't avoid the loss of two more spade tricks for down one.When East plays the spade king at trick one, it must be a singleton. If South stops to consider his alternatives, he will realize that ducking his ace is a good play. Then, when West wins with the heart ace and leads another spade, declarer plays low from the dummy. If East ruffs, he is trumping a loser.The spade ace and queen remain to take tricks in a moment. If East doesn't ruff, South wins with the ace and ruffs his two diamond losers in the dummy. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Country music concert returns to American Corner Nov. 18
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Country music concert returns to American Corner Nov. 18

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 2A | Section: News 
 
 390
 Words

 Following a five-year hiatus because of the COVID pandemic, a popular concert and top country and bluegrass stars will return Saturday, Nov. 18, to the Curtis Andrew Auction Facility in American Corner.Billed as a "Bluegrass Country Concert," three acts will be featured, with Rhonda Vincent and the Rage headlining. Vincent is a Grammy Award winner, a member of the Grand Ole Opry and the "Queen of Bluegrass." "We love the Andrew family, and I've been performing there over 20 years, so it's like coming home," Vincent said."We've had a good relationship from day one, and the public really loves her," auctioneer and owner Curtis Andrew said of Vincent."She's an easy person to please when she comes here.What you see - that's the real Rhonda." The opening act will be Wilson Fairchild, billed as the "Ambassadors of Country Music." Wil Reid's father is Harold Reid, and his cousin Langdon Reid's dad is Don Reid of the legendary Statler Brothers.As the Fairfax Trio, U.S.Navy Band musician Haley Stiltner, Matthew Songmaker Ziesing and his wife Sally Sandker create close harmonies and craveable bluegrass Gospel music.Andrew and his family have hosted the family-friendly country and bluegrass music concerts at the auction facility since 1997.He values the opportunity to give back to the community and bring smiles to the faces of friends, neighbors and those as far away as Kansas and Canada who comprise the toe-tapping audience.Despite the enormous amount of hard work and coordination the concerts require of him and his family and staff, Andrew said he enjoys "watching the fans having a good time and an enjoyable evening." The musicians and singers he's met through the years prompt fond memories. Artists like Hank Williams III, John Anderson, Marty Stuart have graced the stage of the large auction building, which is completely emptied of auction tables and transformed into a concert hall with professional stage, lighting, sound system and curtains.Tickets are $60 each.Call 410-754-8826 or email info@acurtisandrewauction.com for ticket availability.Plenty of parking is available and RVs are welcome, but with no hook-ups.Recordings and videotaping are prohibited.The facility's restaurant and staff will serve reasonably priced dinners and lighter fare. The restaurant will open at 4 p.m.The Curtis Andrew Auction Facility is located at 25631 Auction Road, Federalsburg.The website is www.acurtisandrewauction.com.

 "My Three Sons" (MeTV, Monday, Nov. 5, through Friday, Nov. 9): Now a part of the weekday lineup, this sitcom gave Fred MacMurray one of the sweetest work schedules anyone ever has had, actor or otherwise. As widower and dad Steve Douglas, the star filmed all of his scenes for a season over the course of two months giving him the rest of the year to do whatever he wanted. That's why he's often seen on the screen by himself here, since other cast members would film their portions later."Family Affair" (Catchy Comedy, Monday, Nov. 5, through Friday, Nov. 9): Executive producer Don Fedderson also was behind "My Three Sons," and he gave this show's Brian Keith the same work arrangement that Fred MacMurray had on the other series - with all of his scenes as orphan-guarding "Uncle Bill" Davis compacted into two 30-day blocks for a season. Kathy Garver, Anissa Jones and Johnny Whitaker play Davis' young wards, with Sebastian Cabot as manservant Mr. French."Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" (Turner Classic Movies, Friday, Nov. 10): One of the most emotionally grueling house parties ever is the basis of then-debuting director Mike Nichols' 1966 film of the Edward Albee play. Legendary showbiz spouses Eiizabeth Taylor (who won an Oscar here) and Richard Burton get a chance to shatter their glamorous images as an argumentative married couple who put their guests (George Segal and Sandy Dennis, the latter also doing Academy Award-winning work) through quite a wringer during the night they spend together.

title: celebrity update - Jesse L. Martin

content:

 Q: I'm glad to see Jesse L. Martin back as a series star in "The Irrational." I know he also was in "Law & Order" and "The Flash," but has he done any other shows?A: Yes. After appearing on the ABC daytime serial "One Life to Live" early in his career, Martin landed a starring role in the short-lived "413 Hope St.," a seriocomic Fox show about a crisis center. He stayed with Fox for a recurring part on "Ally McBeal" during its first two seasons, then NBC's "Law & Order" came his way, and he appeared in just under 200 episodes over eight years as Detective Ed Green.Martin had another recurring role in the NBC musical-drama series "Smash" during its second and final season, then his next long television run - lasting the better part of a decade - with his portrayal of Joe West on The CW's "The Flash." Martin was cast in the "Irrational" before his "Flash" engagement ended, and he went from regular to recurring status on the superhero show so that he could begin work on "The Irrational," on which he's also a producer.The fact that Martin started work early on "The Irrational" is a big reason the show was able to premiere as it normally would have at the start of the fall season, when so many other series were unable to start at the usual time because of the actors' and writers' strikes that prevented production from taking place. Enough "Irrational" episodes had been banked by the time the strikes began to enable the program to have the September start that it always was planned for. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses actor Jesse L. Martin's TV roles and a new series, which aligns with entertainment news about television and celebrities.

title: Trivial pursuit: New comedy film 'Quiz Lady' wins big
author: Sarah Passingham
content:
Trivial pursuit: New comedy film 'Quiz Lady' wins big

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sarah Passingham | Page: 9A | Section: News 
 
 555
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Fingers on buzzers! Which streamer premieres a brand-new comedy film starring Awkwafina ("Renfield," 2023) and Sandra Oh ("Grey's Anatomy") on Friday, Nov. 3? The answer is Hulu, and the film in question is "Quiz Lady," a buddy comedy about two sisters who come together to win a quiz show and save a dog.Awkwafina is Anna, the reliable, type-A sister who is called away from her work as an accountant when her mom's senior living facility reaches out to let Anna know that they had lost her mom - but not to the afterlife.The attendant corrects herself in the trailer, telling Anna, "Sorry, that was terrible phrasing. I meant we don't know where she is." After making it to the facility, Anna is joined by her estranged and distraught sister Jenny, portrayed by Oh, whose purple highlights, oversized sunglasses and flamboyant personal style contrast with Anna's head-to-toe grey wardrobe. Anna is clued in to her mother's whereabouts when a bookie informs her that her beloved pet pug, Mr. Linguini, has been kidnapped and is being held hostage over her mother's massive gambling debts.With the debts creeping up her back and seniors home infractions stacking up, Anna and Jenny's mom flees to Macau, leaving them to sort out what she owes and be reunited with Mr. Linguini. Anna's salary isn't quite generous enough to settle their mother's $80,000 tab, and Jenny's constant search for her latest passion hasn't resulted in financial stability. Two weeks is all they're given to cough up the funds.The siblings are at a loss for ways to get rich quick until Jenny sees Anna participate in her favorite game show, "Can't Stop the Quiz," from her sofa. The show is must-watch television for Anna, who tunes in daily, usually accompanied by her canine companion, and effortlessly answers every single question correctly. Seeing Anna in her element turns on a light bulb over Jenny's head.It's decided, then, that the pair will travel to Los Angeles, get Anna on "Can't Stop the Quiz," and all their problems will be solved when she wins. Leaving the safety of her routine life in Philadelphia behind, Anna joins Jenny on a wild road trip across the United States and embraces her sister's chaotic, adventurous way of life. Neither of them is completely certain that Anna's trivia skills will transfer from the comfort of her couch to the pressure of the game show's set, but this is the best chance they've got to scrape together enough money to bring Mr. Linguini home unharmed.Having spent years apart, estranged over their differences, Anna and Jenny have a lot of ground to cover - geographically and emotionally - on their road trip. Anna's strictly balanced life greatly differs from her sister Jenny's listless pursuit of purpose. They have things to learn from each other, whether it's how to let loose and go on an adventure or focus enough to successfully achieve a goal."The element that really attracted me was the sister dynamic," director Jessica Yu told Deadline at the world premiere of "Quiz Lady" at the Toronto International Film Festival in September. She added, "For one thing, I just haven't seen a lot of comedies about sisters, and the fact that at the center of this was two Asian-American sisters, made me think, 'Oh, this will be really fun to explore.'" 
 
 Caption: Sandra Oh and Awkwafina in "Quiz Lady" 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Netflix's 'Sly' charts Sylvester Stallone's life and career
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Netflix's 'Sly' charts Sylvester Stallone's life and career

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 12A | Section: News 
 
 315
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The saga of Sylvester Stallone continues to add new chapters, but he already has quite a story to tell.The actor-writer-director - famous for creating his own fame as the originator of the "Rocky" franchise - is the subject of "Sly," a Netflix documentary that makes its streaming debut Friday, Nov. 3, after premiering at the Toronto International Film Festival in September.Directed by Thom Zimny, who also has done projects about Bruce Springsteen, Elvis Presley and Johnny Cash, the profile is built on a wealth of Stallone's remarks about the triumph and setbacks he has experienced in his personal and professional lives. Family members also contribute comments, as do Stallone colleagues and friends Arnold Schwarzenegger and Henry Winkler, and filmmaker Quentin Tarantino.Born in New York's Hell's Kitchen in 1946, Stallone made one of his first notable appearances as a subway-train hoodlum in Woody Allen's "Bananas" (1971), and he gained some attention in "The Lords of Flatbush" (1974) opposite Winkler and in "Death Race 2000" (1975). His breakthrough clearly was the original "Rocky" (1976), which he wrote and insisted on starring in himself, with the huge success of the saga of a struggling Philadelphia boxer winning its year's Oscar for best picture. It also yielded five direct sequels and inspired the "Creed" series, with "First Blood" (1982) giving Stallone another continuing character in famously rugged Vietnam veteran John Rambo.Stallone remained a box-office king for years afterward, with "Cobra" (1986), "Tango & Cash" (1989), "Cliffhanger" (1993), "Demolition Man" (1993), "The Specialist" (1994) and "The Expendables" (2010) among the bigger hits that sustained his career when such efforts as "Oscar" (1991) and "Stop! Or My Mom Will Shoot" (1992) didn't register strongly by comparison.The star picked up critical acclaim for pictures including "Cop Land" (1997), and he became an Oscar nominee for reprising (and aging) the Rocky role in the first "Creed" movie (2015). 
 
 Caption: Sylvester Stallone stars in "Sly" 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a new Netflix documentary about Sylvester Stallone, focusing on his film career and the streaming release, which fits the Entertainment category best.

title: Cake o'clock: Buddy Valastro premieres two new shows on A & E
author: Caroline Collacutt
content:
Cake o'clock: Buddy Valastro premieres two new shows on A & E

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Caroline Collacutt | Page: 14A | Section: News 
 
 364
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's time to have your cake and eat it, too! Buddy Valastro is joining A & E's Home.Made.Nation with two new series, premiering on the network this Saturday, Nov. 11: "Legends of the Fork" and, immediately following, "Buddy Valastro's Cake Dynasty." "We're back on TV, baby!" the infamous cake boss himself said. "I'm excited to bring not one, but two brand-new shows to A & E starting this November.Viewers are going to love 'Buddy Valastro's Cake Dynasty,' featuring the whole Valastro family, just a little older and maybe a little more grown-up (maybe!)."And I hope people enjoy all the great culinary stories I showcase on 'Legends of the Fork,' while traveling throughout the country looking for the most iconic food and flavors," Valastro concluded, giving viewers a taste of his first new series.During each half-hour episode of "Legends of the Fork," the superstar baker travels from Los Angeles to New Jersey, out to "see, hear and taste the stories, histories, legacies and flavors of America's iconic restaurants," according to the network. "Buddy explores how these historic eateries offer diners an astonishing panorama of the country's social, cultural and demographic history, as well as its culinary traditions." Following the premiere of his tasty travel series, Valastro invites viewers behind the scenes at Carlo's Bake Shop in "Buddy Valastro's Cake Dynasty," in which Buddy and his extended family work together in order to balance the nonstop demands of their cake empire with their always-hectic home life."The business is growing with restaurants, nationwide shipping, automated cake vending and more," a news release from A & E describes. "While baking thousands of cakes, Italian specialty desserts and cookies each day, while also creating the most brain-busting, innovative cakes around," this new series takes Buddy and the bakery to a whole new level. During this first season, Carlo's welcomes high-tier clientele, crafting massive cakes for Neil Patrick Harris' 50th birthday, the 20th anniversary of "Wicked" on Broadway, the 50th anniversary of Secretariat's legendary win, and even a massive anniversary cake for Caesars Palace in Las Vegas.With sugar, spice and everything nice, Home.Made.Nation welcomes Buddy to the family, as "Legends of the Fork" and "Buddy Valastro's Cake Dynasty" premiere back-to-back, Saturday, Nov. 11, on A & E. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: The Price Sisters to kick off Southern Maryland Bluegrass Series
content:
The Price Sisters to kick off Southern Maryland Bluegrass Series

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 8A | Section: News 
 
 352
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Southern Maryland Bluegrass Concert Series will return with a concert by The Price Sisters at 2 p.m. on Sunday, Nov. 5, at the Calvert Elks Lodge No. 2620, located at 1015 Dares Beach Road in Prince Frederick.Hailing from Kentucky and recording for Del McCoury's record label, a news release said the band has become one of the most promising acts in bluegrass music today.With a playing style of the likes of Bill Monroe and the Bluegrass Boys, twin sisters Lauren and Leanna Price are becoming the torchbearers for bluegrass music.The release added that while their playing is strongly rooted in the classic bluegrass style, their smooth, polished sibling harmonies infuse the music with a fresh, contemporary appeal.For their eighth birthday, Lauren and Leanna were gifted instruments and began taking lessons within a year or so afterward, though they didn't take an interest in bluegrass music until their later school years.In 2016, they signed with Rebel Records and released an EP and began touring professionally as The Price Sisters. In 2018 they released their first full-length album, "A Heart Never Knows." They now perform at many venues and festivals across the United States as well as in Germany, Austria, Switzerland and Canada.Other band members include Trevor Holder on banjo, bassist Bobby Osborne Jr. and guitarist Conner Vlietstra.The next concert in the series will feature an all-Christmas program on Dec. 10 with the Becky Buller Band featuring Ned Luberecki. Other performances planned for early 2024 will be by Lonesome River Band on Jan. 14, The Grascals on Feb. 11, High Fidelity on March 3, Russell Moore & IIIrd Tyme Out will perform March 24 and Dave Peterson & 1946 will close out the series April 28.Tickets for The Price Sisters are $23 per person, free for ages 12 and younger with a paid adult.Doors open at noon and food and beverages will be available for purchase.For more information, call 301-737-3004 or go to www.somdbluegrass.com. 
 
 Caption: SUBMITTED PHOTO
 
Kentucky-based The Price Sisters will kick off the Southern Maryland Bluegrass Series with a concert on Nov. 5 at the Calvert Elks Lodge.

title: Bridge - Fishing for red herrings
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Fishing for red herrings

 November 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 278
 Words 

 Read News Document

 William Shakespeare made mention in "Twelfth Night" of "A plague o' these pickle herring!" If he had been a bridge player, perhaps he would have rephrased that to a plague o' pickle red herring.On some deals there are cards, usually honors, that tempt declarer into a losing line of play. If only the honor were a low card, the contract would present no difficulty.Today's deal is an example.After North, via a transfer bid, showed a balanced hand with five hearts, South selected four hearts. He knew of an eight-card fit and, more importantly, the potential blockage in the heart suit might prove to be lethal to three no-trump. Here, though, three no-trump was laydown, and four hearts needed careful handling. It is impossible to bid perfectly on every deal without seeing all of the cards.West, with an unappealing lead, selected a trump.Declarer won in hand, played a diamond to dummy's ace and finessed the club queen.West won with the king and played his second heart.Declarer continued with the diamond king and another diamond, but East won and led a third round of hearts.Now South had to go down one, losing one spade, two diamonds and one club.The club queen was a red herring. If declarer immediately plays the club ace and queen, he cannot go down. West wins and leads a trump, but declarer crosses to dummy with a diamond to the ace and ruffs the club seven in hand for his 10th trick.If a ruff can be taken in the short-trump hand, even if that is the declarer's, it is almost certain to be the right play. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: When do you play second hand high? - Bridge
author: Phillip Alder
content:
When do you play second hand high? - Bridge

 November 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 266
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In her poem "Sanctuary," Dorothy Parker wrote, "My land is bare of chattering folk;/the clouds are low along the ridges,/and sweet's the air with curly smoke/from all my burning bridges."At the card table, we try not to burn our bridges with partner. One of the best known ways of keeping them intact is "second hand low." Why rush up when your partner is last to play to the trick?This week, let's look at the times when your problem is deciding between second hand high and low.First, second hand low. A textbook example is in this deal. How should the play go in six spades after West leads the heart king?If North were a member of the Real Bridge Players Don't Need Blackwood Club, he would jump straight to six spades. Here, he uses Roman Key Card Blackwood to learn that his partner has either two aces or one ace and the spade king.Declarer wins the first trick with dummy's heart ace, cashes the three diamond winners, discarding his remaining heart, ruffs the heart four in his hand and leads a club toward dummy's king-jack.West must play second hand low -- and do it with no hesitation. He should know that his side needs two club tricks to defeat the contract. He must not give declarer the contract on a platter with caviar, lobster and toast points.Then, if declarer calls for dummy's king, West will say: "Sorry, partner. Next time I will lead a low club, which will surely cause South to misguess."©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bridge - Make declarer guess correctly
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Make declarer guess correctly

 November 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 284
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We are looking at second hand low and, later in the week, second hand high.It is important for defenders to make declarer guess well to land his contract. They must not make things easy for him.The heart suit in this deal is one example. How should South plan the play in six spades? West leads the diamond 10.After South opened one spade, North understandably launched into Blackwood, signing off in six spades when he learned that one ace was missing. He expected South to claim immediately, but the mirror distribution meant that play had to proceed.South, who can afford to lose only one heart trick, wins trick one in the dummy, draws trumps, cashes all of the minor-suit winners ending in his hand and leads a heart. If West wins with the ace, it is all over. So, let's assume West plays low. Now South calls for dummy's heart queen. (This is a better play than immediately finessing dummy's 10.) If East takes the trick, he is endplayed, forced either to return a heart into dummy's K-10 or to concede a ruffand-sluff. So, let's assume East also plays low.Declarer returns to his hand with a trump and leads another heart. Again, if West wins with the ace, South claims. When West plays low, though, declarer has a guess. He might or might not get it right, but at least the defender with the ace - whether it is East or West - did his best.Finally, note that both West and East must play low so smoothly that the kibitzers think the deck is missing the heart ace. Any hesitation gives the game away. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bridge - The singleton will be led
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The singleton will be led

 November 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 11 | Section: News 
 
 281
 Words 

 Read News Document

 You are sitting over the dummy. It is a trump contract. Dummy has a sidesuit singleton, and in that suit you have the ace without the king or queen. You know what will happen. Declarer will get into the dummy and call for that singleton. Do you win with your ace, or do you play low smoothly?North, despite having six losers (one spade, two hearts, two diamonds and one club), blasted into Blackwood and then leapt to six spades. A four-club splinter bid would have been a wiser choice - if North-South were using that toy, of course. (Four clubs would have shown fourcard or longer spade support, at least game values and a singleton or void in the bid suit.)A diamond lead would have defeated the contract by two tricks, but West understandably selected the heart queen. Declarer won with dummy's king and called for the club seven.East was immediately on the spot. What should he have done?If the ace is the setting trick, he (almost always) should grab the trick. But far more often than not, second hand should play low, not win with the ace. This deal is a tough example. Although South has no guess in the suit, if East wins with his ace, the contract makes. Declarer gets two club winners, on which he discards dummy's two low diamonds. He takes five spades, two hearts, one diamond, two clubs and two diamond ruffs in the dummy.Luckily for the defense, East had been there before: He played low smoothly. That cost one club trick, but two diamond tricks come back in return. The declarer had no chance. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Out of this world TV: Season 4 of 'For All Mankind' enters new millennium
author: Dana Simpson
content:
Out of this world TV: Season 4 of 'For All Mankind' enters new millennium

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Dana Simpson | Page: A9 | Section: News 
 
 425
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Whether it takes "one small step" or "one giant leap" to get to your couch, do it "For All Mankind." The hit Apple TV+ television series "For All Mankind" is back for a fourth season Friday, Nov. 10, after taking a yearand-a-half-long hiatus. With one Primetime Emmy win under its belt already, the sci-fidrama's newest season is comprised of another 10 episodes, thus bringing the total episode count for the series to a whopping 40.The series first made (gravitational?) waves when it premiered on its home streamer in 2019. Marketed as an alternate version of 1969, in which "the Soviet Union beats the United States to the moon" (per IMDb), the series reimagines history and speculates how this one change in events could have sparked a whole new world order. Largely focused on the political and scientific ramifications of the then-U.S.S.R. making history on the moon, "For All Mankind" Season 1 leaned into the idea of a space race that "continues on for decades with still grander challenges and goals." With the premiere of Season 2 in February 2021, the astronauts faced an all-new set of challenges that took place more than a decade after the moon landing. Having confronted everything from lunar ice and trespassers to gender debates in Season 1, the next two seasons promised higher stakes and bigger problems. And on this promise it surely delivered.From natural disasters such as solar storms and generally harsh living conditions to personal qualms ranging from reckless and selfish behavior to ego-based contests and grand political motivations, there has never been a dull moment on the screen - or in the lives of "For All Mankind's" fictionalized astronauts and their families.One of these astronauts is Edward Baldwin, played by "The Killing's" Joel Kinnaman. The head of the Baldwin family, which has seen some serious struggles throughout the show's three seasons to date, Ed is one of NASA's best astronauts and is rumored to have been based upon real-life Apollo 10 commander Thomas P. Stafford.While Ed has been supported by several family members over the years, including Karen (Shantel VanSanten, "Shooter"), Kelly (Cynthy Wu, "Holidate," 2020) and Shane (played by brothers Teddy and Tait Blum, "Big Little Lies" and "Shooter," respectively), the only confirmed Baldwin returning (other than Ed) is Kelly.Joining Ed in space and on Earth are returning characters Ellen Wilson (Jodi Balfour, "Quarry"), Margo Madison (Wrenn Schmidt, "Nope," 2022), Danielle Poole (Krys Marshall, "Supergirl"), Helios Aerospace founder Dev Ayesa (Edi Gathegi, "The Blacklist") and Aleida Rosales (Coral Peña, "The Post," 2017). 
 
 Caption: Wrenn Schmidt in "For All Mankind"

title: Universal miss: 72nd Miss Universe pageant continues deal with Roku Channel
author: Caroline Colacutt
content:
Universal miss: 72nd Miss Universe pageant continues deal with Roku Channel

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Caroline Colacutt | Page: A24 | Section: News 
 
 394
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Beauty, grace, humanitarianism and swimsuits: the "72nd Miss Universe" pageant broadcasts live from the National Gymnasium in San Salvador, El Salvador, Saturday, Nov. 18, on the Roku Channel.Airing as part of an ongoing deal between The Miss Universe Organization (now owned by JKN Global Group PCL), The Roku Channel and Telemundo, the event marks the second live event for Roku and will be broadcast in English and Spanish on said networks, respectively.This year marks some important changes for the organization, as this competition will be the first in 66 years in which the Miss Universe Organization has allowed married women and women with children to walk the stage once again: this welcomes Camila Avella (Colombia), Michelle Cohn (Guatemala) and Alexandra Stoyanova (Bulgaria), who otherwise would not have been able to compete.The event also welcomes Rikki Kolle (Netherlands) and Marina Machete (Portugal), who will be the second and third transgender contestants taking part in the pageant (following Angela Ponce from Spain, in 2018).It will also mark the debut of Pakistan to the competition (Erica Robin), and the returns of Denmark, Egypt, Guyana, Hungary, Ireland, Kazakhstan, Latvia, Mongolia, Norway and Zimbabwe, all of which have not entered the competition for at least two years.Last year's winner - R'Bonney Nola Gabriel of the United States - will return to crown her successor at the end of the event. This year, the U.S. is entering 24-year-old Noelia Voigt of Park City, Utah.The program features events that will eventually select a winner, a process including personal statements, interviews, evening gowns and swimwear.The winner takes office immediately after coronation, becoming an ambassador for a year, spreading the organization's positive message and humanitarian works, including fighting for women's ethnic minority rights, racial issues, public health issues and environmental issues.Winners also receive a cash allowance and other perks, such as scholarships, modeling opportunities, beauty products, clothes, styling, fitness services and more.The organization claims: "Miss Universe Organization exists to advocate for a future forged by women - women with the courage to push the limits of what's possible, who are curious enough to make world-shaking discoveries and audacious enough to do this over and over. We believe that the future of humanity rests on reaching gender equity around the world." The "72nd Miss Universe" pageant airs live, Saturday, Nov. 18, on the Roku Channel.

title: Michael Caine - OF THE GREAT ESCAPER ON MISC.
author: Adam Thomlison
content:
Michael Caine - OF THE GREAT ESCAPER ON MISC.

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Adam Thomlison | Page: A24 | Section: News 
 
 267
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Q: Is Michael Caine still working? What's his next project going to be?A: His next project is going to be taking it easy, and enjoying being a granddad.The legendary English actor told the BBC last month that, at 90 years old, he's now officially retired.He said so while doing press for what will now be his last movie, "The Great Escaper," a biographical drama about a war veteran who escapes his retirement home to attend the 70th anniversary of the D-Day landings in France. It was released in early October.It's been well received so far, and Caine said he's unlikely to get another leading-man role again at his age. "The only parts I'm likely to get now are old men, 90-year-old men, maybe 85. And I thought, 'Well, I might as well leave with all this - I've got wonderful reviews. What have I got to do to beat this?'" It caps off an incredible career that launched with small parts in war movies in the mid-1950s. But he really got on the map in the mid-'60s with young, heartthrob roles in hits like "The Ipcress File" (1965) and "Alfie" (1966).He kept up an incredible work rate even into his 80s, appearing, for example, in three different films in 2020 alone (the fantasy drama "Come Away," the kid-friendly comedy "Four Kids and It" and the smash-hit sci-fithriller "Tenet").But he told People magazine a little while ago that becoming a grandfather changed his view of life and ultimately overshadowed his career. "I am completely besotted by my grandchildren. It's my best role, and I don't need any awards for it." 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bridge - When sould he play second hand high?
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - When sould he play second hand high?

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 283
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Phillip Alder So far this week, we have looked at the classic situations for second hand low by a defender. However, there are three critical positions when second hand must play high, like it or not!With that enormous hint, it shouldn't be hard to work out in this deal how the defense can defeat three no-trump after West leads the heart queen.When someone opens two no-trump, his hand will usually contain seven controls, an ace being two controls and a king one.Here, South had eight controls, with which he might have upgraded and opened two clubs. However, he had no five-card suit or good intermediates (nines and 10s). He sensibly started with two no-trump.South had seven top tricks: one spade, two hearts, three diamonds and one club. So, even if diamonds were 3-3, declarer needed to make something of dummy's club suit.South won the first trick with his heart king and immediately led a club.West's big moment had arrived: He had to play second hand high, putting his king onto the table.Note that if West had played his low club, declarer would have called for dummy's nine. Whether East won with his queen or ducked, South would have gotten four club tricks and 10 in all.However, when West played his club king, declarer was caught between a rock and a hard place. If he had ducked in the dummy, another heart would have established West's suit. Instead, when South won with dummy's ace and played another club, East ducked, holding declarer to a pair of club tricks. With the diamonds 4-2, not 3-3, the contract had to fail. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: "Alien" remains a top scare show
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
"Alien" remains a top scare show

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: A16 | Section: News 
 
 170

 "In space, no one can hear you scream." That was the memorable ad line for "Alien," director Ridley Scott's 1979 thriller that launched a franchise largely built around Sigourney Weaver's astronaut character Ripley - the role that made her a star. FX shows the film Saturday, Nov. 17, and even with editing done for basic cable, it remains one of the most tense and troubling sci-fimovies made to date. Its realistic, understated approach in the early going has the effect of softening up the audience for what's to come.Ripley is one member of a deep-space crew that investigates a distress signal and picks up a highly unwelcome visitor the title creature, which grows into something larger and increasingly lethal as it runs amok within the vessel named Nostromo after making quite an explosive entrance. (Anyone familiar with one co-star's big exit scene will know what we're talking about.)Tom Skerritt, Yaphet Kotto, John Hurt, Ian Holm, Harry Dean Stanton and Veronica Cartwright comprise the rest of the cast.

title: Matt LeBlanc
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Matt LeBlanc

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: A10 | Section: News 
 
 242
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Q: I know Matt LeBlanc had a couple of series after "Friends." What has he been doing lately?A: Not a lot professionally since his CBS sitcom "Man With a Plan" ended in 2020. He famously appeared with his former fellow stars in the 2021 streaming special "Friends: The Reunion," which still can be found on Max, and it's quite touching to watch the embraces and memories shared by him and the other five actors with whom he shared so much time - and success - over the decade-long run of that much-repeated show (which was seen originally on NBC).LeBlanc also was part of a 2021 "Top Gear" special that paid tribute to the late race driver Sabine Schmitz, who appeared often on that BBC series. LeBlanc's presence on that special acknowledged his own presence on "Top Gear" as a presenter on episodes that were spread over four seasons, after his participation as a guest. He was required to be in England to make the show, and he ultimately decided to leave that job and remain largely in the U.S.It's not new for LeBlanc to take extended breaks from television work.He also did that after the NBC run of the "Friends" spinoff "Joey," and what was planned as one year off became five, with the actor eventually returning (and playing a variation of himself) in the Showtime comedy series "Episodes." He won a Golden Globe Award for that show, then he spent four seasons on "Man With a Plan."

title: Double date: All-new series explores the dating lives of identical twins
content:
Double date: All-new series explores the dating lives of identical twins

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A12 | Section: News

 When you're born a minute apart and look exactly the same, how different can you be, really? From Amazon Studios and ITV America's ITV Entertainment comes a new dating reality series - a social experiment unlike any other, delving into the dating world of identicals. The Amazon Freevee series "Twin Love" premieres Friday, Nov. 17, on Prime Video.The series, hosted by professional wrestling duo Brie and Nikki Garcia ("WWE Smackdown!"), formerly the Bella Twins, welcomes a cast full of doubles. Amazon Prime describes: "Ten sets of twins will be split up and placed into two houses of 'identical' casts, where they'll begin a unique and compelling search for love. With double the fun and drama, the series will discover if their inherent similarities extend to their romantic desires." "When separated from their twin brothers and sisters - some for the first time ever - will they pursue the same identical partners?" Amazon asks. "Or will their choices be dramatically different?" There's only one way to find out.During this inaugural season, twins include: Whittnay and Brittnay James, who have both been single for over four years; Sabella and Hanna Radostitz, with matching tattoos for former boyfriends they now regret; Cameron and Ceara McKegney, a pair of opposites who still share in their quick-witted and entertaining personalities; Zoie and Baelee Bogart, twin sisters who have never been apart for more than a day; Morgan and Madison Ramsey, two self-proclaimed tomboys who mind their manners; Seth and Luke Banks, the chatterbox brothers, both golfers from a big family; Jair and Micquel Bernier, two confident and popular, party-going jocks; Matthew and Andrew Beatty, who have lived all over the world, making friends globally with their outgoing personalities; Samir and Samer Akel, twins born in Syria who moved to the United States 10 years ago, now successful restaurateurs; and David and Aaron Cabello, both high school dropouts who started their own business that quickly spread across America.From executive producers Simon Thomas ("Love Island"), Bernie Schaeffer ("Edge of Alaska"), Kenny Rosen ("Hell's Kitchen") and Jessica Nahmias ("The Marriage Pact"), "Twin Love" premieres Friday, Nov. 17, on Prime Video.

title: Santa's (cookie) workshop: Season 7 of 'Christmas Cookie Challenge' pays homage to holiday classics
author: Caroline Collacutt
content:
Santa's (cookie) workshop: Season 7 of 'Christmas Cookie Challenge' pays homage to holiday classics

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Caroline Collacutt | Page: A14 | Section: News 
 
 425
 Words

 It's the season to get baking, and no one knows it better than Food Network. Packed with holiday cheer and tasty treats, an all-new season of "Christmas Cookie Challenge" is now airing on the network.Hosted by former NFLplayer, current "Food Network Star" (Season 11), food truck owner and private chef Eddie Jackson, alongside writer, photographer, cookie-making mom and experienced cooking show host, Ree Drummond ("The Pioneer Woman"), this series follows as "confident and daring bakers compete to prove their holiday cookie-making skills," Food Network describes, promising that as four new bakers are introduced each episode, "tough-love judges are on hand to crown the holiday cookie master, [each of whom] will go home with a $10,000 prize!" From gingerbread to snickerdoodles to swirly-twirly gumdrops, the series whips up cheer and inspires bakers back at home. The competing cookie makers are tasked with fun challenges, like crafting usable gingerbread puppet theaters, decorating snickerdoodles and even paying homage to classic Christmas films such as "Elf" (2003), starring Will Ferrell."Four of the finest cookie makers around get inspired by 'the seven levels of the candy cane forest' and 'the sea of swirly-twirly gumdrops,'" Food Network explains, "[creating] cookies that show the parts of Buddy's journey not featured in the movie. When it's over, one 'cotton-headed ninny muggin' will be sent home for the holidays, while the one who decorates the most fantastical journey will win an advantage for the next round." "Their magical displays will have to incorporate ingredients from Buddy the Elf's favorite meal: maple syrup, chocolate syrup, candy-coated chocolates, chocolate breakfast pastries or cooked spaghetti," they say, encouraging some interesting flavors.This current season will also feature an all-star episode, set to air Thursday, Nov. 16, on the network.During this "Champions" episode, Jackson and Drummond welcome eight former "Christmas Cookie Challenge" champions back to the kitchen, asking them to prove who is the best of the best."This time, the cookie makers are facing challenges so merrily massive that they'll be put into teams of two.First, the bakers must weave magic as they create Christmas cookie quilts.One team will have the rug pulled out from under them as they're eliminated.Then, the three remaining teams construct gigantic stadiums worthy of the finest North Pole games that also incorporate ingredients perfect for watching a snow bowl: eggnog, hot chocolate, apple cider or mulled wine" (per Food Network).Keep the holidays extra sweet with "Christmas Cookie Challenge," airing new episodes Thursdays on Food Network.

title: Bridge - Partner's suit is nearly established
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Partner's suit is nearly established

 November 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 21 | Section: News 
 
 277
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Luciano Pavarotti said, "Am I afraid of high notes? Of course I am afraid. What sane man is not?" Today's deal illustrates a time when a player sitting second hand must not be afraid to play high.South is in three no-trump, and West leads the spade queen. What happens after that?Opposite a 15-17 notrump, when responder has 10 points, no interest in the majors and no singleton or void, he should just blast straight into three no-trump.(When your minimum combined count is 25, bid game. When your maximum combined count is 25, settle for one no-trump unless you also have a five-card suit.)South has seven top tricks: two spades, three hearts and two clubs. He must establish two diamond tricks to get home.When declarer has two stoppers in the suit led and two high cards to dislodge, normally he should duck the first trick. (He could win the first trick here as long as he ducks the second round of spades.) After taking dummy's spade ace at trick two, South calls for a diamond.East knows that his partner's suit is one lead from being established. When this is the situation, he should do his utmost to win the next defensive trick. Here, East must play his diamond king. Then, when he holds the trick, he can lead his last spade. West's suit is established, and West has the diamond ace as his entry card. The defenders take two diamonds and three spades.Note that if East does not play his diamond king, West's ace will be gone before his spade suit is ready to run. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
