title: Bridge - Are the robots occasionally psychic?
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Are the robots occasionally psychic?

 November 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 256
 Words 

 Read News Document

 If you play at a Bridge Base Online casual table, you will usually have one or two robots filling in. You might be surprised by some of the opening leads they find. For example, they would do a lot better if they always led fourth-highest from their longest and strongest against no-trump (not a minor-suit singleton, which I have seen a few times).In today's deal, though, the robot found a terrific opening lead. West dealt and passed. South opened one spade in fourth position, North responded one notrump, and South rebid two spades, ending the auction. What would you lead as West?South's rebid showed a minimum opening with at least six spades. No one else felt called on to compete. However, if East is psychic, he can make three no-trump! Against two spades, it looks obvious to lead the heart ace. That isn't fatal, but suppose West shifts to the diamond queen. Declarer wins with dummy's ace and plays its trump. Now at double dummy (you can see all of the cards), East must play his spade queen!At my table, though, West made life much easier for his side. The robot led the club six. East ruffed with the spade seven and returned a heart. West took that trick and delivered a second club ruff. West got back in with the heart ace and gave his partner a third club ruff.That was a quick five tricks for East-West, but where was the sixth defensive trick?Right -- West's spade 10, hiding behind the king-jack, was guaranteed to take the setting trick. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a bridge card game and the behavior of computer opponents, which is a leisure activity and fits best under the Entertainment category.

title: More on planning at trick one - Bridge
author: Phillip Alder
content:
More on planning at trick one - Bridge

 November 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 274
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Every beginner is told to pause before playing from the dummy at trick one.He should form a plan of campaign before continuing the battle. You might think that experts never fall from grace in this respect, but you would be wrong.Today's deal comes from a match between two different countries. How should South play in six hearts after West leads the diamond five?At the other table, North-South stopped in four hearts, making five. This pair was more adventurous. Three diamonds was a transfer bid, East doubling to show good diamonds. Throwing caution to the winds, North rebid a quantitative four notrump.(If he had wanted to ask for aces or key cards immediately, he would have used a Texas transfer at the four-level.) South, despite having minimum count and two diamond losers, took a shot at the slam.The declarer won the first trick with his diamond ace and drew trumps in three rounds. Then he paused to assess the situation - too late.He should have noted that he had only 11 winners: three spades, five hearts, one diamond and two clubs. It was necessary to capture a third club winner.The right line is to draw only two rounds of trumps, keeping an honor in the South hand. Then declarer plays off his three top spades, discarding one of dummy's clubs. A club to the ace, a club to the king and a club ruff follow. South, thankful to see the 3-3 split, plays a trump to his jack (or king) and cashes the club nine, discarding one of dummy's diamond losers. He concedes just one diamond trick. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: French food frenzy: Julia Child takes the cake in 'Chopped'
author: Caroline Col
content:
French food frenzy: Julia Child takes the cake in 'Chopped'

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Caroline Col | Page: 14A | Section: News 
 
 392
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sixteen chefs, one iconic kitchen: an all-new season of this fan-favorite cooking competition honors one of the greatest names in cooking, as "Chopped" returns with new Julia Child-inspired episodes. "Chopped: Julia Child's Kitchen" airs new episodes Tuesdays on Food Network."Julia Child was a chef, instructor, author and legend! Even today she influences modern chefs to achieve greatness and push themselves to be their best," Food Network recently shared. "In this competition, four Julia Child fans compete in a preliminary battle with baskets inspired by Julia's recipes." Keeping to the same format as usual "Chopped" seasons, this "Child-ish" competition features three rounds, in which four chefs must use random and often unusual "mystery basket ingredients" to complete a tasty dish. Each round, one chef is eliminated until only two remain, together facing the judges in the final dessert round, where one is finally crowned the winner.This - "Chopped's" 55th season - will feature a panel of rotating judges, said to include the likes of Scott Conant (chef, host of "24 Hour Restaurant Battle"), Susan Feniger ("Too Hot Tamales"), Amanda Freitag ("Iron Chef America"), Alex Guarnaschelli ("Ciao House"), Nilou Motamed ("Top Chef"), Michael Voltaggio ("Bobby's Triple Threat") and Isabella Rossellini (who stars in "Julia," premiering its second season two days later on Max). Each episode will also see the arrival of four new chefs, with each winner moving on to the tournament's finale, where the final four will fight for a grand prize of $25,000 and a Julia Childthemed dream trip to France.Upcoming episodes of the series feature bright and bold flavors - some Julia herself would never approve of - as the series' second episode promises that "citrus and a salad are part of the puzzle in the appetizer round, and the three chefs who make it to the entrée round must make use of some unusual powder and fancy mushrooms," while a description for the third episode shares that: "The chefs get an unusual piece of chicken and a potato product that would have made Julia cringe." However, in a season featuring fish stew, veal, processed cheese and more, host Ted Allen learns that the stinkiest thing of all might just be his cohorts' Julia Child impressions.As the chefs continue their journeys to France - and practice their accents - "Chopped: Julia Child's Kitchen" premieres an allnew episode, Tuesday, Nov. 21, on Food Network. 
 
 Caption: Ted Allen from "Chopped: Julia Child's Kitchen"

title: All The Leaves Are Red, Yellow, and Orange - Top U.S. Destinations For Leaf Peeping And Other Fall Adventure
author: Michael Pollick; Wealth Of Geeks
content:
All The Leaves Are Red, Yellow, and Orange - Top U.S. Destinations For Leaf Peeping And Other Fall Adventure

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Pollick; Wealth Of Geeks | Page: 4A | Section: News 
 
 950
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The pumpkin spice lattes are flowing, and post-Halloween pumpkins are getting chunked.But there's still interest in family road trips, especially to destinations where the annual changing of the leaves is at its peak.A study by lawn care specialist LawnStarter reveals the top states for leaf peeping and other fall-related activities. Beyond Oktoberfest and Halloween, many cities offer harvest festivals as local crops come into season. Others organize arts and crafts shows or music festivals, while local wineries debut their latest releases.The allure of fall foliage may put cars on the road, but the states on LawnStarter's shortlist have found creative ways to reward visitors for their interest.TOP FIVE STATES FOR VIEWING FALL FOLIAGECaliforniaCalifornia ranks at or near the top in virtually every metric used in the LawnStarter study. It has the most national parks, the most scenic drives, and the most Fall-related attractions. Outside of Sacramento, Apple Hill features over 50 local farms and a fall festival with apple cider donuts and u-pick pumpkin and apple venues. The Napa Valley is famous for its fall foliage, along with wine tastings and grape stomping adventures.New YorkOne measurement used in the LawnStarter study was the number of peak days for the leaf-watching season. New York ranked highest, with a total of 31 days of ideal leaf peeping available. New York is also home to the Finger Lakes, renowned for their cideries. Other points of interest include the Adirondacks and the Catskills for hiking and historical towns such as Sleepy Hollow for ghost chasing.WashingtonWashington State's mountainous and forested terrain offers adventurous foliage seekers over 12 weeks of peak viewing time. Besides a generous number of hiking trails and national parks, visitors to Washington State can also visit the alpinethemed village of Leavenworth for its Autumn Leaf Festival and enjoy adult beverages at local wineries.MichiganMichigan's extended foliage viewing season of 12 weeks makes it very appealing for Midwesterners who seek a more local destination than coastal states. Michigan also has a high number of cideries, ranking second overall in the Lawn-Starter study. A scenic drive north of Harbor Springs is known as the Tunnel of Trees and offers travelers breathtaking views of hardwood trees and their colorful leaves. The Pumpkin Train is another popular Fall-related attraction located in western Michigan.PennsylvaniaPennsylvania's abundance of undeveloped forests helps land it in the fifth position on the Lawn-Starter survey. The view of tree-covered hills and rolling pastures has enticed visitors for literally hundreds of years. The Pocono Mountains host the annual Jim Thorpe Fall Foliage Festival, a ghost tour, and a scenic train ride.THE BEST TIME TO GO LEAF PEEPINGWhile the first leaves may start to change as early as mid-September, the peak Fall foliage season doesn't generally arrive until the middle to late part of October, when air temperatures also begin to drop in many regions. The most colorful part of the transition is often over by Thanksgiving, as leaves fade to brown and trees become bare.Min Park, Ph.D., Academic Program Coordinator School of Sport, Recreation, and Tourism Management at George Mason University, says, "In general, fall foliage peaks in most parts of the nation in mid-October through mid-November.Some mountains in the northwest are often at their most colorful in mid-September to early October."As I live in Virginia, Virginia's Shenandoah National Park is one of the best for fall colors. The best time to experience gorgeous fall colors in Shenandoah National Park is in October. Visitors can make the scenic cruise along the 105-mile-long Skyline Drive, which offers 70 overlooks where travelers can hop out of the car for a better view of foliage with red, yellow, and orange leaves.".FALL FESTIVALS AND OTHER ATTRACTIONSEven if fall foliage is not at its peak or travel options are limited, there are still many Autumnal activities individuals and families can enjoy. In many areas of the country, the temperatures and climate are still favorable for camping, hiking, and attending outdoor festivals.Rosa Abreu, Assistant Professor, Hospitality Management, New York City College of Technology, offers her suggestions for a satisfying fall-related excursion. "Stay in a place that has a fire pit and roast marshmallows. Have a few drinks by the fire. Go glamping. Pumpkin and apple picking is always fun." Other fall-related festivals and destinations you might want to check out include: Morton Pumpkin Festival, Morton, Illinois The village of Morton, Illinois, produces almost all of the canned pumpkin products in the international market. The village considers itself to be the pumpkin capital of the world and celebrates annually with the Morton Pumpkin Festival in September.Salem, Massachusetts, Haunted ToursThe small coastal city of Salem, Massachusetts, has become a popular fall destination because of its association with the Salem witch trials. The city hosts several festivals throughout the fall season and guided tours of local landmarks.Vermont's Sugarhouses and Maple SyrupThe state of Vermont supplies over half of the country's maple syrup, and the fall months are the best time to watch the process unfold. Numerous sugarhouses in Vermont provide guided tours of their facilities, and guests also enjoy a taste of small-town New England life.World's Largest Corn Maze, Spring Grove, Illinois Corn mazes, hayrides, and harvest festivals are always popular destinations for families, and Richardson Farm in Spring Grove, Illinois, offers over 9 miles of hayride trails and mazes on its 28-acre cornfield.This article was produced by Media Decision and syndicated by Wealth of Geeks. 
 
 Caption: WIKIMEDIA COMMONS/FLEMMING CHRISTIANSEN
 
There are plenty of places locally, across Maryland as well as travel spots nationally to check out autumn leaves and fall events.
 
WIKIMEDIA COMMONS/LIZ WEST
 
New England is a popular destination to enjoy the sights of fall and the changing of the leaves 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Taylor-made - Vast repertoire ' across multiple musical genres: 'An Evening with Livingston Taylor' at the Avalon
content:
Taylor-made - Vast repertoire ' across multiple musical genres: 'An Evening with Livingston Taylor' at the Avalon

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3A | Section: News 
 
 262
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Livingston Taylor will bring his eclectic and formidable musical talents to the Avalon Theatre for a show on Saturday, Nov. 18, at 8 p.m.Taylor "vast repertoire" includes 22 albums and popular songs, according to a concert announcement from the Avalon. He is from the musical Taylor family and is the brother of James Taylor.Tickets to "An Evening with Livingston Taylor" at the Avalon are between $42 and $47 as well as $35 for ADA seats.Livingston Taylor has appeared and toured with the likes of Linda Ronstadt, Fleetwood Mac, Jethro Tull, Joni Mitchell and Jimmy Buffet."He's a natural performer, peppering his shows with personal stories, anecdotes and ineffable warmth that connect him to his fans.His relaxed on-stage presence belies the depth of his musical knowledge, and fans might just as often be treated to a classic Gershwin or a favorite from a Broadway musical," the Avalon's show announcement continued.Taylor's music delves into multiple genres including folk, pop, gospel and jazz.He taught for three decades at the Berklee College of Music in Boston and created a course on stage performance.Former students include John Mayer, Liz Longely, Gavin McGraw, Molly Tuttle, Charlie Puth and Susan Tedesci. Taylor continues to teach at other schools and college including the Frost School of Music at the University of Miami.He also has upcoming shows in New York, Virginia, Minnesota, Wisconsin and his home base of New England.For more information check out https://livingstontaylor.com/or https://www.avalonfoundation.org/event/livingston-taylor.

title: More Retro Rewinds
content:
More Retro Rewinds

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 16A | Section: News 
 
 234
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "All in the Family" (Catchy Comedy, Sunday, Nov. 19): The continuation of an all-weekend "Binge" split between this and another Norman Lear-produced comedy, "Good Times," includes a four-part story that pits Archie Bunker's (Carroll O'Connor) household against a foe that still is quite present in daily life inflation. Compounding that challenge is the strike that Archie's union calls, something he tries to keep from Edith (Jean Stapleton), unaware that she already knows about it."A Boy Named Charlie Brown" (MeTV, Sunday, Nov. 19): The animated specials based on Charles M. Schulz's perpetually popular comic strip "Peanuts" proved so popular, their makers decided to go the big-screen route with them as well, making this the first of the franchise's several feature films. The 1969 release finds hapless Charlie Brown (voiced by Peter Robbins, reprising the job he'd had since "A Charlie Brown Christmas") a contestant in the National Spelling Bee."Runaway Train" (MGM+ Hits, Wednesday, Nov. 22): Jon Voight gives an uncompromisingly gritty performance in director Andrei Konchalovsky's terrific 1985 thriller, which builds mightily upon the supposedly simple premise promised by the title. Voight and Eric Roberts (both Oscar-nominated here) play escaped convicts who hop aboard a locomotive, expecting a ride to freedom - but when circumstances send it out of control, they end up hurtling toward what could be their fate instead. Rebecca De Mornay also gets dirty, quite literally, as a railroad worker also trapped aboard the train. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Lacey Chabert and Scott Wolf reunite for 'A Merry Scottish Christmas'
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Lacey Chabert and Scott Wolf reunite for 'A Merry Scottish Christmas'

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 12A | Section: News 
 
 308
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The reunion is only for a party of two, but for fans of a certain show and a couple of its enduring stars, that's likely to be more than enough.Lacey Chabert and Scott Wolf played orphaned sister and brother Claudia and Bailey Salinger on the original, much-beloved version of the 1994-2000 drama series "Party of Five," and they're back together as siblings again - albeit relatives who have a much more strained relationship, at least initially - in "A Merry Scottish Christmas," a Hallmark Channel movie that debuts Saturday, Nov. 18.The actors play Lindsay and Brad, whose fractured relationship could be healed when they travel to Scotland to spend the holidays with their mother (played by Fiona Bell). Their discovery of an enormous family secret seems destined to unite all the parties or drive them farther apart but since this is Hallmark Channel, take a guess at which outcome prevails. The script is by "Dateline NBC" correspondent Andrea Canning, who has written a number of movies for both Hallmark Channel and Lifetime, and author Audrey Schulman ("The Dolphin House").Both Chabert and Wolf are familiar with the Hallmark brand of holiday tales, since both stars also have done them in the past. Wolf starred with Kristin Chenoweth in the 2019 film "A Christmas Love Story," and Chabert is unquestionably one of the queens of such projects, having made at least one annually for a number of years.Among her seasonal Hallmark stories have been "A Royal Christmas" (2014), "A Christmas Melody" (2015), "A Wish for Christmas" (2016), "The Sweetest Christmas" (2017), "Pride, Prejudice and Mistletoe" (2018), "Christmas in Rome" (2019), "Christmas Waltz" (2020), "Christmas at Castle Hart" (2021) and "Haul Out the Holly" (2022). (The latter movie has a new sequel, the Chabert-starring "Haul Out the Holly: Lit Up," which Hallmark Channel will debut Nov. 25.) 
 
 Caption: Lacey Chabert stars in "A Merry Scottish Christmas"

celebrityupdate

 Q: I've seen a lot of Elvis Presley movies on television lately. Which were the first and last ones he madeftA: The first was "Love Me Tender" (1956), which actually was renamed from the original "The Reno Brothers" to coordinate with the title song, a giant hit for Presley that he performed in the film. He played one of the Reno siblings during the Civil War, youngest brother Clint, who tended to the homefront while his brothers fought in the battle. Top-billed Richard Egan portrayed the oldest brother, while the role of another Reno was filled by James Drury, later to become "The Virginian" on weekly TV.Presley's final film as an actor was "Change of Habit" (1969), casting him as an inner-city doctor who became enamored of a colleague - unaware that she was a nun working incognito.The picture's leading lady was Mary Tyler Moore, in the last movie she made under a contract with Universal Pictures.Interestingly, another co-star (as a cop) was Edward Asner, a year before he and Moore began their legendary TV work together on "The Mary Tyler Moore Show" he also had worked earlier with Presley in "Kid Galahad" (1962).If it's Presley's last movie overall that you're looking for, though, that would be the concert attraction "Elvis on Tour" (1972) - which earned its year's Golden Globe Award for best documentary film.Hampton Roads and Richmond in Virginia were among the stops featured, as were Jacksonville, Fla., and San Antonio, Texas. After that, what turned out to be the superstar's career-concluding performances were in a couple of TV specials, "Elvis: Aloha From Hawaii" (1973) and "Elvis in Concert" (1977). 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Life and death in the Midwest: Hamm, Temple join 'Fargo' for fifth season
author: Dana Simpson
content:
Life and death in the Midwest: Hamm, Temple join 'Fargo' for fifth season

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Dana Simpson | Page: 9A | Section: News 
 
 440
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As anyone living in or visiting Alberta this past October can testify, the province is a great place to film a snowy series. And while the cast and crew of "Fargo" had long since finished filming by the time Calgary received its most recent unseasonable dumping of snow, TV audiences are just now about to witness the magic (and crime - lots of crime) for themselves. Season 5 of "Fargo" begins Tuesday, Nov. 21, with back-to-back episodes on FX. Episodes are available to stream the following day on Hulu.Despite filming in Canada, the current season of the series created by Noah Hawley ("Legion") is set primarily in North Dakota (as indicated by its title). Expected to run for 10 episodes, "Fargo's" fifth season is set in 2019, making it the series' most recent timeframe to date. (For those interested, seasons 1 through 4 take place in 2006, 1979, 2010 and 1950, respectively.)Those unfamiliar with "Fargo" may not know that the critically acclaimed series is based on the 1996 film of the same name by the Coen Brothers ("Blood Simple," 1984), which starred William H. Macy ("Shameless") and Steve Buscemi ("Boardwalk Empire") alongside Frances McDormand ("Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri," 2017) in her Academy Award-winning role as police officer Marge Gunderson. Like the film, FX's "Fargo" is a black comedy, but rather than follow the same storyline as the film, the series opted to present its content as an anthology, jumping through timelines and to various locations in order to tell a series of related tales, each as unsettling - yet somehow inviting - as the next.Season 5 stars Juno Temple ("Ted Lasso") as Dorothy (Dot) Lyon, a Minnesota-based housewife who appears to lead a normal, happy lifestyle. But, when Dot ends up getting into trouble with the local authorities, her past comes back to haunt her - a past that is much more sinister than anyone would have expected from this average midwestern woman. As she tries to sort out the best course of action, Dot is pursued by North Dakota Sheriff Roy Tillman (Jon Hamm, "Mad Men"), Deputy Witt Farr (Lamorne Morris, "New Girl") and a mysterious man named Ole Munch (Sam Spruell, "The Martian," 2015).Jennifer Jason Leigh ("The Woman in the Window," 2021) joins the main cast as Dot's well-off mother-in-law, while "Stranger Things'" Joe Keery and "Never Have I Ever's" Richa Moorjani step into the roles of the sheriff's son, Gator Tillman, and Deputy Indira Olmstead, respectively.Meanwhile, David Rysdahl ("Oppenheimer," 2023), Jessica Pohly ("Stalker"), Nick Gomez ("She-Hulk: Attorney at Law"), Lukas Gage ("The White Lotus") and Dave Foley ("The Kids in the Hall") star in recurring roles throughout the newest season.

title: The finesse was avoidable after all - Bridge
author: Phillip Alder
content:
The finesse was avoidable after all - Bridge

 November 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 20 | Section: News 
 
 256
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Here are a couple of signs spotted in Canada. In Vancouver, "For your added convenience, this Post Office will be closed on Saturdays." And on Highway 11 in Ontario, "You are now halfWay to the North Pole." That reminds me of the famous two-liner:"Do you know the way to Town X?""Yes, but you can't get there from here."Today's deal was played in a Canadian event, and South showed that he could circumnavigate the apparently unavoidable diamond finesse.After a takeout double of a preemptive opening bid, the advancer - -as the doubler's partner is called - is assumed to hold 6 points. He makes a simple response unless holding noticeably more than that. However, after North cue-bid to show a very strong hand with spade support, South was happy to control-bid his top heart card. North needed no more encouragement.Maybe West should have led a diamond, which would have killed the contract. However, he led his singleton, optimistically hoping his partner had the heart ace.After East allowed dummy's heart 10 to win the first trick, declarer cashed the spade king (hoping West had a singleton honor) and followed with a trump to his ace, getting the bad news.South continued with a heart to dummy's ace, ran the heart jack, played a heart to his nine and cashed dummy's top clubs, eliminating the rounded suits. With his preparations complete, declarer cast adrift with a trump. East won with the queen and had to lead a diamond away from his king into dummy's ace-queen tenace.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Bridge - Up or down, win or lose?
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Up or down, win or lose?

 November 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 256
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Bridge is full of guidelines - or rules of thumb, if you prefer. However, as the English author Robert Burton wrote in "The Anatomy of Melancholy," "No rule is so general, which admits not some exception." Which is the exception in today's deal? South plays in three no-trump, and West leads a low spade. How many tricks should declarer win?South is right to open two no-trump despite the low tripleton in diamonds. He has a balanced hand with 21 points; no other sequence would describe this so accurately.Declarer saw that he had seven top tricks. He needed two more from the diamond suit. So, after winning the first trick with his spade king, South led a diamond and finessed dummy's 10.East won with the queen and returned a spade to South's ace. Declarer led a second diamond, capturing West's king with dummy's ace. A moment later South was claiming 10 tricks: two spades, one heart, four diamonds and three clubs."Why didn't you play the diamond king at trick two?" asked East."Because my textbook says second hand low," replied West."Yes, that is right most of the time," observed East."However, here, with South trying to establish dummy's suit, you must disobey the rule. If you play the diamond king, dummy's suit is dead and we can defeat the contract." "But what if South has the diamond queen?" asked West."Then your king is dead anyway," explained East.Watch out for the suitkilling second hand high. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses strategies and rules for playing the card game bridge, which fits best under Entertainment rather than physical sports or other categories.

title: Bridge - Back and forth to victory
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Back and forth to victory

 November 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5A | Section: News 
 
 266
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Tennis players hit the ball back and forth across the net until someone misses.There is a similar situation in bridge, highlighted by today's deal.After West's takeout double, North's jump raise to three spades was preemptive, showing a weak hand with, presumably, four trumps.(With the same hand and a fifth trump, North would have bid four spades.) When holding 10 or more points and good trump support, North would have responded with a conventional two notrump.South, with only six losers, took a shot at game.West led the heart king.When the dummy appeared, South saw that the layout was ideal for a crossruff. To lay the foundation, after winning with the heart ace, declarer immediately conceded a diamond trick.The defenders did the best they could, cashing two heart tricks before switching to a trump, but it was to no avail.South won in the dummy, ruffed a diamond in hand, cashed the club ace and crossruffed home.If the declarer is planning a crossruff, clearly the defenders should lead as many rounds of trumps as possible. Suppose West leads a trump at trick one here.Can the contract still be madeftNot against best defense.South wins the first trick in the dummy and calls for a low diamond, but East steps in with the king and leads a second trump.Although it didn't apply in this deal, watch out for one other technique when planning a crossruff. You should cash all of your sidesuit tricks first. If you don't, an opponent might ruff one of those winners late in the play. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Holiday House Tour to feature one of area's most famous homes
author: Contributed
content:
Holiday House Tour to feature one of area's most famous homes

 Folks are eagerly awaiting the arrival of the 38th annual Festival of Trees, taking place Nov. 25 through 28 in Easton.The seasonal favorite includes events such as the Festival of Trees, Carols by Candlelight, Santa 5K Fun Run, Santa's Workshop, and a Holiday House Tour.Proceeds from Festival of Trees, presented by Friends of Hospice, benefits Talbot Hospice.The Holiday House Tour is generating a lot of interest this year, according to organizers, as it features the square-top mansard roofed home known as Mulberry Manor, located at 29790 Matthewstown Road in Easton.The home, completed in September of 1872, will be elegantly decorated for the season and will feature 10 decorated Christmas trees and two main fireplaces. The owner, Randy Decker, has some festive plans in store that are perfect for families getting into the spirit of Christmas.In addition to touring the home's decorated downstairs, guests will depart through the kitchen, where fresh baked holiday cookies will be offered before the next part of the tour begins outdoors.The side yard will be festooned with countless Christmas inflatables that are perfect for fun holiday photo opportunities.Santa will be happy to pose for photos as well, as he is visiting the home tour.Unlike many traditional home tours, Decker wanted this tour to be fun for families of all ages.The home is well known in the area. A traveler's landmark, it indicated to beachgoers that they were halfway to the beach.It stood for many generations along Route 50 before it was meticulously transported over a mile through fields to its current location in 2009. It was even televised on Maryland Public Television.The house has been and continues to be many Plein Air artists' favorite subject when the renowned outdoor art festival is hosted here in Easton.Decker is holding the Home Tour in Memory of Ed Johnson.Tours will be available from noon to 8 p.m. on Nov. 25 and from noon to 5 p.m. on Nov. 26. Tickets are $20 in advance at festival-of-trees.org and $25 on site the day of.

title: Bridge - It turns out to be a woman's world
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - It turns out to be a woman's world

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 265
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We all know the expression about not sending a boy to do a man's job. But is it possible to send a boy to do a woman's job? Of course it is!The bidding in today's deal was impressive, if slightly complex. South's two hearts was a transfer bid. When South continued with three diamonds, his second suit, North bid three hearts to show length and strength in that suit. After South rebid his six-card suit, North control-bid the heart ace.Finally, when South showed his first-round club control, North used the Grand Slam Force, asking partner to bid seven diamonds with two of the top three trump honors.South ruffed the club-king lead and cashed the diamond ace, getting the bad news.Now it was a matter of establishing his spades, in case they were dividing 4-2, and without losing trump control. Declarer unblocked dummy's top spades, ruffed a club to get back to hand and led the spade six. When West discarded, South wondered if it was safe to ruff with the boy: dummy's diamond six. But if he had, he would have fallen to defeat. After cashing dummy's diamond queen, South would have had to ruff a club to return to hand, leaving himself with only one trump to East's two.Instead, South ruffed the third spade with dummy's diamond queen. Then he led a low trump to his nine, drew the remaining trumps and claimed.Not bad to bid and make a grand slam with only a combined 26 high-card points. Still, a well-placed void may make a mockery of point-count.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bridge - A economy of spot cards
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - A economy of spot cards

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 9A | Section: News 
 
 263
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I wish all of my American readers a very happy Thanksgiving. When we are enjoying our Thanksgiving feast, we do not worry too much about the calories being consumed.Sometimes, when playing in a bridge contract, you have to be economical with your cards. In today's deal, the declarer had to be particularly careful with his handling of the trump suit.Despite having only 5 highcard points, North's hand, with four trumps and a doubleton, was well worth a single raise.After winning the first trick with the heart ace, South saw that he had two logical lines of play. He could cash the spade ace, hoping to drop a singleton king, or he could play for East to hold the club king. The former chance being only 26% (a third of the 78% probability of a 2-1 trump split), the declarer opted for the 50-50 finesse.So, at trick two, South led the spade jack from his hand. (This had a secondary advantage: West, afraid his partner held the singleton trump ace, might have ducked his king.) No luck this time, though. West won with the king, cashed his two heart tricks and switched to a diamond.South won with his ace and led the spade seven to dummy's queen. After the club finesse had worked, South played the club three to his ace. Now came the spade three to dummy's five.The club jack was covered and ruffed. Finally, South led his carefully preserved spade four to dummy's six and cashed the club 10, discarding his diamond loser.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

 Q: I know I've seen Morgan Kohan of "Sullivan's Crossing" in some cable movies. Where did she get her start?A: The British Columbia native started out studying dancing as her principal path in show business, but her main attention shifted to acting when she was accepted at Toronto's Randolph Academy. She began doing guest roles on such series as "Murdoch Mysteries" and "Star Trek: Discovery," then continued with appearances on shows including "When Calls the Heart" and "The Bold Type." Around the time of the later guest shots, Kohan also started getting prominent parts in cable movies on the order of "The Black Widow Killer" (2018) and "Love on Harbor Island" (2020). The fact that those have been repeated often didn't hurt her chances to land the lead in "Sullivan's Crossing," Among other movies that have featured Kohan are "A Romance Wedding" (2021) and "A Whirlwind Wedding" (2021), and she also was seen on the shows "Batwoman," "Transplant" and "When Hope Calls." Inspired by novels by Robyn Carr, "Sullivan's Crossing" (which already has been renewed for a second season) originated on Canada's CTV network, and its inclusion of two veterans of The CW in its regular cast - Chad Michael Murray ("One Tree Hill") and Scott Patterson ("Gilmore Girls") - likely got the latter outlet interested in picking up the series for the American market, especially when production delays linked to the entertainment-industry strikes made finding product from other sources a necessity.

title: Rockefeller Center and Graceland host a holiday night for NBC
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Rockefeller Center and Graceland host a holiday night for NBC

 November 23, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 12 | Section: News 
 
 461
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Following the network's annual telecast of the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, one night in two iconic locations will help NBC - and viewers - dive deeper into the holiday season.Wednesday, Nov. 29, will see an annual special mark a major milestone, and it will be followed for the first time by a celebration from another legendary site both shown live in the Eastern half of the U.S. (and also streamed on Peacock). First, the 91st "Christmas in Rockefeller Center" will maintain the yearly tradition of the lighting of the giant tree in midtown Manhattan, though that obviously wasn't broadcast in its early years (it started as a local offering for the New York market before the full NBC network began showing it). Then, the first "Christmas at Graceland" special will showcase the Memphis, Tenn., estate that famously was the home of entertainment legend Elvis Presley.Kelly Clarkson (who's now doing her syndicated weekday talk show from "30 Rock") will host and perform on "Christmas in Rockefeller Center," and it's a given that Radio City Music Hall's famed Rockettes will show their high-kicking stuff, while various other music stars - including icons Cher and Barry Manilow - put their own spins on famed yuletide songs.Members of NBC's "Today" broadcast team typically are featured on the special, and Savannah Guthrie, Hoda Kotb, Al Roker and Craig Melvin are expected to be on hand for the two-hour show's ultimate highlight: the flipping of the switch that illuminates the giant holiday tree (which comes from Vestal, N.Y., this time) that's a "must" destination for countless tourists during the season. After that, the tree will be lit daily until Jan. 13.Actress Riley Keough ("The Girlfriend Experience"), one of' Elvis' granddaughters and now the sole owner of Graceland - following the passing of her mother, Lisa Marie Presley, last January - is among the executive producers of "Christmas at Graceland." Its lineup of performers also hadn't been confirmed at press time, but it's certain that the song list will include tunes associated with Elvis, "Blue Christmas" surely being among them. In fact, "Elvis' Christmas Album" and "Elvis Sings The Wonderful World of Christmas" were among his musical releases, so there are a good number of seasonal numbers that he lent his touch to."Christmas at Graceland" is being staged with Elvis in mind, and don't be surprised if it integrates clips from a famous telecast that he did himself: his so-called 1968 "Comeback Special," which aired in December of that year. That program had been intended as a Christmas attraction, but it ultimately was broadened out to cover the full scope of Presley's music career. However, it did include "Blue Christmas," and that would seem like a prime clip to be excerpted by "Christmas at Graceland." 
 
 Caption: Kelly Clarkson is hosting NBC's annual "Christmas in Rockefeller Center" 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes NBC's holiday television specials, performances by music stars, and the lighting ceremony—content focused on TV entertainment and popular culture rather than sports, business, or other categories.

title: Mr. Magoo goes full Scrooge for Christmas
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Mr. Magoo goes full Scrooge for Christmas

 November 23, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 16 | Section: News

 Words

 Charles Dickens' classic seasonal story has gotten many screen workouts, but one of the most unique is the animated special "Mr, Magoo's Christmas Carol," which Peacock is streaming during the holiday season. Originally televised in 1962, this variation of the tale casts the famously near-sighted Magoo (voiced by Jim Backus, of "Gilligan's Island" fame) as legendary miser Ebenezer Scrooge and to its credit, the script stays pretty faithful to the Dickens original while also allowing Scrooge to adopt Magoo's quirks.Morey Amsterdam and Jack Cassidy also are in the voice cast. and the original songs are by Jule Styne and Bob Merrill, whose Broadway credits included "Funny Girl." Be forewarned that despite Magoo's amusing demeanor, some of the moments here give heartstrings a forceful yank; we point specifically to Tiny Tim (voice of Joan Gardner) singing "Alone in the World," which it might help to make an advance buyout of a whole tissue factory for.

title: Revisiting 'Australia': Film gets a revamp in new series 'Faraway Downs'
author: Sarah Passingham
content:
Revisiting 'Australia': Film gets a revamp in new series 'Faraway Downs'

 November 23, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sarah Passingham | Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 634
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We all roll our failures over in our minds from time to time, so it would make sense that even blockbuster film directors are no different. In cultural memory, the 2008 epic drama "Australia" has remained a dim corner in director Baz Luhrmann's spectacular filmography, which includes massive hits such as "Romeo + Juliet" (1996) and "Elvis" (2022). Luhrmann went back to the drawing board to give "Australia" a second chance and came away with the new miniseries "Faraway Downs," premiering Sunday, Nov. 26, on Hulu.Using additional footage cut from the original movie, "Faraway Downs" spans four hours, split into six episodes, adding new layers to the story told in "Australia." The series, like the film, stars Nicole Kidman ("Special Ops: Lioness") as Lady Sarah Ashley, a British widow who inherits her late husband's sprawling cattle station, called Faraway Downs, on the cusp of the Second World War in 1939. Having made the trip to Australia to convince her husband to sell the property before he died, Lady Sarah has a man known simply as The Drover (Hugh Jackman "The Son," 2022) lead the cattle to Darwin for sale.The pair lead a team and the cattle on a risky adventure across the outback and manage to thwart a rival rancher looking to achieve a meat monopoly in the region of Northern Australia. Lady Sarah and Drover find love on their trip to Darwin and return to Faraway Downs intent on making the station the success that her late husband couldn't.Trouble comes for them when the well-being of Nullah (Brandon Walters, "Operation Buffalo"), the Indigenous Australian boy that the two have been caring for like an adoptive son, is threatened and acts of war loom over Northern Australia.When the reworked miniseries was announced in June 2022, Luhrmann shared in a statement the intent behind both the original film and "Faraway Downs," saying, "I originally set out to take the notion of the sweeping, 'Gone With the Wind'-style epic and turn it on its head - a way of using romance and epic drama to shine a light on the roles of First Nations people and the painful scar in Australian history of the 'Stolen Generations.'" In the film, Nullah is left orphaned after his mother dies trying to evade police, who are attempting to forcibly separate him from his family.The Stolen Generations of mixed-race Indigenous children were removed from their homes to live in church-run missions throughout the latter half of the 19th and into the 20th century, as late as the 1970s in some parts of Australia.Luhrmann added in his statement: "While 'Australia' the film has its own life, there was another telling of this story; one with different layers, nuances and even alternative plot twists that an episodic format has allowed us to explore." Luhrmann alludes quite clearly to what "Faraway Downs" will expand on with its longer runtime and segmented installments. More depth will be paid to Indigenous history in the series and Luhrmann's original ending, cut in favor of a happier final act in "Australia," will finally be seen by audiences.The first episode of "Faraway Downs" screened at SXSW Sydney Screen Festival in October, and The Guardian reported that the soundtrack was "given a contemporary First Nations overhaul," including a song from Budjerah ("Ready for the Sky"), whose music plays over an opening credits sequence animated by Indigenous artists."Faraway Downs" also stars Bryan Brown ("Darby and Joan") as Lesley (King) Carney, a rival cattle farmer; David Wenham ("Pieces of Her") as Neil Fletcher, the station manager at Faraway Downs who is secretly working with King Carney; Jack Thompson ("High Ground," 2020) as Kipling Flynn, accountant of Faraway Downs; David Gulpilil ("The Leftovers") as King George, an elder and Nullah's grandfather; and David Ngoombujarra ("The Circuit") as Magarri, Drover's brotherin-law. 
 
 Caption: Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman in "Faraway Downs" 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the revamp of the film 'Australia' into a new miniseries, focusing on production details, cast, and release, which aligns most closely with entertainment news.

title: Future of Movie Theaters - How cinemas are navigating all the upheavals hitting Hollywood
author: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor
content:
Future of Movie Theaters - How cinemas are navigating all the upheavals hitting Hollywood

 November 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1768
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The movie business has gone through some blockbuster and generational sea changes in recent years with the streaming revolution, the shutdowns of the coronavirus pandemic and ensuing 40-year highs with inflation and this year's Hollywood writers' and actors' strikes.All those upheavals in Hollywood have also been impacting movie theaters - from large chains with suburban cineplexes to hometown operators and historic venues that are often nostalgic downtown centerpieces in America's small towns.Owning and running a movie theater is not an easy business even in the best of the times.It's even tougher in the worst and most challenging times.COVID and its shutdowns prompted an 83% drop in ticket sales and box office revenue from 2019 to 2020, according to Nash Information Services LLC.Ticket sales and box offices have bounced back this year - led by strong showings by "Barbie", "Oppenheimer" and "The Super Mario Bros Movie". They are up from the depths of the pandemic and 26% from 2022.With about six weeks to go in the year, 2023 box offices and ticket sales are off 28% from pre-COVID business in 2019.Three women operating smaller movie theater businesses in Montana face very similar challenges and have very similar resilient love and passion for their tiny slice of "show business."A LABOR OF LOVESue and Larry Schilling bought the Choteau Roxy Theatre in 1988.The theater is in Choteau, Montana, just under an hour's drive from the next closest cineplex in Great Falls, and 90 minutes from the Canadian border.The Roxy was built in 1945 and first opened in 1946 with its first show on July 4. The Schillings added a stage several years ago to host other performances."We've had several plays and several live performances," said Susan Schilling.She said that has included local musical performances and events for community groups and nonprofits.The husband and wife team added digital projection equipment and new surround sound systems in 2013 and 2014.FAMILY FRIENDLYSchilling said the theater shows top 10 movies on their first runs just like its larger cohorts. She said the theater operates in a small town activities and sports kind of dig into (movie) attendance," she said.CHANGING EXPECTATIONSSmaller theaters also have less space and ability to expand concessions, restrooms and other amenities seen at larger cineplexes in the suburbs and urban areas with as many 24 screens, multiple concession stands, party rooms and ample restrooms.The Roxy has a small lobby and "only two bathrooms", Schilling said. She said the movie going experience and moviegoers expectations have changed."It wasn't about the experience, about eating popcorn," she said.But now, theaters face competition from other entertainment options as well as watching movies at home on big screen televisions and on streaming services.There are significantly more sports, especially football, on multiple days, competing for eyeballs."It's got to be better than sitting in their living room," Schilling said.This summer's slate of movies led by "Barbie", "Oppenheimer" and the latest installment in Tom Cruise's "Mission Impossible" franchise helped propel a strong movie season."Barbie" and "Oppenheimer" had worldwide box offices of $1.45 billion and $949 million, respectively, while "The Super Mario Bros. Movies" brought home $1.36 billion, according to IMDB, which tracks the movies industry."We built our own Barbie Box. We kind of hyped it up," Schilling said. "People want a good experience." The "Barbenheimer" summer phenomena helped remind people of the joys of going to the movies after the shutdowns of the coronavirus pandemic and waves of superhero franchise movies turned off some moviegoers."They had a different attitude when they walked in the door. People are really happy to be here," Schilling said.Movie chains and smaller operators have also had to grapple with four-decade highs with inflation after all the monetary and fiscal infusions undertaken in the U.S. and worldwide during the COVID pandemic.Many U.S. households are still feeling the pinch of high grocery prices, housing costs, car payments and health care outlays along with higher interest rates from the Federal Reserve aimed at lowering inflation.In Choteau, the Roxy's ticket prices are $8 for adults, $6.50 for kids and seniors with $7 for large popcorn."We stay very economical," Schilling said.TIME TO SELLThe 35 years owning the Montana theater has been a labor love but the Schillings, who had full-time jobs while operating the Roxy.But now the couple wants to spend more time with their grandchildren who don't live close by."We have grandchildren we want to go spend time with," Schilling said.The couple has listed the 4,800-square-foot theater for sale with an asking price of $284,000.Phyllis Bechtold, a local realtor and owner of Buy N Sell Montana, said property, with its vintage look and signage, is also an important part of the small town community.Schilling agrees."People are very appreciative that we are still operational," she said.BY THE NUMBERSMovie theaters and cineplexes employ 155,000 workers nationally, according to a March 2023 report by the Cinema Foundation.There were 38,474 indoor movie screens operating in the U.S. at the end of 2022, according to the National Association of Theater Owners. That's 5% fewer than 2019 before COVID.More than 48% of those screens are operated by the three largest cineplex chains - Kansas-based AMC Entertainment Inc., Knoxville, Tennessee-based Regal Cinemas and Dallas-based Cinemark USA Inc., according to the theater owners' group.But there are also plenty of smaller and regional operators across the country.NEW REVENUE STREAMSBecky Dupuis is a principal with Polson Theatres - a smaller chain with screen and properties in Montana and Idaho.Dupuis and Candis Harrop, CFO of the regional operator, said they have started renting out theaters more for special events - including gaming, birthday parties, baby and wedding showers - to generate more revenue.Parties, showers and other private gatherings include a private showing of movies."We've seen a big increase in people interested in private showings," Dupuis said.She said private showing interest started during and right after the pandemic but has continued. "It kind of surprised us," Dupuis said."We just had a 50th birthday party." They said they charge $200 for the first hour and $50 for each additional hour or a flat $150 to $250 rate depending on the time of the event. Harrop said the trend has made the Montana chain think about other revenue generating options and how some people forgot the enjoyment and American cultural experience of 'going to the movies.' "It's been kind of eye opening for us," she said, of the private showings and special events. "Those kinds of things have really helped." Other theaters across the country have also looked to private events - including ones hosted by businesses and nonprofits - and special showings of concerts, operas, old movies and pay-per-view MMA and other fights.But Dupuis and Harrop said theaters, especially smaller ones with limited screens, waivers from movie studios and distribution networks if they supplant films already running at their properties.That's why special showings or private events are often in the mornings before regular movie times.Polson Theatres has 22 screens in 8 locations in Montana and Idaho, including theaters that first opened in 1914 and 1911. They are located in small, rural towns such as Dillon, Havre, Wolf Point and Lewistown, Montana and Salmon, Idaho.They have populations ranging from 2,600 to 6,000 people."Most of our theaters are twins," Dupuis said of the scheduling challenges that can arise from trying to book events and still abiding by studios' contracts with cinemas.'BIG CONCERN'While the writers' and actors' strikes have been settled with studios, the work stoppages are poised to offer some short-term challenges to theaters next year.Some movies have had their release dates moved forward because of the labor disputes - including the next installments of "Dune" and "Mission Impossible." "It's a big concern," Harrop said.Theaters have already seen the exponential growth of streaming services such as Netflix, Disney/Hulu, Apple TV and Amazon take movie and other productions from traditional venues.Movie theater operators - especially in small towns - have also seen their lineup of films dominated by superhero franchises. Those might appeal to younger demographics and families but not necessarily older audiences."We have a very large older population," Dupuis said.Though the Montana movie theater operators see potential in Christian and other faith-based films pointing to the success of "Sound of Freedom" earlier this year.Other theaters in states with larger Indian and South Asian populations have also shown 'Bollywood' films' to attract other office segments.'THAT's NOT NICE'Like other theaters - large and small, the Polson chain has felt consumer pressure to offer more food and drink options."We've never done anything but candy and popcorn," Dupuis said.But now they are offering Italian sodas, nachos and pretzels. That's still a way from the bigger national chains who offer sandwiches, pizzas, burgers and alcoholic beverages.Movie tickets at the Polson theaters are $9.25 for regular showings, $6.25 for matinees and $5 on Tuesdays.Keeping prices down for consumers is key with inflation coming off 40-year highs and many Americans living 'paycheck-to-paycheck' with high costs for housing, health care and car payments."We don't want to raise our prices," Dupuis said.But she also said theaters are getting hit hard with higher costs - especially for repairs and replacing equipment as well as the costs of doing any kind of upgrades to their properties."It's killing us," she said, pointing to some technology-related repairs and upgrades that are 30% higher than pre-COVID inflation wave levels."That's not nice," Dupuis said.'HERE TO STAY'Despite all the changes, the three Montana women at the two movie theater operations are optimistic the American cultural experience of 'going to the movies' won't disappear even with younger demographics glued to their phones."The movie theater industry has gone through a lot of ups and downs - but it has never shut down," Harrop said. "We made it through COVID. People love the movies and they can't replicate the popcorn. I think it's here to stay."

The Choteau Roxy Theatre is located in a small town in Montana. Its current owners have owned the cinema for more than three decades.

title: Bridge - Top or bottom, take your pick
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Top or bottom, take your pick

 November 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 251
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Mark Twain was barred from meteorological school when he said, "Probable nor'east to sou'west winds, varying to the southard and westard and eastard and points between; high and low barometer, sweeping round from place to place; probable areas of rain, snow, hail and drought, succeeded or preceded by earthquakes with thunder and lightning." Which two of those words apply in today's deal? How should South weather the storm brewing in four hearts against the lead of the spade queen?When the dummy appeared, South saw that he could afford two trump losers, but not three. After winning trick one in hand with the spade king and cashing the heart ace, he could continue with a low heart or with the heart jack (or 10).Either would work if the suit was dividing 3-3, but if the opposing hearts were 4-2, declarer realized that he had to find either East or West with honordoubleton.So, at trick three, declarer continued with a low heart. When West had to win with the king, declarer smiled inwardly to himself.South won West's spade continuation in the dummy, cashed the diamond ace, ruffed a diamond in hand and drove out East's heart queen. Declarer ruffed the next spade, drew East's last trump and forced out the club ace. He had one trump left with which to ruff the fourth round of spades - all he needed.When you can play high or low, consider both carefully. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bridge - Negative inference better that positive
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Negative inference better that positive

 November 28, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 273
 Words 

 Read News Document

 By Phillip Alder Despite Sir Isaiah Berlin's claim that men live by positive goals, there are times when bridge-playing men - and women, of course - have to live by negative goals.You learn something critical because of a bid or play that an opponent didn't make.Drawing these negative inferences is one of the arts of the game.The bidding in today's deal was tricky. Ideally, North-South would reach three no-trump, but that is easier said than done - unless you employ a modern gadget.On the first round, South makes a jump cue bid of three hearts. This shows eight or nine guaranteed tricks, usually with a long, solid minor, and asks North to bid three no-trump with a heart stopper. However, without this string to your bow, suppose you wind up in five diamonds.After winning trick one with the spade ace, you draw trumps. Then you lead a low heart from hand. When West puts in the eight, which card should you play from the dummy?Given that West has at least five hearts and opening-bid values, it looks best, at first glance, to put up the queen, playing West for the heart ace and king, but think back to the opening lead. If you were West, holding the spade K-Q and heart A-K, which card would you select? Right, the heart king (or ace).Therefore, because West didn't lead a heart, surely East has a singleton heart honor. Duck in the dummy and East's king or ace will fall on low cards. A moment later, you will lead toward the heart queen again and make your contract. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bridge - Try to reduce your assets
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Try to reduce your assets

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 265
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Mark Twain, or Samuel Langhorne Clemens if you prefer, had the right idea when he wrote, "Tell the truth or trump - but get the trick." Sometimes, though, strange as it sounds, you might have too many trumps. If so, you must do something to reduce the number. Today's deal features one such play technique.Against four spades, West led the club ace. When East signaled with the 10, West continued with the club king and a third club. East exited with the spade three: two, eight, king. How should South have continued?South's three-spade rebid was invitational. North, with the two top trump honors, had an automatic raise to game.With all of the side suits safe, declarer's only concern was the trump suit. If that was breaking 3-2, he would have no trouble, but what if East had started with four spades including the jack?(If West had jack-fourth, the contract was beyond resuscitation.) The only chance would be a trump coup. To reduce his trump length to the same as East's, South made the farsighted play of immediately cashing dummy's heart ace and ruffing a heart in his hand.After declarer had played a trump to dummy's ace, getting the bad news, he ruffed another heart in his hand. Then South cashed his three diamond tricks, ending in the dummy. Luckily, East had to follow suit throughout.South was left with the Q-10 in spades, and East had the J-5. When South called for a heart, East's apparent trump trick disappeared in a textbook trump coup.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Christmas confections: 'Elf on the Shelf' comes to life in new baking competition
author: Caroline Collacutt
content:
Christmas confections: 'Elf on the Shelf' comes to life in new baking competition

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Caroline Collacutt | Page: D14 | Section: News 
 
 422
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There are all sorts of elves, but only some are talented enough to make cookies for Santa. This allnew series puts confectioners to the test, as "The Elf on the Shelf: Sweet Showdown" continues with new episodes, airing Sundays on Food Network.Hosted by Duff Goldman ("Holiday Baking Championship"), this five-episode, Christmas-themed series boasts chef Kardea Brown ("Delicious Miss Brown") and pastry chef Ashley Holt ("Bake Squad") as judges, rounding out a team of Christmas-loving cooks."Santa and his loyal Scout Elves, along with the help of legendary cake master Duff Goldman, will challenge six teams of sweetmakers in a competition full of surprises. Each week, the teams must create edible showpieces that bring the holiday season to life," a recent news release from Food Network describes - and with two challenges per episode, the season has already produced some crazy confectionary creations.So far, teams have adopted their own Scout Elves, created personalized and edible shelves for them to enjoy, crafted show-stopping, snow globe showpieces, prepared for "elfie selfies" and tirelessly sewed the sugared seams of some runway-ready elffits - and the season's just begun.Descriptions given by the network share that upcoming episodes will see more Christmas chaos, with a synopsis for the season's third episode describing: "the Scout Elves want to play the 12 Days of Christmas at their elf concert tonight, but they accidentally mixed up all the lyrics! Host Duff Goldman tasks the remaining teams with figuring out their jumbled lyrical prompts and delivering a twisted-up 12 Days of Elfmas showpiece."During the fourth, "host Duff Goldman revs up the teams as they create an edible sleigh design that will wow Santa and show off their magical skills. Then, two teams go head-to-head in the Santa Showdown by creating inventive snow forts."Finally, the remaining three teams will square off in a super-sized season finale, just before the Scout Elves head back to the North Pole to help Santa prepare for his big night. The flight home is long and cold, but the Elves fly over some of their favorite places on Earth in the meantime, and the remaining bakers pay homage by "elf-ify"-ing a famous landmark in their honor.After the final round of eliminations, one team - and their very special elf - will earn the ultimate Christmas gift: $25,000 and the title of The Ambassadors of Confectionery Concoctions.Sugary sweet and full of Christmas magic, "The Elf on the Shelf: Sweet Showdown" airs an all-new episode Sunday, Dec. 3, on Food Network.

title: 'It's the holiday season' - Spend this Christmas with Paddington, Melissa McCarthy, Lori Loughlin, Denise Richards and more
author: Alicia Rancilio
content:
'It's the holiday season' - Spend this Christmas with Paddington, Melissa McCarthy, Lori Loughlin, Denise Richards and more

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Alicia Rancilio | Page: D6 | Section: News 
 
 1435
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Festive TV programming is starting to stack up like toys in Santa's sleigh.Holiday favorites like "A Charlie Brown Christmas" and "A Christmas Story" will soon return, along with new family friendly films including "Dashing Through the Snow" on Disney+ and Melissa McCarthy's "Genie" on Peacock.There's music to enjoy too, with Hannah Waddingham leading an Apple TV+ special and the annual Tabernacle Choir concert airing on PBS. Plus, familiar faces including Lori Loughlin, Teri Hatcher and Lacey Chabert have holiday romcoms airing.Here's where - and when, in Eastern Standard Time - to watch this year's holiday TV bonanza.GETTING AN EARLY START Hulu has its own original feelgood holiday movies: " A Christmas Frequency " starring Denise Richards and " Reporting for Christmas," which are among the offerings available now."Desperate Housewives" star Hatcher stars in a cute twist on Kate Hudson's "How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days" with " How to Fall in Love by the Holidays," now up on the Roku Channel. Hatcher plays a reporter reluctantly writing a column with tips on finding in love in time for Christmas - and sparks her own romance.Loughlin returns in her first original holiday movie since getting ensnared in a massive college admissions bribery scandal, called " A Christmas Blessing," now available on Great American Family. Loughlin plays a chef who has just wrapped her long-running TV cooking show and is planning a two-year sojourn to write a book. A quick detour to Milwaukee to handle some family business ends up taking her longer than expected when she finds love with James Tupper.Paul Hollywood and Prue Leith judge " The Great American Baking Show: Celebrity Holiday," also on Roku Channel, where celeb contestants including comedians Joel McHale, Phoebe Robinson and Heather McMahan compete in a bake-off.Chris "Ludacris" Bridges plays Eddie, a dad who has been anti-Christmas because of a traumatic childhood experience in " Dashing through the Snow " for Disney+. When his estranged wife (Teyonah Parris) asks him to take their young daughter out on Christmas Eve, they encounter a man named Nick (played by Lil Rel Howery), who seems to think he's Santa Claus. Eddie thinks the man needs medical attention but ends up going on a magical adventure. It begins streaming Friday.Young shopping mall workers find love in " The Holiday Shift." Premiering Friday on Roku Channel, the five-episode series stars Varun Saranga, Jean-Luc Bilodeau, Devyn Nekoda, Nadine Bhabha and Sarah Levy of "Schitt's Creek."The likeability and comedic talents of Leighton Meester ("Gossip Girl") and Robbie Amell ("Upload") infuse some fresh air into the genre with " EXmas," out on Amazon Freevee Friday. They play former fiancees, Graham and Ali, who find themselves in a nightmare scenario when Graham surprises his family by returning home for the holidays - and finds Ali already there as a special guest.MORE HOLIDAY LOVEAnother exciting duo to watch is former "Party of Five" co-stars Lacey Chabert and Scott Wolf who again, play siblings in " A Merry Scottish Christmas " for the Hallmark Channel premiering Saturday at 8 p.m.Jenn Lilley and Matthew Morrison also jet set in their Great American Family film, " A Paris Christmas Waltz " airing at 8 p.m. on Sunday.Hatcher offers a second holiday movie helping this season with a rekindling romance rom-com. She co-stars in "Christmas at the Chalet" with William DeVry on Nov. 25 at 8 p.m. on Lifetime.Chabert also has two holiday movies this year. She stars in "Haul Out the Holly: Lit Up" - a sequel to last year's hit, "Haul out the Holly" - about a neighborhood that takes their holiday decoration competition very seriously.The lights go up Nov. 25 at 8 p.m. on Hallmark Channel.Kristoffer Polaha and Bethany Joy Lenz filmed a time-traveling romance story at the famed Biltmore Estate in North Carolina. " A Biltmore Christmas " debuts on Hallmark at 8 p.m. on Nov. 26.Loni Anderson, Morgan Fairchild, Linda Gray, Donna Mills and Nicollette Sheridan team up in " Ladies of the '80s: A Divas Christmas " for Lifetime at 8 p.m. on Dec. 2.The quintet portray former soap opera co-stars who come together for a live holiday special and play matchmakers with their producer and director.Another Hallmark regular, Jonathan Bennett, returns with a dose of holiday cheer in "Christmas on Cherry Lane" airing at 8 p.m. Dec. 9.He stars alongside Vincent Rodriguez III ("Crazy Ex-Girlfriend"), Erin Cahill and John Brotherton. The project is also an onscreen reunion for James Denton and Catherine Bell of "The Good Witch."A book editor in New York returns to her family farm and the Amish community she lived in as a child where she helps save a family bakery and meets a handsome local. " Christmas at the Amish Bakery " premieres Dec. 10 at 7 p.m. on UPtv.In "Yes, Chef!", Tia Mowry stars as a culinary instructor whose life takes a surprising turn when she competes in an annual Kringle Cook-Off where she finds career challenges and a possible love interest. Buddy Valastro, known as The Cake Boss, makes his acting debut. It airs Dec. 10 on Lifetime at 8 p.m.SOMETHING NEW FOR THE KIDSNickelodeon's "The Tiny Chef Show" presents a Thanksgiving-themed show called "Fwendsgiving" on Nov. 20.Melissa McCarthy plays a genie who brings holiday cheer to Paapa Essiedu in the new comedy " Genie," debuting Nov. 22 on Peacock.The weekend after Thanksgiving is a big one for Candace Cameron Bure's household.Both she and her daughter, Natasha Bure, have movies on Great American Family this season. Candace's movie "My Christmas Hero" airs Nov. 24 at 8 p.m. and Natasha makes her acting debut in "A Christmas for the Ages" alongside Cheryl Ladd, at 8 p.m. on Nov. 26." The Bad Guys: A Very Bad Holiday," based on the animated feature "The Bad Guys," features villains Mr.Wolf, Mr. Piranha, Mr. Snake, Mr. Shark, and Ms. Tarantula, setting out to do what they do best, (be bad) on Christmas.But when the holiday is canceled, they change course to pull off a happy holiday. Drops on Netflix Nov. 30.IT WOULDN'T BE CHRISTMAS WITHOUT Some classics still hold up, such as the 1974 movie "The Year Without a Santa Claus," featuring the voice of Andy Rooney as Santa. To the dismay of children, Santa decides he's burnt out and needs to take a holiday off.One little boy recognizes how hard Santa works and rallies everyone to give gifts to Santa so he can feel the love. The movie begins playing on Saturday, Nov. 18 on TBS and Sunday, Nov. 19 on TNT.CBS will air the Christmas classic "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer" at 8 p.m. on Nov. 27. It will repeat at 8 p.m. on Dec. 16, followed by long-time favorites "Frosty the Snowman" and "Frosty Returns."Apple TV+ once again makes " A Charlie Brown Christmas " available for free Dec. 16 and 17 so viewers can test out the streaming service, and enjoy the Christmas classic.The 24-hour marathon of " A Christmas Story " begins Dec. 24 on both TNT and TBS.HANUKKAH SPECIALSNick Jr. will air Hanukkah-themed programming beginning at 8 p.m. on Dec. 8 with a special "Paddington" episode followed by an episode of "Bossy Bear."Hallmark Channel also will have a Hanukkah-themed movie called "Round and Round" starring Vic Michaelis and Bryan Greenberg. It airs at 8 p.m. on Dec. 10.HOLIDAY TUNES "Ted Lasso" star Hannah Waddingham taps into her musical theater background by hosting her own Christmas special for Apple TV+ called " Hannah Waddingham: Home for Christmas." Debuting Nov. 22, the event was taped in front of a live audience at the London Coliseum and features special guests."Season of Light: Christmas with The Tabernacle Choir," airs Dec. 12 on PBS at 8 p.m. and Dec. 17 at 8 p.m. on BYUtv. Broadway's Lea Salonga leads the annual concert with the beloved Tabernacle Choir that was recorded in 2022 to air this year. Sir David Suchet narrates.Fox's hit show "The Masked Singer" gets into the holiday spirit with "The Masked Singer Holiday Sing-Along" on Dec. 12, featuring season 10 contestants, "Masked Singer" alums and Nick Cannon, Jenny McCarthy-Wahlberg, Ken Jeong, Robin Thicke and Nicole Scherzinger as "carolers." 
 
 Caption: This image released by Disney+ shows Lil Rel Howery as Nick, left, and Chris "Ludacris" Bridges as Eddie in a scene from the holiday special "Dashing Through the Snow."

title: Picking up speed: MI-5 agents ramp up in third season of 'Slow Horses'
author: Dana Simpson
content:
Picking up speed: MI-5 agents ramp up in third season of 'Slow Horses'

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Dana Simpson | Page: D9 | Section: News 
 
 442
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The phrase "You can't teach an old dog new tricks" may or may not be true, but Apple TV+ has proven that, at least when it comes to horses, even the slowest ones can gain speed. Based on the Slough House book series by English novelist Mick Herron, "Slow Horses" begins its third season with two fresh episodes Friday, Dec. 1, on Apple TV+.The first season of the Gary Oldman ("Darkest Hour," 2017)-led series kicked off on the streamer in April 2022 and made good use of Herron's first Slough House novel, "Slow Horses," for which the show's is named. Season 2 continued the author's saga, taking its plot details from the literary series' second book, "Dead Lions."Now, heading into its third season to be released within a year and a half, the newest instalment will follow the tradition of pulling content chronologically from the novels, this time focusing on Herron's "Real Tigers," the third book in the series.On screen, the spy dramedy follows a group of aging and disgraced MI-5 agents, who all appear to have lived out their usefulness within the high-ranking British espionage organization. As such, the agents have been relegated to another department, "known un-affectionately as Slough House," where a large part of their job involves sitting behind a desk and pushing papers; a lowstakes operation for agents who have made "career-ending mistakes."Slough House is headed up by "brilliant but misanthropic leader" Jackson Lamb (Oldman), and also acts as a sort of workplace home to recovering alcoholic Catherine Standish (Saskia Reeves, "Luther"); former hactivist Roddy Ho (Christopher Chung, "Waterloo Road"); Louisa Guy (Rosalind Eleazar, "Uncle Vanya," 2020), assigned to Slough House following a botched tailing job; and River Cartwright (Jack Lowden, "Dunkirk," 2017), whose desire to redeem himself in the field set the tone for the premiere season.Other agents have come and gone over the seasons, including Jed Moody (Steven Waddington, "Jamestown"), Struan Loy (Paul Higgins, "Apostle," 2018), Min Harper (Dustin Demri-Burns, "Cardinal Burns"), Shirley Dander (Aimee Ffon-Edwards, "Peaky Bllnders"), Marcus Longridge (Kadiff Kirwan, "Ths Is Going to Hurt") and Sidonie "Sid" Baker (Olivia Cooke, "Bates Motel"), the last of whom was a competent MI-5 agent assigned to Slough House for seemingly unknown reasons.Headed into Season 3, many Season 1 and/or 2 characters are expected to return, including Lamb; Cartwright; Ho; Guy and Standish; MI-5 director general and head of operations Diana Taverner (Kristin Scott Thomas, "Gosford Park," 2001); Cartright's grandfather, retired intelligence officer David Cartwright (Jonathan Pryce, "Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl," 2003); and MI-5 agent James "Spider" Webb (Freddie Fox, "Victor Frankenstein," 2015). Supporting characters Harper, Dander and Longridge are also scheduled for Season-3 return. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
