title: Beloved Easton holiday parade set for Saturday
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Beloved Easton holiday parade set for Saturday

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 486
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Easton's long-beloved holiday parade is back again to spread joy and holiday cheer this Saturday, Dec. 2.The annual festivities kick off with Santa's arrival at Thompson Park in downtown Easton at 5:30 p.m., followed by the town's tree lighting at 6 p.m. in the same location.The holiday parade, presented by Preston Automotive Group and supported by Soistman Family Dentistry, starts at 6:30 p.m.The parade route runs from Talbot Town, then heads south on Harrison Street, loops on South Street and then heads north on Washington Street past the panel of judges at the courthouse.Over 60 entrants will be competing across several categories: best nonprofit entry, best commercial entry and best in show.This year's parade will bring a number of firsttime parade participants, said Deena Kilmon, the director of strategic initiatives for Easton Economic Development Corporation.It also marks the first time recently-elected Mayor Megan Cook will lead the parade.There are still opportunities to volunteer or to serve as a parade judge, Kilmon said. Those wishing to volunteer can reach out to Kilmon at deena@eastonedc.com.For Kilmon, who's been working and living in town for over 25 years, the community aspect is what makes the parade and this time of year so special."Coming downtown and seeing your neighbors and just enjoying the absolutely beautiful and charming town that we all live in and sharing that with each other - that's the spirit of the season," she said.Making connections through fun experiences like the holiday parade are crucial to making Easton better." When you have these memories, it makes you a stronger citizen and a person that really wants to work hard for the best of all of us, and that's why we do it," Kilmon said.Two holiday markets will also complement the parade.After a four-year hiatus due to the pandemic, the Easton Holiday Marketplace is back at the Waterfowl Building to feature the best arts and crafts presenters and vendors.The Holiday Marketplace is open Friday, Dec. 1, from 4 p.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturday, Dec. 2, from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; and Sunday, Dec. 3, from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m.And for the first time, a holiday market featuring gifts and photo opportunities with Santa will be open in the historic Ebenezer Theater. Live holiday music will regale attendees on Friday, Dec. 1, from 5 p.m. to 9 p.m. Photos with Santa will be available on Saturday, Dec. 2, from 2 p.m. to 6 p.m.Another new element this year is accessible parking and seating for the parade. Sponsored by The Arc Central Chesapeake Region, parking will be available in the Harrison Street parking lot. Those needing special accommodations will have access to a reserved seating area. 
 
 Caption: A young girl excitedly shows Santa and Mrs. Claus her stuffed Clarice reindeer before the Easton holiday parade Saturday, Dec. 3.
 
A Santa, joined by two elves, waves from an elaborately constructed chimney on a float at Easton's holiday parade Saturday, Dec. 3.

content:
Christmas Music - All-time albums

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: D2 | Section: News 
 
 232

title: Toy trains light up EVFD - Holiday Trains Display delights fire department visitors
author: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com
content:
Toy trains light up EVFD - Holiday Trains Display delights fire department visitors

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 514
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Easton Volunteer Fire Department was all lit up for Christmas.Their big doors for the trucks were lined in white holiday lights, and there was a gigantic green star up above.But the real holiday fun lay inside the fire station atop miniature train tracks.On Tuesday evening, as part of EVFD's Holiday Trains Display, the building was filled with toy trains running circles through fantastic miniature neighborhoods.Parents brought their kids to see the trains and an odd menagerie that included airplanes, dinosaurs and the Yuengling man bringing frosty kegs home for the holidays.One village mimicked the settings of Charles Dickens. One was staged like the North Pole. The Grinch was there, if you looked for him. There was even a Starbucks.One set of cars is from the Tom Hanks movie "The Polar Express.""We put it on there because it is a steam engine and it is really cool," Tarrang said. "We really like it because of its power. It's a model of the largest steam engine ever built.It is called 'Big Boy,' and there are two that are still in service."And like Where's Waldo, the firefighters asked visiting children to find the tiny donut shop."It keeps the kids entertained for a few minutes," Tarrang said.It took volunteers from Oct. 1 to Black Friday to build the displays."This is Lionel O gage. The train in the back is HF. It is smaller, and we did that to make it look far off in the distance," Tarrang said, showing off the Department's work. "When I was a kid we used our allowance to buy HO trains, which shows how cheap they were. You can't do that anymore.""These are all digitally controlled DCs," he said. "We have two controllers for all the trains. There are certain degrees these trains can handle and it is relative to a real train.These are set up to mimic real trains." Tarrang built all the underpinning structure out of wood to support all the trains.The other person implementing and maintaining the train display is Barry VanVechten, who is also a firefighter.Once enough children were there, the lights were turned off. The train sounds seemed amplified, and the glow from the trains and villages filled the darkness. An audible gasp of wonder came from those in attendance. It was a moment of pure Christmas magic.This toy train spectacle will be open through Christmas Day, with an optional donation requested at the door. During the week, it is open from 6 to 8 p.m., and during the weekends it is open from 2 to 8 p.m. 
 
 Caption: Every kid got to check out the trains and find the Grinch. Leah Maxwell, Caleb Maxwell, and Brooklyn Shortall got fire helmets from the EVFD.
 
An engine passes Santa on a white horse. One could also find the Grinch, a building on fire, a dinosuar and a miniature Easton Volunteer Fire House at the Holiday Trains Display.
 
There are several villages that the trains travel through, like the Dickens Village, the North Pole and the airport.
 
The Budweiser Clydesdale horses with attending Dalmatian dog can be found here. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a holiday train display organized by the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, focusing on a community entertainment event for families rather than policy, safety alerts, or economic matters.

title: TCM will Grant you this: A double feature of Hugh
content:
TCM will Grant you this: A double feature of Hugh

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: D12 | Section: News 
 
 346
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Had it not been for his taking a sharp turn into romantic comedy, Hugh Grant might have remained consigned to classics and period costumes for the bulk of his acting career.Instead, he's reached a point where the audience is expected to be perfectly comfortable seeing him play an Oompa-Loompa in "Wonka," the latest incarnation of the saga of Willy Wonka - he of chocolate-factory fame, now portrayed by Timothee Chalamet - that's slated to open in theaters Dec. 15.In preparation for that, Turner Classic Movies salutes Grant with a double feature Sunday, Dec. 3, with each attraction showcasing one of his screen specialties.First up is the picture that changed Grant's professional trajectory, the 1994 international hit "Four Weddings and a Funeral." He plays Charles, a self-deprecating Englishman who's hesitant to commit to a woman unless he sees lightning strike, quite literally. He finally knows what love is when he falls for Carrie (Andie MacDowell), a visiting American with quite a lengthy history of romances and even when it looks like he's lost her to another man, he can't get over her nor the hope that things still might eventually work out for him with her.Another great aspect of "Four Weddings and a Funeral" is the group of close acquaintances that director Mike Newell and writer Richard Curtis surround Charles with. Kristin Scott Thomas, Simon Callow, John Hannah, James Fleet, David Bower and the late Charlotte Coleman portray that bunch, and their easy camaraderie is one of the movie's foremost enduring joys.The second attraction on TCM's Grant double bill is director Ang Lee's 1995 version of "Sense and Sensibility," for which star Emma Thompson adapted the script from Jane Austen's novel (and won an Oscar for doing so).Grant's role is what his norm was before the success of "Four Weddings and a Funeral," as a houseguest who becomes involved with one of three sisters (the Thompson character) who have been left just about destitute after their father's death. Kate Winslet, Hugh Laurie and "Four Weddings" co-star Fleet also have prominent roles. 
 
 Caption: Andie MacDowell and Hugh Grant in "Four Weddings and a Funeral" 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

 "Petticoat Junction" (Catchy Comedy. Sunday, Dec. 3): The 1960s sitcom continues its weekend "Binge" that continues through early Monday morning, detailing the experiences of the staff and guests of the Shady Rest Hotel. Bea Benaderet (the voice of Betty Rubble on "The Flintstones") started the show's run as Kate Bradley, who ran the site with her three comely daughters (played by several actresses, including Linda Kaye Henning and Meredith MacRae) and less-than-energetic Uncle Joe (Edgar Buchanan). The show was a cousin of "The Beverly Hillbillies" and "Green Acres" with its similarly rural undercurrent."Walk the Line" (Cinemax, Sunday, Dec. 3): Joaquin Phoenix is excellent country-music icon Johnny Cash in this fine 2005 drama, but an equally superb Reese Witherspoon was the film's Oscar winner as June Carter, who became Cash's performing partner and wife. Director and co-writer James Mangold captures the couple's stormy relationship superbly, with such other figures as Waylon Jennings (played by the real Waylon's son Shooter) and Elvis Presley ("One Tree Hill's" Tyler Hilton) factoring into the story."The Love Boat" (MeTV, Sunday, Dec. 3): Mickey Rooney appears as a Pacific Princess passenger who has something magical about him in the seasonal episode "The Christmas Presence." Rooney's wife Jan also has a guest role as a nun traveling with a boys' choir; Donny Osmond, Maureen McCormick ("The Brady Bunch"), Teresa Wright, Keenan Wynn and Henry Gibson are on board as well.

title: ZooLights returns to Smithsonian's National Zoo
content:
ZooLights returns to Smithsonian's National Zoo

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: D5 | Section: News 
 
 749
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Washington, D.C.'s beloved family-friendly winter wonderland, ZooLights, returns to brighten the holiday season at the Smithsonian's National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute.Now in its 15th year, Zoo-Lights is brighter than ever and will run for 23 select nights including Nov. 30- Dec. 3, Dec. 7-10, Dec. 14-17, Dec. 21-23 and Dec. 26-30. On Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights, Zoo-Lights will take place from 5 p.m. to 9 p.m. On Sundays, ZooLights will run from 5 p.m. to 8 p.m.ZooLights is generously brought to you by its lead sponsor, M&T Bank.Visitors strolling through the Zoo can bask in the glow of more than half-a-million environmentally friendly LED lights. True to the unique setting of the Zoo, visitors will see 130 lanterns depicting ocean, desert, grassland, rainforest and polar habitats, and the animals that call them home. Illuminations, live musical performances, delicious treat offerings and plenty of opportunities for holiday shopping make this special event a dazzling and immersive experience for families and nature aficionados.ZooLights tickets go on sale Thursday, Oct. 26, to Zoo members and non-members.This year, ZooLights will have a ticket price of $6 per individual.Each attendee, including children over the age of 2, will need a ticket. Paid tickets are a change from past years when this special event was free to attend. The ticket fee is needed to offset the significant increase in costs associated with running this event. Parking is available for pre-purchase online at $30 per vehicle.ZooLights is an extremely popular event with Washington-area families.Due to limited capacity, visitors are encouraged to plan ahead and purchase tickets and parking passes early. Any proceeds from tickets, concessions and parking sales benefit animal care and conservation science at the Smithsonian's National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute.On general-admission nights, all indoor animal exhibits will be closed to allow animals to get a full night's rest. Daytime visitors who would like to view the Zoo's animals can obtain a free entry pass and/or paid parking pass on the Zoo's website. Per normal operating hours, the Zoo will close at 4 p.m. to all visitors. It will reopen at 5 p.m. for visitors with ZooLights tickets and parking passes.Visitors can get further into the holiday spirit with live music performances by local artists and school groups. The Speedwell Foundation Conservation Carousel is the only paid ticketed attraction open at ZooLights pending weather (it will close if the outside temperature is below 35 degrees Fahrenheit).Visitors may purchase tickets on site at the carousel's entrance for $4. During this special event, visitors can warm up indoors while shopping for holiday gifts inside the Visitor Center, Panda Plaza and Great Cats stores or while dining at Elevation Burger at the Mane Grill.Special winter treats, including s'mores, popcorn, kettle corn, holiday cookies, soft pretzels and seasonal gelato, will be available for purchase. Hungry visitors can dine outdoors at Sbarro or enjoy ZooLights specials at Bootheel BBQ, including brisket chili, gumbo and jambalaya.Children can stay warm by sipping hot chocolate or spiced cider while adults enjoy holiday beverages, including a cinnamon vanilla bean latte, warm bourbon-spiked cider, a hot cocoa cocktail at Vintage Views and mulled wine at Elevation Burger.Smithsonian National Zoo members can reserve up to six free entry passes and one free parking pass for three exclusive Member Nights - Nov. 30, Dec. 7 and Dec. 14 - from 5 p.m. to 9 p.m.Member Nights include special after-hours access to popular Zoo exhibits, including the Small Mammal House, Elephant Community Center and Reptile Discovery Center.During any night of ZooLights, members can use their standard 15% discount on in-park food and retail during any night of ZooLights when they present their membership card and photo ID at checkout. Due to limited capacity, advanced reservations for Member Nights are required.ZooLights will be held rain or shine. Only guests with a parking pass will be permitted to enter the Zoo's Connecticut Avenue entrance with their vehicle. Guests using ride-share vehicles will be dropped off and picked up at the designated rideshare zones near the Connecticut Avenue and Harvard Street entrances. Zoo staff will scan tickets at both the Connecticut Avenue entrance and the lower entrance near the Kids' Farm.Metro Bus (L1 and L2) and Metro Rail (Woodley Park-Zoo and Cleveland Park) have stops within walking distance of the Zoo's main pedestrian entrance on Connecticut Avenue.For more information, visit the Zoo's website at nationalzoo.si.edu/events/zoolights. 
 
 Caption: Trees festively decorated with brightly colored lights dazzle visitors at ZooLights at the Smith sonian's National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a seasonal public event (ZooLights) at the Smithsonian's National Zoo, focusing on lights, performances, food, and family activities, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category.

title: A Paddy Chayefsky party starts with "Marty"
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
A Paddy Chayefsky party starts with "Marty"

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: D16 | Section: News 
 
 175
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Widely recognized as one of the greatest screenwriters, Paddy Chayefsky gets a two-night tribute from Turner Classic Movies starting Wednesday Dec. 6, with one of his most famous works. "Marty" was a television play starring Rod Steiger before it became a 1955 film, with Ernest Borgnine assuming the title role of a lonely Bronx butcher and winning an Oscar for performance that transformed his career from the bad-guy roles he largely had been playing. The movie also earned Academy Awards for best picture, director (Delbert Mann) and Chayefsky's adapted screenplay.Marty generally hangs out with his pals after work, but a visit to a dance hall introduces him to shy teacher Clara (Betsy Blair), and they take a real shine to each other but the critical comments of Marty's buddies make him doubt pursuing a relationship with her. The picture is alternately amusing and heartbreaking, but always affecting. Notable supporting players include Frank Sutton, who would become Sgt. Carter to TV's "Gomer Pyle, USMC," and Jerry Paris - later one of TVs top sitcom directors ("The Dick Van Dyke Show," "Happy Days"). 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Time can be the great reaper
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Time can be the great reaper

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 18 | Section: News 
 
 263
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Although it feels as if summers run and winters crawl, time moves at a steady pace. However, maybe you agree with Eugene Ionesco: "We haven't the time to take our time."At the bridge table, though, we should take our time.When the dummy appears, all three active players should pause to plan the campaign.Sometimes we must judge the right time to win a particular trick.Today's deal was declared by Roger Trezel, a Frenchman who died in 1986. How did he time the play in five spades after West had led the diamond king? West's bidding isn't recommended. First, why preempt when you might be able to make three no-trump? A two-diamond overcall is normal. Second, having jumped to four diamonds, West shouldn't have bid five.If he was willing to go to five diamonds, he should have bid it on the first round.Despite West's sacrifice, Trezel wasn't willing to assume that East had the club ace. To try to establish the heart suit without risking East's gaining the lead, Trezel ducked the opening lead.When West continued with a diamond to dummy's ace, declarer discarded a low heart. South drew trumps, cashed the heart ace, played a heart to dummy's king and ruffed a heart. Back to dummy with a trump, Trezel discarded two club losers on dummy's heart winners.Nicely done.At another table, South won the first trick with dummy's diamond ace. However, after drawing trumps ending in the dummy, he called for the diamond two. When East failed to put in the 10, South discarded a low heart and recovered from his earlier error.

title: Bridge - The reflexes of a snail
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The reflexes of a snail

 December 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 281
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Whatever else your feeling about Woody Allen, he has written many funny lines.I like this one: "I'm not a fighter; I have bad reflexes.I was once run over by a car being pushed by two guys." Many bridge deals require rapid reflexes. Some declarers, when they need a misdefense to make their contract, will play very quickly. This isn't kosher, but it often works.However, when defending, don't be hurried. Say that you want to take some time to think things through.Rather than rely on speed, it is preferable for the declarer to play his cards deceptively so that the defender doesn't see the trap in time.Playing in four hearts, the ingenuous declarer wins the first trick with dummy's club ace, draws trumps and plays a diamond to the king. Against some opponents, this will work. West will lead a second club, allowing South to ruff and discard one of dummy's spade losers on the diamond queen. However, against more sophisticated defenders, it won't succeed.First, East will play his two trumps in the order 5 then 2, trying to show a top honor in spades. Second, West will see that the club queen can wait. He will recognize the possibility of a discard and switch to the spade four at trick five.As South knows East has the club king and is marked with a top spade (West didn't lead the spade ace or king), West must hold the diamond ace.A more deceptive approach is to lead dummy's diamond at trick two and put in the nine. If West falls for the trap, later South can ruff out West's diamond ace and get his discard.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: A view from behind the cameras - Filmmaker talks metaphors, process and independent films
author: Matt Hubbard; mhubbard@chespub.com
content:
A view from behind the cameras - Filmmaker talks metaphors, process and independent films

 December 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Hubbard; mhubbard@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1190
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ELKTON - For most of his life, filmmaker Samuel White has been focused on captivating audiences through the thought-provoking narratives and community-building aspects of his films, a drive that recently brought him recognition at the 2023 Cecil County Independent Film Festival."Through creating art, my hope is to get people wanting to talk about the art," said White. "Even if they disagree, I want people to communicate, talk about ideas and get to know each other and I think that's the reason I make films." White, 33, of Elkton, developed an interest in filmmaking after he saw the 1960 film "Psycho" when he was 11 years old. White recalls seeing certain shots within the film the artistic intention of which peaked his interest.From that point forward, White took his enjoyment for writing stories and began to think of them as films until he began playing with his grandfather's camcorder to bring his ideas to life. Now, White says filmmaking is his favorite form of storytelling."I cannot picture a time in my life where I didn't think cinematically," White said. "I don't know if I showed any talent as a filmmaker when I was a kid but at that time, I learned that the camera is an important storytelling tool." In high school, White was homeschooled under an umbrella program that granted him the opportunity to meet fellow students who were also interested in filmmaking. Based on their shared love of film, White and his friends created the Cinematography Club, where they would get together and practice different filmmaking techniques.From 2004 to 2008, when White was in high school, video production technology was rapidly evolving with the introduction of HD video and video cameras.After White's senior year of high school, digital single lens reflection (DSLR) cameras took over the market."With the DSLRs, it was like an 'oh my god, we could actually do this,' moment for me with filmmaking because of how video friendly and available DSLRs became," White said.DSLR cameras often have interchangeable lenses, shoot on compact flash or SD cards and are capable of both still photography and shooting high quality video. To learn more about video technology, White attended Cecil College where he majored in video production."When I was at Cecil College, I didn't have an interest in the actual degree, I wanted to get as much hand on tech experience as I could and I did," said White. "It was fantastic because they gave me the tools and opportunities to work and learn with the technology and techniques." White said that his favorite course at Cecil College was called Gorilla Filmmaking, where he had the opportunity to to work with top of the line filmmaking equipment while receiving guidance and criticism on his work from professional photographer and videographer Floyd Dean.During that class, White created his first short film that documented a female character suffering from an unknown problem that was slowly destroying her body. The horror film utilized only music - no dialogue - which White says was intentional, as it left much of the film up for interpretation."For me, the girl running around with her face falling off asking for help and being ignored was kind of like personal feelings I have had throughout my life relating to personal things," said White. "I enjoy films that are abstract that invite you to feel and interpret what you want." White graduated from Cecil College in 2012 and has gone on to build himself a filmmaking portfolio of 14 independent films; six of which he wrote and directed on his own.His most recent film, "Safewords," follows a soonto-be bride and her adventure into an alternative lifestyle.The film won best full-length feature and best scriptwriting."Safewords" took three weekends for White and his crew of three to create, which he said took about 10 years off of his life expectancy due to stress."I didn't give myself enough time, and it was a massive learning experience because of the amount of stuff I didn't know about while making an hour and a half long feature film," White said. "I am proud of the film, and I am glad it turned out the way it did." White often holds his new films up against his 2020 film "The Day Bingo Died," as he said it is his favorite film that he has made to date.The film follows a brother and a sister who return to their childhood home to euthanize their family dog.Both siblings grieve the loss and decide to go to a bar after burying the dog. The siblings later end up intoxicated and arguing over who loved the dog more, which White said is the "weirdest mix between two adults acting like spoiled drunk children." Odd mix aside, White considers "The Day Bingo Died" to be his favorite film because it presents viewers with an uncomfortable, yet relatable, view of grief and family."It plays on the power behind words and the expression of grief and how the differences between the two speak to human nature," White said. "I love putting people in that uncomfortable space where they don't know if they should laugh or not because the uncomfortable feelings come from situations being relatable." Much of White's inspiration comes from directors Alfred Hitchcock, Lars Von Trier and David Zucker, as well as his personal competitive streak to build and improve film ideas using metaphor.White explained that he often views everything in his life as a scene in a movie, which helps him grow as a filmmaker because it allows him to connect metaphors to true meaning."When something emotional or interesting happens to me, I ask what it would look like visually and how would that fit into a story," said White. "If it's a fear of commitment, my metaphor would be a wedding ring stuck on a finger that irritates the skin - stuff like that." White's consistent hunt for metaphors to add into his films is what he says is the base of traditional filmmaking and is what makes his films art. But to keep the sense of traditional filmmaking alive, White said film festivals are essential as art on the big scene is slowly fading into the background."If you want to be a filmmaker, from now throughout the future, there will be less chances to get your film on an actual big screen, which is why I go to local film festivals - to keep the traditional art form of filmmaking alive because of streaming," said White.Looking to the future, White is working to grow his production company, Outsider Film Company, to a point where it can help independent filmmakers produce their work. The film company currently offers a variety of professional video services and can be found on Instagram or Facebook."I will be making art for the rest of my life," White said. "If you're considering making movies, Cecil County is a great place and you're in a great time period.Get out and give it a try."

Sam White (left) uses a camera to record a musical performance.
 
CONTRIBUTED PHOTO
 
An actress reads over her lines during the production of Sam White's "Safewords."
 
CONTRIBUTED PHOTO
 
Director Sam White stands with an award from the Cecil County Independent Film Festival.
 
CONTRIBUTED PHOTO
 
A screengrab from a scene in Sam White's "Safewords."

 EASTON - Frosty's Holiday Village was teeming with children having fun Friday.There were gigantic blow up characters, like Rudolph, and there was hot chocolate and cookies. A couple hundred children came to this free event, which was moved at the last minute from the courthouse lawn to the Anchor Church on 620 Goldsoboro Street due to concerns about the weather.Family after family streamed in the church's entrance, passing a giant blow up Frosty, many of their children dressed in holiday finery.There was face painting, professional photos with Frosty and a continuous screening of "Frosty's Winter Wonderland" in the church's sanctuary.A DJ played a continuous round of classic Christmas songs. That is, until he put on the "Electric Slide", during which lines of women formed to do the dance and clap in unison, a fun reminder that the holidays can be terrific and inclusive.For All Seasons, a community behavioral health center, put the whole three-hour extravaganza together. title: Bridge Scout Out The Opposition
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge Scout Out The Opposition

 December 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 11 | Section: News 
 
 282
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Duke of Wellington was discussing war, but with a small change we can make it look as if he was talking about bridge: "All the business of bridge is to endeavor to find out what you don't know by what you do."In other words, as you play out the deal, you learn more about the opponents' hands and can use that information.Against four hearts, West led the club 10. East won the first trick with the ace, cashed the club king (the accepted way of showing a doubleton) and exited with a diamond.With a guaranteed spade loser, declarer had to find the trump queen to make his contract. Assuming West had five clubs to East's two, there were 11 empty spaces in East's hand for the heart queen, but only eight in West's hand. However, those odds of 11-to-8 weren't good enough for South. He wanted to find out more about the distribution before committing himself.Judging that West would have led a singleton diamond if he had one, declarer overtook the diamond king with dummy's ace and discarded his club queen on dummy's diamond queen.Now came the spade queen from the dummy. East won with the ace and returned a diamond.Immediately South ruffed with the heart ace, cashed the spade king (discarding dummy's club loser) and ran the heart eight. When it won, he repeated the heart finesse, drew the last trump and claimed.Why was South so confident about the hearts? Because East had passed as dealer and already shown up with 11 points: the club ace-king and the spade ace. He couldn't hold a queen as well. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Whoville 'Mayor' Launches Fifth Annual Family Event
author: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub. Com
content:
Whoville 'Mayor' Launches Fifth Annual Family Event

 December 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub. Com | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 647
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO - The misting rain held off as Whoville Honorary Mayor Doug Gray of Burrsville opened the fifth annual event 5 p.m. Friday, Dec. 1, at the Greensboro Volunteer Fire Company Community Hall."Behold, citizens of Greensboro," Gray proclaimed."The most magical time of the year has arrived.The Greensboro Whoville Village Holiday Park is back, more magnificent and grand than ever before.""You see our big Whoville sign, but wait till it's dark; you can see it from space, I'm pretty sure," Greensboro Mayor David Spencer said."We're really proud that the fire company has partnered with us to allow us to move over here."Despite the forecast and the light rain that began a half-hour into opening night, visitors showed up to walk the 2,000-foot winding path past inflatables, about 50,000 lights and the Grinch's lair to enjoy the free festive holiday display hosted by the Town of Greensboro."We wish the weather could be a little better, but at least it's not freezing cold," Spencer said.The event takes place over the next two weekends.For the faint-of-heart intimidated by the Grinch's dreary lair, visitors had the option of walking along the outside of it. However, the Grinch, with his trademark onion, seemed fairly harmless as he sported a necklace made of Christmas lights.Over the past five years, town employees and volunteers have put on the event, adding elements and improving the experience.This is the second year the holiday village has been set up at the hall.Potential flooding from the Choptank River prompted organizers to move the popular event to higher ground last year.Inside the hall, about 15 local vendors had set up tables. By the last weekend of Whoville, there will be about 25, according to Town Manager Tammy Kelledes. Visitors could purchase hamburgers, hot dogs and drinks from the GVFC Auxiliary.Among the nearly two dozen volunteers were Spencer's grandchildren."It's a family affair," Spencer's wife Cathy said.Also represented were Public Works Director Brandon Cunningham's son and Community Outreach Coordinator Amanda Weaver's son, who volunteered as elves.Their job? "To spread Christmas joy," Weaver said, smiling.Santa and Mrs. Claus greeted children in their cozy shed decorated by Brandon Cunningham's wife Katie Beebe-Cunningham.Although Santa Claus had seen only a few children during the first hour of the village festivities, he said he saw about 1,500 children last year on the first night of Whoville. Mrs. Claus said they usually gravitate towards her first, and then feel more at ease to visit the jolly old elf.At the end of the path was a silhouette Nativity scene set up by Greater Impact Church in Greensboro.It's been about a month of work for the town employees who set up Whoville this year.Public safety was top of mind for organizers, and Greensboro Police and Caroline County Emergency Services were on site.Although the town relies on sponsors and donations, it has yet to break even on the cost of putting on the event, Kelledes said."This splendorous affair is all thanks to the generous donations and in-kind contributions from our beloved community businesses and citizens," Honorary Mayor Gray proclaimed."It's a time to cherish with your loved ones, sip cocoa, and get lost in a wonderland of lights."For more information about Greensboro Whoville Village Holiday Park, visit the Town of Greensboro's Facebook page, call 410-482-6222, text 443-239-4160 or email aweaver@greensboromd.com.

title: Away from it all: Luxury getaway goes south in 'Leave the World Behind'
author: Sarah Passingham
content:
Away from it all: Luxury getaway goes south in 'Leave the World Behind'

 December 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sarah Passingham | Page: D9 | Section: News 
 
 636
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A family's stay at a luxurious vacation home is unexpectedly extended due to a mysterious apocalypse in the new thriller "Leave the World Behind," premiering Friday, Dec. 8, on Netflix.Based on the bestselling 2020 novel of the same name by author Rumaan Alam, the adaptation stars Julia Roberts ("Ticket to Paradise," 2022) and Ethan Hawke ("Moon Knight") as married couple Amanda and Clay Sandford, whose family getaway to Long Island is steered far from the rest and relaxation they expected.After putting off a much-needed break from their busy day-to-day city life, Amanda tells Clay in the official trailer for the film, "I figured if I made the reservation and packed our bags, it would eliminate most of the reasons to say no."Off they go to a sprawling home near the beach with their two children, teenager Archie (Charlie Evans, "Everything's Gonna Be Okay") and their youngest, Rose (Farrah Mackenzie, "United States of Al").While Amanda and Clay watch on as their children enjoy the pool and they all begin to settle into their temporary home, the peace and quiet begins feeling eerie. The cable and internet are mysteriously out, but the Sandfords try to make the most of it by pulling out games to pass the time. A knock at the door in the dark of night puts them face to face with two strangers in formal wear.Mahershala Ali ("Swan Song," 2021) is G.H.Scott, the owner of the home, he explains to the bewildered couple blocking his doorway. This fateful introduction deepens the uneasiness that's beginning to build, when Amanda says to G.H. like an accusation, "This is your house?" G.H., joined by his daughter Ruth (Myha'la, "Industry"), face down their guests until they are eventually let into their home.Widespread blackouts led the Scotts to flee New York City for their Long Island residence, wanting to wait out the outage away from the panic of the city. Relegated to the basement in-law suite by a forcefully skeptical Amanda, the divide between the two families intensifies.If Amanda is determined not to make any friends in the apocalypse, her efforts are matched only by gruff contractor Danny, portrayed by Kevin Bacon ("City On a Hill"). Holding his shotgun as a warning in the trailer, Danny sternly tells G.H., "I would do anything to protect my family.What you do is your business." A woman desperately clings to the passenger side door as Clay accelerates away, lost in this unfamiliar beach town, leaving the Sandford and Scott families no choice but to rely on each other for the time being.All they know for certain is that a countrywide cyberattack has caused sweeping power outages along the East Coast. Confirmed with an unsettling "unrecognized emergency warning" blasting bright blue light from the beach home's flat-screen TV, G.H.'s hunch that the seemingly unrelated disasters are connected grows."Leave the World Behind" is written and directed by "Mr. Robot" creator Sam Esmail, who spoke with The Hollywood Reporter in October about adapting the novel shortly after it was published during the COVID-19 pandemic. Esmail shared, "It was a crazy time, those early days [of the pandemic], and when I read the book what really resonated for me was this idea that in a moment of crisis, just how easily we could forget our common humanity."Alam executive produced the film with Tonia Davis ("Rustin," 2023), Daniel M. Stillman ("Eurovision Song Contest: The Story of Fire Saga," 2020), Nick Krishnamurthy and Barack and Michelle Obama ("We the People"). Esmail also shared what it's like to collaborate with the former president and first lady, saying, "They gave notes on everything from the disaster elements to the characters." The director added, "It's a highlight of my career that I got to work with the Obamas. They're some of the most brilliant minds on the planet and I'm really grateful for their involvement."

title: Tony Shalhoub returns as "Monk" in new Peacock movie
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Tony Shalhoub returns as "Monk" in new Peacock movie

 December 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: D12 | Section: News 
 
 502
 Words 

 Read News Document

 With the way that popular series of the past have been recycled - even in the streaming era that has added so much content - the second coming of "Monk" may not be that huge a surprise.As it happens, streaming is the avenue by which Tony Shalhoub is reprising his multiple-Primetime Emmy-winning portrayal of obsessive-compulsive detective Adrian Monk. Peacock premieres "Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie" on Friday, Dec. 8, with the hugely phobic title character on a very personal mission to help his journalist step-daughter Molly ("Home Economics" alum Caitlin McGee) when tragedy strikes as her wedding nears. The film might claim that this is Monk's final investigation, but of course, a ratings triumph for the picture can change that notion easily. (Consider that there have been three movie sequels to another former USA Network series, "Psych," and a fourth has been under discussion.) Also an executive producer of the new film, Shalhoub isn't the only "Monk' veteran returning for it. Series creator Andy Breckman ("The Good Cop") wrote the script and returns as an executive producer as well (with "Hit & Run's" David Hobernan also reprising the latter job), and Randy Zisk ("Midnight Caller") - who directed many of the original show's episodes, including the finale - calls the shots again on the movie.Other familiar faces from the "Monk" cast also are back. Traylor Howard ("Two Guys, a Girl and a Pizza Place") again plays Natalie Teeger, who was Monk's second assistant on the show; Ted Levine ("The Silence of the Lambs," 1991) and Jason Gray-Stanford ("A Beautiful Mind," 2001) return as the police-connected Leland Stottlemeyer and Randy Disher; Hector Elizondo ("Last Man Standing") resurfaces as psychiatrist Neven Bell; and Melora Hardin ("The Office") resurfaces as Monk's late wife Trudy."Monk" premiered on USA Network in 2002 and enjoyed an eight-season run, with Shalhoub earning three Primetime Emmy Awards for it along the way. John Turturro ("Barton Fink," 1991) and Stanley Tucci ("Big Night," 1996) each picked up an Emmy for guest stints on the show, and Randy Newman ("Toy Story," 1995) won two of the honors for his musical contributions to it. Shalhoub also won a Golden Globe and two Screen Actors Guild Awards for the program.The series brought stardom to Shalhoub after his tenure as a respected supporting actor on stage and screen. When "Monk" began, he was known to viewers largely as Antonio on the sitcom "Wings," and he also had gained notice for roles in such movies as "Big Night" (1996, with the aforementioned Tucci) and "The Siege" (1998). He also had earned the first of what would be his four Tony Award nominations to date, for "Conversations With My Father" (1992); his others have been for "Golden Boy" (2013), "Act One" (2014) and "The Band's Visit" (2017), and he won the honor for the latter play.For now, though, it's back to "Monk" territory for Shalhoub's - and though "Last" is in the movie's name, don't necessarily bank on that being the fact. 
 
 Caption: Tony Shalhoub in "Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie" 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Driving down the wrong road
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Driving down the wrong road

 December 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 12 | Section: News 
 
 262
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Whenever some bridge declarers come to a crossroads, they always seem to crash.In today's deal, South thought he was driving so cleverly along the main highway when in reality he was heading down a side road that looked superficially attractive but was leading to a cliff top.Against three no-trump, West led the heart three: four, jack, king. South counted seven top tricks and anticipated getting two more from diamonds. He also knew an avoidance play when he saw one.South led a diamond to dummy's king, returned to hand with a spade and led a second diamond. If West had played the queen, South was planning to duck in the dummy, keeping East off the lead. However, when West played the 10, declarer put up dummy's ace and led a third round. South was pleased to see West win this trick, but he was less pleased when West promptly switched to the club nine (the high card denying interest in the suit) in answer to his partner's encouraging club seven discard on the previous trick.East won with the ace and returned a heart: down one.South's path required finding the diamonds 3-2, West's holding the club ace and West's having to win his side's diamond trick. However, there was a much better route available.Assuming West's heart three was an honest card, the suit had to be splitting 4-3. If so, South just needed to find West with the club jack. At trick two, South should have finessed dummy's club 10.His nine tricks would have been four spades, one heart, two diamonds and two clubs. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Seasonal seasoning: Tilly Ramsay joins 'MasterChef' dad to judge junior holiday competition
author: Caroline Collacutt
content:
Seasonal seasoning: Tilly Ramsay joins 'MasterChef' dad to judge junior holiday competition

 December 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Caroline Collacutt | Page: D14 | Section: News 
 
 378
 Words 

 Read News Document

 You have to whisk it to risk it - and maybe add a little nutmeg for a taste of holiday cheer.Celebrity chef Gordon Ramsay welcomes both his family and yours to spend some time in the kitchen this holiday season, as the all-new "MasterChef Junior: Home for the Holidays" airs a two-part special, taking place Sunday and Monday, Dec. 10 and 11, on Fox."Gordon Ramsay welcomes nine young culinary contestants to cook up seasonal delights themed to Christmas, Hanukkah, Kwanzaa, Lunar New Year and more," a recent news release from the network shared, continuing: "Judges Gordon Ramsay, his daughter Tilly Ramsay, Aarón Sánchez and Daphne Oz will crown a winner, who takes home the ultimate holiday gift: a $25,000 grand prize, a Viking Kitchen package and a one-ofa-kind 'MasterChef ' snow globe trophy." In fact, each junior chef who competes will leave with a kitchen-related prize, including a second Viking Kitchen package for the runner-up.Like its predecessor, "MasterChef Junior," this iteration will also feature young aspiring cooks - children aged eight to 13 - with each episode putting the heat on these talented junior chefs with a series of challenges.They'll compete in skills-based tests, boxes of mystery ingredients, team challenges and elimination rounds, including the "Pressure Test," in which losing team members must compete against each other to make an impressive dish within a limited time frame.Once the competition is reduced to its strongest chefs, the remaining few must face off in a three-course cook-off, with all courses equally weighed by judges to determine an overall winner.It's a big feat to face one Ramsay for chefs of all ages - let alone two. A world-renowned chef himself, Gordon Ramsay's daughter, Tilly, was previously a contestant on "Celebrity Master-Chef Australia," proving that talent in the kitchen might just be genetic. The second-generation Ramsay is also set to join the cast as a judge of "MasterChef Junior's" upcoming ninth season, acting as a reminder of what young chefs can accomplish once they really get cooking.Bubbling over with family fun and holiday cheer, this seasonal special is sure to give fans a taste of what's to come in "Master-Chef Junior" Season 9. "Master-Chef Junior: Home for the Holidays" airs as a two-night event, Dec. 10 and 11, on Fox.

title: Celebrity Update
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Celebrity Update

 December 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: D10 | Section: News 
 
 281
 Words 

 Read News Document

 David DuchovnyQ: It's been interesting to see David Duchovny back in the public eye for the movie he made with Meg Ryan. How long was he on "The X-Files"?A: The actor's run as FBI Agent Fox Mulder began in 1993, and he has said that he didn't expect the Fox series (now repeating on Comet) to last as long as it did, nor to be as popular as it became. His regular weekly run on the show went through the seventh season, when headlines were made by a lawsuit Duchovny filed against 20th Century Fox Television, alleging that it sold rights to repeats of the show to Fox-affiliated stations for less than they were worth thus costing him some profits.The suit was settled, but Duchovny's contract for the show was up, so he left as a full-time cast member (with Robert Patrick assuming the role of a Mulder surrogate, John Doggett). However, Duchovny returned for part of the eighth season, with the explanation that Mulder had been abducted by aliens.He also came back for the presumed series finale in Season 9, but as it turned out, he wasn't done with the show yet.Fox gave "The X-Files" revivals as a limited-run program in 2016 and 2018, which were deemed to be the 10th and 11th seasons of the show. Series creator-producer Chris Carter has inferred that there are more stories in that universe to be told, but any discussions of a continuation of the franchise haven't come to fruition. The show also yielded two theatrical films in which Duchovny played Mulder (opposite Gillian Anderson's Agent Dana Scully), "The X-Files: Fight the Future" (1998) and "The X-Files: I Want to Believe" (2008).

title: Bridge - Bridge is still no passing fancy
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Bridge is still no passing fancy

 December 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 272
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The death knell of bridge has been sounded several times. When the game was first invented, many claimed it would be a quickly passing fancy. Nowadays, with fewer young players coming into the game, some are saying that bridge will die with the elderly in 20 years or so. Still, somehow I have a feeling it will be going as strongly as ever come 2043.We have heard about passing in the auction. But what about passing in the play? If you thought that was impossible, look at today's deal.The contract was four spades. West led the heart jack: three, ace, queen.Back came the heart six to declarer's king. Declarer cashed his top spades, receiving a shock when West discarded a low diamond on the second round. Suddenly South was faced with four losers: two spades, one heart and one diamond. However, he didn't throw in the towel.He realized he might win 10 tricks after all.Declarer played a club to dummy's king and ruffed a heart in hand. Then he played a club to dummy's ace and ruffed a club in hand.Next he cashed the diamond ace before playing a diamond to dummy's king. That gave declarer nine tricks. He could lead either dummy's last heart or club and leave East with no answer. If he didn't ruff in, South would trump for his 10th trick, whereas if East did ruff in, South would discard his diamond loser and be assured of one more trump trick with his remaining 5-4 doubleton.This play, which generated an extra trump trick, is called a coup en passant.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bridge - The Lead Paints The Picture
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The Lead Paints The Picture

 December 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 275
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In today's deal, West's opening lead reveals a lot about both his hand and his plan for defeating the contract. However, it isn't immediately apparent how the declarer can thwart West's dastardly scheme.Also, even then an ice-cool West might thwart South's thwart!
Defending against four spades, West leads the club ace: three, four, 10. He switches to the diamond nine, two, 10 How should South continue?
Given North's opening bid, West must have led a singleton club ace. South must win trick two, to stop the lethal club ruff. However, even with a singleton, West's lead is unattractive. So declarer can place king-third of spades with West: some measure of trump control.
If this is the position and he attacks trumps now, West is bound to score a club ruff, East having a diamond entry.
Have you seen the key play?
South must hope that West has the heart jack. At trick three, he leads the heart ace, squashing dummy's king.
Then he cashes the heart queen, discarding one of dummy's diamonds, and continues with the heart 10.
Assuming West covers with the jack, declarer discards dummy's last diamond.
When South regains the lead, he plays the spade ace and another spade. East never wins a trick, so West never gets his ruff.
However, if West has the courage to play low smoothly on the heart 10, he might deflect declarer to defeat.
Thinking East has the heart jack, South might decide his only chance is to ruff and play the spade ace and another spade, hoping the trumps are 2-2.
If an opponent wants you to play a particular card, don't. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

 Read News Document

 Greta Gerwig's "Barbie" dominated the Golden Globe Awards nominations with nine nods for the blockbuster film, including best picture musical or comedy as well as acting nominations for Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling and three of its original songs.It was closely followed by its release date and meme companion Christopher Nolan's "Oppenheimer," which scored eight nominations, including best picture drama and for actors Cillian Murphy, Robert Downey Jr. and Emily Blunt.In a statement, Gerwig said she, "can't wait to bring the Barbie party to the Globes." The revamped group, now a for-profit endeavor with a larger and more diverse voting body, announced nominations Monday for its January awards show, after scandal and several troubled years, including one without a broadcast. Cedric the Entertainer and Wilmer Valderrama presided over the announcements from the Beverly Hilton Hotel, where the show will also take place on Jan. 7.Films nominated for best motion picture drama included "Oppenheimer," Martin Scorsese's "Killers of the Flower Moon," Bradley Cooper's "Maestro," Celine Song's "Past Lives," Justine Triet's "Anatomy of a Fall" and Jonathan Glazer's "The Zone of Interest." In the best motion picture musical or comedy category, "Barbie" was joined by "Air," "American Fiction" "The Holdovers," "May December" and "Poor Things." Yorgos Lanthimos' "Poor Things" and Scorsese's "Killers of the Flower Moon" both received seven nominations each. "Poor Things" saw nominations for Lanthimos, its actors Emma Stone, Mark Ruffalo, Willem Dafoe, and Tony McNamara for screenplay. "Killers of the Flower Moon" got nods for Scorsese, for direction and co-writing the screenplay with Eric Roth, and stars Leonardo DiCaprio, Lily Gladstone and Robert De Niro.Stone, who was also nominated for the Showtime series "The Curse," said in a statement that she was "Feeling extremely bewildered and thankful for it all." She also said her "Poor Things" character Bella Baxter is her favorite.DiCaprio praised Gladstone in his statement: "She is the soul of our film and helped to bring this sinister and painful part of our nation's history to life," he wrote. The film is about the murders of wealthy Osage individuals in Oklahoma in the early 20th century."Barbie" tied for second-most nominations in Globes history with "Cabaret," from 1972. Robert Altman's "Nashville" remains the record-holder with 11 nominations.It went into the morning as a favorite and got a big boost from its three original song nominations, including "I'm Just Ken," and one of the year's new categories, recognizing cinematic and box office achievement. One person who was not nominated was America Ferrera, who delivered the movie's most memorable monologue."Succession" was the top-nominated television program, with nine nods including for series stars Brian Cox, Jeremy Strong, Sarah Snook and Kieran Culkin, followed by Hulu's "The Bear." As always there were some big surprises, like Jennifer Lawrence getting nominated for her bawdy R-rated comedy "No Hard Feelings" for best performance by a female actor in a musical or comedy. She was nominated alongside Robbie, Stone and Fantasia Barrino ("The Color Purple"), Natalie Portman ("May December") and Alma Pöysti ("Fallen Leaves").Barrino heard the news from her husband who she immediately called back to make sure she wasn't dreaming."My voice is shot because I've been screaming, crying and just telling God, 'Thank you.' I almost allowed fear to hinder me from this role, to keep me from this role," she told the AP through tears.She's been on the road for work and said she's excited to go home and experience it with her children. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses Golden Globe nominations, movies, actors, and industry awards, which are core subjects of the Entertainment category rather than broader Arts & Culture.

title: St. Michaels Parades Bring Holiday Music, Bright Lights And Candy
author: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub.Com
content:
St. Michaels Parades Bring Holiday Music, Bright Lights And Candy

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub.Com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 720
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS - Visitors and residents of St.Michaels had plenty of holiday-themed entertainment to keep them busy Saturday.
Throughout the day, Christmas in St. Michaels hosted a variety of events, including two parades: the Talbot Street Parade and the Lighted Boat Parade.
The Talbot Street Parade kicked off in the morning, beginning on Talbot Street at Perry Cabin and ending at Seymour Avenue.
A variety of floats, fire trucks, antique cars and boats towed by trucks made their way down the street as parade-goers watched and cheered from the sidelines. Some of those in the parade came on horseback. There were 46 entries in the parade this year.
Instruments, jingle bells and voices rang through town Saturday morning. From "When the Saints Go Marching In" to Christmas classics like "Jingle Bell Rock" and "Santa Baby," there was something for everybody.
Britany Francis was most excited to see her brother, Weston Dunlap, in the parade. Dunlap joined the St. Michaels Fire Department this year.
"I moved here almost two years ago," Francis said. "So this is my first parade, my brother's first Christmas parade."
Danielle Toth brought her two daughters, Emerson, 4, and Camryn, 2, with her to the Talbot Street Parade this year.
Camryn liked the candy the most but also liked seeing Santa as well as the floats that spouted out bubbles to make it look like it was snowing.
Emerson liked seeing the horses from the Tuckahoe Pony Club and the Maryland Rough Riders.
After the sun set on Saturday evening, the second parade of the day, the Lighted Boat Parade, began. Eighteen boats lit up with colorful string lights and different Christmas decorations traveled around St.
Michaels Harbor.
For the Redl family, who live in northern Virginia but have a house in Bozman, this was their first year seeing the lighted boat parade. The three of them said they would definitely come back to see it again next year.
"I think it was cool to see all these people who took their time to put up cool decorations and then come by and show us those lights," Benjamin Redl, the son of David and Amy Redl said.
Benjamin and David Redl's favorite boat in the parade was one that had three Christmas trees, each covered in a different color of lights. Amy Redl liked the boat that had a lighted image of a dolphin wearing a Santa hat.
"It's a lovely thing that the Town of St. Michaels does for families and everyone," Amy Redl said about the parade. "It's really nice."
Jay and Kim Anderson have been coming to the Lighted Boat Parade for seven years now. The couple from Virginia always walks in the Talbot Street Parade with their two Chesapeake Bay Retrievers and then sticks around for the Lighted Boat Parade.
"You don't see this anywhere else," Jay Anderson said. "I mean we live on a lake in Virginia, and they have started doing the lighted boat parade the last couple of years, but just the it's the town, it's quaint."
Ann Law, who has been to six Lighted Boat Parades in the last seven years, said she lives outside Philadelphia and has seen Philadelphia's boat parade.
"But it's too commercial," she said. "This isn't."
The first place winner of the Lighted Boat Parade was Shannon Pickens' boat, Working Girl, with the theme "Christmas in St.
Michaels."
Emma Brown and Bryan Hines' boat, Harbor Shuttle II, came in second place with the theme "Santa's Workshop."
Basil DeLashmutt's boat, Knot Knormal, came in third place with the theme "Take it to Eleven."
Mike Kuperberg's boat, Karisma, came in fourth place with the theme "It's Five o'Clock on the Chesapeake."
Sam Hughes' boat, Samron, came in fifth place with the theme, "Oysters for Christmas."

title: Brampton Inn Offers Vintage Holiday Celebrations
author: Contributed
content:
Brampton Inn Offers Vintage Holiday Celebrations

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News

 CHESTERTOWN - 'Tis the season to sparkle.The Brampton Inn is igniting the festive season by transforming into a winter wonderland for guests and the community alike. The Italianate-Greek Revival manor house, built in 1860, sets the stage for the inviting, magical ambiance of the holidays.
Take a journey through time as you seamlessly transition between the holidays you experience today and the holidays of the past. Enjoy festive lighting displays, live music, crackling fires and more.
To kick off the holiday season in style, on Saturday, Dec. 16, the Brampton invites you to Celebration de Noel, at the Renaissance Garden terrace. Enjoy a selection of holiday-inspired refreshments from 3:30 p.m. to 6 p.m., along with a special performance by River Voices.
Donning Dickens-style costumes, the ensemble will perform a selection of holiday songs and sing-along carols.
Take a ride with friends and family in a horse-drawn carriage clip-clopping through the historic country estate and enjoy the stunning display of holiday lights.
During the holiday season, the inn is planning an array of experiences for guests looking to enjoy all that Chestertown and Maryland's Eastern Shore has to offer.
For revelers coming in from out-oftown, the hotel provides an uniquely festive atmosphere for holiday get-togethers with friends and family.
Chestertown is the ultimate storybook escape. Celebrate the most wonderful time of the year at Brampton Inn. The inn is decorated with all the trimmings and all accommodations feature a fireplace or wood stove to curl up in front of during your stay, ensuring a serene place to unwind. A roaring fire in the library will set the mood on Christmas Eve and during Christmas dinner for the ultimate winter getaway.
If you are in the mood to celebrate New Year's at the inn, jump, jive and swing into 2024 with Brampton's oneof-a-kind 1940s-inspired New Year's Eve celebration, featuring numerous delights and surprises throughout the weekend.
Enjoy an afternoon end-of-year feast at the Brampton Inn before boarding the historic Chester River Packet for a 1940s inspired cruise, providing the perfect atmosphere for dancing, socializing and fun.
Guests are encouraged to wear vintage attire.
Then celebrate the arrival of the new year in style with a 1940s inspired cruise aboard the historic Chester River Packet on Sunday from 4-6 p.m.
While onboard, guests will enjoy an assortment of decadent cheeses, desserts and drinks (cash bar) and listen to live music while enjoying exceptional views of Chestertown's historic waterfront, sunset and allaround good-time.
Ring in 2024 back at the Brampton - uncork a bottle of bubbly and enjoy a delicious grazing box assortment alongside your loved one.
Delicious, full breakfast prepared with fresh local ingredients each morning and a mimosa or Irish coffee toast.
Reservations can be made directly online at BramptonInn.com or by calling 410-778-1860.

title: Bridge - The Conditions Made It Easy
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The Conditions Made It Easy

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 11 | Section: News 
 
 286
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Karl Marx, that wellknown resident of Highgate Cemetery in London, wrote, "Mankind always sets itself only such problems as it can solve; since, looking at the matter more closely, it will always be found that the task itself arises only when the material conditions for its solution already exist or are at least in the process of formation."Today's deal contains an element of this line of thinking; but please don't deduce that this means I see eye to eye with Mr. Marx on matters political. How should South plan the play in five clubs, given that the trumps are breaking 2-1, not 3-0? West leads the heart king.
True, three no-trump would have been a much easier contract. Maybe North should have rebid three spades over three clubs, but raising with primary support is rarely wrong.
Declarer could have banked everything on the diamond finesse, or he could have hoped for some luck in spades. However, South knew it was best to call on his opponents to play the spade suit for him. He won the first trick with his heart ace, played a diamond to dummy's ace and ruffed a diamond high in hand. He crossed to dummy twice with trumps and ruffed the last two diamonds, thus eliminating the minors. He then exited with his last heart.
Whichever opponent wins the trick won't enjoy the experience. If he switches to a spade, declarer is assured of only one loser there.
And if he returns a red suit, declarer ruffs in the dummy and discards his spade four.
Either way, South loses only two major-suit tricks.
Getting an opponent to help you is a design devoutly to be desired. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: 'This Is Really Cool' - Christmas In Ridgely Draws Thousands
author: Angela Price; Special To The Times-Record
content:
'This Is Really Cool' - Christmas In Ridgely Draws Thousands

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Angela Price; Special To The Times-Record | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 582
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY - Christmas in Ridgely drew thousands of people from throughout the Shore to town on Saturday, Dec. 9, to celebrate the holiday season.The family-oriented winter festival ran from 4 to 9 p.m., and all the attractions were free - ice skating, interactive ice sculptures, trackless train rides, selfie stations, character meet and greets, model trains and more than an acre of inflatables.
"This is great. What a wonderful event. Truly magical," said Trish Murchake of Church Hill, as she watched her granddaughter Leah Thomas, 7, skate on one of two iceless skating rinks set up near the town hall. It was Leah's first time on skates, she said.
Saturday was their first time attending the winter festival, and they were having a lot of fun, Murchake said, adding, "It's the perfect night for it."
While all the attractions were free, there were more than 70 vendors and food trucks for visitors' shopping pleasure.
The Boggs family of Ridgely were enjoying the displays and activities in Railroad Memorial Park. They thought last year's festival was great but said this year managed to top it - more lights, more attractions, more everything.
Steve and Kristel Vacek of Ruthsburg brought their children, Ellie, 8, Jackson, 11, and Mason, 13.
"We missed it last year. There's really a lot to see and do," Steve Vacek said. "This is really cool."
Jenn Lowe and her daughter Ensle Joseph, 5, traveled an hour and a half from Salisbury to enjoy the festivities. Lowe said they were meeting a friend from Goldsboro. They had started on Central Avenue and were working their way through the attractions in the park on their way to the inflatables. Along the way, they got their picture taken in a lighted sleigh and visited Buddy the Elf, who was greeting fans inside a life-size gingerbread house.
Children and families got pictures with Santa inside the train station and told him their Christmas wishes.
Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer, Yukon Cornelius and Abominable Snow Monster greeted visitors next to "The Island of Misfit Toys" display. Frosty the Snowman and Snoopy were also in attendance.
Reggie Cody of Hurlock brought his two kids, ages 4 and 6, to the festival.
"It was great," he said, adding that his children's favorite thing was the bounce house section.
"And the selection of food was good," Cody said. There was something for everyone. Drink choices included hot apple cider, hot chocolate, sodas and bottled water. Food choices ran the gamut from hotdogs and pizza to pulled pork and surf and turf. Cody ate from the Jimmy's Fat Rolls food truck, while the kids had nuggets and fries.
Saturday marked their first visit to the festival, but it won't be their last.
"It's going to be a yearly event for us," Cody said.

title: Tastytv - Flay Gets Festive: All-Star Culinary Colleagues Face-Off In 'Holiday Throwdown'
content:
Tastytv - Flay Gets Festive: All-Star Culinary Colleagues Face-Off In 'Holiday Throwdown'

 December 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A14 | Section: News 
 
 402
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Making Christmas dinner with your colleagues is all fun and games - that is, unless your colleagues are all professional chefs. After seven weeks of cooking alongside some of the best in the game, celebrity chef Bobby Flay ("Bobby's Triple Threat") has one last chance to prove himself a festive-feast champion as "Beat Bobby Flay: Holiday Throwdown" airs its final episode Tuesday, Dec. 19, on Food Network."Food Network's favorites come together for holiday-themed culinary competitions and the chance to beat Bobby Flay," a series description given by the network explains. "In each supersized episode, three chefs must bring their A-game and battle it out over two festive rounds to get to Bobby."
In true "BBF" fashion, the chefs must first compete against each other, creating spectacular dishes that feature secret ingredients of Bobby's choice. Whoever does it best moves on to the final round, then forcing Flay to cook their own surprise signature dish, with Flay testing his culinary prowess against the chef who knows it best. If Bobby can't cut it, the guest chef takes home the greatest prize of all: the pride of knowing they beat one of Food Network's best.
So far, this holiday special edition has seen Sunny Anderson ("The Kitchen"), Darnell Ferguson ("Worst Cooks in America"), Duff Goldman ("Ace of Cakes"), Chris Scott ("The Great Soul Food Cook Off "), Alex Guarnaschelli ("Alex Vs America"), Eddie Jackson ("Outchef 'd"), Michael Symon ("Symon's Dinners Cooking Out"), Antonia Lofaso ("Cutthroat Kitchen"), Damaris Phillips ("Southern at Heart") and more face off against Flay, with guest judges Tiffani Faison ("Duck It!"), Katie Lee Biegel ("The Kitchen"), Carson Kressley ("BBQ Brawl") and Bobby's own daughter, Sophie Flay ("Bobby and Sophie on the Coast"), all stopping in to give their say.
During this upcoming season finale, however, the pressure (cooker) is on, as chef Jeff Mauro ("Sandwich King") taps in as judge and Flay faces his toughest competition yet: Andrew Zimmern ("Family Dinner"), Brooke Williamson ("Top Chef ") and Jet Tila ("Ready Jet Cook").
With a slate of restaurants and businesses to his name, Bobby Flay is hard to beat. But if anyone can manage it, it's one of his Food Network colleagues. As this Christmas-party-turned-food-fight reaches its end, Tila, Zimmern and Williamson hope to take down their very own culinary Goliath.
"Beat Bobby Flay: Holiday Throwdown" airs its final episode Tuesday, Dec. 19, on Food Network.

Bing Crosby Is 'Going My Way' Again For The Holidays

 Turner Classic Movies will be packed with Christmas attractions in the week before the holiday, and one of the most beloved is "Going My Way," the Leo McCarey-directed 1944 drama that earned Bing Crosby an Oscar for best actor.Being shown Tuesday, Dec. 19, the picture also won six other Academy Awards including best picture and best song (for "Swinging on a Star," which became a standard in Crosby's musical repertoire).

Crosby proved so popular in his role, McCarey crafted another film for him in the part: the following year's "The Bells of St. Mary's," which TCM appropriately will show right after "Going My Way."

title: Bridge - The Chimp Is The Champ
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The Chimp Is The Champ

 December 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: B11 | Section: News 
 
 267
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We are supposedly descended from apes; in particular, we admire the intelligence of chimpanzees.Adriaan Kortlandt, who has studied chimps extensively, wrote, "Behind their lively, searching eyes one senses a doubting, a contemplative personality, always trying to make sense out of a puzzling world."
Maybe we should teach chimps bridge. It certainly pays to search through a contract with doubting eyes, looking for the best line of play. In today's deal, how should South plan the play in three no-trump? West leads the diamond queen.
The original declarer won the first trick with dummy's diamond king. (He might have ducked in both hands, but that would have risked a dangerous shift to hearts.) After a club to South's king won, declarer continued with the club queen. However, East won with the ace and returned his second diamond.
Now South couldn't get nine tricks before the defenders took five.
"Why didn't you lead back a low club the second time?" asked North, as irritating partners are wont to do.
"Because I haven't got X-ray vision," replied South curtly.
With six tricks on the side, South needs only three club tricks, and his A-10 of diamonds is safe from attack if West is on lead. So the best play at trick two is a club to South's nine.
West wins with the 10 and switches to the heart queen.
Declarer wins with dummy's ace, plays a spade to his ace and leads the club king.
Unless clubs are 5-1, the defenders can never get more than four tricks: two hearts and two clubs. Here, South wins an overtrick.
©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Celebrityprofile
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
Celebrityprofile

 December 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: A10 | Section: News 
 
 272
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Burl IvesQ: When actors like Burl Ives and Fred Astaire narrated such holiday specials as "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer" and "Santa Claus Is Comin' to Town," were their characters supposed to look like them?
A: Most definitely, though the format also allowed creative liberties to be taken in the seasonal classics made by producers Arthur Rankin Jr, and Jules Bass.
When you look at the character Sam the Snowman in "Rudolph" (being shown on CBS and Freeform this season) and you compare that to the actual image of Oscar-winning talent Ives, there's little question that the character was modeled physically on that actor. That also owes to Ives' performances of such songs as "A Holly Jolly Christmas" and "Silver and Gold" on the soundtrack, where the image certainly relates to the musical success Ives already had had by the time the special first aired in 1964.
Similarly, the mailman who tells the story in the 1970 show "Santa Claus Is Comin' to Town" (an annual ABC attraction lately) is meant to resemble iconic actor-singer-dancer Astaire, right down to his wiry physical build. Though Mickey Rooney voiced Santa in that program, Father Christmas has such a traditional look, the resulting image was sort of a hybrid of that and Rooney's own appearance.
Other examples of veteran talents whose likenesses were used for their animated counterparts in Rankin/Bass shows included Jimmy Durante in "Frosty the Snowman," Shirley Booth in "The Year Without a Santa Claus," Angela Lansbury in "The First Christmas: The Story of the First Christmas Snow," Ethel Merman in "Rudolph and Frosty's Christmas in July" and Danny Kaye in the Easter-themed "Here Comes Peter Cottontail."

title: Calendar
content:
Calendar
