title: Something funny’s going on at the Garfield Center
author: Staff Writer
content:
Something funny’s going on at the Garfield Center

 January 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 768
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — What do you do when, to inherit a large sum of money, you must take a dead guy on his last planned vacation to Monte Carlo? We're all going to find out starting on Feb. 9 with the Garfield Center for the Arts' 2024 Season opener, the over-the-top musical comedy Lucky Stiff.Lynn Ahrens and Stephen Flaherty met and wrote their first song together at the Lehman Engel BMI Musical Theatre Workshop in 1983. According to Ahrens, one song led to another, songs grew into musicals, and musicals grew into a body of work. The two later went on to collaborate on the well-known musicals Ragtime, Seussical and Once on This Island.
Their first successful collaboration, the musical Lucky Stiff, had its premiere at New York's Playwrights Horizons in an extremely limited run in 1988, but had a longer and more successful run at Maryland's Olney Theatre starting in May 1989. It won the 1990 Helen Hayes Award for Best Musical, and landed its lead actor, Evan Papas, an award for Best Actor in a Musical. In 1994, a studio cast recording was released and the musical had its British debut at the Theatre Royal in England, followed in 1997 by a West End production in London. Since then there has been a film adaptation of the musical, and the production has been successfully staged all around the world.
Based on the novel "The Man Who Broke the Bank at Monte Carlo" by Michael Butterworth, the musical tells the story of how London shoe salesman Harry Witherspoon is set to inherit $6,000,000 because his distant uncle, Anthony Hendon, has been murdered. Harry is Anthony's only living relative, but he only gets the money if he takes the embalmed, wheelchair-strapped body on his Uncle's planned vacation to Monte Carlo. Harry must follow his Uncle's detailed itinerary for the trip, or the money will go instead to the Universal Dog Home of Brooklyn, whose director, Annabel Glick, follows Harry, hoping he'll make a mistake. Add in an abrasive gangster's girlfriend, a nervous optometrist, a boisterous Italian playboy, a sexy French cabaret singer, and a variety of other over the top characters, and it all results in a story of mistaken identities, disguises, surprising love interests, plot twists and unexpected reveals.
In the upcoming Garfield Center production, playing the role of Harry is Max Hagan, who appeared at the GCA in Shrek, Prescription: Murder and Sweeney Todd. Playing Annabel is Shannon Carter, who also appeared in Shrek, Sweeney Todd and The Play That Goes Wrong, among others. Melissa McGlynn, who plays Rita, has appeared in countless Garfield productions, including Annie, Shrek, The Play That Goes Wrong and many more. As Vinnie, JW Ruth again appears at the GCA after memorable performances in The Addams Family, Psycho Beach Party and The Play That Goes Wrong. Natalie Hagan returns to the Garfield stage to play Cabaret performer Dominique after her terrific performances in The Addams Family, Prescription: Murder, and Shrek. Matthew Newman, who sings in the Chester River Chorale, makes his GCA stage debut in the role of Luigi. And in the pivotal role of The Body, the GCA is thrilled to announce that longtime favorite Jim Landskroener is back on stage entertaining our community.
The show also boasts a seasoned group of performers in the Ensemble, with each actor-singer playing multiple roles. Appearing in the Ensemble is Heather Joyce-Byers, Nic Carter, Heather Robuck and Steffi Ricketts. Heather Joyce-Byers was last seen as the Narrator in Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat at the GCA. Nic Carter, the Garfield's Theatre Manager, has appeared on our stage many times, including roles in Sweeney Todd, The Play That Goes Wrong, and he directed last season's Prescription: Murder. Heather Robuck and Steffi Ricketts both return to the GCA stage after appearing as Ancestors in The Addams Family.
Directing the production is GCA's Executive Director Steven Arnold, the Music Director is JW Ruth, Choreographers are Jennifer Tosten and Natalie Hagan, the Costume Designer is Barbi Bedell, and the Props Designer is Wendy Wiseman. Jordan Dixon is the Stage Manager, Benji Price is the Sound Engineer, Butch Clark is the Technical Director and Builder, Nic Carter is the Lighting Designer, and Beverly Hall Smith is the scenic painter.
Lucky Stiff opens Feb. 9 and will run weekends through Feb. 25. Show times are 8 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays, and 2 p.m. on Sundays. Tickets may be secured anytime online at www.garfieldcenter.org or purchased in person or over the phone during regular box office hours on Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. The box office number is 410-810-2060. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Mainstay musical events to showcase original talent, tribute to Beatles, and more
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Mainstay musical events to showcase original talent, tribute to Beatles, and more

 January 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Music 
 
 650
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For Marylanders looking for invigorating musical events in the upcoming weeks, The Mainstay in Rock Hall has got you covered.Captain Mark Einstein, owner of Blue Crab Chesapeake Charters, and board member at The Mainstay, a nonprofit music venue on Main Street shared his excitement, "There's lots of cool stuff happening."
Like many personalities you'd meet during open mic nights the second Wednesday of each month, Einstein balances his work on the water, with his entertaining talents. He was recently a participant in "Kent's Got Talent" with his trio "The Singing Captains."
Their now infamous song, "Doin the Rock Hall Rag," had everyone waving towels in the air in bemusement.
He's at it again this year and brought some of his talented friends.
Einstein credited Mainstay Executive Director Matt Mielnick for drawing performers from all over the map to the establishment.
Encouraged by these connections, over the summer, Einstein and a group of talented folks created a local singer/songwriters association, Delmarva Singer/Songwriter's Association (DSSA). They performed in monthly meetings, fostering their gifts and sharing ideas.
Springing out of that came an exciting notion — to do their part to help heal the world through music.
Drawing from music videos like 1985's, "We are the World," which attracted singing sensations like Diana Ross, Prince and Billy Joel, to raise money for famine relief in Africa, the Songwriter's Association decided to make a music video addressing world issues.
With The Mainstay closed during January, Einstein thought that might be the ideal time to work on a video project.
Enthusiastic replies followed.
"We have a multitrack recording device, a PA system, and the ability to stream videos...so why not," he said.
"Songs of Hope 2024" is a compilation of 12 artists performing original songs, each containing an inspiring message. A brief intro explains a little about the artist and his or her message.
The video shoot begins on Jan. 20. Upon completion, it will be available to stream.
Einstein hopes the video inspires a "world needing it." "We're inundated with reasons to be sad," Einstein said. "Wars, elections, and everything. We want to give people a reason to be happy."
He sees music as a great unifier, bringing people together, transcending politics, skin color or age.
A good example of songs bringing people together through the decades are the Beatles oldest works like "All You Need is Love," and "I Want to Hold Your Hand."
Universally known, their music will be performed at The Mainstay on Feb. 7; a tribute to when they first appeared on the Ed Sullivan show Feb. 9, 1964. The project, "Sing-A-Long Beatles USA," is a 60th anniversary tribute, where their famous tunes will be performed by The Mainstay players.
Einstein recalls watching the program on prime time television with his parents. It left a powerful memory, and he was inspired to play the drums when watching Ringo playing left-handed on a right-handed kit.
The audience will hear songs from their first album, "Meet the Beatles," to the more experimental and esoteric, "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band."
For only $10 a ticket, people can sing their favorites while eating oysters, and bond through tunes.
"Everybody knows the melodies," Einstein said. "It's noteworthy because this literally transformed the history of society and culture."
He said there are so many Beatles fans and also excellent musicians, so they put together an ensemble of Mainstay community players, consisting of Mielnick, Barbara Parker, president, and fellow board members.
Sponsors now include, Barts Records and The Listening Room, at 332 and 320 Cannon St. Chestertown. A surprise sponsor is Leland Castro, an impressionist painter from Hawaii. Castro's work can be seen in advertisements for the event and online at https://leland-castro.pixels.com/
Because the Beatles are so all-embracing, the decision to allow the audience to participate was a no-brainer.
"We figured we can't stop them from singing if we tried, so why bother," Einstein said with a chuckle.
In the wait time between Rock Hall's version of "Beatlemania," you might find Einstein performing at Watermen's Crab House on Friday nights. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on local music events, concerts, and a Beatles tribute, which are primarily entertainment news rather than broader cultural analysis.

title: Specters sought at historic Kitty Knight House
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Specters sought at historic Kitty Knight House

 January 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 766
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GALENA — On a blustery, wintry Friday night while some were eating salty treats watching football, guests showed up at the inn, ready to spend hours searching for paranormal clues. They dined, and, like a reality show, they got to know each other, sharing stories that drew them to this particular place at this particular time.Eighteen guests met with Tony Avallone, founder of the Mid-Atlantic Paranormal Project, (MAPP), and seven other members for an overnight investigation a the historic Kitty Knight Inn in Galena.
Their goal, to seek out supernatural activity using Avallone's ghost-tracking equipment.
And for a longtime ghost hunter, Avallone, who's had his share of disconcerting experiences, he wants to bring a positive light, even some fun, to this activity. "MAPP's here to help businesses and families understand the unexplained," he said.
Before embarking on their adventure, guests shared past stories, those having left a phantom handprint on their lives from an early age.
Somebody mentioned their deceased grandfather had appeared to her and told him his feet were cold. Later, when she told her grandmother, she was informed he was buried without shoes on. Some had experienced voices and shadows flitting in and out. Some felt heavy oppression at abandoned penitentiaries where tormented spirits lurked.
Others had doors swing wide open without the wind's provocation, and the doorknob shake violently. One couple said they travel far and wide looking for places like this — open to all phenomenal experiences.
Like any group of adventurers and believers, there was a skeptic among them as well. "I'm just along for the ride," he said, arms folded. He was unsure what the night would bring.
The air crackled with positive excitement that only increased when Avallone introduced himself halfway into their meal. Avallone gave them a rundown on what would happen through the night.
Using electromagnetic frequency detectors to follow electromagnetic activity, audio recorders to track electronic voice phenomena and DVR cameras in every room — a total of 12 devices would run for eight hours, from 8 p.m. to 3 a.m., he explained, the time when it's said that supernatural activity peaks.
The house itself has a mysterious history.
Director of Marketing for the Jamestown Hospitality Group, which owns the property said in an interview with Chesapeake Bay Magazine, "We definitely have chatter about the house being haunted. Guests say that doors will shut, or you'll hear voices when no one is there."
Avallone attested that when previously staying in Knight's bedroom he awoke completely cold. Unexplainable because the thermostat wasn't touched when he watched the footage back.
The night started off slow with little responses in the tavern. Then they broke up in teams of three, rotating through the three main "hots spots" — Room 4, Kitty Knight's Room, where Avallone felt that intense cold years back, Room 8 where a spirit of a little boy they call "Captain" is alleged to resides, and the basement — where voices from the Civil War era and voices of children playing had been reported to be heard.
As the evening progressed, guests donned a blindfold and put on noise-canceling headphones. Known as the Estes method, they listened to what Avallone called, "the spirit box," an AM/FM radio that speeds through the dials so fast no words get through.
But when they do, it is believed to be something speaking from beyond.
It was a big thrill for the guests.
Guests on the other side of the room asked questions and if the guest with the headphones answered, that meant something supernatural was speaking to him or her.
The results were both fascinating and disturbing. "Ninety-five percent of the questions were adequately aligned with the questions asked," Avallone remarked.
In the morning, Avallone met the guests at breakfast and answered their questions. It will take weeks for him to comb through the collected data, but he promised to share the results.
In the several years Avallone has been visiting the inn, he's discovered a whispery, hushed, "Hi," and in the basement sounds of of children at play. He's heard footsteps when all was still and an entire conversation that could have revealed knowledge of an earlier time period.
He's also seen a glowing orb, which looked like a lot of insects in a group, yet not moving like bugs, but more like hovering.
He's seen shadows that looked human-like.
But he's never felt threatened by the Kitty Knight Inn experience.
"Whatever is there, enjoys having the company of the guests," he said.
For those intrigued on the next adventure, don't miss out, the Mid-Atlantic Paranormal Project will be having their last public investigation of the season at Kitty Knight Inn on Feb. 3. Find them on Facebook and Instagram @midatlanticparanormalproject 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a paranormal investigation event presented as a public entertainment experience, fitting the Entertainment category best, with Arts & Culture as a secondary fit.

title: Remembering the Beatles at The Avalon
author: LINDA EVANS Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Remembering the Beatles at The Avalon

 January 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LINDA EVANS Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Entertainment 
 
 319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Avalon Theater of Easton hosted "'1964' The Tribute," an endearing and authentic performance remembering the Beatles, on Jan. 12.Performed with the magic of years gone by, "1964" focused on the time in history when the Beatles first performed in America.
Experienced musicians meticulously recreated the accents, body movements, facial expressions and even toe-tapping to imitate the Beatles for the audience. Instruments styled after those of the '60s were used, and there was lively banter among the performers as well as with the audience.
The hairstyles were modeled after the Beatles' moptops, and after tunes such as "A Hard Day's Night" and "Can't Buy Me Love," the audience seemed to transfix on the stand-ins of John, Paul, George and Ringo.
"It's great to be back here in the colonies," joked John as he played the harmonica as accompaniment.
"We were very impressed with their body language and facial expressions, as well as their vocal impersonations. It felt like we were actually at a Beatles show," said Dr. Jean Carlson of Easton, who attended the show. She mentioned that she had seen the real Paul McCartney five times in the U.S.
As one hit after another rocked the Avalon, a feeling of reminiscence and delight poured over the packed house.
Instead of the swoons of the '60s, there were smiles and deep satisfaction, singing along with the words so remembered as to be never forgotten and recalling thoughts of a simpler time.
The group performs 70 or so shows per year, but this year it has planned at least 80 shows due to an increased demand during the 60th anniversary of the Beatles coming to America.
The Avalon, located at 40 East Dover Street, is a historic theater located in downtown Easton, originally built as a cinema in 1921. The Avalon was billed as the "showplace of the Eastern Shore." Today it serves as the prime venue of the Mid-Shore for the performing arts nationally and locally.

title: Music at the Avalon: Robert Cray Band leads February, March concert lineup
author: Staff Writer
content:
Music at the Avalon: Robert Cray Band leads February, March concert lineup

 January 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1881
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Avalon Theatre in downtown Easton is hosting a number of upcoming concerts and other performances. That includes shows by the Robert Cray Band, local favorites Black Dog Alley as well as Alaina Stacey & Madeleine Kelson.For more on ticket prices and other upcoming events check out https://avalonfoundation.org/
Aleksi Campagne
Saturday, Feb. 10
Doors: 6:30 p.m. / Show: 7 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room
"His performances are impressive not just sonically but also visually as you watch him seamlessly navigate different instruments and languages." Garnette Report Aleksi Campagne is a bilingual contemporary indie-folk fiddle-singer from Montreal. As the son of Canadian Folk icon Connie Kaldor and student of Jazz Violin Legend Didier Lockwood, Aleksi combines his powerful voice with rich songwriting, all while accompanying himself on the violin and seamlessly switching between English and French.
By the age of twenty-five, with only a six-song EP, Aleksi has graced the lineups of some of the most competitive folk festivals across Canada for threeconsecutive years — including the Regina, Canmore, and Bear Creek Folk Festivals.
Robert Cray Band
Thursday, Feb. 15
Doors: 6:30pm / Show: 7:00pm
Avalon Theatre
"Since 1974, The Robert Cray Band has been touring and recording their unique groove, born from a love of Soul, R&B, Gospel, Blues, and Rock n Roll. With over twenty acclaimed albums that have sold millions worldwide, the five- time Grammy winner has also been inducted into the Blues Hall of Fame and earned the Americana Music Awards Lifetime Achievement for Performance.
With Cray's distinctive guitar style and impressive vocals, the band has also had many opportunities to perform with legends like Albert Collins, Muddy Waters, John Lee Hooker, as well as The Rolling Stones, Tina Turner, and Eric Clapton.
Black Dog Alley
Friday, Feb. 16
Doors: 6:30 p.m. / Show: 7 p.m.
Avalon Theatre
"Black Dog Alley has quietly turned into a 'Go-To' Band on The Eastern Shore. Always solid, great set list and a good bunch of guys who just keep getting better and better and never disappoint." WhatsUpMag.com.Easton-based Black Dog Alley is on a mission to move, groove, and rock your very soul.
And with a track record of entertaining audiences across Delmarva and Pennsylvania with hundreds of live performances, they know just how to do it!
Their style draws from influences as varied as Stevie Ray Vaughn, Jimi Hendrix, James Brown, ZZ Top, and Sublime, so their eclectic set list ranges from classic jam rock and rhythm and blues, to funk and reggae-tinged grooves. If you're looking for a home-grown blend of classic and original material, Black Dog Alley will not disappoint."
Ampersand — CD Release Party
Friday, Feb. 23
Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Show: 7 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room
"Called the "Swiss army knife of folk music," this quartet of multi-instrumentalists brings guitar, banjo, mandolin, cello, hammered dulcimer, and penny whistles to underscore their four- part harmonies and great joy in sharing early traditional music with a modern audience.
From Appalachian ballads to sea shanties to Irish dance tunes, this Easton-based group explores the history of early music and its connections to modern folk and blues. Ampersand features Beth Lawton, her partner Dick Hogle, son Topher Lawton, and honorary family member Dave Moore. Favorite venues include Stratford Hall in Virginia, as well as various national park sites and historical societies. Join them as they celebrate their newest CD, "Love Will Find Out the Way," showcasing the music of 1600-1830. www.ampersandmusic.org."
Spy Nights: A Writers Series Word Girls
Wednesday, Feb. 28
Doors: 5:30pm / Talk: 6:00pm
Avalon Theatre
"Continuing the Spy Nights: A Writers Series is the collective brilliance of the "Word Girls". Who are the "Word Girls"? Three gifted poets—Meredith Davies Hadaway, Erin Murphy, and Amanda Newell—with strong local ties to Chestertown, Gunston School, and Washington College. They're all set to captivate audiences with original verses that span environmental, societal, and deeply personal themes.
Meredith Davies Hadaway is the author of three poetry collections, including "At The Narrows" (winner of the Delmarva Book Prize for Creative Writing). She has received fellowships and awards from the Virginia Center for Creative Arts and the Maryland State Arts Council. Hadaway was also recently the Sophie Kerr Poet-in-Residence for Spring 2023 at Washington College. Erin Murphy is the Poet Laureate of Blair County, PA, and the author or editor of thirteen books, most recently "Taxonomies" (2022) and the forthcoming "Human Resources". She is Professor of English at Penn State Altoona and Poetry Editor of "The Summerset Review". She is an alumna of Washington College and UMass Amherst and an inductee in the Blair County Arts Hall of Fame.
Amanda Newell's collection, "I Will Pass Even to Acheron", won the 2021 Rattle Chapbook Prize, and her first full-length collection, "Postmortem Say", is forthcoming in 2023. She is Associate Editor for Special Features and Social Media for the contemporary poetry journal "Plume". Her poem, "A Woman from the Infant Mortality Review Board Calls" won the 2015 Patricia Dobler Poetry Prize.
The Reagan Years — Dance Shindig
Friday, March 1, 2024
Doors: 6:30 p.m. / Show: 7 p.m.
Avalon Theatre
"The Reagan Years recreates all the rad sounds of the 1980s! They're a group of talented musicians with very diverse vocal abilities enablingthem to replicate uncanny versions of the Pop, Rock, New Wave and Heavy Metal hits that defined the MTV Era. The Reagan Years covers all the decade's mega-artists: Bon Jovi, Madonna, Devo, Joan Jett, Def Leppard, Duran Duran, Billy Idol, Journey, Modern English, Guns 'N Roses, A-Ha, ZZ-Top, and so many more! You'll want to sing along with every song! The band pioneered the 80's tribute concept and, like any great idea, many have imitated them, but none have replicated the magic of The Reagan Years!"
www.thereaganyears.com
Alaina Stacey & Madeleine Kelson
Thursday, March 7
Doors: 6:30pm / Show: 7:00pm
Stoltz Listening Room
"Two up-and-coming Nashville talents performing together in the Stoltz makes for one great night of music. The Chicago Sun-Times praises Alaina Stacey's "lush voice, her captivating melodies and lyrics, and her wholly easeful stage presence."
One year after founding the Nashville based Americana group, Maybe April, Alaina appeared onstage with her group at the Wilshire Theatre in Los Angeles, alongside Bonnie Raitt, Kris Kristofferson and The Goo Goo Doll's Johnny Reznick as part of a GRAMMY-week performance called A Song Is Born. Her band has performed at Pilgrimage Music Festival, Merlefest, SXSW, CMA Fest, and other festivals, and won "Americana Group of the Year" twoyears in a row at the Arkansas Country Music Awards.
Madeleine Kelson is a Nashville-based Americana artist who pulls from a rich tradition of folk, country, and Americana, challenging its boundaries as a queer artist to represent the modern world. In 2022, Madeleine released her debut, self-produced album, "While I Was Away," which gained praise from No Depression, has been featured multiple times in NPR, and was a finalist in the Kerrville New Folk competition. Her queer country anthem, "The Way I Do," became a viral TikTok hit with over 1.6 Million views and her new EP, "Where The Spirit Meets The Muscle," is set to come out in February 2024."
Medium Debbie Wojciechowski
Saturday, March 9
Doors: 6:30 p.m./ Show: 7 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room
"Debbie Wojciechowski is a self-proclaimed "normal person" who possesses an extraordinary ability…the ability to communicate with your loved ones on the "other side."
With a Master of Science degree from Johns Hopkins University and a 25-year federal law enforcement career, Debbie has also established herself as an acclaimed and certified Evidential Medium, someone who is able to communicate information from what is beyond this realm. Her federal law enforcement experience coupled with her mediumship gifts enable her to consult on cold cases and missing persons' investigations. Sinceher professional career included extensive work in the areas of mental health and grief counseling, she can often draw on this background during the sensitive readings she gives in private counseling and during public events. Debbie feels both humbled and privileged to channel messages for clients and takes this responsibility very seriously.
Jonathan Richman
Tuesday, March 12
Doors: 7:30pm / Show: 8:00pm
Avalon Theatre
"Richman is one of America's most unique and dynamic songwriters…" — Nashville Scene Called the Godfather of Punk, Jonathan Richman and his former band The Modern Lovers have influenced everyone from the Sex Pistols and Iggy Pop to the Violent Femmes and They Might Be Giants.
After his pop profile was boosted later by appearing on Late Night with Conan O'Brien and in the film "There's Something about Mary," Richman is still going strong in the new century and remains as dedicated as ever to crafting new music, like his latest album, "Want to Visit My Inner House?" (2021).
According to Jonathan, his new music is always his main focus: "Please do not expect old songs. Many singers my age do a retrospective; this show is not like that. It's mostly stuff made up in the last 3 and 4 years…One last thing, my idea of a good show has nothing to do with applause. It's about if all the songs I sang that night were ones that I felt." Prepare to share a unique experience with Jonathan Richman when he takes the intimate Avalon stage!"
An Evening with Tom Rush (accompanied by Matt Nakoa)
Friday, March 15
Doors: 7:30 p.m. / Show: 8 p.m.
Avalon Theatre
"Tom Rush is a gifted musician and performer, whose shows offer a musical celebration…a journey into the tradition and spectrum of what music has been, can be, and will become. His distinctive guitar style, wry humor, and warm, expressive voice have made him both a legend and a lure to audiences around the world. His shows are filled with the rib-aching laughter of terrific story-telling, the sweet melancholy of ballads and the passion of gritty blues.
Rush's impact on the American music scene has been profound. He helped shape the folk revival in the '60s and the renaissance of the '80s and '90s, his music having left its stamp on generations of artists. James Taylor told Rolling Stone, "Tom was not only one of my early heroes, but also one of my main influences." Country music star Garth Brooks has credited Rush with being one of his top five musical influences."
https://www.tomrush.com/
The Last Revel
Friday, March 22
Doors: 7:30 p.m. / Show: 8 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room
"The Last Revel is an acclaimed three-piece folk group from Minneapolis, Minnesota. Utilizing their multi-instrumental abilities, members Lee Henke, Ryan Acker, and Vincenzio Donatelle, bring a full spectrum of modern Americana to life with lush arrangements of three-part vocal harmonies, acoustic guitar, upright bass, fiddle, and 5-string banjo to consistently support impassioned performances of their honest and heartfelt songwriting.
Drawing influence from their salt of the earth Midwest ethos the band's songs so naturally blend the genres of Folk, Old Time String-Band and Indie Rock to create a sound that echoes the current heartbeat of America. Their latest release, Dovetail, highlights each members strength as songwriters and collaborators, and further solidifies their musical foundation."
THE MET: LIVE IN HD ROMÉO ET JULIETTE
Saturday, March 23
Doors: 12:30pm / Show: 1:00pm
Avalon Theatre
"On March 23, two singers at the height of their powers—radiant soprano Nadine Sierra and tenor sensation Benjamin Bernheim—come together as the star-crossed lovers in Gounod's sumptuous Shakespeare adaptation, with Met Music Director Yannick Nézet-Séguin on the podium to conduct one of the repertoire's most romantic scores. Bartlett Sher's towering staging also features baritone Will Liverman and tenor Frederick Ballentine as the archrivals Mercutio and Tybalt, mezzo-soprano Samantha Hankey as the mischievous pageboy Stéphano, and bass-baritone Alfred Walker as Frère Laurent.
This live cinema transmission is part of the Met's award-winning Live in HD series, bringing opera to movie theaters across the globe." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: "An Evening wit Marti Gould Cummings and Peachz" at Church Hill Theater
author: Staff Writer
content:
"An Evening wit Marti Gould Cummings and Peachz" at Church Hill Theater

 January 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 289
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Marti Gould Cummings, a native of Kent County and a New York-based drag queen performer, is returning to the Church Hill Theater for fundraiser of music and laughter."An Evening with Marti Gould Cummings and Peachez" is scheduled for Feb. 17 at 7:30 p.m. Tickets are $35 in advance and $40 at the door. The show benefits Church Hill Theater.
Born and raised in Locust Grove, some of Marti's earliest stage experiences were here at CHT, as a member of the annual summer Green Room Gang Program. Peachez is Peachez Iman Cummings.
"Marti is a world-renowned drag artist who has appeared on Bravo, the Good Network, and Fusion. They made history when they ran for City Council in NYC as the first non-binary and first drag candidate for city office in New York and founded the Hell's Kitchen Democrats. Marti served on the Mayor's Advisory Council on Nightlife and sat on Community Board 9. They were invited to lead a panel at the United Nations making them the first drag artist to do so and have been invited to the White House. Their a film Queen of NY, (October 2023) documenting their campaign is making waves across the film festival circuit," the Eastern Shore theater said in a press release promoting the event.
Peachez is the winner of season 23 of Food Network's "Worst Cooks in America" and was featured in the Hulu hit "Drag Me to Dinner". "Peachez is focused on using her platform to highlight Black queens in the city's seemingly monochromatic nightlife scene," the theater said its show announcement.
For more information or to reserve tickets, call the Church Hill Theatre office at (410) 556-6003, Monday through Friday between 11 a.m. and 5 p.m., or visit their website at www.churchhilltheatre.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

It also touches on cultural aspects of drag performance, placing Arts & Culture as a secondary match, while the fundraising angle gives a modest relevance to Business/Economy.

title: Maryland author pens 'Betrayal on Beltane'
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maryland author pens 'Betrayal on Beltane'

 January 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 933
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland author Carol Amorosi recently self-published her novel "Betrayal on Beltane."The book, which was released Feb. 1, is the inaugural novel in the Dun Cael Mysteries series.
Amorosi, who is from Bryans Road, has also published a three–book series titled "The McKay Mysteries."
She and her husband Dan, who recently moved to Bryans Road, has two cats and a Border Collie/Corgi mix Widgit, the History Hound, who Amorosi said "joins us on our adventures."
To order the book, go to www.amazon.com/Betrayal-Beltane-Cael-Mysteries-Book-ebook/dp/B0CRF5FHD7 or go to https://carolamorosi.com/.
How long have you been writing, and how did you get started?
Writing is something I always wanted to do someday. There just never seemed to be time. Then, in 2020, COVID hit, and the lockdowns where we lived in Germany were tight. When my son challenged me to join a writing course he was doing, I thought it would be a lark, something to fill the time. But I loved it, and I've never looked back.
What inspires you to write?
History. I've always had a fascination with history, especially the everyday lives of people. I want to share that passion with others. My books are written for entertainment but also to let people know that history can be fun.
Do you consider writing to be a career?
As I start the new series, yes, I do. I currently have a three-book series based in Colonial America and have started a new one set in the time of the ancient Celts in Europe.
What kind of writing process do you use?
Most writers are somewhere along the scale between pantsers (who write by the seat of their pants) and plotters (who have every detail worked out before they start). I definitely fall closer to the pantser end of that scale. That is the main reason I write mysteries. There is an underlying story to be resolved, which prevents me from including every cool historical tidbit I learn and keeps me moving.
Who are some of your favorite authors and why?
I love the classic mystery authors such as Agatha Christie, P. D. James, Dorothy L. Sayers, and Ruth Rendell, to name a few. I enjoy their characters, and it's fun to solve the murder along with the protagonist. And I have to admit Ellis Peters' Cadfael series and M. C. Beaton's Hamish Macbeth, with their depictions of a community, heavily influenced my first series, "The MacKay Mysteries."
What are you working on now?
My current work-in-progress is a new series set in a time when ancient Celts dominated mainland Europe. Recent archaeological finds paint a different picture of these people than was previously known from the writings of the Romans and Greeks. While we lived in Bavaria (ancient Bohemia), I became fascinated by the art and culture of this early civilization.
What do you want readers to know about you?
I already mentioned I love history. My second passion is travel. I love to explore new places. Being married to a retired Naval aviator who still works for the Navy means we've moved a lot. And I've enjoyed every moment of it, especially the years we spent in Italy, Greece, and Germany. I have a daughter in North Carolina and a son in England, so I hope to continue traveling.
Please include a brief description of your book
Born into the warrior elite, Jannon showed great promise as a fighter. But that life was not for him. Despite his father's intentions, he fostered with the Master Bronzesmith to learn his trade.
But when a dead man is found in the smithy, his father demands he return home. In desperation, Jannon and his friend, Leuca, embark on a perilous journey to uncover the truth behind the stranger's death. Amidst a web of motives and treachery, they unearth a series of events leading to a shocking betrayal that threatens the very heart of their tribe.
Will their quest for justice expose the culprit in time, or is the village's fate sealed?
Please include an excerpt from the book
In the early morning hours, Jannon returns to the smithy after a night at his family home.
As Jannon opened the door, he heard a rustle in the dim interior. Someone moved inside. He froze in the doorway. "Who's there?"
"It's me," Garos answered. Jannon could barely make out the figure of the young lad sitting on his sleeping bench. "When did you get up?"
"Get up? What do you mean?" Jannon asked.
"From the workbench." Even in the dim light, Jannon saw Garos' eyes grow wide as he stared at the table.
Jannon's eyes followed the boy's gaze. The light was beginning to filter through the window cover, revealing a dark shape on the workbench. Someone was sleeping on the top. Chills ran down his spine. "Who is that?"
"I t-t-thought it was you." Garos stuttered, pulling the fur tighter around him.
As Jannon crossed the room, a beam of light broke through the mist and shone through a slit in the hide covering. Jannon stiffened momentarily, stopping in his tracks. Then he slowly approached the other side of the workbench, not quite believing what he saw.
"Light a torch," he told Garos.
The young lad's face was pale as he crawled from under the pelts. But he quickly rushed to the shelf to grab a pine stick coated in pitch. He plunged it into the banked embers of the hearth. Flickering light illuminated the space immediately surrounding him. When Garos joined Jannon on the other side of the table, he sharply sucked in a breath.
In the light, it was clear — a man sprawled face-down on Jannon's workbench. A dagger stuck out of his back. Once again, red blotches splattered across the surface — but this time, it was blood. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is an interview with a local author about a newly released novel and is placed in the newspaper's Entertainment section, making Entertainment the most appropriate category, with Arts & Culture as a close secondary fit.

title: Smithsonian Gardens present annual orchid exhibition
author: Staff Writer
content:
Smithsonian Gardens present annual orchid exhibition

 January 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 457
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Smithsonian Gardens and the United States Botanic Garden present "The Future of Orchids: Conservation and Collaboration" now through April 28, filling the entire Kogod Courtyard of the Smithsonian American Art Museum and National Portrait Gallery with around 350 live orchids.The display will feature a series of newly commissioned and loaned works by contemporary multimedia artist, Phaan Howng, to help audiences visualize the future of orchids and be inspired to take action toward a sustainable future.
Centered around the themes of the future of orchids and orchid conservation, the exhibition will explore the numerous challenges facing wild orchids today, including climate change, habitat destruction and over-collecting, and offer a glimpse into the work being performed today by a diverse group of scientists and conservationists to protect the future of orchids. The exhibition will inspire visitors to take action to support orchid conservation and introduce young visitors to career opportunities in conservation.
"'The Future of Orchids' is a rare and spectacular opportunity to take a deep dive into the weird and wild world of orchids," said Joy Columbus, director of Smithsonian Gardens. "The exhibit celebrates the diversity of orchids, which, with an estimated 30,000 species, is one of the largest and most diverse families in the plant kingdom. With this immersive exhibit, visitors can check out their bright colors, showy patterns and unexpected forms, and maybe catch a smell of their wildly varying aromas too."
The 2024 orchid exhibit will feature artworks by Howng, who is known for her large-scale paintings and immersive installations that explore the complex relationships between humans and nature.
Baltimore-based Howng will present a series of newly commissioned paintings and sculptures, titled "The Orchids' Fungi Garden Paradise," which includes her "Mountains" series. She drew inspiration for her work from Smithsonian Gardens' vibrant Orchid Collection. Howng adapted 3D scans of orchids created by the Smithsonian Digitization Program Office, which specializes in advanced 3D imaging of the Smithsonian's collections.
Sculptures inspired by these 3D digital renderings will be showcased alongside hundreds of colorful orchids from the Smithsonian and U.S. Botanic Garden's living collections.
"It is a joy to continue this collaboration to spotlight the beauty of orchids, the challenges they face and the opportunities we have to save them," said Susan Pell, executive director of the U.S. Botanic Garden. "Both of our institutions help conserve rare and endangered orchids through our international collections stewardship and our collaboration on the North American Orchid Conservation Center."
This orchid exhibition is the 28th annual collaboration between Smithsonian Gardens and the U.S. Botanic Garden. The annual exhibition was established to provide the public with the opportunity to learn about both institutions' rich and biodiverse orchid collections.
The Smithsonian Gardens Orchid Collection, which was started in 1976, contains more than 5,000 species and hybrids. Visit gardens.si.edu to learn more. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article announces a public exhibition of orchids with artistic installations, fitting the newspaper's Entertainment section, while also relating to arts & culture and environmental conservation.

title: Tred Avon Players seeking directors, assistant directors
author: TRED AVON PLAYERS
content:
Tred Avon Players seeking directors, assistant directors

 February 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TRED AVON PLAYERS | Section: Entertainment 
 
 257
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Tred Avon Players is a nonprofit organization with a commitment to enriching, educating and entertaining its community through high-quality theater on the Shore. The organization has thrived over the decades, and its success is attributed to the steadfast support of hundreds of local performers, production crews, audience members and donors.Planning is underway for Tred Avon Players' 2025 Season, and they are seeking proposals from directors and assistant directors. TAP invites artists from the community who are passionate about bringing theater productions to life to join in this exciting endeavor.
ProposalsIndividuals with prior experience directing theater and who want to contribute to TAP's vibrant community should send a proposal to info@tredavonplayers.org. Please include "Director Submission" in the subject line. You may also call 410-226-0061 with questions.
Proposals must include a resume of theatrical and directorial experience, along with a brief description of why he or she wishes to direct with TAP and the advantage they will bring to the production. Multiple proposals may be submitted.
TAP directors and assistant directors receive a modest stipend and production budget.
Submission DeadlineProposals are due by March 1. A committee appointed by the TAP Board of Directors will carefully assess proposals and scripts. Selected directors and assistant directors will be notified once the review process is complete.
Approximate 2025 season dates
Feb 13, 14, 15, 16, 21, 22, 23Apr 17, 18, 19, 20, 25, 26, 27Aug 14, 15, 16, 17, 22, 23, 24Oct 23, 24, 25, 26, 31 Nov 1, 2
To learn more about Tred Avon Players, visit www.tredavonplayers.org and follow Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

title: Chesapeake Music bringing Ensemble/132 to Ebenezer Theater
author: Staff Writer
content:
Chesapeake Music bringing Ensemble/132 to Ebenezer Theater

 February 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 324
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Chesapeake Music will present an exciting program for its Interlude concert on March 10 at 2:00 p.m. at Easton's Ebenezer Theater."A piano quintet of artists from ensemble/132 will delight the audience with a one-of-a-kind chamber music experience. The quintet includes pianist Sahun Sam Hong, violinists, Abi Fayette and Stephanie Zyzak, violist, Luther Warren, and cellist, Zachary Mowitz. Chesapeake Chamber Music patrons will remember Sahun Sam Hong and Zachary Mowitz as members of the Trio St. Bernard, the 2018 Lerman Gold Prize winner of the Chesapeake Chamber Music Competition" the Easton-based music nonprofit said in a press release promoting the performance.
"I'm particularly excited for ensemble/132 to bring this delightfully eclectic program to Chesapeake Music. It shows so much of what chamber music can be. Every piece has something entirely unique to offer, whether it's Haydn's exquisitely and cleverly crafted trio, a dramatic cast of characters such as those in Schumann's Carnaval, Perkinson's thrilling blend of a jazz idiom with a classical approach to counterpoint and form, or Petrouchka with its timeless story, its folk dances, and its symphonic scope. It doesn't hurt that Sam's arrangements — Carnaval and Petrouchka — capture the essence of these wonderful pieces while bringing a new palette of colors that we all get to explore together," Cellist Zachary Mowitz said.
Ensemble/132 is comprised of eleven chamber musicians. Marcy Rosen, Artistic Director of Chesapeake Music, is the artistic advisor to ensemble/132.
For more information and to purchase tickets, please visit the Chesapeake Music website at https://chesapeakemusic.org. There you will find information for upcoming events including the 11th International Chamber Music Competition on April 13, community concerts featuring Competition finalists on April 14, the Chesapeake Chamber Music Festival running June 7 through June 15, the Steven Philip Harvey Octet on July 20, and the Isidore String Quartet on October 5.
Based in Easton, Maryland, Chesapeake Music is a nonprofit organization whose mission is to bring renowned jazz and classical musicians to the Eastern Shore.

title: Ice cream for breakfast?
author: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com
content:
Ice cream for breakfast?

 February 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 376
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Is there anything more fun than eating a big bowl full of ice cream for breakfast?If you were lucky enough to be in downtown Stevensville Saturday morning, Feb. 3, at the Tasty Toucan Ice Cream Shop you'd know the right answer to that question.
Hosting her third annual Ice Cream for Breakfast Day celebration, owner Nikki Neboshynsky said, "I learned about this day as a member of the National Ice Cream Association. They put out information about things like this every year. They told us it was one of the biggest ice cream promotions, so we joined in three years ago."
Neboshynsky, who won a national award at the annual Ice Cream Convention in Las Vegas last year for her handmade natural fruit popsicles, is no stranger to being creative. And she's all about serving quality products.
All of the ice cream sold at the Tasty Toucan is 100%, "cow to cone," made on the Eastern Shore.
The menu included a variety of breakfast-inspired treats, including a donut sundae, a hot cocoa float, a cinnamon-roll-inspired ice cream sandwich, a Pop-Tart milkshake and even a unique bacon sundae.
National Ice Cream for Breakfast Day was started by a mom of six living in Rochester, New York, during the mid-1960s. It was late January, and schools were closed due to a raging blizzard there. It was too cold to go outside, and the children were restless.
The mom, Florence Rappaort, is purported to have announced to her children, "Okay, we're going to have ice cream for breakfast."
The family continued to enjoy the event once every winter. It became a family tradition. Over the years, the family served the ice cream, topping breakfast items such as pancakes, waffles and donuts.
When the children went off to colleges, they shared their tradition with their college dorm colleagues. From there, it grew in popularity with students going home and sharing it with other family members. The tradition continued to spread.
Somewhere in this creation, the first Saturday morning in February became the nationally recognized day of celebration. Neboshynsky notes one of their regular customers recalls her family partaking in the tradition when she was a child.
"We're going to continue to do this the first Saturday in February every year," said Neboshynsky. "It's a lot of fun." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: The King's Singers head back to Maryland
author: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com
content:
The King's Singers head back to Maryland

 February 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 398
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Although February may be the shortest month of the year, even during a leap year when a 29th day is added, the renowned musical group The King's Singers will endure a very busy schedule beginning with a concert at the St. Mary's College of Maryland on Friday, Feb. 16, that will feel like a homecoming event.The King's Singers are comprised of six male members listed alphabetically Nick Ashby, Christopher Bruerton, Edward Button, Patrick Dunachie, Julian Gregory and Jonathan Howard. Included among the group named in honor of King's College in Cambridge, England, where the original group was formed are two baritones, two countertenors, one bass and one tenor.
"This is the group's first time in St. Mary's City in recent history," Johnathan Howard, who sings bass for the group, said. "And I know that the group is very excited to perform here as the first stop on this month's tour of the United States of America. The group has an extraordinary history of performing in Maryland, and it always feels like a homecoming when we land in the state for the first time after an extended absence."
Having earned the reputation of having established the veritable gold standard among a cappella singing group's on the world's greatest stages for over 50 years, The King's Singers will only make a brief stop at the St. Mary's College of Maryland for one concert. Their travels resume almost immediately with concerts slated every two days through the remainder of the month before making the long trek for a performance in Nanjing, China on March 9.
"This concert is a deliberate mix of music from lots of favorite recent projects," Howard added. "Including music from our 'Finding Harmony' album that celebrates songs from brought people together throughout history, our 'Tom & Will' album [which includes music by two of England's greatest renaissance composers] and 'When You Wish Upon a Star.' The concert is designed to feel quite a wild ride, and we're really excited to take the audience on the journey with us."
Renowned largely for their unrivaled technique, musicianship and versatility, which stem from both the group's rich heritage and its drive to bring an extraordinary range of new and unique works, collaborations and recordings to life, The King's Singers extensive discography has led to numerous awards, including two Grammy Awards, an Emmy Award and a place in "Gramophone" magazine's inaugural Hall of Fame. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: "The subtle beauty of sitting still': Glen Phillips, Shawn Mullins at Rams Head on Stage
author: Staff Writer
content:
"The subtle beauty of sitting still': Glen Phillips, Shawn Mullins at Rams Head on Stage

 February 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 489
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Glen Phillips — who was the lead singer and main songwriter for Toad the Wet Sprocket — and Shawn Mullins will perform at Rams Head on Stage on Thursday, Feb. 22.The show starts at 8 p.m with doors opening at 7 p.m.. Tickets are $39.50.
"During his years as lead singer and main songwriter of Toad the Wet Sprocket, Glen Phillips helped to create the band's elegant folk/pop sound with honest, introspective lyrics that forged a close bond with their fans. When Toad went on hiatus, he launched a solo career with Abulum, and stayed busy collaborating with other artists on various projects including Mutual Admiration Society, with members of Nickel Creek and Remote Tree Children, an experimental outing with John Morgan Askew," Rams Head said in a write up on the upcoming concert.
"Until recently, I've seldom allowed myself to stay in one place for very long," Phillips said in the Rams Head announcement, explaining the genesis of his new album, There is So Much Here. "I was lucky during the COVID lockdown to move in with my girlfriend, now fiancée, and to stay home for the longest stretch I've had since the birth of my daughter, 20 years ago. I began noticing the little things. After a life of travel and seeking out peak experiences, I began to appreciate the subtle beauty of sitting still."
Phillips continues:
"I've been playing a songwriting game with Texas folksinger Matt The Electrician, for about ten years. Every Friday, he sends out a title. We have a week to write a song that includes it. The process allows me to write songs I wouldn't write on my own. When my friend John [Morgan Askew] asked me to come up to his studio and make music, I said, 'Yes!' I collected a bunch of the new songs and headed up to Bocce Studios, in Vancouver, Washington. John invited drummer Ji Tanzer and bass player — / — multi-instrumentalist Dave Depper along. When we started playing, I wasn't sure we were making an album, but as the process unfolded, the songs began to make sense to me," he said, according to Rams Head.
"After a series of indie releases and growing buzz in the Atlanta music scene, Shaw Mullins' critical and commercial breakthrough came when 1998 Soul's Core shot him to fame on the strength of Grammy-nominated No. 1 hit, "Lullaby" followed by AAA/Americana No. 1 hit "Beautiful Wreck" from 2006's 9th Ward Pickin' Parlor," the concert announcement reads. "Shawn revisited the music of Soul's Core by recording two new versions of the album. He calls this Soul's Core Revival. This is not a remix or a remaster of the original, but rather brand new recordings with new arrangements of the songs — one album is stripped down solo performances, some on guitar, some on piano and maybe one a cappella and the second is a new studio recording with his full band, Soul Carnival."
For more: https://www.ramsheadonstage.com/

title: Smithsonian presents Mother Tongue Film Festival, 'Finding Balance'
author: Staff Writer
content:
Smithsonian presents Mother Tongue Film Festival, 'Finding Balance'

 February 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 756
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The annual Mother Tongue Film Festival will take place at the National Mall in Washington D.C., from Wednesday, Feb. 21, to Saturday, Feb. 24.Featuring 23 films in 27 languages from communities around the globe, the festival will explore the theme "Finding Balance" through personal journeys and will examine the path to building harmony within our world, societies, families and selves.
The ninth annual festival will open on the United Nations International Mother Language Day and take place in various locations in Washington, D.C. All screenings are free and open to the public.
"From children to adults, families to the individual, we are highlighting the unique journeys of people searching for enduring balance and harmony," said Joshua Bell, festival co-director and chair of anthropology at the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History. "We could not be more excited to bring these beautiful and important films to viewers."
"Language is culture," said Amalia Córdova, festival co-director and supervisory museum curator of world cultures at the Smithsonian's Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage. "In our efforts to strengthen cultural knowledge, it's crucial that people have access to diverse stories through the lens of language diversity. The festival will be another opportunity for filmmakers to connect audiences to these stories."
The Mother Tongue Film Festival is hosted by Recovering Voices, an initiative of the Smithsonian founded in response to the global crisis of cultural knowledge and language loss.
Viewers can visit the Mother Tongue Film Festival webpage at mothertongue.si.edu for the schedule and registration. All screenings and events are free.
Festival highlights include:
Opening ceremony and "Frybread Face and Me"
Wednesday, Feb. 21, 7 p.m. at Smithsonian's National Museum of the American Indian
Following opening remarks from Smithsonian organizers, the festival presents "Frybread Face and Me." The film features two adolescent Navajo cousins from different worlds who bond during a summer herding sheep on their grandmother's ranch in Arizona while learning more about their family's past and themselves. The screening will be followed by a Q&A with Charley Hogan, who plays one of the film's protagonists, Frybread Face.
Regeneration
Thursday, Feb. 22, 7 p.m. at Smithsonian's Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden
Stories of loss, revelation and recovery can lead people on the path to restoring a sense of wholeness. In this program, which features films "Mother's Tongue" and "Mamá/Mom," youth confront generational trauma and seek to break through for a brighter future. Following the screening, the audience is invited to stay for a Q&A with "Mamá/Mom" director Xun Sero.
Bridging Worlds
Friday, Feb. 23, 7 p.m. at Planet Word
In this program, two films intersect at the crossroads of love and resistance. "Aikane" and "Y SŴN" illustrate the spiritual connections that can be formed and the cultural ties that can be broken in the fight against political repression. Though artistically varied, both display the transformative power of commitment, be it to a person or a cause, iterating the fight for identity as a universal narrative. The screening will be followed by a Q&A with "Y SŴN" director Lee Haven Jones and Eoghan O'Regan, the deputy head of North America from the Welsh Government based in the British Embassy.
Hidden Letters
Saturday, Feb. 24, 1 p.m. at Smithsonian's National Museum of Asian Art
Nüshu, a clandestine language created and used solely by Yao women in Hunan Province, offers a unique legacy that unites its practitioners. Delving into the lives of women in modern China bound by the once-secret script, "Hidden Letters" is a poignant exploration of female bonds and the generational echoes of gendered oppression in China. The documentary artfully portrays two women's journeys as they grapple with the complexities of independence and traditional expectations that both define and confine them. The screening will be followed by a virtual Q&A with one of the film's directors, Violet Du Feng, diving deeper into Nüshu's enduring legacy.
About the festival and Recovering Voices
All films are fully open captioned or subtitled in English. American Sign Language interpretation will be provided for all introductory remarks, Q&As and discussions. All venues are wheelchair accessible. For questions about access services, email folklife@si.edu.
This film festival has received support from Arenet, the Embassy of Mexico in the United States, Ferring Pharmaceuticals, the Mexican Cultural Institute of Washington DC, Planet Word, The Elizabeth and Whitney MacMillan Endowment, and Wick and Bonnie Moorman.
Recovering Voices is an initiative of the Smithsonian works with communities and other institutions to address issues of Indigenous language and knowledge diversity and sustainability. Recovering Voices is a collaboration between staff at the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History, National Museum of the American Indian, Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage and Asian Pacific American Center. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article announces and describes a film festival, a cultural event focused on movies and screenings, which aligns most directly with the Entertainment category, while also relating to Arts & Culture.

title: 'Charley's Aunt' kicks off Church Hill Theatre 2024 season
author: Staff Writer
content:
'Charley's Aunt' kicks off Church Hill Theatre 2024 season

 February 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 298
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "Charley's Aunt", by Brandon Thomas, will start off the Church Hill Theatre's 2024 season.Directed by Charles Michael Moore, "Charley's Aunt" will run at the Rock Hall theater from March 8 to 24, with a new evening starting time at 7:30 p.m.
"Who knew that class, gender, sexism and patriarchy were such burning (and hilarious) issues that "Charley's Aunt" would smash attendance records when it opened at London's Theatre Royal in 1892? Almost a century-and-a half later, the issues are just as relevant—and the comedy is just as fresh. We all know the title but few of us have seen the play. This superlative revival makes us wonder where Charley's aunt has been all those intervening years.," CHT says in a press release promoting the play.
"The Oxford undergrads are Jack Chesney (Dominic Delcoco), Charley Wykeham (James Fordi), and Lord Fancourt Babberley (Ian Stotts). Jack's dashing father, Colonel Sir Francis Chesney, is played by Patrick Pearce. Eddie Vance plays Brassett, the devious college scout. Amy Spettigue (Izzie Squire Southworth) and Kitty Verdun (Noelle Wheeler) are hounded by their guardian Stephen Spettigue (Gil Rambaugh). The mysterious, but not old and ugly, Donna Lucia D'Alvadorez is portrayed by Minnie Maloney. Her lovely young friend, Eli Delahay, is played by Brianna Johnson," according to the
Charles Michael Moore, who recently appeared in CHT's "Harvey", teams with producer, Bonnie Hill, and stage manager, Jean Messick. Others on the production team include Doug Kaufmann, Earl Lewin, Cassi Pinder, Connie Fallon, Tina Johnson, Wendy Wiseman, and Carmelo Grasso.
"Charley's Aunt" opens March 8 and runs until March 24, with performances at 7:30 pm on Fridays and Saturdays and at 2 pm on Sundays. Tickets are available by calling the CHT office at 410-556-6003 Monday through Friday between 11:00 a.m and 4:30 p.m., or on the CHT website: churchhilltheatre.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article announces a theatrical production and provides performance details, which aligns directly with the Entertainment category. Arts & Culture is a close secondary fit, while Business/Economy is less relevant.

title: Crawfish boil and muskrat leg eating world championship has "cult" following, back for 14th year
author: Staff Writer
content:
Crawfish boil and muskrat leg eating world championship has "cult" following, back for 14th year

 February 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Life 
 
 371
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — The Annual Crawfish Boil and Muskrat Leg Eating World Championship will bring muskrats, crawfish, blues music and fun to Cult Classic Brewing Company in Stevensville on Saturday, Feb. 17, from noon to 6 p.m."We're psyched to be hosting the 14th Annual Crawfish Boil and Muskrat Leg Eating World Championship," Rohry Flood of Cult Classic fame said. "It's a perfect partnership of the weird and wonderful things we love about where we live and the crazy creativity of our neighbors."
The fan-favorite Muskrat Leg Eating World Championship welcomes any aspiring or established competitive eaters confident enough to tackle this unique Eastern Shore specialty.
"If you are looking for a good place to have fun, this festival is the place," defending world champion Chunky Hesson said. "I'm looking forward to retaining my championship as an elite muskrat leg eater."
The competition will kick off at 5 p.m., with contestants competing to see who can eat the most muskrat legs. Registration will be open day of the festival at the t-shirt tent.
The musical entertainment will kick off at noon with local favorite "Hit Man" Eddie Hitt bringing his Bloody Mary's and Karaoke until 2pm.
Then, D.C. Blues Legend Jimmy Cole (JB Hutto) will bring his "Delmarva All-Stars" to the stage from 2 p.m. until 5 p.m. Ron Holloway (Gov't Mule, Dizzy Gillespie) will be on tenor sax. Sam Paladino will be on the Hammond Organ. George Sheppard (Frank Sinatra, Frank Zappa) will be on drums. Bryan Smith (Tennessee Rockets, Billy Hancock) will be on bass. Jimmy Stepanson (Blue Dogs) will be on lead guitar.
Palm Beach Willies (Taylors Island) will be preparing muskrat in multiple ways in addition to other choices for those not-so-adventurous. And, of course, there will be crawfish from Louisiana! Craft vendors will also be on hand again for the event this year.
This is a family friendly event.
Admission is $10 and supports multiple local charity organizations.
"We've crafted a unique event that still manages to be authentic to Eastern Shore living," Event Organizer Keith Graffius said. "This is a great opportunity to experience the best of it — food, drink, music and a family-friendly atmosphere."
For more information about the Crawfish Boil Muskrat Stew Fest visit the Facebook event page at facebook.com/crawfishboilandmuskratstewfest/ or email muskrateatingworldchampionship@gmail.com.

title: The most American pop culture phenomenon of them all
author: Katherine Meizel The Conversation
content:
The most American pop culture phenomenon of them all

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Katherine Meizel The Conversation | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1152
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "American Idol" was "born" exactly nine months after 9/11. The timing was significant, because since its premiere on June 11, 2002, the show has become an integral part of the country's coping strategy — a kind of guidebook for our difficult entry into the 21st century.By carefully curating a distinctly American mix tape of music, personal narratives and cultural doctrine, "American Idol" has painted a portrait of who we think we are, especially in the aftermath of tragedy, war and economic turmoil.
As the show concludes after 15 seasons, it's worth looking at how the past and present collided to create a cultural phenomenon — and how we're seeing shades of the show's influence in today's chaotic presidential race.
All our myths bundled into one
The premise of "American Idol" — the idea that an ordinary person might be recognized as extraordinary — is firmly rooted in a national myth of meritocracy.
This national narrative includes the dime-novel, rags-to-riches fairy tales of Horatio Alger, which were intended to uplift Americans struggling to get by after the Civil War. Then there was the American Dream catchphrase — first coined in 1931 by James Truslow Adams in his book "The Epic of America" — that promoted an ideal of economic mobility during the hopeless years of the Depression.
Indeed, decades before host Ryan Seacrest handed out his first golden ticket to the first golden-throated farm girl waiting tables while waiting to be "discovered," we'd been going to Hollywood in our dreams and on screen.
The show has shown us archetypes of immigrant narratives, like when Season Three contestant Leah Labelle spoke of her Bulgarian family's defection to North America during Communist rule. It has demonstrated how to rely on faith in the face of hardship, exemplified by Fantasia Barrino's victory song, "I Believe," performed with a gospel choir. Meanwhile, it served as a stage for patriotic passion, broadcasting two performances of Lee Greenwood's "God Bless the U.S.A." when the United States entered Iraq in 2003. Meanwhile, the many "Idol Gives Back" specials remind us of American philanthropic values.
The show has celebrated failure as both a necessary stumbling block and a launchpad to fame. Many singers needed to audition year after year before they earned their chance to compete. For others, such as William Hung, their televised rejection brought fame and opportunity anyway.
"American Idol" has also served as a course in American music history, featuring discrete genres like Southern soul and Southern rock, together with newer, blurrier categories like pop-country and pop-punk.
Making the old new again
In one sense, "American Idol"'s format was nothing new. In fact, British entertainment executives Simon Fuller and Simon Cowell — who shepherded in a 21st-century version of the "British Invasion" — fashioned their juggernaut show as a new take on old business models.
There is something distinctly American about contestants standing in a Ford-sponsored spotlight, judges sipping from Coca-Cola glasses, and viewers sitting in front of television screens texting their votes on AT&T phones. The show's conspicuous commercialization recalls the earliest days of television, when programs were owned and produced by advertisers. And "Idol," like that early programming, was intended to be "appointment television," bringing families together at the same time every week.
"Idol"'s production model is also a throwback. It's structured like Berry Gordy's Motown — a one-stop fame factory that offers stars a package of coaching, polishing, a band, album production and promotion.
The format also draws from amateur regional and national radio competitions of the early 20th century. (Frank Sinatra got his start winning one on "Major Bowe's Amateur Hour" in 1935, with the Hoboken Four.) Another influence is the half-ridiculous and totally political "Eurovision Song Contest," the hugely popular and mercilessly mocked annual televised event that pits nation against nation in (almost) friendly singing competition.
A vote that counts?
"Eurovision," which originated in 1955 as a test of transnational network capabilities and postwar international relations, introduced telephone voting a few years before "Idol" premiered.
And like Eurovision, the impact of "American Idol" extends far beyond our annual crowning of a new pop star. The show's rise has taken place at a time when the boundaries between entertainment, politics and business have become increasingly blurred.
Season after season, "American Idol" fans have placed votes for their favorite contestants — options which, somewhat like our presidential candidates, have been carefully cultivated by a panel of industry experts looking for a sure bet.
The initial success of "Idol" heralded not only an era of similar television programming, but also a new era in which we're given the opportunity to "vote," whether it's for dum-dum pop flavors or the world's most influential people.
Considering these trends, it's not so farfetched to suggest that the wild popularity of shows like "American Idol" played some role in setting the blinding chrome stage and slightly "pitchy" tone for this year's election.
It isn't just that Donald Trump presided over "The Apprentice," a reality competition that rode in on "American Idol"'s coattails.
His persona also seems to meet the same sadistic public need satisfied by original "Idol" judge Simon Cowell: the executive heir, the imperious arbiter of taste who owes his fortune at least as much to his superiority complex as to any financial acumen. At the same time, personas like Cowell and Trump deign to give an ordinary, hardworking American a chance.
That conceit, though, is mitigated cleverly by both moguls: they capitalize on what Cowell has identified as a universal desire to feel important.
The crux of their personal appeal is that they understand that everyone wants to matter, and we are willing — as TV viewers or as citizens — to risk an awful lot just to feel like we do. We each want to imagine our own sky-high potential, and laugh in relief when we see others who will never get off the ground. We want to be judge and jury, but also be judged and juried.
"Idol" gives Americans permission to judge each other, to feel like our opinion makes a difference. Trump's unfiltered rhetoric has done something similar, giving his supporters implicit and sometimes explicit permission to mock, dismiss, exclude and even attack others based on racial and ethnic identity, religion or ability.
And so now, as "Idol" makes its final journey from Studio 36 to the Dolby Theatre, we deliberate over whose victory will herald the last "Seacrest — out."
Whatever happens, and whichever way our presidential election goes, the U.S. is on the brink of something new, a major cultural shift. Wherever we're going, "Idol" has served its purpose, and we don't need it in the same desperate way anymore.
I think, though, that we'll always be searching for the next big thing. And we'll always be glad we had a moment like this.
Katherine Meizel is an associate professor of ethnomusicology at Bowling Green State University.
(The Conversation is an independent and nonprofit source of news, analysis and commentary from academic experts.This article is republished from The Conversation under a Creative Commons license. Read the original article here: https://theconversation.com/the-most-american-pop-culture-phenomenon-of-them-all-56555. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the cultural impact of the TV show "American Idol," focusing on its role in pop culture and media, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment topic.

title: From 'Blue Bayou' to 'Your No Good': Linda Ronstadt Experience heading to Maryland
author: Staff Writer
content:
From 'Blue Bayou' to 'Your No Good': Linda Ronstadt Experience heading to Maryland

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 246
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There are scores of cover bands dotting the American music landscape performing at venues across country.Then there are next level cover acts rekindling the music of next level musical arts.
The Linda Ronstadt Experience — which features American Idol vocalist Tristan McIntosh — has upcoming Maryland shows Feb. 29 in Annapolis at Rams Head on Stage and March 1 in Havre de Grace at the Star Centre.
The group will cover Ronstadt's hits including "You're No Good," "When Will I Be Loved," "That'll Be The Day," "Blue Bayou, " "Different Drum" as well as hits from Jackson Browne, Tom Petty, Little Feat and other rockers.
Ronstadt had scores of hits and platinum albums and set the tone and stage for female vocalists during her reign in the upper echelons of popular music.
The Leap Day (Thursday, Feb. 29) show at Rams Head starts at 7:30 p.m. Doors open at 6:30 p.m. Tickets are $28.50
"American Idol Star Tristan McIntosh creates a stunning portrayal of Linda Ronstadt in the prime of her career. Supported by a superb backing band, Tristan's formidable vocal talent and stage presence will transport you to a time when Linda Ronstadt ruled the airwaves as one of the most popular female vocalists in music history," a Rams Head announcement of the concert reads.
The Havre de Grace show at the Star Centre is at 8 p.m on Friday, March 1. Tickets ranged between $39.50 and $65.
For more on the shows: https://starcentremd.com/events/ and https://www.ramsheadonstage.com/
