title: Maryland author tells of learning to be a commercial fisherman
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maryland author tells of learning to be a commercial fisherman

 April 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 409
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Deborah Curtis recently published her inaugural book "A Day of Crabbing on my Daddy's Boat" through Dorrance Publishing.The Maryland author, who is retired from her job as a certified medical assistant, loves nature walks, crafting, sewing, creating a bird sanctuary in her backyard and reading mystery novels.
Curtis, who lives in Lusby, also said she enjoys spending time with her six grandchildren, who are between the ages of 1 and 18.
She said she selected Dorrance Publishing after it was recommended by a friend.
The book retails for $23 and can be found at https://bookstore.dorrancepublishing.com/a-day-of-crabbing-on-my-daddys-boat/.
How long have you been writing, and how did you get started?
This is my first book. I always wanted to write a children's book on the life of a waterman mainly because I never saw one and having worked in the school system for over 30 years in the Bay area, I truly believed it was important to let the younger generation know about this occupation. It was a big part of our lives.
What inspires you to write?
Wanting the young to know and understand the occupation of a commercial fisherman.
Do you consider writing to be a career?
No, strictly a hobby.
What kind of writing process do you use?
Narrative.
Who are some of your favorite authors and why?
Agatha Christie, fell in love with her when I read "Murder on the Orient Express" back in 1973, Leslie Wolfe and Michael Connelly and numerous other mystery authors. I love suspenseful murder mysteries that keep you turning the pages. However, I don't believe they influenced me to become a children's book writer. It is just something I always wanted to do.
What are you working on now?
Currently nothing, however if "A Day of Crabbing on my Daddy's Boat" does well, I would like to continue with the family tradition that has been passed on to the next generation and possibly do "A Day of Oystering on my Mommy's Boat."
Please include a brief description of the book
[The book is] an endearing story narrated by Melissa who's father is a commercial fisherman. She explains and shows you through pictures what it takes to be a commercial fisherman crabbing on the Chesapeake Bay. Put on your life preserver and hop aboard to discover this amazing world.
Please include an excerpt from the book
"I warn Crystal of the danger of putting her hand in the basket of live crabs. The claw of the crab is very powerful and could cause a great deal of pain if it pinches you." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Fair Hill family and its 'star' pet dog featured on television show
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Fair Hill family and its 'star' pet dog featured on television show

 April 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1116
 Words 

 Read News Document

 All five members of the Sottnick family in Fair Hill, Maryland made their television debut this week. But the star of the show was the family's beloved pet Corgi — Ollie.Wizard of Paws, an animal-niche program that airs on BYUtv, Hulu and Disney+, featured the Sottnicks and 3-year-old Ollie on a 27-minute Season 6 segment that premiered on Sunday (April 14).
Derrick Campana, who owns and operates Bionic Pets in Sterling, Virginia., is the Wizard of Paws host. Campana specializes in crafting custom-made prosthetics for animals with missing limbs.
Campana has successfully created prosthetic limbs for an array of deformed animals, including foxes, goats, rabbits, ducks and all sorts of other birds and even an elephant in Thailand.
The gist of Wizard of Paws: On each episode, Campana and his film crew travel to the home of a selected family that owns a pet with a missing or deformed limb and then he builds a prosthetic designed exclusively for that animal.
Through on-camera interviews, owners of the handicapped pets tell their stories. The show's nail-biting climax always hinges on this: Will the pet accept or reject its new prosthetic and will it help the animal walk and run better?
The Sottnicks were selected for the show because Ollie was born with a deformed front limb because of condition known as ectrodactyly, a term used mostly by veterinarians. Laypeople commonly refer to it as "split-foot" or "lobster claw."
"Ollie is basically a tripod," Kara Sottnick said, explaining that standing and walking was difficult for Ollie because both rely heavily on balance. "He could actually run better than he could walk."
The Sottnicks also were picked because of the upbeat vibe that the family projected during a couple of Zoom interviews with Wizard of Paws producers, after Kara had emailed information about her family and Ollie as the first step in the process for show consideration.
"They are just as interested in the family's story as they are their pet's story," Kara said.
In addition to Kara, the Sottnick family includes her husband, Kris, who is an aviation inspector, and their three children — Gavin, 21, who works at Williams Chevrolet in Elkton; Abrey, 20, who works at Elkton-based Terumo Cardiovascular; and Kody, 17, who is a junior at Tri-State Christian Academy, also in Elkton.
(In addition to Ollie, the non-human side of the Sottnick family includes two other pet dogs — 7-year-old Toby and 3-year-old Huxley, both of which are Cavalier King Charles Spaniels; and an outdoor cat named Little Pea.)
BEHIND THE SCENES
So Campana and a seven-person film crew came to Fair Hill in October and spent five days at the Sottnick's home. Campana brought his mobile lab, so he could create the special prosthetic limb for Ollie on location while filming the Wizard of Paws segment that is cleverly and appropriately titled, "Ollie, Ollie, Running Free."
The crew members filmed for four days, between eight to 10 hours each day before heading back to their hotel after every session. Filming also involved cameramen getting B-Roll away from the Sottnicks' property. The crew, for example, went to a historically-significant spot known as The Beehive on Telegraph Road (Route 273) in Fair Hill and filmed the annual Apple Butter Festival held by the Elk Creek Land Preservation Society.
"We absolutely fell in love with the film crew and Derrick (Campana). We became friends with them," Kara said. "The sound guy is in a band out in L.A. On breaks, he and Gavin would go into our basement and jam together on the guitars and drums."
Kara made friends with the producer who hails from Australia and they still keep in touch through email and social media. Abrey and a personal assistant on the crew also hit it off, piquing her interest in that profession.
The crew brought breakfast for the Sottnicks every morning when they arrived and also treated them to lunch, with all that food coming from Cecil County restaurants. Crew members also provided cupcakes and sang "Happy Birthday" to Gavin when he turned 17 during the filming week.
After the last day of filming, the Sottnicks, in turn, treated the crew to dinner at Schaefer's Canal House in Chesapeake City to show their appreciation. Earlier in that week, the Sottnicks also treated the crew members to cider doughnuts from Milburn Orchards near Elkton, providing another opportunity for them to sample local food favorites. "They loved the cider doughnuts," Kara said.
Campana was affable and accommodating, too. "He cared for us and for Ollie's needs above the filming. He made sure there were plenty of breaks," Kara summarized.
As for the "Ollie, Ollie Running Free" segment's moment-of-truth ending (SPOILER ALERT, if the title didn't already give it away), Kara commented, "He loved it, and took to it right away. There was a 50/50 chance that the prosthetic would work."
In addition to the free prosthetic limb for Ollie, the Wizard of Paws representatives gifted the Sottnicks with six free hydrotherapy sessions for Ollie at BluePearl Pet Hospital's rehabilitation center in Newark, Delaware.
PATH TO 'PAWS'
Interestingly enough, Kara's goal wasn't for her family and Ollie to be featured on Wizard of Paws. In fact, she didn't know that the TV show even existed when she embarked on her original quest — getting a prosthetic limb for Ollie.
The Sottnicks are dog lovers. They strive to always have two dogs in their home for the sake of pet companionship. After Rigley died from cancer in 2020, the remaining pet dog, Toby, was alone. So the family started searching for another pet dog — specifically a Corgi.
In a way, the Sottnicks picked the runt of the litter after meeting with the breeders, who, as it turns out, did not even advertise Ollie, most likely because of his deformed front limb.
"I think they saw him as problematic. It was almost like they discarded him," Kara said, before remarking, "But we thought he was absolutely adorable. He was so cute and we were up for taking on the challenge. We sort of rescued him."
After consulting with the veterinarian, Kara started exploring the possibility of getting a prosthetic limb for Ollie and, during her research, she learned about Campana's business, Bionic Pets. When she visited its website, Kara learned that Campana was a TV star.
"That's when I learned about the show," Kara explained.
Having worked as a hairdresser until 2020, Kara now devotes her time to "building Ollie's social media account." OllieTheTripodCorgi can be found on YouTube, Facebook, Instagram and TikTok, she noted.
Reflecting on the week-long Wizard of Paws filming in October and this week's premiere of the segment featuring her family, Kara marveled, "I would have never guessed in a million years that they'd pick us to be on the show. The filming of it was the highlight of 2023 for us." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a family’s appearance on a TV show about a pet dog, which is primarily entertainment news, with secondary mentions of animal prosthetic health.

title: CBMM's Members-Only Marina goes high tech
author: Staff Writer
content:
CBMM's Members-Only Marina goes high tech

 April 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 251
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum in St. Michaels has streamlined the process of making reservations at its Members-Only Marina through a new partnership with industry technology leader Dockwa.CBMM members can nw reserve marina slips via Dockwa's web portal and app. The Dockwa app is free for iPhone and Android through the App Store and Google Play.
"We believe this is a game-changer for our Members-Only Marina," CBMM's Vice President of Engagement Shannon Mitchell said. "Dockwa makes booking a reservation quick and easy. A majority of our members are already using the platform, so we anticipate a seamless transition."
CBMM's Members-Only Marina offers 55 slips with electric, pump-out service, climate-controlled showers, Wi-Fi, and other amenities. Hourly and overnight docking are available on the St. Michaels museum's waterfront campus along the Miles River,. More information, including an updated Boaters' Guide for the 2024 season, is available at cbmm.org/docking.
Dockwa offers marina management software company with more than 2,000 partner marinas, 300,000 active boaters, and 10 million nights booked across the U.S. For more: dockwa.com and accessible via cbmm.org/docking.
Members are encouraged, but not required, to create a Dockwa account to book overnight reservations. Requests can also be made by contacting the marina via phone (410-745-4946) or email (dockmaster@cbmm.org).
Overnight docking is reserved for CBMM members at the Mariner level and above, while Household level members and above have hourly docking privileges, with the slips first-come, first-served if space is available.
To purchase a CBMM membership visit cbmm.org/memberships or contact Membership Services Coordinator Debbie Ruzicka at 410-745-4991 or druzicka@cbmm.org.

title: Explore Maryland: Dance and cheer at annual Celtic Festival
author: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com
content:
Explore Maryland: Dance and cheer at annual Celtic Festival

 April 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 481
 Words 

 Read News Document

 This Saturday, rain or shine, the Celtic Society of Southern Maryland will host the 45th annual Southern Maryland Celtic Festival at Jefferson Patterson Park in St. Leonard where guests of all ages can gain an appreciation for the various traditions that have stood the test of time for centuries.With the unmistakable sound of bagpipes providing the audible background for those on hand, the Southern Maryland Celtic Festival along the scenic banks of the Patuxent River that buffer Jefferson Patterson Park is traditionally a cheerful endeavor for guests.
In all, the seven Celtic Nations will be celebrated on April 27 in a cheery, festive occasion complete with food, music and dancing associated with the various groups.
"We are so fortunate to have this gem of a festival in Southern Maryland," Kaitlyn Likas said in a previous interview. The Patuxent High School graduate who grew up in St. Leonard has become a fixture among the various musicians who annually perform at the festival along with Pond Scum, a St. Mary's County band. "I can't wait to return home for my hometown festival and make more memories and reunite with some old friends."
Much of the music will be provided by various internationally known Celtic bands, which will perform on various stages dispersed throughout the grounds. In addition to the music, dancing and jam sessions that will be immediately noticeable, onlookers can learn more about the Celtic heritage at Clan Row, an informative assemblage where more than 50 clans and societies will be featured and highlighted.
Guests are also encouraged to stop by the Celtic marketplace onsite for a wide selection of traditional and non-traditional Celtic foods and gifts providing an old world atmosphere. Attendees are also encouraged to check out the Children's Highland Games and the all-day competitions taking place throughout Jefferson Patterson Park on Saturday, again regardless of the elements, which will include pipers, drummers, pipe bands, highland dancers, highland athletics and rugby games.
Also, guests are reminded that they should park in general parking and then be prepared to wait in line for entry if you have no pre-purchased tickets. No pets are allowed on the grounds during festival hours on Saturday and guests can not bring alcoholic beverages onto the site, but alcoholic beverages of various kinds, primarily with a Celtic theme, will be available for purchase at various spots throughout the grounds.
If you go
The Southern Maryland Celtic Festival will take place this Saturday, April 27, from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., rain or shine, at Jefferson Patterson Park, located at 10515 Mackall Road in St. Leonard.
General admission is $25 (pre-sale) and $30 at the gate for those 13 and older Children 6 to 12 are $5, while those 5 and under get in free with an adult. Tickets can be purchased by credit card only; no cash sales at the gate.
For more information and a map of the grounds, visit the website www.cssm.org.

title: Explore Maryland: Boyz II Men, Cole Swindell to play marine museum
author: Staff Writer
content:
Explore Maryland: Boyz II Men, Cole Swindell to play marine museum

 April 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 283
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Boyz II Men and Cole Swindell will perform concerts this summer at the Motto Mortgage Preferred and RE/MAX One Waterside Pavilion as part of the Calvert Marine Museum's Waterside Music Series.Boyz II Men will perform at the museum in Solomons on Friday, June 28, and Cole Swindell will take the stage on Aug. 16. Both concerts are scheduled for 7 p.m. at the Calvert Marine Museum.
With a string of Grammys, American Music Awards, Soul Train Awards, Billboard Awards, a Hollywood Star on the and more, Boyz II Men is a powerhouse in the music industry.
Their chart-topping hits like "End of the Road," "I'll Make Love To You," and "One Sweet Day" have become timeless classics. As the best-selling R&B group of all time, the group's smooth harmonies and enduring themes continue to resonate with fans worldwide.
Tickets for the Boyz II Men concert are $59-$99 and will be available at the museum's website at 10 a.m. April 23 for museum members and 10 a.m. April 26 for the general public.
Multi-platinum-selling superstar and ACM award-winner Cole Swindell's fourth studio album Stereotype has been a massive hit and produced multiple No. 1 hits like "Never Say Never" featuring Lainey Wilson, "Single Saturday Night" and his 3-time platinum-selling "She Had Me At Heads Carolina." Nashville-based rising country artist Noah Hicks will be the opening act.
Tickets for Swindell's concert are $49-$99 and will be available at the museum's website at 10 a.m. April 23 for museum members and 10 a.m. April 26 for the general public.
Proceeds from the concert series support education and preservation efforts of the Calvert Marine Museum.
For more information about the concerts, membership or upcoming events, call 410-326-2042, ext. 8063, or go to www.calvertmarinemuseum.com.

title: Star Democrat launches weekly online podcast
author: JIM JOHNSON
content:
Star Democrat launches weekly online podcast

 April 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JIM JOHNSON | Section: Columns 
 
 432
 Words 

 Read News Document

 This week the Star Democrat started creating a weekly podcast, highlighting newspaper stories from the previous week.The podcast is posted on StarDem.com under the multimedia section on Monday mornings. The podcast is compiled by Managing Editor Wendy Weitzel.
For those who have not listened to a podcast before, it is just an audio version of a story, similar to a radio broadcast.
To create the podcast, we are using software called Speechify Studio, which generates voices to "read" the stories. The podcast is about 5 minutes long. Each is designed so you can listen to them in your car on your way to work or school or while you are doing a workout or taking a morning walk.
While we are starting out producing these podcasts once per week, we may do them more frequently in the future.
I'd love to hear what you think about the podcasts. Do we feature the right stories in them? Are they too long or too short? Will you listen to them regularly? Send me a note at jjohnson@chespub.com.
The podcasts were a suggestion from the Star Democrat Reader Advisory Board, a group of readers who meet with the newspaper's top managers and offer suggestions on ways the newspaper can improve. The board meets quarterly.
The advisory board is not the only way we receive feedback at the Star Democrat. Readers frequently will call and tell us what they thought about an article that appeared in the newspaper. We hear comments from people in the community as we go about our lives — at church, in the grocery story and at meetings we attend. All comments, as long as they are not flaming diatribes, are taken seriously and discussed as we continuously strive to make the newspaper better.
If you have comments about anything in the newspaper, please reach out to me at jjohnson@chespub.com or calling me at 410-770-4060.
We had some great stories in the Star Democrat this week. If you missed any of them, you can find them on the StarDem.com website.
Man arrested in kidnapping, murder of woman in Cambridge.
Oxford clerk-treasurer takes oath of office.
Colonel strikes early, hangs on late in baseball.
Saints top Eagles, stay unbeaten in baseball.
Women to Watch event recognizes more than 200 local leaders.
Talbot Council approves Resolution 338 and its amendment.
'I am speechless:' TCPS awards teacher, support staff of the year
Easton Town Council passes cannabis ordinance.
Colonels upend unbeaten Queen Anne's in softball.
Local religious leaders pray for prosperity in upcoming crab, clam, fishing seasons at Blessing of the Fleet.
Jim Johnson is the executive editor of the Star Democrat. He can be reached at jjohnson@chespub.com

title: Unlock the secret to a perfect, stress-free Mother's Day
author: Samantha Erb Food Drink Life
content:
Unlock the secret to a perfect, stress-free Mother's Day

 April 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Samantha Erb Food Drink Life | Section: Entertainment 
 
 951
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Samantha ErbFood Drink Life
Don't spend Mother's Day faking a smile. From self-care rituals to low-stress family activities, here's how to actually enjoy your day.
This Mother's Day, you can have everything you want and need to make your day special. You just have to ask for it.
If you're a mom, you've probably experienced the unpleasant feeling of Mother's Day plans gone wrong. Perhaps you were surprised with a pancake breakfast — and the bonus gift of having to clean it all up afterward. Or maybe you were hoping for some quality family time, but no one made time for you.
This year, you deserve a Mother's Day that doesn't involve faking happiness when you're actually feeling disappointed. So why not ask for it? And if you don't know where to start, keep reading for a list of effortless options that can restore the joy, relaxation, and family bonding that Mother's Day should be all about. After all, it's your day.
A peaceful, grounded start to your dayWhoever came up with the idea of a loud, messy and chaotic breakfast in bed to kick off Mother's Day definitely wasn't a mom. In the immortal words of Chief Hopper, "Mornings are for coffee and contemplation." So if you're not into getting toast crumbs all over your sheets, why not start a new tradition?
Think about what you'd actually like to get out of your morning, and then tell your family so that it actually happens. Maybe your perfect morning involves reading a book or taking a solo walk to a coffee shop. If possible, ask your partner to step in so that you aren't dealing with childcare during what ought to be a restful morning.
Easy activities and recipes to enjoy as a familyIf quality time with your children is an important part of your Mother's Day, choose manageable activities that won't get out of control. Playing a board game or doing a puzzle together is a great way to bond as a family without the mess of elaborate craft projects or baking endeavors.
Getting in the kitchen is another easy way to spend time together with a fail-proof recipe like three-ingredient peanut butter balls. With minimal cleanup — that will ideally be taken care of by someone else — and no baking involved, these treats will still allow your family to feel like they're spoiling you on your special day.
On Mother's Day, take time for yourselfMother's Day can be complicated. Having a difficult relationship with your own mom or dealing with grief are just a few of the factors that can make Mother's Day an emotionally charged time.
If you would benefit from having time to yourself on Mother's Day, ask for it. Working on your favorite hobbies, trying an art or fitness class, getting your nails done or just lounging around on the sofa are all excellent ways to take care of yourself on your special day.
Whatever you do, just don't feel any pressure to cook, clean, run errands or otherwise be helpful. Enjoy your relaxation time, because you've more than earned it.
Low-stress family outingsDoes your ideal Mother's Day involve a family outing? A simple picnic in your local park can be a stress-free way to enjoy the outdoors together. Gather some sandwiches, water bottles and healthy-ish snacks like fresh fruit and fruit dip. Better yet, let someone else pack the picnic basket and you're ready for a fun-filled afternoon in the sun.
Let your family treat you to Mother's Day dinnerDepending on how old your kids are, you can wrap up your Mother's Day by preparing a favorite meal together. Cooking together in the kitchen, especially if someone else washes the dishes, can be just as meaningful as enjoying the meal itself. End your night sweetly with an easy dessert like canned peach pie, which only requires ten minutes of prep time.
If you don't even want to think about the kitchen during Mother's Day, why not order your favorite takeout food for dinner? This easy option gives your family plenty of time to decompress, especially if you've had a day packed full of activities.
End the day with a cozy family movieCan anyone say no to a family movie night? Cuddling up together and watching a movie before bed is a great way to conclude Mother's Day. Laughing over a favorite film or discovering a new one together is the perfect way to wind down the day. Alternatively, let the kids have a movie night while you and your partner enjoy some alone time.
Practicing gratitude as a familyTowards the end of the day — perhaps over dessert, or just before bed — take a moment to reflect upon what everyone was grateful for during Mother's Day. It might sound cheesy, but acknowledging the love and effort that your family members put in can start a beautiful new tradition that will ultimately bring the family closer.
A Mother's Day tradition worth startingInitially, asking for what you want on Mother's Day might feel overly demanding. It's ironic that even on a day that's supposedly for them, moms are expected to put their families first.
A self-planned Mother's Day doesn't have to add a ton of items to your to-do list, either. A simple conversation with your family before the big day, or even on the morning of, will keep your Mother's Day from falling flat. Sometimes, dropping a hint just isn't enough.
If all else fails, just send your loved ones a link to this article. Then, get ready to enjoy a day that is truly focused on you. You — and all moms everywhere — deserve it.
Samantha Erb is the owner of Everyday Family Cooking, a recipe website focused on providing simple meals with few ingredients that still pack on the flavor. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article offers lifestyle advice, recipes, and activity ideas for Mother's Day, fitting the Entertainment section's focus on leisure and personal enjoyment rather than strictly health, education, or other categories.

title: 'The Sum of Me' is one man's journey of discovery, redemption
author: Staff Writer
content:
'The Sum of Me' is one man's journey of discovery, redemption

 May 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 480
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Mark Brundage Odom recently self-published his book "The Sum of Me."Odom spent more than 10 years as a K9 Officer of a bomb detection dog and a 20-year career with Homeland Security as an Inspector for Federal Protective Service before retiring in March.
Originally from Pittsburgh and having traversed the globe in his formative years, the U.S. Navy veteran enjoys flying airplanes, scuba diving, classic cars and riding motorcycles. He now lives in Prince Frederick with his wife Ariane.
The book is the story of how the 58-year-old Odom embarked on a profound journey to piece together the intricacies of his identity and trace his roots. He said penning the book was because of his "desire to help others is the overwhelming reason" but also "a way to document for my own family the heritage and mystery."
The 160-page book retails for $15 and is available at www.barnesandnoble.com.
How long have you been writing, and how did you get started?
I have been writing a few years, I got started writing when I began my research to discovery my biological Father. I got started from documenting my research and journaling my feelings.
What inspires you to write?
My inspiration comes from a desire to use my story to help someone else.
Do you consider writing to be a career?
I recently retired from my career in federal law enforcement. Writing has been both therapeutic and a new hobby.
What kind of writing process do you use?
My process has been based on investigation, documentation and introspective feelings released on paper.
Who are some of your favorite authors and why?
Toni Morrison and Maya Angelou express the African American experiences and stories that are so relatable to all people.
What are you working on now?
I just published The Sum of Me and will be working on promoting it.
What do you want readers to know about you?
I want readers to know their circumstances alone does not determine their destiny. I want them to be inspired and motivated to control their destiny.
Please include a brief description of your book.
According to a news release, the book is "the deeply personal story of his quest to uncover his biological father's identity. Raised by his stepfather with little knowledge of his true paternal lineage, Odom's curiosity about his origins grew over the years, fueled by his mother's silence and subtle family dynamics.
In his fifties, Odom confronts the secrets of his family's past, discovering the identity of his biological father. This revelation, while initially unsettling, leads to a journey of healing and newfound purpose. Through his struggles with conflicting emotions, Odom aims to shed light on his experiences, offering solace and guidance to others grappling with similar questions of identity and heritage.
"The Sum of Me" is a raw and honest exploration of the complexities of self-discovery, resonating with readers who have faced similar challenges. Odom's memoir is a testament to resilience and the universal human desire for truth and belonging. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: The Wailers, Southside Johnny highlight upcoming shows at Avalon Theatre
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
The Wailers, Southside Johnny highlight upcoming shows at Avalon Theatre

 May 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1410
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Avalon Theatre in downtown Easton has an upcoming slate of shows that includes reggae stalwarts The Wailers, New Jersey rockers Southside Johnny & The Asbury Jukes and other performances. The music and performing arts venue is located at 40 E. Dover Street in Easton. Here's a rundown of upcoming shows with performance descriptions from the Avalon.For ticket prices and more show and venue information at the Avalon and its Stoltz Listening Room online check out avalonfoundation.org.
The Met: Live in HD Madama Butterfly
Saturday, May 11th
Doors: 12:30pm / Show: 1:00pm
Avalon Theatre
Extraordinary soprano Asmik Grigorian tackles the demanding role of Cio-Cio-San, the loyal geisha at the heart of Puccini's devastating tragedy. Tenor Jonathan Tetelman stars as the callous American naval officer Pinkerton, whose betrayal destroys her. Mezzo-soprano Elizabeth DeShong reprises the role of the steadfast maid Suzuki, and baritone Lucas Meachem is the American consul Sharpless. Acclaimed maestro Xian Zhang takes the podium on May 11 to conduct Anthony Minghella's vivid production. This live cinema transmission is part of the Met's award-winning Live in HD series, bringing opera to movie theaters across the globe.
Dar Williams with Guest Heather Maloney
Saturday, May 11
Doors: 7:30 a.m.; Show: 8 p.m.
Avalon Theatre
Dar Williams' lyrics contain bouquets of optimism, delivered on melodies alternating between beguiling lightness and understated gravity.
Always in the right place at the right time for the success she's had over a 25+year career, Dar rose out of the vibrant mid-90's Boston scene, inspired by the eclectic influences of alt-rockers, Berklee jazz musicians, slam poets, and folk artists like Patty Griffith, Melissa Ferrick, the Throwing Muses, Vance Gilbert, and Jonatha Brooke.
Through all the ups and downs, however, it's always been about staying true to herself. "Good and bad things happen, and it's not necessarily a reward or indictment. I've just got to meet it," she observes. "Like, I'm bringing my whole life to this moment; it will surprise me, challenge me, show me where I was wrong, even make a fool out of me, but my job is to show up and not take adversity personally. Real happiness doesn't have to feel like Snoopy dancing with Woodstock; it can just be knowing you have the resilience to meet whatever comes to you. I will call that a good life."
Dar will be joined by special guest Heather Maloney, a Massachusetts-based singer songwriter whose voice is her "not-so-secret weapon" (Boston Globe) and whose "lyrics cut to the chase" (Huffington Post).
Minor Gold
Wednesday, May 15
Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Doors: 7 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room
Minor Gold are ARIA-nominated artists Tracy McNeil and Dan Parsons. Canadian and Australian, respectively, this Trans-Pacific duo echo '70s cosmic Americana with an easy charm and potent honesty.
The strength of the songwriting and the indeterminate perfection of how these two artists' voices lock in together hit right where the emotions live inside us. With dynamics ranging from the intense restraint of campfire intimacy through to open-throttle abandon, Minor Gold delight and enthrall as they weave masterful harmonies and deft guitar playing around unforgettable, stripped-back performances.
Since releasing their critically acclaimed self-titled debut album in August 2023, the duo have been on the road—recently returning from a 30-date North American album tour with supports for The Teskey Brothers and an official showcase at AmericanaFEST in Nashville, as well as the 2024 Folk Alliance International in Kansas City. https://www.minorgoldmusic.com/
Julian Brezon
Friday, May 17, 2024
Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Show: 7 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room
New York-based Easton native Julian Brezon returns to the Stoltz with a stellar quartet presenting jazz standards and original compositions. As a saxophonist, composer, and educator, Julian brings a fresh ear to the world of modern creative music. His compositions strike a delicate balance of harmonic adventurousness and familiar listenability while his takes on standards blend a love of tradition with an ear for experimentation.
Julian recently earned his Master of Music degree in jazz performance at the City College of New York in Harlem. He has studied with jazz greats Gary Thomas, Steve Wilson, Jason Rigby, and Vincent Herring. https://www.julianbrezon.com/
Boy Band Review
Saturday, May 25
Doors: 6:30 p.m.; Show: 7 p.m.
Avalon Theatre, 40 E. Dover Street, Easton, MD
Boy Band Review is THE best boy band tribute show in the country! They have played numerous high-profile events, private engagements, a Las Vegas residency at Planet Hollywood Casino, performed with Chris Kirkpatrick of NSYNC joining the band for multiple shows, and selling out countless venues across the country to capacity crowds.
Having captured the hearts of fans with their #boyband shows that transport audience members back in time to the days of frosted tips and hunky front-men professing their undying love. The #boyband shows are an incredible throwback experience reliving your best years with a full band, choreography, and harmonies.
They are playing to capacity crowds nationwide…so don't let this opportunity to see them perform in the Avalon go "bye bye bye"!
https://boybandreview.com/
Carpool — Cars Tribute Band
Saturday, June 1
Doors: 7:30 p.m.; Show: 8 p.m.
Avalon Theatre
Carpool is a tribute band that recreates the sound, feel, look and vibe that made the Cars world famous. The band is comprised of five of the best and hardest working full-time musicians in the Atlanta area. Their performances meticulously capture the sleek, synth-heavy, steady-beat and driving-guitar sound that made the one-and-only Cars so awesome.
A Carpool show helps you "shake it up it" and takes you right back to when the Cars were (and continue to be) the soundtrack of our lives, reminding us all of why the Cars hold a very special place in our hearts and minds. https://carpooltributeband.com/
Mutlu
Thursday, June 6
Doors: 7:30 p.m.; Show: 8 p.m.
Stoltz Listening Room
A Philadelphia musician who proudly carries a torch for the city's soul legacy, Mutlu (pronounced moot'-lu) makes a connection with every audience. Coming up in the Philly scene, he played around town and in area clubs before landing his first tour opening for Joe Jackson. Since then he's toured across the U.S. and Europe with his musical brother, Amos Lee, who discovered Mutlu's music just as both of their careers were taking off.
In addition, he's found an advocate with Daryl Hall & John Oates, who invited Mutlu to support a national theater tour. http://www.mutlusounds.com
Southside Johnny & The Asbury Jukes
Friday, June 7, 2024
Doors: 7:30 p.m
Avalon Theatre, 40 E. Dover Street, Easton, MD
Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes emerged from the New Jersey shore scene in 1974, and though they carried over a significant influence (and some key personnel) from Bruce Springsteen & the E Street Band, the Jukes evolved as more of an R&B horn band in the Memphis Stax Records tradition.
Organized by singer John Lyon, guitarist/songwriter Steve Van Zandt (who decamped for the E Street Band in 1975, but continued to produce, manage, and write songs for the Jukes) and Richie Rosenberg, the band is well known for high-energy shows and no-holds-barred songs, including "I Don't Wanna Go Home," "Havin' a Party," "The Fever," "Talk to Me," "Trapped Again," and "This Time It's For Real."
Still tinged with the exuberant rhythm and blues feel that is the Jukes' trademark, and loaded with the driving sound of the legendary Jukes horn section, Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes continue to expound their signature Jersey Shore sound – all for the sheer joy of it. https://www.southsidejohnny.com/
The Brothers Comatose
Thursday, June 20
Doors: 7:30 p.m.; Show: 8 p.m.
Avalon Theatre
Whether traveling to gigs on horseback or by tour bus, Americana mavens The Brothers Comatose forge their own path with raucous West Coast renderings of traditional bluegrass, country and rock 'n' roll music. The five-piece string band is anything but a traditional acoustic outfit with their fierce musicianship and rowdy, rock concert-like shows.
The Brothers Comatose is comprised of brothers Ben Morrison (guitar, vocals) and Alex Morrison (banjo, vocals), Steve Height (bass), Philip Brezina (violin), and Greg Fleischut (mandolin, vocals). When they're not headlining The Fillmore for a sold-out show or appearing at Hardly Strictly Bluegrass Festival, the band is out on the road performing across America, Canada, Australia, and hosting their very own music festival, Comatopia, in the Sierra foothills. https://www.thebrotherscomatose.com/
The Wailers 2024 Legend Anniversary Tour
Wednesday, July 3
Doors: 7:30 p.m.; Show: 8 p.m.
Avalon Theatre
The Wailers are a rare breed of musicians who have earned their place in the annals of music history. Their culture-defining music, embodying the spirit of the '70s reggae movement, has left an indelible mark on the industry.
Experience the magic of their timeless classics and incredible cuts from Bob Marley's vast repertoire in a set that is truly unforgettable. Under the guidance of Aston Barrett Jr, son of the legendary "Familyman", The Wailers continue to preserve the legacy of their iconic sound. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'Live' from Worton, WKHS airs 50th anniversary
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbintrager@chespub.com
content:
'Live' from Worton, WKHS airs 50th anniversary

 May 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbintrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 404
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Broadcasting out of Kent County High School in Worton, 90.5 WKHS radio celebrated TuneFest, the station's 50th anniversary, on Saturday, May 9. next door at Red Acres Hydroponics farm.Station manager and Career and Technical Education Instructor Chris Singleton received gratitude as well as a golden microphone trophy as he recalled his start in 2008.
Singleton had a lot of people to thank, and made sure he got as many KCHS staff, programmers, students, and others as he could.
Going down the line, Singleton mentioned how each was instrumental in the journey to make WKHS the influence it is today — one of the most powerful high school stations in the country.
At 17,500 watts with flat terrain all around, their signal can be heard up to 60 miles in any direction.
Plaques were presented to outgoing Superintendent Karen Couch and former Station Managers Steve Kramarck, Rob Futterman, Karyn O'Brien, Ted Dively, June Fox, Keith Hill, Walt Barcus and the "godfather," inaugural WKHS station manager Jim Hammond.
Hammond reflected. "The very first song we played, March 28, 1974, was "Rocket Man." Part of that was when I was on the air, you never used your real name. I was 'Captain Space' because I played progressive rock."
While they talked, food vendors served and in between the rainfall people jetted out to grab a carbonated beverage and some food then hurried back for the live music.
"It wouldn't be a radio celebration without music, right. So we've assembled a great variety," Singleton told the crowd.
LOCAL TALENT
Sombarkin' played blues and some toe-tapping gospel. Justin Singleton and the Shorebillies performed soulful country-style songs with original lyrics. Philip Dutton and the Alligators rocked out Louisiana-style, and the Blake Thompson Band performed later that day with some classic rock/blues/folk music.
On the smaller stage, Maryland Delegate Jay Jacobs presented Singleton a citation of recognition.
The station also received a certificate of recognition in March from the Kent County Commissioners.
While the crowd mingled, Singleton's junior students, the class of 2025, took the sound coming from the stage and broadcasted it out for those who couldn't make it that day.
The "on-air" on the barn wall above the bands wasn't just for decoration.
Singleton was appreciative of the community support.
"It's pretty amazing. Everybody coming together from all walks of life today, celebrating for a common cause. We're the only high school radio station in Maryland and still going strong."
You can discover Singleton and his crew's work on the radio dial at 90.5. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a high‑school radio station's 50th anniversary celebration featuring live music and community performances, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category, while also touching on Arts & Culture and the educational setting.

title: Simplify your Baking: Quick bread basics for beginners
author: Maike Corbett Wealth of Geeks
content:
Simplify your Baking: Quick bread basics for beginners

 May 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maike Corbett Wealth of Geeks | Section: Entertainment 
 
 766
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Making bread at home intimidates many home bakers who don't have tons of experience making yeast bread. Several steps are involved, and there's no guarantee of an edible end result. Plus, making bread is time-consuming. That's probably part of the reason why the global bakery market is expected to reach $9.62 billion by 2030, according to 360iResearch.It's convenient for shoppers with busy schedules to grab a loaf of bread or another pre-packaged bakery item. They're available in every grocery store, reasonably inexpensive, and the quality is consistent. However, home cooks who like to know what's in their food may still want to try their hand creating their own baked goods. Quick bread is an excellent solution to that dilemma.
What Is Quick Bread?
Quick bread is a type of bread that does not use yeast or another biological agent for leavening. These goods include pancakes, waffles, zucchini bread, banana bread, American biscuits, Southern cornbread, and more. This category also includes flatbreads like naan or tortillas.
According to the Wheat Foods Council, quick breads became more popular during the mid-19th century, when baking soda and baking powder came on the market. After the Civil War started, home cooks needed bread recipes that didn't require several hours to let yeast doughs rise. The result was what we now know as quick bread.
American biscuits are one of the earliest types of quick breads, although making them before the Civil War wasn't quick. Since yeast was hard to find and expensive, bakers kneaded the dough to incorporate enough air into it so it would rise when baked. Baking powder makes the process much easier.
Why Quick Bread?
Quick breads don't have to rise, and the dough doesn't always need to be kneaded. Quick bread recipes are usually easy. Since they don't require specialized techniques, they're great for beginners, including kids. Most quick bread recipes are "dump and stir."
Making a quick bread is a good way to learn several basic cooking techniques, including correctly measuring and sifting flour. The loaves don't have to be shaped, either. The cook only needs to pour the batter into a greased baking pan.
Quick breads yield consistent results. If the person follows the recipe, the results should come out well. It's hard to mess up quick bread. Another reason these are great starter recipes.
Quick breads are also versatile. The recipes are forgiving; cooks can add different ingredients to suit their family's preferences. For example, if no one likes walnuts, the cook can add pecans to banana bread or omit the nuts entirely. They can also add chocolate chips or even dried blueberries or cranberries for a different take on the bread.
Anna Chesley, with Salt in My Coffee, says, "I make a lot of quick breads, and our favorites vary with the seasons. In spring, we love rhubarb quick bread, topped with a maple streusel crumble. In the summer months, we go through a lot of zucchini bread, and by late fall, we're so ready for cranberry orange bread — our favorite through the cold weather months."
Those with a bumper crop of zucchini in their gardens often make zucchini bread in the summer. They may also try pumpkin bread if they have a pumpkin in the garden. It's a good way to use surplus vegetables so they don't go to waste.
Healthier Choices
If people are concerned about gluten in their food, eat a plant-based menu, or have other dietary concerns, quick breads are a viable option. You may think quick breads are sugary and carb-heavy, but that's not always true. The best part of making a quick bread is that the cook controls the ingredients. There are low-sugar recipes and low-carb options that incorporate almond flour or another lower-carb flour to lower the carbohydrate count.
"We make whole food plant based oil free banana bread with dairy free chocolate chips," says Jacqueline Sanchez of My Plant Based Plan. "It's a great breakfast with a side of fruit and coffee or an afternoon snack after school for the kids."
Quick breads aren't necessarily loaves, either. Flatbreads are quick and a popular alternative to the standard white sandwich bread. Tiffany McCauley with The Gracious Pantry says, "My favorite is Socca, a chickpea flatbread. It's super quick and easy to make and is totally gluten-free. It tastes great and even works as a pizza crust. I use it that way often and love it."
For those who don't have time to work with yeast bread, making quick bread is a good way to have savory or sweet baked goods that can be served for any meal.
This article was produced by Media Decision and syndicated by Wealth of Geeks. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a cooking guide about quick breads, placed in the Entertainment section and focuses on recipe tips rather than health, agriculture, or economic analysis.

title: Maryland junior prepares for Miss Maryland Teen USA
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland junior prepares for Miss Maryland Teen USA

 May 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 473
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Lily Belle McDowell has been on stage many times before, but the Leonardtown High School student is preparing to step onto arguably her biggest stage yet.After being selected as a Maryland state finalist, McDowell will compete with the title Miss Leonardtown Teen USA in the Miss Maryland Teen USA competition, which will be held May 31 to June 1 at the Bethesda North Marriott in Bethesda.
"I've always had an interest in being on stage and performing and I saw this opportunity," McDowell, who is a junior, said. "I figured I'm getting older; I'm almost out of high school; and I've always wanted to try this. It just really speaks to me. And I love all the dresses, too, so that's a lot of fun."
She will compete in honor of her grandfather, Bob Richardson, who was a prominent figure in St. Mary's County Babe Ruth Little League and the county's recreation and parks department who died earlier this year.
Because of the various clubs and activities she is involved in, McDowell is no stranger to being on stage. As a 5-year-old she won a cute baby contest at the St. Mary's County Fair.
For the upcoming state competition, she's planning on wearing a dark green formal gown that is "prominent and catches the eye." She also will wear a fitness outfit, business suit and a traditional pink cocktail dress to match her fellow competitors.
"I feel I interact well with adults, and I feel I can talk to the judges well," said McDowell, who added she hopes her genuine personality and her "contagious smile" will help her stand out with the judges.
She has been practicing answering sample questions with her mother.
"The big thing is just be yourself and showcase your personality," she said.
The 17-year-old has been her class president for the past three years, a treasurer with the National Honors Society, secretary of the Key Club, a member of the SGA and a member of the Potomac Voices, Leonardtown High's chamber choir. She plays forward for the varsity field hockey team.
"All the more power to her," said Leonardtown High School media specialist Brenda Hager, who also teaches McDowell journalism. "She is a bright beaming light to every room she enters. She is a refreshing, positive energy to our student body. The best word to describe Lily Belle is her kindness; it just overflows. She's something special."
In 2023 she was awarded the Relentless for a Cure award by the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society Fly4ACure for her fundraising efforts, and this year as a team leader, she helped raise $88,000, good for first runner-up in the state.
"I'm really excited to go there for the experience, to meet new people and to learn from them as well," she said. "I honestly would love to win the whole thing. I feel like that would be amazing, and I'd enjoy that."

title: Angie Harmon is suing Instacart and a former shopper who shot and killed her dog, Oliver
author: Staff Writer
content:
Angie Harmon is suing Instacart and a former shopper who shot and killed her dog, Oliver

 May 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 461
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Actor Angie Harmon has filed a lawsuit against Instacart and one of its former shoppers who fatally shot her dog in March while delivering groceries at her North Carolina home.The lawsuit filed earlier this month in Mecklenburg County seeks to hold the shopper and Instacart liable for accusations of trespassing, gross negligence, emotional distress and invasion of privacy, among other allegations. It accuses Instacart of engaging in negligent hiring, supervision, retention and misrepresentation. The suit seeks monetary damages, to be determined at trial.
Instacart says the shopper has since been permanently banned from its platform.
Harmon is known for her work on TV shows including "Law & Order" and "Rizolli & Isles." She told ABC News that it was "so unfathomable to think that there is somebody in your front driveway that just fired a gun."
"I think Instacart is beyond responsible for all of this. This didn't have to happen," Harmon said in the interview that aired earlier this month on "Good Morning America." ABC News described the dog as a "beagle mix."
According to the complaint, Harmon ordered an Instacart groceries delivery from a Charlotte store on March 30. The Instacart app showed a shopper named Merle with a profile photo of an older woman, with whom Harmon believed she was exchanging text messages about her order, the lawsuit says.
Later that day, Harmon was upstairs filling her squirrel feeders when a "tall and intimidating younger man," not an older woman, showed up to deliver the groceries, the lawsuit says.
Harmon said she heard a gunshot sound and rushed outside. She found her dog, Oliver, had been shot, and saw the delivery person putting a gun into the front of his pants, according to the suit. Her teenage daughters, who had already been outside, were "in distress," it says. The dog died at the veterinarian's office.
The shopper told police that he shot the dog after it attacked him, the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Department told news outlets, adding that they did not pursue criminal charges.
In an Instagram post last month about the encounter, Harmon wrote that the shopper "did not have a scratch or bite on him nor were his pants torn."
Instacart says it immediately suspended the shopper after receiving the report about the shooting, then later removed him permanently. The company says it runs comprehensive background checks on shoppers, prohibits them from carrying weapons and has anti-fraud measures that include periodically requiring them to take a photo of themselves to ensure the person shopping matches their photo on file.
"Our hearts continue to be with Ms. Harmon and her family following this disturbing incident," Instacart said in a statement. "While we cannot comment on pending litigation, we have no tolerance for violence of any kind, and the shopper account has been permanently deactivated from our platform." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Side dishes for Memorial Day
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Side dishes for Memorial Day

 May 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 675
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Memorial Day will always mean the same no matter the situation at home or abroad.Memorial Day is an American holiday celebrated the last Monday of May. This day honors the men and women who died while serving in the United States Military.
Originally known as Decoration Day, it originated in the years following the Civil War and became an official federal holiday in 1971.
My fellow Americans, I fly the United States flag each day to honor all who died in the line of duty — military, law enforcement, first responders, and anyone who lost their life while helping their fellow people. Stand proud of these people as they gave all for you and me and the USA. Fly those flags with great pride as we all know someone who answered "the call."
This year's celebrations may be different since gasoline and supplies are so expensive. Remember the "carpooling" days a few years ago?
Plan a day at home to barbecue, play outside games, safely have a few fireworks, make homemade ice cream, watch home movies or catch up with family. These will be some of your most cherished memories in the years to come.
Sit under the shade tree or on the front porch with the older folks and listen to their "recollections" of years gone by.
When the crowd gathers for food, the host may ask for each family to bring a dish, so today I will give you some recipes that can be easily prepared.
Usually the host prepares the meat, so side dishes are appreciated. Let us begin with a favorite.
GERMAN POTATO SALAD
Cook 5 large potatoes (peeled and sliced) until tender, drain and set aside. Saute one bunch of sliced green onions and 1 small, diced onion in 6 tbsps butter until tender. Add 1/3 cup vinegar, 1/3 cup sugar, 2 tbsps mustard, 1/2 tsp thyme, and salt and pepper to taste. Add the potatoes and toss. Cook over low heat for 15 minutes to blend flavors. Do not refrigerate.
CUCUMBER SALAD
Mix 1/2 cup mayonnaise, 1 tbsp sugar, 2 tbsps vinegar, 2 tbsps milk, and salt and pepper to taste. Mix well and pour over three peeled and thinly sliced cucumbers. Let stand for at least an hour before serving.
STRAWBERRY ICEBOX CAKE
8 oz. cream cheese at room temperature, 1 cup powdered sugar, 3 cups heavy cream (divided), 1 tbsp vanilla bean paste or extract, 1 tbsp lemon zest, 40 graham cracker squares, 2 pounds strawberries (sliced about 1/4-inch thick), 3/4 cup sliced almonds (optional).
Beat cream cheese in a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer until smooth. Add powdered sugar; beat until smooth. Scrape down the sides of the bowl. Add 1 cup of the heavy cream and beat at low speed until smooth. Add the remaining 2 cups of cream; beat at medium to medium-high speed until soft peaks form, increasing speed as the mixture begins to thicken. Fold in the vanilla and lemon zest. Spoon 1/4 cup of the cream mixture into the bottom of a 9-by-9-inch pan or baking dish; spread into a thin, even layer. Top with graham crackers in a single, even layer, breaking them as needed to fit. Spread about 1 1/2 cups of the cream mixture over the graham crackers, smoothing into an even layer using a spoon or offset spatula. Top the cream mixture with an even layer of berries (about 1 1/2 cups). Sprinkle evenly with 1/4 cup almonds, if using. Repeat two more times with the remaining graham crackers, cream mixture, berries, and almonds. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate at least four hours and up to overnight.
MARINATED PEAS
Mix together in a bowl: two one-pound cans sweet peas, drained, with one chopped onion, one chopped green pepper, 2 stalks chopped celery, 1/4 cup oil, 1/2 cup vinegar and 3/4 cup sugar. Cover and let marinate for 6 hours before serving.
Arrange a tray of sliced pickles, a variety of cheeses, onions, olives and other fresh veggies. Deviled eggs and plain hard-boiled eggs are great for any gathering and don't forget the chips. Enjoy your day together. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

What can Frederick Douglass, Talbot County's most famous native son, teach us as America continues struggling with racial divisions, the legacy of enslavement, and the quest for a just, free, and embracing society? Join Jeff McGuiness and Lance Morris in a discussion of the eloquent words penned by Douglass himself, juxtaposed against the very landscape that bore witness to the genesis of his quest for a society that transcends differences and dismantles the constancy of hate. Two sessions, May 22 and 29. $30. To register, visit chesapeakeforum.org.
PLANNING FOR OUR FUTURE BEFORE IT REACHES US, 1 to 2:30 p.m., Easton Family YMCA or via Zoom. Join experts Gordan Fronk and Elena Sallitto as they demystify estate and elder planning, ensuring that you are well-prepared for the future. "Planning for Our Future Before It Reaches Us," delves into the intricate world of estate and elder law to safeguard your assets, make informed decisions, and prioritize the well-being of your loved ones. Two sessions, May 29 and June 5. $30. To register, visit chesapeakeforum.org.
THURSDAY, MAY 30
OYSTER GARDENING 101, 4:30 to 6 p.m., Pickering Creek Audubon Center. Oyster gardening provides import nursery habitat as well as filtering the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries; oyster reefs are a vital part of conserving the Chesapeake Bay. Come learn about a new spat growing program, the challenges these bivalve face, and the research methods we use to analyze the success of oyster nurseries. Sign up at pickeringcreek.org/programs/upcoming-programs/.
BUCKETS OF WARM SPIT, 10 to 11:30 a.m., Easton Family YMCA or via Zoom. Join Raymond Vergne, M.D., as he turns his focus on the intriguing lives and careers of selected vice presidents from the 20th century. This course is the final chapter in his comprehensive series, offering a deep dive into the often overlooked but fascinating world of Vice Presidents. Three sessions, May 23, 30 and June 6. $40. To register, visit chesapeakeforum.org.

NATURE AT NIGHT HIKE, 8:30 to 10:30 p.m., Pickering Creek Audubon Center. Explore Pickering Creek's Farm-to-Bay Loop at night and use special UV flashlights to reveal nocturnal wildlife and unique plants and fungi not usually visible to the human eye. By the main parking lot, stop by a mothing station with the opportunity to see Luna moths and other impressive early summer species. Sign up at pickeringcreek.org/programs/upcoming-programs/.

title: 'One Night in Old Havana' bringing all things vintage Cuba to Oxford
author: Staff Writer
content:
'One Night in Old Havana' bringing all things vintage Cuba to Oxford

 May 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 308
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Oxford Community Center will host a "One Night in Old Havana" event on Saturday, June 1, at 6:30 p.m.The event will mirror a Cuban social club from the 1950 with salsa music, neon lights, cigars, Latin-inspired food and vintage cars. There will be a cigar lounge on the OCC's patio.
The 'Old Havana' event will also feature signature cocktails featuring locally based Lyon Rum.
The music portion will include various singers, salsa dancers and a group lesson from dance instructor and champion dancer Scott Lazarovs.
"We look forward to transporting you back to 'One Night in Old Havana," said OCC Executive Director Liza Ledford. "This will be an immersive experience filled with tropical cocktails, live music, and plenty of salsa dancing. It promises to be a wonderfully entertaining evening supporting our mission."
Attendees can break out their best cocktail party attire or get vintage wear from The Factory in Easton along styling packages.
"1950s Havana is calling you," said event chair and Oxford resident Jennifer Leps. "We look forward to whisking you away to another time and place. Salsa rhythms will spill out onto the patio cigar bar, while inside, a mesmerizing display of song and dance unfolds. Prepare to be transported to one night to remember!
The tickets are $75 with an open bar and appetizers from The Ivy and hand-rolled cigars from Port of Call Cigars.
"Come in costume, stay for the performances, and experience an unforgettable evening while supporting our 501c3's work to bring the community together," Ledford said.
Styling sessions cost $250 "with The Factory's professional costumers and stylists. The hour includes a full period costume for the event, hair & make up consultation, self care party favors and Cuban inspired cocktails & snacks. Each guest will receive a bespoke floral headpiece made by our costumers that compliments their look," according an announcement from the Oxford Community Center
For more: https://oxfordcc.org/ 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a themed social event with music, dancing, costumes, and food, which fits the Entertainment category more directly than Arts & Culture.

title: Lip Sync fundraiser nets $112,000 for shelter
author: Staff Writer
content:
Lip Sync fundraiser nets $112,000 for shelter

 May 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 399
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot Interfaith Shelter staged a successful eighth annual Lip Sync Battle fundraiser on April 27 at the Waterfowl Building in Easton.After raising nearly $83,000 last year, Talbot Interfaith Shelter surpassed this year's $100,000 fundraising goal to the tune of $112,000 by the end of the live show. Attendees enjoyed an evening of music, laughter and joy as the community gathered to support the shelter's mission of providing shelter, stability, support and a path to success for local families and individuals in need.
This year's vibrant showcase of talent and generosity kicked off with a heartfelt thank you from shelter Executive Director Julie Lowe and hosted by crowd favorites Jayme D, Jay Hudson and Ricky Vitanovec. The distinguished panel of judges included Talbot County Commissioner and CEO of Foundation of HOPE Keasha Haythe, Easton Mayor Megan Cook and John Horner, president and chief operating officer of Easton Utilities.
Participants took the stage to deliver captivating live team lip sync performances, intercut with clips from the Online Video Competition teams — all in the spirit of raising crucial funds for the Talbot Interfaith Shelter.
Nineteen teams competed for the top fundraiser titles and the coveted Lip Sync Battle trophies. Many familiar faces returned to the stage alongside fresh talent, with notable newcomers including Playa Bowls, Rise Up Coffee and Capriotti's. All eight live show teams rocked the stage during the initial freestyle round followed by the unpredictable and hilarious roulette round.
The following teams taking home trophies at the end of the evening: Best Fundraiser (Live Show): The Country School faculty; Best Fundraiser (Online Video): Team TIS; Best Live Show Performance (tie): Black Wizard and The Country School faculty; and Best Online Video Performance: The Factory. The show was recorded and can be streamed online: talbotinterfaithshelter.org/lsb
"We are still glowing from the beautiful and uplifting experience of Lip Sync Battle 2024," Executive Director Julie Lowe said. "It's more than just a fundraiser; it's a celebration of community spirit and resilience."
The 2024 Lip Sync Battle was made possible by the support of Platinum Record Sponsor Sun Management Rising Technologies and a host of dedicated local sponsors.
Talbot Interfaith Shelter is a homeless shelter and transitional housing program based in Easton, MD and serving the five counties of the Mid-Shore (Talbot, Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Annes). To learn more about the organization and how to help, visit talbotinterfaithshelter.org or contact Julie Lowe at 410-310-2316 or julielowe@talbotinterfaithshelter.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community lip sync battle fundraiser, focusing on performances and entertainment to raise money, making Entertainment the most fitting category.

title: Circus comes to Easton
author: Tom McCall
content:
Circus comes to Easton

 May 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 256
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The big tent reached 100 feet into the sky with blue and yellow stripes as the Zerbini Family Circus came to the Talbot Agricultural and Education Center on May 22 and 23.The circus brought parading ponies, gravity-defying acrobats and zany clowns. The audience of all ages was rapt.
There was a palpable sense of joy as the ringmaster announced each act in a booming voice.
Children had their faces painted like butterflies and queued to hold a real albino snake. One happy grandmother from Trappe, waving at her grandson, said, "I am already in for $100, but it is OK."
In the darkened tent, the spectacle glowed on the children's faces.
The balancing act was like a surfer on a board. He placed seven cylinders beneath his board and stood 30 feet above the ground wobbling. The crowd was in awe of this seemingly dangerous act. He dismounted with his arms up in victory.
There was a 20-foot inflatable koala bear teetering around the ring and providing photo ops for children.
There were two clowns that were supported by timely sound effects. The whole tent was laughing with them and at them.
Horses pranced and jumped and put their forward hoof on stands in unison. Mini donkeys performed the same tricks.
Most of the performers are from Mexico but are based in Florida, according to employees of the circus, and tour the East Coast.
They travel from Rock Hall to Collcoon to Woodstown, performing two or three shows in each spot, and then roll it up and head to the next town. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Sweet tea smackdown: which iced tea version is best?
author: Leah Ingram Food Drink Life
content:
Sweet tea smackdown: which iced tea version is best?

 May 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Leah Ingram Food Drink Life | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1013
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Order a glass of iced tea in the South and you're guaranteed to get sweet tea. In most other places in the United States, your server will likely ask if you want your iced tea sweetened or unsweetened. In time for June's National Iced Tea Month, here is a look at why some Americans prefer one kind of tea over another.The popularity of tea
Many cultures around the world prefer to drink hot tea. However, in the United States, tea lovers tend to enjoy it cold and over ice. The National Tea Association said that 75% to 80% of all tea that Americans drink is done so cold.
Fun fact: the very first versions of American iced tea were more akin to that bar favorite the Long Island Iced Tea. It wasn't until the 1904 World's Fair in St. Louis, says National Public Radio, that Americans really developed a taste for non-alcoholic iced tea. "The hot summer weather caused fairgoers to ignore hot beverages in favor of cold ones — including iced tea," said an NPR article. "The fair's 20 million visitors cooled themselves with iced tea and brought the new style back to their homes throughout the United States and the world."
The South becomes synonymous with tea
About 100 years before the St. Louis World's Fair, tea drinkers in the South had already developed a taste for sweet tea. A few things contributed to this trend. One was the abundant access to ice, so they no longer had to drink tea hot. Another was the sugar trade reaching America's southern shores.
Perhaps the biggest contributor, though, was the fact that South Carolina farmers had been growing tea since the 18th century. They planted Camellia Sinensis on Wadmalaw Island, near Charleston, South Carolina, on land the Bigelow Tea Company now owns. That flower is one that, even today, you can plant in your backyard to grow tea.
Map of iced tea consumption
Today, sweet tea is synonymous with Southern cuisine. Why else would Dolly Parton's character in the movie "Sweet Magnolias" refer to sweet tea as the "house wine of the South"?
"In the South, if you order an iced tea, it is almost always going to be sweet tea," added Susannah Brinkley Henry of Charlotte, North Carolina, who writes the beverage-heavy Feast + West blog. "It is always easy to recognize a non-Southerner at a restaurant. They will either order unsweet iced tea or send it back when it is too sweet."
If you were to draw a map of where tea drinkers prefer sweet tea over regular iced tea, it might look a lot like The Sweet Tea Boundary. This iced tea map appears on a University of Alabama fan page called Tide Fans.
States that lean toward sweet tea include South Carolina — not surprising, given its tea roots — along with North Carolina, Alabama, Georgia, Mississippi, Arkansas and Tennessee. After that, the map includes states that supposedly have tea lovers of both persuasions — sweet tea drinkers and those who drink unsweetened iced tea. Those states are Florida, Louisiana, Texas, Oklahoma, Missouri and Illinois.
The remaining 37 states are either agnostic on iced tea — no preference stated — or presumed to prefer unsweetened iced tea. Interestingly, within those agnostic areas, there are cities that lean heavily towards sweet tea. One such city is Richmond, Virginia.
Brewing iced tea at home
Want to brew iced tea at home in time for National Iced Tea Month? Here are a few things to keep in mind. First and foremost, never use straight-from-the-tap water, unless you have a filter system installed. Basically, public or well water can give off an odd flavor or odor when brewing tea so it's best to avoid using it at all, unless you have that aforementioned water filter system. Otherwise, purchase bottled spring water for your tea brewing.
Also, when brewing iced tea, you'll want to use double the amount of tea bags as you would when brewing hot tea. Why? Because when you add ice to the drink, it tends to dilute the flavor as it melts. To retain the tea taste, you brew iced tea to be doubly strong.
This is true whether you're brewing a one-off glass of iced tea or a whole pitcher. Jere Cassidy of Northern California has learned to make tea on the spot when ordering iced tea when she goes out to eat. "If a restaurant doesn't serve unsweetened tea," said Cassidy, who writes the One Hot Oven blog, "I will ask for teabags and hot water and brew my own. Then, I pour it over ice cubes."
The long and short of brewing iced tea
How you brew iced tea depends on how much time you have. There are methods that call for a long, overnight brew and others that you can make as quickly as you would a hot cup of tea as Cassidy does. You can find the recommended brewing times on the box the tea bags came in. Set a timer on your phone so you'll know when steep time is over and you should remove the bags. If you compost your food scraps, you can add the used tea bags to your compost pile.
When brewing a pitcher of hot tea to turn into iced tea, remember to double the tea bags to avoid diluting the flavor when serving over ice. Also, if you're making a sweet tea, you add the sugar, honey or molasses when the tea is still hot and brewing. It's not something you add after the fact to make it sweet.
Final thoughts on which tea America prefers
If that aforementioned iced tea map were an indicator of which kind of iced tea Americans prefer, there is a clear winner, based on population alone. With only seven Southern states on team sweet tea, it appears that unsweetened iced tea is the leader in the United States. However, don't tell that to a sweet tea drinker. Chances are they'd rather drink seawater than tea that hasn't been sweetened.
Leah Ingram developed a taste for iced tea during the Snapple heyday. These days, she writes a food blog called Bagels and Lasagna.

title: Time to get crabby: Annual Lions Club festival on tap
author: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com
content:
Time to get crabby: Annual Lions Club festival on tap

 May 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 537
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The 38th annual St. Mary's County Crab Festival will be held Saturday, June 8. at the St. Mary's County Fairgrounds in Leonardtown.The crabs are the main attraction on Saturday at the fairgrounds. But there will also be live music provided by a pair of local bands — "Totally Stoked" and "Reagan Years" — food vendors and, fittingly, a crab-picking contest that will serve a duel purpose of providing competitive entertainment and crab meat for those who indulge.
George Kirby has been associated with the Leonardtown Lions Club for the past decade and now he is among the committee members who are seeking to make the annual crab festival even more festive each year. In recent years, Kirby noted several new items have been added to the entertainment venue and each of them has been received in appreciable fashion.
"One thing that we added a few years ago, and it has become really popular, is the crab-picking contest," Kirby said. "We started a new tradition last year. Instead of just giving away a trophy to the winner, we have a big trophy with the name of each annual winner engraved on it. It started last year and we'll keep adding a name to it each year."
In addition to the crab-picking contest, the St. Mary's County Crab Festival also features a classic car show, homemade craft exhibits, a petting zoo, a face painter and free hearing and vision screenings, all of which debuted a year ago and are free to the public.
"I think we're expecting about 30 to 40 cars for the show," Kirby said. "There are a lot more car shows around now, so that number could be a little lower. But we're still going to have a contest with judges and trophies to the winners. ... Our health screenings are free and they're important."
While there are a bevy of eating and entertainment options for patrons throughout the eight-hour outing, the crab-picking contest has evolved into a must-see event. Hardly a subjective viewing event, the champion of the crab-picking contest is the individual who picks the most crab meat during a brief, contentious, four-minute window, and then is immortalized on a trophy that could someday emulate the Stanley Cup.
"I hope in my heart that people come out because the Leonardtown Lions Club is a good community service group and we'll use all the money we get to give back to the community," Kirby said. "And a good humanitarian fundraiser is for some people worth coming to just to sit around and say 'I helped.' We do really good things and part of that depends on people coming. We just want people to have a good time."
If you go
The 38th annual St. Mary's County Crab Festival will take place this Saturday, June 8, from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. at the St. Mary's County Fairgrounds, located at 42455 Fairgrounds Road in Leonardtown.
This event will feature hot crabs, an animal zoo, jump houses, crafts, car shows, a crab-picking contest, free vision and hearing screenings and performances from local bands Totally Stoked (noon-3 p.m.) and Reagan Years (4-7 p.m.).
Tickets for the event are $10, while children under 12 get in free. For more information, view the website at https://e-clubhouse.org/sites/leonardtownmd or call 301-997-5779. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
