llm_classification.explanation: The article is a travel and leisure guide focusing on beer tourism in Europe, published in the Entertainment section, making Entertainment the most fitting category.

title: Chestertown’s casual gin connoisseurs
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Chestertown’s casual gin connoisseurs

 September 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 1229
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — It all began with the little juniper berry, which actually isn't a berry at all, but what botanists describe as a seed cone with an unusually fleshy circumference and merged scales called a galbulus that gives it its berry-like appearance.It was this humble berry-like seed cone, however, that became the go-to ingredient for the all-important spirit and mixologist staple, gin.
The true origin of gin, has been historically debated, some tracing it back as far as the Middle Ages, where it was consumed for medicinal purposes only, and later in history it shows up again in the Netherlands in the 1700s as a more refined spirit called 'jenever' that was developed by a Dutch doctor, who also administered it for its healing properties.
This later iteration of gin was further developed in England after juniper berries were imported by Dutch merchants, who also talked up the wonders of the elixir derived from them. It is this history and, of course, the flavor profiles of the spirit that has made gin enthusiasts out of Lynn and Steve Mitchell of Chestertown.
The Mitchells are what you might consider casual aficionados of gin in the sense that they collect both common and rare varieties and are known to have about 20 different types on-hand at any given time. They enjoy entertaining friends and neighbors at smart gin-themed soirees and love discovering new gins on their various travels.
"With wine in the middle part of the 19th century becoming extremely expensive in England due to the duties placed on it, no one was buying wine, and they had to diversify," said Steve, a self-described fan of gins with a traditional juniper profile.
Among the bottles in their collection, Steve pulled out a large bottle of Gilbey's, which he described as a standard gin: one that offers good value for the money.
"If you're going to have a party and you're serving gin, this is the gin you want to serve," said Steve, who remarked that it is also a designated London Dry Gin, which historically means that it meets a standard for quality, although the term is often interpreted by some to be indicative of its flavor profile.
The distillers of Gilbey's gin, Steve said, were originally part of the larger contingent of wine producers that needed to pivot once those duties on wine and brandy were imposed. Gin consumption then became extremely popular in England creating what would become labeled as the "Gin Craze."
Steve, who attests to having more than a wee bit of British blood, (his mother was a World War II GI bride) said he learned later in life that he had ancestors who worked for Gilbey's early in the distiller's history. While he takes some of his ancestral tales with a grain of salt, he can verify that his great grandfather worked as a warehouseman for a liquor company in London.
As far as other solid, reasonably priced gins he pulled out a bottle of his secret weapon, something he said they often find at Costco.
Yes, Costco.
In fact, their Kirkland Signature label London Dry Gin made from natural botanicals is rumored to be produced by one of the most prestigious distillers in the world, although as part of the deal, Costco is forbidden to reveal which distiller it is.
While the online scuttlebutt often surmises it is a Tanqueray or Gordon construct, Steve has his own theory.
"I think it may be Bombay gin," he said, noting the shape of the bottle and its characteristic handle molded into the glass. These are gins that you can easily pick up locally, but there are others in the Mitchell's collection that are harder, if not impossible, to come by stateside.
There are two similar bottles that take a prominent place in the collection from the Slingsby Premium label, one a rhubarb-infused gin, the other gooseberry. These, he said, are best enjoyed sans-mixer in the cocktail style of a martini.
"Those I know I can't get until I go back to England."
Some of the smaller batch brands in the collection originate from as far away as Japan and New Zealand, and one organic seaweed gin from London-based distiller, Dà Mhìle, didn't even smell like seaweed at all, but does, indeed, leave the palate with a salty taste, according to Steve.
There's a gin from a boutique distillery once located in D.C. that has since closed that Steve is fond of called Green Hat. The name, he says, is a nod to the shady purveyor that supplied Congress members with alcohol during Prohibition. This particular purveyor was identified to those in-the-know by the green hat that he wore.
The "Navy Strength" designation, he said, denotes a 57% alcohol content, whereas traditional gin ranges between 40 to 45%.
According to Wikipedia, the British Navy required all booze and rum to be at 57% or higher; because if the casks on their ship ever broke and the gunpowder was flooded, the gunpowder would still need to be able to fire."
And then, there's a purple bottle of Hendrick's special edition gin in the grouping called Midsummer Solstice that was distilled for a limited time only.
"This gin was only produced in 2019 for one season, and I bought a bottle at Pip's (Liquors) and drank it, and figured they'd have it again the next year. They didn't [have it] and have not had it since then."
Fortunately, he received a call from the couple's daughter who lives in Cyprus, who told him she found a dusty bottle in a store there and asked if he wanted her to grab it for him. Needless to say, the answer was "yes", and that bottle has been consumed sparingly.
When it comes to gin, Lynn differs from her husband when it comes to flavor profiles.
"I'm not a Juniper fan," she said. "And coupled with my interest in gardening and cooking, I like more of the offbeat botanicals and the other flavors that are now being introduced."
Her favorite is a Japanese Craft Gin called Roku which she usually enjoys with an elderflower tonic.
An avid gardener, Lynn, is attracted to its vibrant floral notes balanced with the subtle spiciness of the Roku. She is also a fan, overall, of the approach some boutique distilleries had on the evolution of gin, particularly Hendricks.
"I think Hendrick's was really the trailblazer with their cucumber and rose combination; it showed that there was potential in the market for something other than just juniper."
Steve referred to Hendrick's approach to gin distilling as, "…. the watershed moment where actually the person who makes Hendricks gin is a female. And she, I guess said, 'Why are we making gin out of just juniper? Let's try something different.'"
This difference is being seen in the craft gin distilling business in a big way as it is now a more palatable option and is being favored by a newer generation of consumers, with a definite increase in popularity among women. According to a 2022 report by the American Distilling Institute, the gin category, and specifically the craft category, has seen exponential growth, specifically a 9% increase each year for nearly a decade.
Our conversation winded down with what else, but a good, old-fashioned gin and tonic while the late day summer sun faded with the couple talking about the possibility of one last gin-themed gathering in their screened-in back porch, and the next trip to England they may take as part of a tour around the holidays. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a lifestyle feature about local gin enthusiasts, focusing on their hobby, tasting, and social gatherings, which aligns best with the Entertainment category. It also touches on cultural aspects of gin and market trends, placing Arts & Culture and Business/Economy as secondary matches.

title: Greensboro Car Show & Music Fest a big hit for locals
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Greensboro Car Show & Music Fest a big hit for locals

 September 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 421
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — Hundreds of cars and even more car enthusiasts gathered on the fairgrounds of the Greensboro Volunteer Fire Department Saturday for the annual Greensboro Car Show & Music Fest.The first half of the event included a bevy of vintage and modern automobiles for attendees to take in. A burnout contest even attracted a trucker and a motorcyclist, both engulfing the applauding crowd in smoke.
As judges walked up and down the rows of cars, a number of entries stood out across 13 separate classes, which included imports, police vehicles and motorcycles.
Sponsors Easton Auto Care and Denton Auto Care selected the top award on Saturday. Kevin Mezick, from Delmar, won the Best of Show trophy with his red 1969 Ford Mustang.
One of the most popular cars of the afternoon was the "Batmobile," designed like the car from the Batman comics and cartoons. Darrell Hughes, who runs the group Heroes for Happiness, brought the car to Greensboro after it won an award earlier in the day at a Houston, Delaware car show.
Hughes said the group goes around Delaware and the Eastern Shore dressing up as superheroes for children's birthday parties and at children's hospitals. The Batmobile was named one of the top five 1980-2000 entries at the Greensboro Car Show on Saturday.
Also awarded a trophy was Rick Miner for his 2004 Harley-Davidson. Miner, from Harrington, Delaware, said he's had his motorcycle for four years.
Miner said many are surprised when they find out his motorcycle has a Harley-Davidson engine but a Volkswagen transmission. He added that he rides it often and that it's not just for show or collecting dust in a garage.
The event was sponsored by many local organizations and businesses. Brandon Cunningham, the town's public works supervisor and one of the car show's organizers, thanked the sponsors.
"Without the help and the support of over 70 sponsors throughout the community, (this event) would not be possible, so thank you to everyone," Cunningham said.
At the conclusion of the car show, local band Rivers & Rhodes entertained fans before headliner and Nashville-based recording artist Trea Landon performed. It was Landon's first live performance in Maryland.
The event, which was free to all attendees, raised money to support the Greensboro Police Department's community basketball program.
Cunningham said the funds will help improvements at Greensboro's park and potentially other nearby parks. Proceeds help the program so that it can continue to be offered for free to local kids.
"Our goal is to venture out to help multiple areas, so we want to thank everybody," Cunningham said during Saturday's event. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily describes a community car show and music festival, highlighting performances, sponsors, and entertainment activities, making Entertainment the most fitting category.

title: World's top winemaking countries: 11 best wineries around the globe to visit
author: Elise Armitage Wealth of Geeks
content:
World's top winemaking countries: 11 best wineries around the globe to visit

 September 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Elise Armitage Wealth of Geeks | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1304
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In 2023, France officially overtook Italy as the top provider of wine on the planet.A new report from Statista estimates France made 48 million hectoliters of wine that year. That accounts for more than 20% of global production. Italy fell behind, but still produced an impressive 16.1% of the worldwide wine supply in 2023, while Spain was responsible for 13.6%.
Most of the world's wineries reside in areas with a mild Mediterranean climate. Weather, terrain, and soil quality are all significant factors in a vineyard's success.
Those looking to expand their knowledge of and appreciation for fine wines can embark on an epic odyssey through the world's top wine-producing countries. Wine tasting is a fun year-round activity you can do at home or abroad. Even better, you can kick back with a glass of vino now, while you plan a journey to enjoy the scenery at the best wineries across the world.
World's 11 Best Wineries To Visit This SeasonStatista identifies the top winemaking countries around the globe according to the total wine produced in 2023. From the mountains of Europe to the valleys of South America, these are 11 essential wineries to visit this season.
Château de L'Engarran, FranceAs the world's top producer of wine, it's unsurprising that France boasts many renowned wineries. If you only have time for one French vineyard visit, consider Château de l'Engarran. This opulent, centuries-old estate sits on the outskirts of Montpellier.
Guests must reserve a guided tour to explore the privately owned castle, cellar, and gardens. In addition to tastings, Château de l'Engarran offers an informative winemaking history museum and a shop where visitors can purchase the estate's wine and local food products.
Antinori Nel Chianti Classico, Italy
Tuscany is among the world's best vacation spots for wine connoisseurs. While there, tour the one-of-a-kind Antinori nel Chianti Classico winery. The Antinoris, a 26-generation Tuscan family, established the vineyard in 2012. They took special care in building the eco-conscious winery with only locally sourced materials.
In 2022, a group of 500 wine and travel experts named Antinori nel Chianti Classico the world's best vineyard, based on its incredible family legacy, innovative design, and thoughtfully crafted wines. To experience this unique operation, book a winery tasting tour and sample three to seven wines. After, catch lunch at the on-site restaurant, Rinuccio 1180.
Bodegas Muga, SpainVisit Bodegas Muga to immerse yourself in La Rioja, Spain's premiere winemaking region. In 1932, members of two local families founded the winery, which now comprises roughly 25,000 square meters. Bodegas Muga combines traditional and modern winemaking techniques to create its signature white, red, and rosé wines.
Activities at Bodegas Muga include an introductory wine-tasting course, guided winery tours, Segway tours through the vineyard, and hot air balloon rides. Skip the slingback heels in favor of comfortable yet stylish shoes, such as sturdy boots or sneakers, as you'll spend much time walking over rough, uneven terrain.
Round Pond Estate, United StatesNapa Valley is a top U.S. wine region, and Round Pond Estate is among the finest local wineries. The estate describes itself as "a destination that promises an immersive, unforgettable experience for wine lovers and travelers alike." This community-driven winemaker specializes in luxurious wines guests can enjoy alongside estate chef-prepared seasonal meals.
According to Round Pond Estate, it uses "one of Napa Valley's only two working olive mills" to produce exceptional olive oils. This California winery is top-notch in every regard, from the property's understated elegance to its breathtaking Mayacamas Mountains landscape.
Madrone Cellars & Cider, United StatesThe Pacific Northwest is another North American winemaking hub, and Washington's Madrone Cellars & Cider is hard to beat. Madrone gives guests an authentic taste of coastal life at its Friday Harbor wine bar and San Juan Island vineyard. Despite being relatively new to the scene, opening in 2017, Madrone has already secured its place among the best wineries statewide.
Shaun and Amy Salamida, a husband and wife duo passionate about natural winemaking, oversee Madrone. The couple believes in producing wines with minimal intervention to allow the fruit's pure flavors to shine. They source all their winemaking grapes from Eastern Washington, emphasizing a commitment to locally grown ingredients and sustainable farming practices.
Viña Santa Cruz, ChileViña Santa Cruz is a must-visit for wine lovers. This Colchagua Valley winery is the first in Chile to be 100% solar-powered. Viña Santa Cruz's mission is to unite the body and soul by educating visitors about the distinct cultures influencing its wines.
Embark on an unforgettable adventure aboard the winery's Swiss cable car and discover the Hill of Cultures, paying homage to the Aymara, Mapuche, and Rapa Nui civilizations. Other unique attractions include carriage rides through the vineyards and stargazing at the on-site astronomical center. These immersive experiences will deepen your appreciation for Viña Santa Cruz's flavorful wine varieties.
Vergelegen Wine Estate, South AfricaSince 1700, the Vergelegen Wine Estate has been at the forefront of South Africa's winemaking industry. Its rich heritage is evident in the sprawling gardens, forests, and central homestead. Vergelegen boasts 21 unique soil types ideal for producing house cabernet sauvignon, merlot, and malbec blends, among others.
From cellar tours to wildlife watching in the Vergelegen Nature Reserve, there's something to entice every guest. Once you taste the winery's iconic creations, you'll understand why it's been a Cape Town staple for centuries.
Audrey Wilkinson, Australia
Visit the Audrey Wilkinson property in Hunter Valley to learn more about Australian wine production. The vineyard's history stretches back to 1886, when the Wilkinson family first acquired the land. In the decades since, Audrey Wilkinson has established itself as a world-class winemaker.
Audrey Wilkinson's picturesque cellar is perched atop a mountain, offering 360-degree views of the valley below. Tasting options include picnics in the vineyard, artisanal cheese and chocolate pairings, and adventures through Hunter Valley Wildlife Park. With several on-site accommodations, Audrey Wilkinson is the ideal getaway for couples or friends who share a love for fine wine.
Bodega Los Toneles, ArgentinaArgentina's Mendoza region boasts many impressive wineries, but Bodega Los Toneles stands above the rest. The historic estate features a mouthwatering restaurant, a chic art gallery, and multiple tasting areas. As an official Cultural Heritage Site of Mendoza, Bodega Los Toneles is an excellent place to dive into Argentine traditions.
Bodega Los Toneles is renowned for its malbec and cabernet sauvignon, which guests can sample on a guided property tour. These unique experiences combine art, history, and winemaking for a one-of-a-kind visit. Tap into the past while savoring the present by enjoying a wine tasting at Bodega Los Toneles.
Weingut Kloster Marienthal, GermanyThe German Weingut Kloster Marienthal has a fascinating history as a former monastery. Various property owners have produced wine at the site for centuries, but it wasn't restored to its former glory until a group of winemakers acquired the estate in 2004. Today, Weingut Kloster Marienthal is a stunning example of 12th-century architecture.
Quality is paramount, as Weingut Kloster Marienthal only produces a small number of wines. Bundle up in tights and a lightweight jacket to descend into the cellar. Learn about the ancient building while sampling several wine varieties. From delicious food offerings to beautiful gardens, there's much to love about Weingut Kloster Marienthal.
Quinta Do Seixo, PortugalPortugal is famous for port wine, and Quinta do Seixo is one of the best places to sample the signature drink. Located in the heart of the Douro Valley, this 100-year-old vineyard makes exceptional tawny, white, ruby, and rosé port wines. Tour the historic winery and taste its iconic creations to gain a deeper appreciation for Portuguese wine.
At Quinta do Seixo, voyagers can enjoy breathtaking views of the Douro River while sipping on flavorful wines, strolling through serene vineyards, and dining on seasonal specialties. Visiting the property will transport wine lovers to a peaceful oasis honoring the past while embracing modernity. Varying tour options make Quinta do Seixo the perfect day trip for any group.
This article was produced by Media Decision and syndicated by Wealth of Geeks. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a feature on travel and leisure, highlighting top wineries to visit worldwide. It is categorized under the Entertainment section and focuses on cultural tourism rather than agricultural production or economic analysis.

title: Glenn Miller Orchestra to perform at Avlaon
author: Staff Writer
content:
Glenn Miller Orchestra to perform at Avlaon

 September 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 168
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Avalon Theatre in Easton is hosting a number of jazz, swing and big band performances through the end of the year.That includes a concert by the Glenn Miller Orchestra on Saturday, Sept. 21. Tickets are $35 The show starts at 7 p.m.
According to an announcement from the Avalon promoting the concert:
"The legendary Glenn Miller was one of the most successful of all dance bandleaders back in the Swing Era of the 1930s and '40s. A matchless string of hit records, the constant impact of radio broadcasts and the drawing power at theaters, hotels, and dance pavilion, built and sustained the momentum of popularity. Today, the 18-member ensemble continues to play many of the original Miller arrangements, from the swinging 'Chattanooga Choo Choo' to the beautiful 'Midnight Serenade.' It also plays some more modern selections arranged and performed in the Miller style and sound. Just as it was in Glenn's day, the Glenn Miller Orchestra today is still the most sought after big band in the world." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article announces a live music performance by the Glenn Miller Orchestra and is published in the Entertainment section, making Entertainment the most appropriate category.

title: Mid-Shore Calendar
author: Staff Writer
content:

 Words

Learning the requirements of obtaining government contracting will open a whole new world of opportunities for your daycare business. Register: womensbusinesscenteratmarylandcapitalenterprises.org/classes/2398/.

Jeff Thompson, a research psychologist at Columbia University Medical Center and retired NYPD detective, will: discuss key risk factors and warning signs, clarify and separate common myths from factsProvide practical tips for everyone, regardless of background. OXFORD LAB UPDATE, 5:30 p.m., Oxford Community Center. Talk is in partnership with Oxford Museum and is in conjunction with the Museum's Oxford Lab exhibit. Free. RSVP at oxfordcc.org.

title: Swans, butterflies, elephants and the 'Art of Storytelling': Chesapeake Film Festival returning to Easton
author: Staff Writer
content:
Swans, butterflies, elephants and the 'Art of Storytelling': Chesapeake Film Festival returning to Easton

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1825
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The 17th Annual Chesapeake Film Festival will be held in Easton at the Ebenezer Theater from Friday, Sept. 27 through Sunday, Sept. 29.Here are some of the prime details for the annual event.
For ticket and event info: www. chesapeakefilmfestival.com
Location: Ebenezer Theater at the Prager Family Arts Center (17 S. Washington Street, Easton, Maryland)
Friday, Sept. 27 events Opening day film: "Call Me Dancer" (Noon)
The documentary film was directed by Leslie Shampaine and Pip Gilmour. According to a description from the festival the film features:
"Manish, a young and talented street dancer from the City of Dreams, Mumbai. He struggles against his parents' insistence that he follow a traditional path because they depend on their son's support. When he accidentally walks into an inner-city dance school and encounters a curmudgeonly 70-year old Israeli ballet master, a hunger develops within him. Ambitious and passionate, Manish is now determined to make it as a professional dancer, but the odds are stacked against him."
After the film, there will be Q&A with director Leslie Shampaine
2024 Women of Impact Award Short Film Block (2 p.m. to 4:15 p.m.)
A number of films will be featured Friday including:
"Dear Josephine" (directed by Amber Monet): "Josephine Baker was a global icon known for her iconic banana dance, but what many may not have know is how much Ms. Baker contributed to what we know today as classical ballet."
"Interception: Jayne Kennedy, American Sportscaster" (directed by Safiya Songhai): "When a bronze-skin bombshell rocks the world of Sunday Morning Football, millions tune in...but few know the tumultuous story of Jayne Kennedy, the first Black woman to boldly run interception on the racial lines of American sportscasting."
"Noisy" (directed by Cedric Hill): "Sam gets on the subway to get home. He catches the eye of April. The two of them discover they have way more in common than where they're heading. Sometimes you need a noisy place to have a quiet conversation."
"Superman Doesn't Steal" (directed by Tamika Lamison): "Based on true events this is a coming of age story, set during the 1970's as seen through the eyes of 9 year old Harriet & her brother, who are fascinated with superheroes. However, when they experience a troubling series of Page 3 events, the impact on their family leaves emotional scars and causes them both to grow up as they redefine their understanding of heroes, villains and Superman."
"Every Monday Night" (directed by Nate Houghteling): "In Berkeley, California, a group of men in their 70s and 80s work out some of life's biggest questions on the basketball court."
"Losing Blue" (directed by Leanne Allison): According to CFF, the film "explores the profound concept of losing a color, particularly focusing on the disappearance of the unique blues found in glacier-fed alpine lakes. These mesmerizing hues, shaped by geological processes over millions of years, are now under threat due to climate change. Through stunning cinematography, the film serves as a metaphor for the broader impacts of environmental degradation.
"Racing Rivals: Log Canoes of Chesapeake Bay": "Elegant and agile, propelled by outsized sails offset by nimble crew serving as human ballast, the iconic racing fleet of Chesapeake Bay log canoes embodies tradition, speed and grace. On breezy summer weekends, those that restore, race, and revere them are out to win, but not at the expense of these unique vessels. "Racing Rivals: Log Canoes of Chesapeake Bay" introduces us to this uniquely Chesapeake sport and the passionate sailors vying for coveted trophies."
The evening of Friday, Sept. 27, will also feature several environmental films. Those include:
"Chesapeake Rhythms" (directed by Dave Harp and written by Tom Horton): "A magnificent celebration of the native trumpet swans who migrate to the marshes of the Eastern Shore."
"Diary of an Elephant Orphan" (directed by Hermien Roelvert-Van Gils): "Over the past decade, Southern Africa has witnessed a surge in orphaned and displaced elephant calves due to increased poaching and human encroachment on their traditional habitats. This Page 4 crisis prompted the establishment of an orphanage with an adoptive family structure crucial for the well-being of these vulnerable elephants. Baby Khanyisa, a three-month-old albino calf rescued from a wire snare, becomes a focal point for hope as Adine and her team endeavor to save her life and integrate her into the Jabulani herd, which uniquely comprises mostly former orphans, offering a promising solution to the challenges of elephant rehabilitation in South Africa."
"Every Acre Counts" (directed by Andrea Campbell): "Farmers in the Chesapeake watershed are a critical part of the Bay's restoration and its future. In Every Acre Counts, four farmers from Maryland and Pennsylvania explain why farming is so important to them and how they're utilizing new technology and techniques to better care for the land."
Saturday, Sept. 28A number of films and documentaries will be featured including:
"A Photographic Memory" (directed by Rachel Elizabeth Seed): "A Photographic Memory is an intimate, genre-bending portrait of a daughter's attempt to piece together a portrait of her mother, an avant-garde journalist and a woman she never knew."
"ImPossible" (directed by Seckeita Lewis): "When a man with big dreams is diagnosed with a life-threatening illness, he forms an unbreakable bond with a widowed fast food worker to do the impossible; transform his life and pursue his passion of becoming a police officer."
"Chinese Painted Paper Cutting Folklife Apprenticeship": "Master artist Shanye Huang taught Chinese painted paper cutting to apprentice artist Etian Huang in a documentary by Wide Angle Youth Media for the Maryland State Arts Council. Funded by Maryland Traditions, Folklife Apprenticeships support the transmission of cultural traditions, enabling master and apprentice artists to collaborate for up to one year. Wide Angle Youth Media, a Baltimore-based production company, amplifies the voices of youth and equips them with media arts skills to document stories across social divides."
"Jamie Wyeth and the Unflinching Eye" (directed by Glenn Holsten): "Part of a three-generation dynasty of painters, Jamie Wyeth has carved out a singular path in the art world. His subjects include John F. Kennedy, Andy Warhol, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Rudolf Nureyev, animals on his farm and on islands of Maine, all through his unique, and sometimes unsettling, lens. Jamie Wyeth and the Unflinching Eye is the first feature length documentary that embraces the full scope of the American artist's life and work."
Sunday, Sept. 29"The Art of Storytelling" event will be held at the Talbot County Free Library from 10:30 a.m. to 11:45 a.m. The event is free and will feature filmmakers from the festival. The library is located at 100 W. Dover Street in Easton.
"Immerse yourself in the world of creating a strategy for your film as professional filmmakers and authors share their stories on the making of their films. Join Glenn Holsten, director of Jamie Wyeth and the "Unflinching Eye", Leslie Shampaine, director of "Call Me Dancer", Vincent de Paul, director of "The Genius of Gianni Versace", Rebekah Louisa Smith, the Film Festival doctor who will share strategies for distribution, Monda Raquel Webb, CFF Board Member and director of "Mother Knows Best" and "Zoo" will share details about what it takes to publish and Theodore Adams, III, CFF Board Member and director of "Tri", "Tyndall Typewriter" and other films will talk about his screenwriting experiences with new films "Shine Box" and "Breathe."
Films featured on Sunday, Sept. 29 include documentaries and short films, including some directed by students.
"Imaginarius" (directed by Juan Ignacio Bello): "Florencia, Amanda, Matias and Agustin, fantasize about the Total Solar Eclipse that will arrive at their quiet hometown, The Elqui Valley an astronomic hotspot near the Atacama Desert. Amid the unusual frenzy that surrounds their town, the kids dream about a more sustainable and brighter future."
"Truth Tellers" (directed by Richard Kane): "Truth Tellers is a film about political artist Robert Shetterly's "Americans Who Tell the Truth", a project that explores our Page 7 country's ongoing struggle to live up to our democratic ideals with those who are not afraid to speak the truth nor challenge the status quo."
"Missing Figure" (directed by Jeremiah Battle): "A young man makes a call to his father who is no longer in his life before his upcoming wrestling match."
"For the Love of the Game" (directed by Ollie Killip): "Towson University's Women's Basketball Team fight through their turbulent first season under their new management team. Experience the season as they do, with a look into the lives of the players, coaches and staff that make the team tick, and be ready to fall in love with the sport all over again."
"Dance Party" (directed by Lucy Saper): "Layers of colorful screen-printed and airbrushed collaged dancers come to life in this vibrant animation."
"Things I Wish I'd Said" (directed by Riley Frutiger): "Unable to sleep, a girl writes a letter trying to articulate the complex emotional turmoil towards her dead brother that's keeping her awake."
"Monarchs in Motion" (directed by Mason Mirabile): "Monarchs in Motion is a documentary featuring footage from the Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserves in Michocan, Mexico. The film tells the story of the migratory Monarch and challenges across its migration from Canada to Mexico. The film features experts from WWF, Monarch Watch and Natural Habitat Adventures."
"Beauty" (directed by Carley Dernetz — In a visually engaging stop motion, a powerful slam poem delves into the weight of beauty standards and body image, as words cut out of paper are intertwined with images from Towson's literary magazine, revealing the struggle for self-acceptance in a world obsessed with appearance.
"Amathus" (directed by Lydia Mastrangelo): "Amathus is a retelling of the birth of Aphrodite that explores modern storytelling and femininity. "
"Portrait Day" (directed by Romina Melissa Nunez): "When a cat and dog are paired to draw each other for a class portrait assignment, total chaos ensues."
"Mary Through the Glass" (directed by Wyatt Cooper Carson): "Busy cars, dotted distant windows and aimless lights make up a city through the whimsical perspective of an indoor cat. "Mary" tells the story of a curious cat who finds the company of an imaginary friend more intriguing than the neighborhood cats, leading her to a new world."
"The Last Epic Ride" (directed by Rick Kain): "The Last Epic Ride is the story of a terminally ill man that, aided by his friends, goes for one last motorcycle ride along a familiar route. "
"Get on the Bus" (directed by Justinian Dispenza): "A journey involving over 50 individuals from Chestertown, MD, traveled to the Legacy Museum in Montgomery on August 25. Along the way, stops at significant civil rights locations in Birmingham, Selma, Montgomery, and Atlanta offered profound insights into often overlooked aspects of Black history and the contemporary African American experience. These experiences are captured in the documentary Get on the Bus!, which chronicles the transformative journey."
Closing Night Film
"In the Whale" (directed by David Abel): "An award-winning feature-length film. Arguably the greatest fish story ever told, though this one is true. It's the account of a man who survived to tell the tale of being swallowed by a whale, and what happened after he escaped. In the shark-filled waters off Cape Cod, Michael Packard has long tempted fate." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details the Chesapeake Film Festival schedule, films, documentaries, and related arts events, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category.

title: Production of Shakespeare's Hamlet features1920s styles
author: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com
content:
Production of Shakespeare's Hamlet features1920s styles

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 667
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Those who enjoy plays by legendary playwright William Shakespeare will argue about which one of the Bard's works is truly best, and one of those plays typically in the discussion will be featured this month as the Twin Beach Players present "Hamlet" for eight shows beginning Friday, Sept. 20 in North Beach.Directed by Harvey Williams and Rachel Clites Cruz, who also plays the title character, the Twin Beach Players production of "Hamlet" will feature the numerous memorable characters and lines made famous by the Bard centuries ago although in costumes more reminiscent of the 1920s. In one scene, however, known as the play within the play, the characters don costumes more conducive to far more basic productions.
Its numerous characters and plot twists are accompanied by memorable lines such as "To thine own self be true" and "There are far more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, than are dreamt of in your philosophy," and of course the engrossing soliloquy in which the title character initially asks, "To be or not to be, that is the question" as his madness approaches.
Williams, however, insisted that a hint of comedic tones were introduced to this version of the play.
"I've always loved Shakespeare," said Williams, who also plays King Claudius in addition to directing the play. "I've read 'Hamlet,' I've seen the play and the movies and I've always wanted to direct it. But for our version I wanted to have a 1920s theme, complete with the costumes and a lot of the characteristics of the era."
Cruz, who also admits a passion for performing in Shakespeare plays dating back to her youth, yields most of the directing chores to Williams for this version while also playing the title character.
Her willingness to assume the lead role came with the knowledge and understanding that Hamlet represents the ultimate challenge for any performer.
"Playing Hamlet is so challenging because his character is the epitome of all Shakespeare characters. He not only has the most lines and the most scenes, but he has seven soliloquies," she said. "But I've always wanted to play Hamlet and be a part of this production. This is only my second time actually being up on stage with Twin Beach Players, but we have an amazing cast and crew here."
Many of the Twin Beach Players regular performers each have key roles in "Hamlet," including Cruz as the title character and Williams as King Claudius and Alexys Adams as Ophelia, Aaliyah Roach as Laertes, Terri McKinstry as Polonius and V. Stardust as Horatio, although audience members will notice that, by design, three characters typically deemed male are played by actresses and intentionally dubbed as female.
Cruz and Williams both noted that the strength of the Twin Beach Players over the years has been its willingness to attract and develop younger performers, with Addie Quinn, still one year removed from her freshman year at Huntingtown High School, playing dual roles as Rosencrantz and Marcellus.
"I got into the theater mainly because my older brother was an actor," Quinn said. "I love working with the actors and directors here at Twin Beach Players. I usually have done other comedies, but I like being in something serious."
If you goThe Twin Beach Players production of Hamlet will run for eight shows at the North Beach Boys & Girls Club, located at 9021 Dayton Avenue in North Beach, from Sept. 20 to Oct. 5. Friday and Saturday shows will begin at 8 p.m. while the two Sunday shows on Sep. 22 and 29 will commence at 3 p.m.
Based on the timeless classic by William Shakespeare and directed by Harvey Williams and Rachel Clites Cruz, the TBP production of Hamlet will include the characters made famous by Shakespeare and will offer the same intensity and drama that onlookers have always expected from the show, but with 1920s attire and occasionally some comedic overtones.
Due to its adult content, dialogue and some scenes, however, this play is not recommended for children under 12 years of age.
For more information, go to twinbeachplayers.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a local theater production of Shakespeare's Hamlet, focusing on performance details, direction, and audience information, which aligns with entertainment coverage. It also touches on artistic aspects, making Arts & Culture a secondary candidate.

title: Celebrating dance and ballet as a community
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Celebrating dance and ballet as a community

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Entertainment 
 
 589
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Calling dancers and dance enthusiasts of all ages! If you enjoy dancing, enjoy watching the art of dancing, or enjoy entertainment paired with wine and light refreshments, these events are for you. On Sunday, Oct. 6, the Carole Cascio Fund For Mind Movement Dance Connections invite the whole community to join one or both of the following dance events.The first event invites intermediate and advanced dancers ages 14 and above to participate in a Ballet Masterclass from 1 p.m. to 2:30 p.m. at Kent Island High School in Stevensville. Doors will open at 12:30 p.m. Ballerina Nicole Duffy, from the acclaimed Hispanico Pa'lante Dancers of New York City, will instruct this complimentary class. At this class, dancers will also have the opportunity to audition for the Ballet Hispanico Summer Intensive. Although there is no fee for this class, registration is required. The registration link is: https://www.carolecasciofund.org/ccf-day-of-dance-ballet-masterclass-registration/
In the evening, the second event will bring the Acclaimed Ballet Hispanico Pa'lante Dancers on stage to perform at the Mark Cascia Vineyard in Stevensville at 5:30 p.m.; seating opens at 5 p.m. The event flier encourages the community to, "bring your lawn chairs and join us on the Vineyard for a fun day of lively celebration and performances. Join us on stage for dancing following the performance." Think Salsa dancing. One glass of wine is included with the entrance donation. Other light refreshments include: lemonade, iced tea, and select cheeses.
This event is the third annual benefit for the Carole Casio Fund. All students attend for free. Adult tickets are $25 each. Registration for this evening event is also required. The event is limited to 300 people. Tickets can be purchased in advance online or at the door. Both cash and credit cards are accepted. The registration link is: https://www.carolecasciofund.org/ccf-day-of-dance-ballet-masterclass-registration/
For almost two years, the Carole Cascio Fund For Mind Movement Dance Connections has enriched our local community with its beautiful exposures to and experiences with the art of dance. Executive Director of this fund, Peter Pucci, shares that he is excited to bring "quality dance from New York City." He is excited to "give the opportunity [to all] to see good, professional dance and celebrate dance." Pucci cherishes the past local dance events and the excitement of bringing all ages of the community together to enjoy dance.
Also, mark your calendar for Nov. 2, for another Carole Cascio Fund dance event entitled "A World Day of Dance" at Chesapeake College's Todd Performing Arts Center. This free day of dance will include dance classes with traditional Chinese Dance teacher, Rose Xinran Qi, South Indian Dance form with Deepti Mukund, and Traditional and Contemporary West African dance with Sylvia Soumah. This event is offered to dancers 12 and above. There will also be culminating performances by the dance teachers followed by a Q&A time as well.
Pucci credits and thanks the community for their support in making not only all these dreams and big ideas come to life but also for helping to remember and celebrate Carole Cascio. For Cascio says, "as we experience our world through moving in it and dancing about it, we remind ourselves of the truth and knowledge that is stored, away from awareness. When a dance is performed and watched, both dancer and audience share another person's awareness conveyed by a language that is universal and for which no words suffice."
If you have questions about these events, would like to donate to the Carol Cascio fund, or want more information, please contact Peter Pucci at ppucci@carolecasciofund.org or visit the website at https://www.carolecasciofund.org/ 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article promotes community dance events, performances, and classes, which are clearly entertainment-focused and fit the Entertainment category best.

title: Jazz, Americana shows coming to Avalon
author: Staff Writer
content:
Jazz, Americana shows coming to Avalon

 September 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 265
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Anthony "Turk" Cannon, a smooth jazz saxophonist from St. Michaels, will perform Friday, Oct. 4, at the Avalon Theatre in Easton.Cannon — who recently sold out tow shows at Blue's Alley in Washington D.C. — will perform with bassist J. Castro during his Avalon show.
According to an announcement from the Avalon promoting the show, "Cannon's love of music began at the age of nine, when he started playing the clarinet. Years later, holding a saxophone and breathing life into its soothing sounds, he discovered the soulful spark that ignites the palpable passion flowing from his horn each time he plays:
The Avalon said Castro is "renowned for his creativity in neo-soul, jazz, fusion and hip-hop."
"J Castro's music speaks of love and life's struggles. His improvisational chops to contemporary jazz elevates the mind of his listeners with a sound that pleases their ears and sets their toes tapping," the venue said.
Singer-songwriter Peter Bradley Adams will perform Saturday, Oct. 5 at the Avalon. The show starts at 7 p.m. Tickets are $30.
"Peter Bradley Adams, formerly one-half of the chamber Americana duo Eastmountainsouth, has gone on as a solo artist to scale back some of the 'mountain' and 'south' in his music for a more modern singer/songwriter approach," according to a concert announcement from the Avalon.
"Adams's musical journey delves into the nuances of tranquil and tumultuous romance, captivating audiences with emotionally charged lyrics. His brand of Americana nestles his often delicate, always heartfelt voice in the warm embrace of gentle guitar, tasteful dobro, subtle banjo, supportive bass, and unhurried percussion," the venue's announcement continued.
For more: https://www.peterbradleyadams.com/, https://avalonfoundation.org/, https://anthonycannon.com/

title: Bluegrass concert series returns
author: Staff Writer
content:
Bluegrass concert series returns

 September 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Music 
 
 369
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Bluegrass fans rejoice as another season of top-notch award-winning music is in store as the Southern Maryland Bluegrass Concerts returns for another year.The series features one concert per month through April.
The season will kick off at 2 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 6, when David Parmley takes the stage at the Calvert Elks Lodge No. 2620 at 1015 Dares Beach Road in Prince Frederick
Parmley is best known for his talent standing next to his father, Don Parmley, in the Bluegrass Cardinals that brought the new generation to their feet back in the 1970s when they moved to Washington, D.C., from the west coast of California. David Parmley has since led his own solo career with bands such as Continental Divide and the Cardinal Tradition.
After a short break from the road, Parmley made a comeback with a new sound and new look asking the question, "So Wha'd I Miss?" which is the title of his latest recording on the 615 Hideaway Records.
Keeping to his traditional roots Parmley is excited to start this new chapter in his career in music with an all-new traditional Bluegrass band.
The concert series continues Nov. 17 with the Larry Stephenson Band, continues with the traditional Bluegrass sounds of Joe Mullins and the Radio Ramblers on Dec. 15.
The new year opens with the Queen of Bluegrass Music Rhonda Vincent and the Rage from Nashville's Grand Ole Opry on Jan. 5, which a news release stated was "a rare and special occasion show sure not to miss."
The remainder of the series brings the return of fan favorites Lonesome River Band (Feb. 9), a doubleheader the following month will feature the hard-core mournful sound of the Junior Sisk Band (March 2) and singer/songwriter Donna Ulisse making her first appearance in the series on March 23.
Closing out the 2024-2025 concert series on April 27 will be 10-time award winning Bass Player of the Year in Bluegrass music Missy Raines and her band Alleghany.
Concerts begin at 2 p.m. and doors open at noon. Food and beverages will be available for purchase until 2 p.m.
Tickets are $23 for each concert, and $40 for the Jan. 5 concert, and are available online or at the door.
For more information, call 301-737-3004 or go to www.somdbluegrass.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Chesapeake Film Festival returns to Easton for 17th year
author: Tom McCall
content:
Chesapeake Film Festival returns to Easton for 17th year

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Entertainment 
 
 468
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Chesapeake Film Festival is bringing a wide array of features, shorts and documentaries to the Ebenezer Theater this weekend. It is the festival's 17th year, and the Friday evening VIP reception was sold out.The premier film, shown at noon Friday, was "Call Me Dancer," which is directed by Leslie Shampaine and Pip Gilmour.
Shampaine won a Fulbright Scholarship for her work on this film. The film was about a young man from the streets of Mumbai facing challenges to achieve his passion for ballet.
"The film was finished before I received the Fulbright," Shampaine said. "... My Fulbright was based on community impact in India for the film."
She said she is using the film to do a lot of outreach to underprivileged youth in India.
"One theme is everyone has a passion and the journey and obstacles that one goes through. Everyone has obstacles in their life. And the perseverance, hard work and hope that you need to keep going," Shampaine said.
John King, executive producer of the film, said it took over five years to complete.
"The biggest challenge was that this was an international production. The fact that it went from India, to the U.S., to Israel, to London and back to the U.S. And for independent documentaries raising the money is a challenge," King said.
Cid Collins Walker, executive director of the film festival, gave opening welcomes and introductions. This is her eighth year with the festival.
By the time the festival ends Sunday, 17 short and feature length films will have been screened in Easton. Filmmakers are coming from a variety of locales, from Chile, to Romania, to Los Angeles.
"As a producer of an event like this, you are always looking for a film that will grab the public's attention. A good opening film is really important. It is the first thing that people see," Collins Walker said.
Curating a film festival is an art in itself.
"I have learned over time that this is what the audience loves. The public loves to hear these stories right from the director or producer's mouth," Collins Walker said.
She said there is a driving purpose to her work.
"The arts are a great connecting force. It connects us all, and I believe we live in a fractured society, sadly. I like to produce these events to bring people together," Collins Walker said.
"The festival is good for the region. It is good for Talbot County. It is good for Chestertown. It is a hidden gem among our many arts celebrations. I would encourage people to check it out. I really love the way they highlight the unexpected," said Cassandra Vanhooser, director of the Talbot County Department of Economic Development and Tourism.
The festival has more screenings and events planned for Saturday and Sunday. To see a schedule and learn more about the festival, visit chesapeakefilmfestival.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the Chesapeake Film Festival, detailing screenings, filmmakers, and cultural impact, which aligns directly with the Entertainment category. Arts & Culture is a close secondary fit because film festivals are also cultural events.

title: Molly's Place brings outdoors lovers together for fun fall event
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Molly's Place brings outdoors lovers together for fun fall event

 October 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 593
 Words 

 Read News Document

 KENNEDYVILLE — Molly's 14th annual fall tent sale returned bigger and better, rebranded as the Maryland Outdoor Festival this year.All through the weekend, Sept. 20-22, Molly's Place set up a massive tent courtesy of Eastern Shore Tent and Events, packed with savings from favorite hunting, fishing and outdoor brands, offering up to 70 percent off purchases.
In addition, there were giveaways like four Yeti coolers worth $250 a piece, autographed by Orioles players and a Sunday Sweeps with a Traeger Grill package.
For three days, residents enjoyed the comfortable weather, browsing the sales, seeking familiar brands like Benelli USA, Hevi-Shot, YETI and many more.
But Molly's tent sale is not just for the hunters and anglers. Rebranded now, the staff aims to create an event enjoyed by the entire community.
One of the organizers Prakash "Chikki" Shajwani emphasized this point, "We wanted to give back to the community. This is a way of getting kids outdoors and for families to get together."
Marketing Director Sara Dion echoed his statements, mentioning the new vendors this year to do that: the decoy table, duck and goose call makers, and some fun activities for kids along with food trucks.
Under the tent with the callers and decoy makers, there was a wealth of information from experts of their craft, people willing to discuss their workmanship, honed from years of experience.
Like Sean Mann the World Goose Calling Champion of Champions. He won championships for duck calling and for making his own calls.
Working beside his son, Ian, who shows his talent for making calls, Mann said he owed his career path to the late Dan Edwards, an instructor at Anne Arundel College and a good friend.
"He made the dream possible. Without him none of this would have happened," Mann said.
These awe-inspiring stories weren't limited to just the vendors.
Looking at crossbows, Delaware resident Rene Swing casually mentioned how she once got a bear using a Horton Legacy crossbow, in a deer stand, in Maine.
These outdoor stories were all over the place, uniting residents and visitors.
Outside the tent, children enjoyed climbing the bouncy castle, The Triple Shots 4-H crew taught kids archery and beside them was a BB gun range run by the National Wild Turkey Federation along with the Queen Anne's County High School Clay Target Team, ensuring proper safety.
With cold beverages and good food there was also a nice mix of local talented musicians entertaining while spectators sat on hay bales.
The Quinn Arnold Band played on Friday, Joe Bryan sang and strummed classics on Saturday, and newcomer Elena Barnett with musician Justin Singleton, closed out Sunday with country, blues and rock covers.
For three days Molly's was bustling with activity.
Dion said last year they drew approximately 15,000. They anticipated recording as many this year, if not more.
Shajwani showed appreciation to all the volunteers such as the Chestertown Lions Club for helping park cars, the Kennedyville Volunteer Fire Company selling beer, and the Maryland State Police for helping on that busy stretch of road navigating people who came as far as Virginia and Baltimore for the event.
And he thanked the community recalling when the place was called Vonnie's noting how it was a hub for Marylanders to meet.
With their tagline, "Fuel your adventure," Shajwani said Molly's shows that same appreciation to the location's history and the culture while making their own mark.
Dion said, "We want to express our gratitude to the wonderful members of our community who attended the event and continue to support Molly's. Kent County holds a special place in our hearts, and we are honored to be part of this remarkable community." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community outdoor festival featuring music performances, vendor sales, and family activities, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category. Arts & Culture is a close second due to the cultural aspects of music and local traditions, while Business/Economy is a lesser fit because the focus is on the event experience rather than economic analysis.

Easton Beer Fest features 40+ breweries, wineries

title: Guitar heroes: PRS Guitars artist program hits record high
author: Staff Writer
content:
Guitar heroes: PRS Guitars artist program hits record high

 October 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 323
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Stevensville-based PRS Guitars announced its largest roster in the five-year history of the PRS Pulse Artist program. The program showcases influential guitar players affiliated with PRS via social media marketing and editorial content, links and offers them discounts with retailers and promotes them to sponsors and venues.PRS said the Pulse Artist Program is up 20% with the class of 2025 totaling 137 artists.
Four artists from the class of 2024 will be graduating to Official Artist status, an increased level of support, effective Oct. 15: Leoni Jane Kennedy (United Kingdom), Pannasit Sukahotu (Thailand), Tomo-Zo (Japan), and Dimitri Peters (United States).
"The global music scene is teeming with remarkable talent deserving widespread recognition," said PRS Guitars Director of Artist and Community Relations,Bev Fowler. "We created the PRS Pulse Artist program five years ago to highlight and support these up-and-coming guitar players. Through their various genres, they are expressing themselves through music that needs to be heard on a massive scale. The program also serves to connect these musicians with each other and to their local guitar dealers, increasing opportunities for development through community."
According to the Maryland company, the PRS Pulse Artist program helps guitar players form stronger relationships with their go-to retail store and each other. Through the program, artists are granted exclusive discounts on guitars, amps, and accessories through their local Authorized PRS Dealer.
"Becoming a PRS Pulse Artist opened so many doors to me, industry wise and for my mentality as a full-time musician and songwriter," said Leoni Jane Kennedy. "Having industry giants such as PRS supporting my creativity has not only been a dream come true, but has shown me what a team should really be. Now that I've graduated into the Official Artist roster, I feel I've achieved something so foundational to my career and I couldn't have asked for a better brand to represent and work with to show the world what I'm really made of. Thank you PRS!"
For more: www.prsguitars.com/artists. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Explore Maryland: Celebrate the Patuxent River at annual event
author: Staff Writer
content:
Explore Maryland: Celebrate the Patuxent River at annual event

 October 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 357
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Join an exciting celebration at Patuxent River Appreciation Day, one of Southern Maryland's longest-running festivals, as the festival marks its 46th year on Saturday, Oct. 12, at the Calvert Marine Museum.From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., families can enjoy a day packed with activities and free museum admission.
This year, the event will feature Fred Tutman, the Patuxent Riverkeeper, who will deliver a welcome address from the Waterside Pavilion stage at 11 a.m. Don't miss this chance to hear his insights on the importance of protecting local waterways.
PRAD promises a full day of fun, including toy boat building, live music, boat rides, crafts, and art vendors. Treat your taste buds with delicious options from a variety of food vendors, with beer and wine available for purchase.
The entertainment lineup at the Waterside Pavilion:
Bushmill Band: 10 — 11 a.m.
Riverkeeper's welcome address: 11 a.m.
One Trick Pony: 11:30 a.m. — 12:30 p.m.
Some Assembly: 1 — 2 p.m.; and
Groove Span: 2:30 — 3:30 p.m.
Explore the museum grounds, where dozens of nonprofit and community groups will showcase their efforts to celebrate and preserve the Patuxent River. Enjoy interactive exhibits, demonstrations on oyster farming, native plants and local wildlife, and a petting zoo.
Don't miss the Drum Point Lighthouse and surrounding boat basin for even more excitement.
Children can build their own toy boats, while the whole family is invited to enjoy free cruises aboard the Wm. B. Tennison, Witch of the Wave, Draketail and Poe Skiff. Try your hand at rowboats, pedal boats or navigating a remote-control sailboat.
Inside the museum, engage in a hands-on recycle craft, discover more interactive exhibits and visit the museum store for unique gifts that celebrate the Chesapeake Bay. Meet North American river otters Chessie Grace and Calvert during your visit.
PRAD is a testament to the community's commitment to preserving the Patuxent River and celebrating its vital role in our quality of life. This event reflects the collaboration of the Calvert County commissioners, the Calvert Marine Museum and various organizations dedicated to supporting local environmental programs and tourism.
For more information about the museum, visit the website at www.calvertmarinemuseum.com or call 410-326-2042. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article promotes a community festival with live music, crafts, and activities, fitting the Entertainment category, while also mentioning river preservation which relates to Environment.

title: 301 haunt conjures more attractions
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
301 haunt conjures more attractions

 October 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 242
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GALENA — Back and more frightening than ever is 301 Devil's Playground, a haunted attraction running until Nov. 9, located at 13335 Alexander Road in Galena."Come visit the scariest Haunted Attractions on the Eastern Shore," their website states, and for good reason.
301 Devil's Playground is the brainchild of Peter Nau, and has been recognized as one of Frightfind's 2021 Top Haunted Houses.
This year, some favorites return. The journey into the House of Hell. Then a haunted 3-D clown experience. This is followed up by lots of chainsaw wielding maniacs, bumps in the dark, monsters waiting in the shadows and chilling twisted dark tunnels.
Also back, heckling crowds who are waiting in line is the character, Biting Bill. If you have thinner skin than Bill, you might want to plug your ears while waiting.
What's new this year is the Barnyard.
Latasha Pennick, one of the organizers, and Nau's daughter, said in addition to the Barnyard some other changes have been made throughout the haunt.
So those attending last year, may see some variations this year.
And for newcomers, Pennick has confidence they will enjoy it as well.
"They will be amazed by all the detail that was put into our haunt and the uniqueness of it," she said.
301 Devil's Playground has five terrifying haunted attractions that will bring your fears to life: House of Hell, The Harvest (haunted corn maze), 3-D Phobia, The Barn of Torture and The Barnyard — an all new attraction.
For tickets, visit 301devilsplayground.com/. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a seasonal haunted attraction, its features, and ticket information, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category.

title: Folk legend Nash returning to Avalon
author: Tom McCall
content:
Folk legend Nash returning to Avalon

 October 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 527
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A Grammy Award-winning folk legend is coming to Easton in March. He wrote and sang the songs that defined a generation.This is the second time Graham Nash has come to the Avalon Theatre. Within hours, his two-night run on March 29 and 30 was nearly sold out.
The Avalon's 400-seat art deco theater is one of the most intimate places to see him perform. He is playing Wolf Trap and in much bigger markets like San Francisco, Dallas and Nashville.
He calls this this show "Graham Nash — More Evenings of Songs and Stories."
Nash epitomized the creative hotbed of Laurel Canyon, California, and dated Joni Mitchell. Before he was the Nash in the Crosby, Stills and Nash, he played in another vocally rich group called The Hollies. Both groups have been inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.
Suzy Moore, house manager and talent buyer at the Avalon, said, "When he was here in 2019 for one night, he was a wonderful and warm performer. When he sang 'Our House' and welcomed everybody to sing along, it was magic. It was my top magic moment in the Avalon Theatre in my 22 years."
She still keeps that moment saved on her phone.
"I have known that song my whole life," Moore said.
Nash's biography on the Avalon's website says, "Legendary artist Graham Nash, as a founding member of both the Hollies and Crosby, Stills and Nash, is a two-time Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductee. He has seen rock history unfold at some of its seminal moments — from the launch of the British Invasion to the birth of the Laurel Canyon movement a year later. An extraordinary Grammy Award-winning renaissance artist — and self-described 'simple man' — Nash was inducted twice into the Songwriters Hall of Fame, for his work with Crosby, Stills and Nash and his work as a solo artist."
To attract this kind of talent takes some effort.
"It is hard to get him. I have the relationships that makes this possible. This is one of the top agents in the country for venues our size. The artists that the agency represents speak so highly of their experience of the venue, the patrons that come and the town. We are known for providing a really great experience on the stage and while they are here in our community," Moore said.
"These shows are not possible without the support of this community who comes and buys the tickets to make these great experiences happen. It feels good that people are like, 'Yes we want them.'
In over 20 years of booking acts at the Avalon, Moore has seen a lot of talent come and go. She tries to gauge his level.
"At his level? Joan Rivers, Dionne Warwick, Wynton Marsalis, Randy Newman and David Sedaris. These are American icons," she said. "He is a legendary musician and an American icon."
Nash will be joined on stage by Todd Caldwell (keyboards and vocals), Adam Minkoff (bass, drums, guitars, and vocals) and Zach Djanikian (guitars, mandolin, drums, and vocals), performing favorites from across his 60-year career.
Aside from VIP tickets, the house tickets are $125, $100 and $80.
Go to avalonfoundation.org for more information. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article announces a concert by folk legend Graham Nash at a local theater, focusing on a musical performance and cultural event, which best fits the Entertainment category, with Arts & Culture as a close secondary match.

title: Valerie and the Sassafras Gang performs
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Valerie and the Sassafras Gang performs

 October 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 318
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BETTERTON — On a recent Saturday, the rain held out for some great music and camaraderie while the Betterton Community Development Corporation thanked their volunteers.The fall concert event was courtesy of the community development group with music from Valerie and the Sassafras Gang.
Music organizer Gerry Werner, who also coordinates Thursdays open mic night at C. Henry Price II, American Legion Post 246, took the act on the road — a quarter-of-a-mile down the road to be precise, at the Betterton Heritage museum.
The audience gathered on the lawn for some great music from 5 p.m. until dusk nodding to classics like "Stop Dragging my Heart Around," originally performed by Stevie Nicks and the late Tom Petty and "White Rabbit," by Jefferson Airplane.
Lead vocals Valerie Maitland easily hit those ranges.
Development corporation President Candi Sorge gave a speech to honor the volunteers, who work at the Betterton Heritage Museum on weekends. Each of the volunteers received key chains and a hearty show of gratitude from the over 50 in attendance.
Werner said their last concert in June was popular, and so they decided to bring it back.
With refreshments available, and volunteers selling museum items like T-shirts and hats, Werner noted they received more donations than last time.
He added it was fortunate they didn't have to move the whole thing inside because of rain.
"We really lucked out," he said. "It worked out well."
You don't need rain to urge you inside though.
The development group encourages the public to check out the museum for an expansive view of the town's storied past. Located in the Most Precious Blood Catholic Church, it is the result of a collaboration between the town and the Betterton Community Development Corporation.
The museum is "intended to serve as a community center and a showcase for historic artifacts, the space was beautifully renovated to both honor the past and provide a functional meeting place for the present," as their website states. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a local live music concert and community event, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category, with Arts & Culture as a secondary fit.

title: 9th annual Easton BeerFest brings community together
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
9th annual Easton BeerFest brings community together

 October 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 381
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Saturday, over 700 people attended the 9th annual Easton Beer Fest. The fundraiser gathered participants from throughout the Mid-Shore region to raise money for the Easton Volunteer Fire Department.This festival featured over 40 breweries, wineries and distilleries sharing over 120 craft beers, ciders, seltzers, wines and spirits from the region. Packed with live music, a variety of food, raffles and games, the Beef Fest, has become a staple on the Eastern Shore.
Chris Hash, Easton Beer Fest organizer and treasurer of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, said this fundraiser provides community engagement and a chance for residents to support their local fire department.
"It's a key fundraising event for the Easton Volunteer Fire Department and allows us to purchase equipment and do things necessary to live up to our motto, 'service for others,'" Hash said.
According to Hash, the event began in 2016 as a way to replace previous fundraising events such as Casino Night and Bull Roast. Now, nine years later, Beer Fest has become a large community event in Easton with a wide attendance from across the Eastern Shore.
Doug Greene, an attendee of Beer Fest, said major highlights of the event were the live music by local band Black Dog Alley and the opportunity for locals and visitors alike to support local businesses.
"I think it's a great way to be a part of the community, to engage in different industries and also, obviously, support the fire department," Greene said. "And one thing that I've always noticed is that a lot of people, after the day of the event, they go into town, they go to restaurants. They may stay for the night or the rest of the day. They really get involved in the area."
Cameron Swell, another attendee of the event, said Beer Fest is not only good for the community but helps attendees expand their horizons with local beers and helps them support local craftsmen and tradespeople from wineries to distilleries.
"(The Fire Department) had a ton of breweries, a bunch of rare beers, and they do one of the best jobs I've ever seen for an event, let alone a beer fest," Swell said. "They put a lot of heart and soul into it, and I know every year they look to improve on the previous year."
