title: America's haunted tourism industry generates up to $500M annually: 12 spooky destinations to visit
author: Elise Armitage Wealth of Geeks
content:
America's haunted tourism industry generates up to $500M annually: 12 spooky destinations to visit

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Elise Armitage Wealth of Geeks | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1135
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Every year, haunted tourism in the United States scares up profits of paranormal proportions.According to America Haunts, a group of 20 haunted attractions nationwide, the U.S. industry brings in between $300 and $500 million annually. Haunts throughout the country attract large crowds year-round, especially around Halloween.
In its 2023 Haunt Industry Report, HauntPay, a haunted attraction ticketing platform, reports 33% of haunts were expecting to receive upwards of 10,000 visitors, a notable increase from 2022. That year, 42% of haunted attractions saw visitor numbers between 1,000 and 5,000.
Venture beyond the grave and visit some of America's scariest real-life haunts to celebrate the season.
12 Terrifying Places in America to Embrace Your Spooky SideFrom abandoned prisons to historic homes and even a zoo, these are 12 of the scariest haunted locations in America worth visiting this month.
Eastern State Penitentiary, PennsylvaniaExplore the supposedly haunted grounds of Philadelphia's Eastern State Penitentiary — if you dare. This abandoned prison once held famous criminals like Al Capone and Willie Sutton before closing in 1971 and falling into disrepair.
"Visiting Eastern State Penitentiary is like stepping into a real-life horror movie," says Partners in Fire owner Melanie Allen. "The desolate, crumbling halls and long-abandoned rooms hold an unyielding tension."
Visitors can tour the prison year-round. The facility also hosts seasonal Halloween Nights, which feature haunted houses, spine-tingling tours, themed bars, and live entertainment.
The House of the Seven Gables, MassachusettsThe House of the Seven Gables, built in 1668, is among Salem's eeriest attractions. Nathaniel Hawthorne's novel of the same name mainstreamed the property.
The home is a must-visit for those interested in colonial architecture and Salem lore. Every October, tourists can enjoy autumnal storytelling performances that heighten the unsettling atmosphere ahead of Halloween.
Waverly Hills Sanatorium, KentuckyGhost-hunting enthusiasts flock to Waverly Hills Sanatorium, a former tuberculosis treatment center operational from 1910 to 1961.
Many visitors report supernatural encounters, from doors slamming on their own to sightings of a young ghost boy. Delve into the property's dark past on a guided tour, or pack a tote with essentials for a private overnight investigation.
Waverly Hills Sanatorium also hosts a terrifying haunted house during the fall, made scarier by the sanatorium's paranormal reputation.
Stanley Hotel, ColoradoThe Stanley Hotel opened in 1909 as a getaway for guests seeking upscale accommodations in Colorado's Rocky Mountains. Its reputation faltered in the 1970s, but one visit from author Stephen King changed everything. King later wrote his horror classic The Shining, drawing inspiration from Stanley Hotel.
Guests often claim to hear disembodied laughter, feel phantom touches, and sense ghostly presences. Amp up the scares during your overnight stay with a theatrical séance or nighttime tour.
Lincoln Park Zoo, IllinoisIn addition to the zoo animals you'd expect to see, Lincoln Park Zoo is reportedly home to several spirits. Lincoln Park was once the site of Chicago's official city cemetery, and some say thousands of bodies remain buried there today.
The zoo hosted its first official paranormal investigation in 2013 after reports of apparitions and disembodied voices in the Lion and Primate Houses.
October visitors can join an evening Haunted History Tour to learn more about the zoo's hauntings. Wear comfortable shoes like boots to enjoy the eerie surroundings while exploring the zoo after dark.
Ohio State Reformatory, OhioThe historic Ohio State Reformatory operated from 1896 to 1990 and is the ideal destination for supernatural lovers. Visitors may recognize it from The Shawshank Redemption, filmed there in 1993.
There have been many documented instances of dark figures and incorporeal voices at the Ohio State Reformatory, even among inmates before its closure.
The reformatory boasts an impressive program for those seeking a supernatural encounter, including group ghost tours and private, hours-long investigations.
The Mark Twain House, Connecticut
Step back in time at the Mark Twain House in Connecticut, where the famous writer and his family lived in the late 1800s.
This Victorian home is a hotspot for unexplained phenomena, including sightings of a ghostly woman in white — possibly the spirit of one of Twain's daughters who died there.
Guests eager to explore this haunt can embark on a Graveyard Shift Ghost Tour to learn the home's most fascinating tales from beyond the grave.
St. Augustine Lighthouse, Florida
The spirits of several young children who died there in 1873 supposedly haunt Florida's St. Augustine Lighthouse.
Some lighthouse employees and visitors claim to hear giggling and see ghostly apparitions, while others feel an otherworldly presence throughout the site.
Hear spine-chilling stories of the lighthouse's hauntings on a group tour, or bring ghost-hunting equipment to conduct a private nighttime investigation.
Winchester Mystery House, CaliforniaThe Winchester Mystery House is among San Jose's strangest attractions. The owner, arms company heiress Sarah Winchester, began the bizarre multi-decade renovation following her family's death. She expanded the home to 24,000 square feet, installing 160 bedrooms, 13 bathrooms, and six kitchens.
"Doors open to nothing, stairs lead to solid walls, and there seems to be an overall feeling of chaos and unsettling vibes that bothered me when visiting," explains Chantelle Kincy of Flannels or Flipflops.
Over the years, many guests have claimed to see specters and hear footsteps in the Winchester Mystery House. Visitors can see areas of the home on year-round guided tours or embark on a seasonal haunted maze through four of the mansion's floors.
Bonaventure Cemetery, GeorgiaWhile southern Georgia's Bonaventure Cemetery is among the world's most beautiful cemeteries, it's also incredibly unsettling.
"It was extremely quiet, and there was an overwhelming feeling of sadness as we walked around," Jessy Hamel of Brighter Things shares about her visit.
Various local legends surround the cemetery, including voodoo rituals and a child spirit that roams the grounds. In October, the cemetery allows guests to embark on a full moon tour, enhancing the creepy atmosphere.
The Conjuring House, Rhode IslandSee the terrifying real-life home that inspired The Conjuring movie universe. The house's haunted history stretches back centuries since its construction in the 1730s.
In the 1970s, the Perron family bought the home and immediately started having ghostly run-ins. At one point, famed paranormal investigators Ed and Lorraine Warren took an interest in the house.
According to the Perron family, at least two spirits — a married couple who passed away in the 1800s — haunt the house. Interest in the property spiked following the 2013 release of The Conjuring, a hit horror movie that spawned an entire franchise.
The current homeowner offers a variety of spooky experiences, from guided daytime tours to overnight investigations where you can bring a blanket and settle in for a night of ghost-hunting.
San Fernando Cathedral, TexasSan Fernando Cathedral, established in 1731, is a beautifully haunting church. It's the oldest of its kind in Texas and is said to be among San Antonio's most haunted locations.
Numerous bodies lie within the cathedral walls, and visitors have reported spectral sightings of dark silhouettes and mysterious orbs. Many San Antonio ghost tours visit the historic cathedral to highlight its storied past.
This article was produced by Media Decision and syndicated by Wealth of Geeks. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily highlights haunted attractions and spooky tourism destinations, framing them as experiences for visitors, which aligns with the Entertainment category. While it mentions industry revenue, the focus is on the attractions themselves rather than economic analysis.

title: CBMM's OysterFest in St. Michaels
author: Staff Writer
content:
CBMM's OysterFest in St. Michaels

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 534
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum's OysterFest is on Saturday, Oct. 26, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. in St. Michaels."At OysterFest, you're invited to enjoy oysters served a variety of ways, along with other local fare, craft beer, and spirits, plus fun for the whole family with live music on two stages, an oyster stew competition, a full schedule of demonstrations and presentations, children's activities, and more," CBMM said in an announcement promoting the local event.
Tickets are on sale now at cbmm.org/OysterFest, with discounted pricing for CBMM members.
The menu features oysters from the Talbot Watermen Association and several local oyster farms, with both raw and cooked options available.
There will also be local food vendors as well as craft beers and speciality cocktails.
"Don't miss your chance to buy an OysterFest mug and join the judging for the always-popular oyster stew competition. You'll sample offerings from area restaurants and then vote for your favorite to decide which chefs claim the coveted title and local bragging rights," CBMM's announcement reads.
There will also be music including from Swamp Donkey Newgrass and guest speakers
sponsored by the Upper Shore Regional Folklife Center through the Maryland Traditions Program of the Maryland State Arts Council.
Food historian Joyce White will discuss historical influences on Maryland's cuisine and her recent book "Cooking Maryland's Way: Voices of a Diverse Cuisine," and historian Eric Cheezum will share the incredible true story of the mysterious sea creature who captured the hearts and imaginations of the Bay region told in his book, "Chessie: A Cultural History of the Chesapeake Bay Sea Monster."
The American Chesapeake Club will be on hand to share demonstrations highlighting the retrieving abilities of its Chesapeake Bay retrievers, while Eric Jackson of Bay Fibers Studio will offer guests a free opportunity to create their own t-shirt designs.
Kids can explore life on the Bay through hands-on activities, including lawn games, model boat building, and more. The Phillips Wharf Fishmobile traveling aquarium will be on site, too.
To close out the day, cruise boat PATRIOT is offering a special OysterFest cruise on the Miles River as part of its final weekend of the 2024 season. Starting at 3:30 p.m., this 75-minute cruise features appetizers provided by Garden and Garnish, including oysters on the half shell. The cost is $62, with a $4 discount for CBMM members. Learn more and buy tickets at patriotcruises.com.
This year's OysterFest is generously sponsored by The Easton Group at Morgan Stanley, PNC Bank, RAUCH inc., and SafeTime by MAGI.
OysterFest tickets can be purchased in advance online or at the door. Admission is set at $22 for adults, $19 for seniors (65+) and students (17+), $10 for active and retired military members, and $9 for children ages 6-to-17, with all children 5-and-younger admitted free.
CBMM members receive discounted pricing to OysterFest and other annual festivals celebrating the best of the Bay throughout the year. Adult member tickets are $10, and all children of members (17-and-younger) receive free admission. CBMM members at the Family & Friends level and above can also receive the $10 discounted admission for two additional adult guests.
During the festival, additional free event parking will be available at St. Michaels Middle/High School, with a free service running to and from CBMM's waterfront campus. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'Stage Fright' brings dark humor to Avalon
author: Staff Writer
content:
'Stage Fright' brings dark humor to Avalon

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 518
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — This Halloween, immerse yourself in a haunting, unforgettable journey as "Stage Fright: Curtain Call" returns to the Avalon Theatre from Wednesday, Oct. 23, to Sunday, Oct. 27. With shows at 6:30 p.m. each night and additional 9:30 p.m. performances on Thursday through Sunday, this locally written and directed show promises a macabre experience that blurs the lines between reality and delusion.The production is recommended for ages 16 and up; guests under 16 must be accompanied by a responsible guardian. Tickets are available through the Avalon Foundation website at avalonfoundation.org/event/stage-fright-curtain-call.
Set in 1997, "Stage Fright: Curtain Call" invites audiences into the dark, twisted world of Lou Baker, a 95-year-old former showman tormented by a violent past and spectral figures. Facing release from a psychiatric institution after over three decades, Lou's story unfolds through a captivating, immersive theater experience filled with unresolved mysteries, dark humor, and a chilling confrontation between past and present.
Inspired by real ghost stories, the experience features sound and lighting effects, unique smells, special themed drinks and specially crafted Lyon Rum cocktails, making it an evening attendees won't soon forget. Mature themes and extensive walking are part of this production.
"Stage Fright: Curtain Call" is the thrilling final act of a trilogy, with each installment having been set in a different era — 1927, 1964 and now, at the turn of the century in 1997. The production explores the final days of Lou Baker, who is "95 and can barely get out of bed on his own." When presented with one last chance to release the spirit of Marguerite, his long, lost love and the ghost of the Avalon Theatre, he is met with a harrowing twist in his spiraling and tortured tale.
Attendees are encouraged to dress up in their favorite '90s attire or Halloween costume. The play draws heavy inspiration from '90s MTV, and The Factory invites guests to arrive as their best Britney Spears, Madonna, Notorious B.I.G., Spice Girls, and other '90s celebrities.
Cecile Strom directs the production, with Talley Wilford as assistant director and Casey Rauch as writer and co-collaborator.
"A key element of The Factory's immersive productions is the integration of film," Director Cecile Storm said. "It adds depth, context, and atmosphere to the live experience. This production takes this idea to new heights. I don't want to give too much away, but expect the boundary between stage and screen to blur in exciting and unexpected ways."
Katie Cox stars in the leading role, supported by the Beauty Shop Quartet: Jennifer Madino as Marguerite Gardot, Grace Vorosmarti as Shirley Boudreaux, Maddie Megahan as Vivian Baker and Jeri Alexander as Minnie Valentine. Art and production are managed by Maggii Sarfaty, and Ray Nissen leads the music direction.
"The acting is captivating and intense. The music is well done and is such a nice touch to this already so creatively awesome haunted house-like experience," shared an audience member from a past production. Another remarked, "It was great to see how the connection is made and everything is so eerily familiar, seeing as it's about the ghost that has haunted the Avalon for many years right here in Easton." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article promotes a local immersive theater production, focusing on performance, costumes, and audience experience, which aligns directly with the Entertainment category.

title: 'Mommy's Adventures' takes young readers on a ride
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
'Mommy's Adventures' takes young readers on a ride

 October 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 287
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — Local author Morgan Glenn invites you to Rollercoaster Land. It's a magical destination where readers go on rollercoasters, enjoy slides, and ride the teacups, as any great amusement park should offer.But you need a mode of transportation usually involving wheels to get to Six Flags America.
But to get to Rollercoaster Land, you just need imagination and Glenn's storytelling.
"Mommy's Adventures," is her first book, self-published, inspired by life with her seven-year-old son, Wyatt.
"It starts out with the mother trying to get her son, Wyatt, to bed. Naturally, he doesn't want to go. So mom pulls out her magical handbag," Glenn explains.
Inside the bag are traveling goodies like sunscreen and a map. Mom utters a special rhyme, and like "The Wizard of Oz," they are whisked away, Rollercoaster Land being the first of what may be many magical locales.
The 30-page book is for ages 3-8, with colorful illustrations from Pakistani artist Ayshea Zaki.
Like the mom in her story, 31-year-old Glenn is being whisked away too. At the beginning of the month she had the joy of reading her book to kindergarteners in H.H. Garnet Elementary School.
And as a cafeteria worker at Rock Hall Elementary School, she has a captive audience, who, at times, are probably more insistent than traditional publishers.
"They're coming up to ask me, 'when's the next book coming out?'," Glenn laughed.
This one took her about six months to write and she's planning on having a table at the next Rock Hall Fall Fest, an event that features various vendors.
For the magic seekers interested in her book, they can find it at Amazon.com under "Mommy's Adventures."
And where are mommy and Wyatt off to for their next mystical journey?
"Maybe space," Glenn said with a smile. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a newly released children's book, its author, and related local events, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category.

title: Candy corn conflict! The Halloween treat that divides us
author: Anne Jolly Food Drink LIfe
content:
Candy corn conflict! The Halloween treat that divides us

 October 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Anne Jolly Food Drink LIfe | Section: Entertainment 
 
 999
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Love it or hate it, candy corn is a Halloween staple. Some people can't resist candy corn's super-sweet taste, while others think it's too artificial and sugary. Whether you're a fan or a skeptic, there's no denying that this tiny, tri-colored treat has a fascinating history that goes beyond mere snacking.There's a little in-between when it comes to this iconic Halloween candy. The great candy corn debate gets people fired up at parties and sparks social media discussion. It's like the pineapple-on-pizza argument but with candy.
Candy corn's unique texture and flavor make it either a classic favorite or a sugary blunder. But no matter how much discussion it provokes, candy corn is a Halloween symbol that you'll find everywhere, just like pumpkins and costumes.
The sweet debateSo, what's the deal with candy corn's love-it-or-hate-it reputation? It all comes down to the flavor. Candy corn is just a mixture of sugar, corn syrup and honey. It's got a waxy feel and a super-sweet taste.
For some, this combo is a match made in heaven; they love the simple, old-school sweetness, which reminds them of trick-or-treating as kids. As Amanda from Simply Awesome Trips reflects, "I love it — It's the perfect bite of sugar. You can't have fall without candy corn. It's like pumpkin spice or Mariah Carey at Christmas. Love it or hate it, the season hasn't truly arrived without these things."
Others think candy corn is just too much; the sugary flavor seems fake to them. The texture is another point of contention — some find it pleasantly chewy, while others say it is weirdly waxy. "I hate candy corn. It's a sad waste of calories! They're pretty to look at, but they taste like a sugary wax candle," Gena Lazcano, from the blog Ginger Casa, argues.
How you feel about candy corn depends greatly on your childhood memories. If you grew up loving it, you're probably still a fan. But if you never liked it, you won't develop a taste for it as you get older.
Generation gapYour age also affects your candy corn preferences. Older generations tend to view it more favorably, probably due to nostalgia. A survey from the National Confectioners Association (NCA) found that candy corn is most popular with GenXers, with 58% of them enjoying it.
Younger generations are divided; some see it as a retro treat, while others ignore it. The same NCA survey found that only 46% of Millennials enjoy candy corn, showing that the popularity of candy is gradually decreasing.
Candy corn through the yearsCandy corn has been around for over a hundred years, starting in the 1880s in Philadelphia. At first, it was called chicken feed because the pieces looked like corn kernels. The candy was marketed to farmers as a special treat with a farm theme.
Candy corn's connection to Halloween happened gradually. As trick-or-treating became popular in the 1950s, candy corn was a common choice for Halloween handouts. Its orange, yellow and white colors perfectly fit the season's theme. Plus, it was affordable and easy to distribute.
Today, it's hard to imagine Halloween without candy corn, but its popularity has been slowly fading. While Halloween candy sales continue to grow, candy corn sales are slowing, a recent CNN report indicates. Sales of other non-chocolate candies like gummies and marshmallows are taking some of candy corn's market share.
Cultural impactCandy corn's influence goes beyond the candy bowl. It is featured in Halloween decorations, costumes and social media posts. Its distinctive three-color design has become a symbol of fall and the Halloween season.
Food manufacturers have created candy corn-inspired products like ice cream, popcorn, coffee creamers and candy corn cookies. Craft breweries even make candy corn-flavored beers. Love it or hate it, candy corn has cemented its place in American pop culture.
You will also see candy corn used to decorate homes. From the blog Get On My Plate, Casey Rooney has found decorating is the solution to her dislike of candy corn, explaining, "I used to hate candy corn, but my daughters love it. They started filling glass jars with it and putting them around the house. It looked so pretty and festive for fall. Instead of eating it, now I just use it as part of my fall decor!"
Seeing candy corn in Halloween decorations and at parties adds a nostalgic element that brings back all sorts of memories. It's a warm and fuzzy feeling reminiscent of happy childhood times.
Alternatives and variationsThere are creative alternatives if you want to incorporate candy corn into your Halloween celebrations but aren't a huge fan of the taste. Combine candy corn with other ingredients, or try recipes that feature the iconic candy corn look without the overwhelmingly sweet flavor.
Mixing candy corn with peanuts is very popular. The salty flavor of the peanuts goes perfectly with the sugary taste of the candy corn, and the mix of crunchy and chewy textures makes it extra satisfying to eat.
You can also create treats that capture the spirit of candy corn without the flavor. A simple idea is to make a candy corn-inspired parfait. Layer some mango, mandarin oranges and yogurt in a clear glass jar for a snack that looks like candy corn but tastes fresh and fruity.
Or make candy corn fudge. White chocolate and food coloring can create those signature yellow, orange and white stripes in a treat that tastes like chocolate, not candy corn. Add some food coloring to your favorite Rice Krispie treat recipe, and you've got a snack that looks like it came from the candy store.
Halloween classicPeople might argue about how candy corn tastes or feels in your mouth, but one thing is certain — it's a big part of American Halloween traditions. Its one-of-a-kind look and connection to Halloween make it a favorite symbol of the season, even if you don't like eating it. It'll keep sparking smiles, starting conversations and maybe even causing a few arguments for many Halloweens to come.
Anne Jolly is the creator of the food blog Upstate Ramblings. She loves cooking but doesn't love candy corn. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the cultural debate and pop‑culture significance of candy corn, fitting the Entertainment section where lifestyle and food trends are discussed.

title: Denton Fall Festival brings out costumes, community
author: Tom McCall
content:
Denton Fall Festival brings out costumes, community

 October 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 288
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Painted pumpkins, candy and a miniature bride of Frankenstein all flocked to the downtown park for a family friendly Fall Festival Oct. 30.There was a costume contest that gathered adults and children alike. A face painter worked past sundown as the fairy lights twinkled during a spectacular sunset. There were vendors selling essential oils, lemonade and cheeseburgers. There was a haunted house that would only take four people at a time.
Isabel O'Brien caters at the Culinary Center and had a table at the event. She had a chef's toque and thin mustache drawn on her upper lip.
"This is my first time being a part of this event specifically. I am just so glad to see that there are so many opportunities for the kids to come out and get as much candy as they can," O'Brien said.
Director of Downtown Denton, Jessica Jean Willoughby, was the primary organizer of all this spooky fun. She loved seeing all the families dressed up and making memories.
Jill Pugh, president of Downtown Denton Main Street, said, "We run several events each year and this Fall Festival is one of them."
Willoughby has written roughly $50,000 worth of grants to stimulate Denton's downtown. She wants to bring businesses and community together.
"I bring community together with all of the festivals. If you bring kids downtown, you bring families. I want to bring lighting all the way down the street. The ones that go across the street. I want to bring people together and just have a good time," Willoughby said.
Alicia Moxley, a member of Downtown Denton Main Street said, "Downtown Denton is a beautiful space, but we still have room to grow. This is a great opportunity to bring people into our town."

title: The English Beat, Marshall Crenshaw at Rams Head on Stage
author: Staff Writer
content:
The English Beat, Marshall Crenshaw at Rams Head on Stage

 October 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 259
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The English Beat will be at the Rams Head on Stage in Annapolis for a show on Saturday, Nov. 16.The English Beat originally formed in 1978 in Birmingham, England, and became known for its mix of pop, rock, reggae and ska music. The group's members were also part of popular bands Fine Young Cannibals and General Public.
The current incarnation of the English Beat performing at Rams Head is led by vocalist and guitarist Dave Wakeling.
The Annapolis is for all ages and starts at 1 p.m.
For tickets, prices and more info: https://www.ramsheadonstage.com/ and http://englishbeat.net/
'SOMEDAY, SOMEWAY'
Rock 'n' roll stalwart Marshall Crenshaw will perform at Rams Head on Stage in Annapolis on Tuesday, Nov. 19.
Crenshaw's rock resume includes 13 albums, playing Buddy Holly in the movie "La Bamba" and the 1980s pop hit "Someday, Someway."
The Rams Head show starts at 7:30 p.m.
According to an announcement from Rams Head, Crenshaw's four-decade musical career includes "13 albums, Grammy and Golden Globe nominations, film and TV appearances (Buddy Holly in "La Bamba") and thousands of live performances. Marshall Crenshaw's musical output has maintained a consistent fidelity to the qualities of artfulness, craftsmanship and passion, and his efforts have been rewarded with the devotion of a broad and loyal fan base. Presently, along with touring around the country and the occasional recording project, other current projects include producing a documentary film-in progress about legendary record producer Tom Wilson."
"This is a road that I'd never imagined taking before, but it's been an incredible learning experience," Crenshaw said in the announcement.
For tickets, prices and show info: https://www.ramsheadonstage.com/

title: Mactoberfest draws hundreds to Denton
author: Tom McCall
content:
Mactoberfest draws hundreds to Denton

 November 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 279
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — A gouda time was had by all at the sixth annual Mactoberfest. The Oct. 25 macaroni and cheese contest, hosted by the Caroline County Chamber of Commerce, was held at the Chesapeake Culinary Center.Chef Tahya Jones won a second consecutive Big Cheese title. The trophy was stuffed with Swiss cheese.
Other chefs included David Murray, Ken Zellers, Keith Blake and David Kneller. DJ Jason played music for the event.
The voting was done by the people in the crowd.
"There were two vegan macs that were made without cheese. It is like going in with your arm tied behind your back," said Victor Reynolds. He manned the CASA tent with around 30 other vendors.
Angel Perez of the Culinary Center said he was mostly in the VIP Area. All of the VIP tickets for the event were sold.
"It is an event where seven different type of chefs compete for the best mac and cheese in Caroline County. I tried all of the macaronis. The winner had a really nice seafood mac and cheese and a sweet potato mac and cheese. All of them were really good so it was hard to choose one," Perez said.
He went on to praise the event.
"It was a great event. It was nice to have the event back in Denton and it is already booked for next year. So it is going to happen at the Culinary Center again. We don't have anything like that around. People should come next year because it is a really nice experience and has great food," Perez said.
The chef sponsors included ScalpReveals LLC, The Paperwork Pros, Caroline County Council on the Arts, Cow Barn Events, Chesapeake Crier and Aflac.

title: Museum to host building bricks lighthouse challenge
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Museum to host building bricks lighthouse challenge

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 388
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Friends of St. Clement's Island & Piney Point Museums, the nonprofit organization that supports the St. Mary's County Museum Division, recently announced an exciting competition in honor of the oldest lighthouse on the Potomac River."To really celebrate Piney Point Lighthouse during the holidays, we thought this competition would be a fantastic way to get families and the community involved," St. Mary's County Museum Division manager Karen Stone said in a release. "What's even more fun is that everyone will be able to see their creations on display at the museum."
Participants will create a lighthouse model using interlocking building bricks and bring it to the Piney Point Lighthouse Museum for display and judging.
The rules are as follows:
All entries must be made with interlocking building blocks in any variety or brand
The final size for entries must be no bigger than 12-inches wide by 12-inches deep by 24-inches high
Entries must be placed on a sturdy base, such as plywood, foam core or heavy cardboard. The base should be able to support the weight of the entry without bending
No pre-assembled or lighthouse kits may be entered. The entry must be constructed as a completely unique creation; and
No electronics or other materials are allowed. All components must be interlocking building blocks.
The challenge has two age group categories: ages 12 and under and ages 13 and up.
Models should be brought to the Piney Point Lighthouse and Museum's main building at 44720 Lighthouse Road Piney Point between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m. Nov. 25-30 (closed Thanksgiving Day).
Winners will be selected by popular vote. Individuals who attend the Evening Tides event, Holiday Open House at Piney Point or visit the museum during December — the museum is closed Christmas Eve and Christmas Day — will receive a ballot.
Regular museum admission applies.
Additional tickets may be purchased at the museum store at five tickets for $1, with proceeds going toward the museum.
Winners will be notified Jan. 2, 2025. The overall winner in each age group will receive a $25 Amazon gift card and bragging rights.
Models will be on display throughout December for voting, and can be picked up between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m. from Jan. 2-12, 2025.
Registration is free. For more information or to register, contact 301-475-4200 ext. 1832, or janet.cooper@stmaryscountymd, or go to www.facebook.com/events/1418049026250622. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

 For the second time in three years, the culinary team from Bistro St. Michaels, led by Chef Doug Stewart, won the Oyster Stew Competition as part of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum's annual OysterFest.After blind polling of 350 guests who sampled six different stews during the recent festival, Bistro St. Michaels earned the People's Choice Award for Stew A. The Oaks Waterfront Inn and Chef Dave Donahue took second place with Stew E, while Gourmet by the Bay at the Village Shoppe, led by Sidney Trond, was third with Stew D. Ruse at Wildset (Stew B), Theo's Steakhouse (Stew C), and Hambleton House Catering & Events (Stew F) were also part of the fun.
CBMM was pleased to welcome more than 3,000 guests to celebrate OysterFest.
Up next, CBMM closes out its festival season with the Holiday Edition of the Eastern Sea Glass & Coastal Arts Festival on Saturday, Nov. 23, from 10am-4pm. Learn more and buy tickets at cbmm.org/SeaGlassFestival.

title: 'The stars aligned for us': Tall Ships festival delights
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Kent County News
content:
'The stars aligned for us': Tall Ships festival delights

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Kent County News | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1419
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For anyone who has ever fantasized about having a sailing adventure aboard a schooner or skipjack on the high seas, the Sultana Downrigging Festival in Chestertown is the place to be. For that matter, it's also a great place to be if you're a fan of unique small craft adventures, model ship building, maritime and Kent County history, bluegrass music, and a variety of Chesapeake-themed foods—because this three-day event has it all and then some!Over the last several years, all these interests have culminated into one of the most popular waterfront festivals in the mid-Atlantic.
A brisk, sunny morning ushered in the day's plethora of activities, which for many, began with the African American History walking tour. Chestertown's old Customs House, now known as Washington College's Starr Center, was the tour's jumping off point which then continued along the waterfront and into notable parts of Chestertown.
The waterfront, said community historian and tour leader, Airlee Ringgold Johnson, has changed quite a bit over the last two centuries, despite its nostalgic appearance with this past weekend's docking of tall ships in the marina.
"Our harbor is remarkably different from the harbor of 19th century Chestertown. There was once a seafood factory, a tomato factory, a basket factory, and a fertilizer factory," she said. "And there was always traffic going up and down the river."
Painting a picture of the challenges of the day, Ringgold Johnson and Paula Reeder, a volunteer for the Chestertown Heartland Group, pointed out some of the town's unique homes and architecture as the group headed to the intersection of Water and Cannon Streets.
By 1871, they explained, Chestertown was home to many freed slaves, or slaves who were able to purchase their freedom from their owners. There were also many rules to be followed, which included not owning a gun, a dog, or a knife, and following strict curfews imposed upon African American residents at that time. It was also well known that this particular part of Water Street was home to the wealthiest residents of Chestertown; but as you head south on Water Street where it meets Cannon Street there was a virtual dividing line between the wealthy homeowners and many of the community's African American population who worked for them and resided in the blocks just beyond Cannon and into the community known as Scott's Point.
While history and education are certainly a big part of what the downrigging weekend is all about, it comes in many forms, including the activities found a few blocks closer to the center of town where the Sultana Education Foundation is located. The Holt Center was home on Saturday to a merry band of live animals at the Echoes of Nature Exhibit, which included various turtle species, a black snake, a broad-chested, red-tailed hawk, and even a cute, cuddly chinchilla. The kids also enjoyed live music and the creative adventure of making their own sailor hats.
Holt Center also buzzed with the enthusiasm of model boat and ship builders and their admirers and like-minded enthusiasts.
Further down Cross Street, impressions of the sea-faring life were on exhibit at the Massoni Art Gallery where artist, Marc Castelli, was in house to talk to art lovers about the stories behind his paintings as depicted in his "Merrier" series of watercolors. Castelli, who also lives what he paints, is well-known for his genuine and realistic depictions of the men and women who take to their local waterways to make a living.
Castelli's book, "Illustrating the New Treasure Island" was also part of a series of book talks featured over the weekend and organized by the Bookplate, which included Edward O. Murdy's, "Field Guide to Fishes of the Chesapeake Bay."
Back down at the marina, by mid-morning the sounds of the bluegrass band, Serene Green, were providing a melodic backdrop for the scores of Downrigging revelers out to tour the impressive collection of tall ships, small crafts, and collector's boats that were on display by private owners and organizations alike.
There were a total of nine amazing tall ships on display. Joining Chestertown's own Schooner Sultana, were several ships out of Baltimore including The Pride of Baltimore II, Lady Maryland, and the Sigsbee, and ships that came from as far away as Nantucket's Lynx and Key West's Bloodhound, a replica of one of the very first racing yachts of its era. Many of the ships took part in group sails down the Chester River that carried some 3,500 passengers over the course of the weekend.
The Bleinberger family of Kent Island, who said this was their second trip to Chestertown's Sultana Festival, enjoyed an on-deck tour of the vessel, Maryland Dove.
"You can't beat the weather, and you can't beat the beauty of the tall ships," said Morgan Bleinberger. The family, who are avid boaters and self-proclaimed fisherfolk, are also fans of live music, so the event seemed like the perfect afternoon out with the family.
"We love bluegrass, too," said Hans Bleinberger of the music at the event. "The weather was perfect, so the stars aligned for us."
Kent County resident, Pat Jewell, who was also attending the festival on Saturday with her son, Zach, said she wanted to bring Zach's daughter, Georgia, out to see the big boats. Having roots on the Eastern Shore, Jewell said she has been to the festival many times.
"I grew up in Calvert County, right on the water… and I sail." Relaying that love of the water and these beautiful vessels is something she said she hopes to instill in her granddaughter.
While Downrigging is truly a festival for kids of all ages, it also serves as a celebratory reminder of the mission the Sultana Educational Foundation (SEF) takes on every year to ensure that all of the area's public school children have the opportunity to explore and learn what an awesome and diverse resource we have in the Chesapeake Bay.
Over the course of the weekend, Drew McMullen, president and founder of the SEF, can be found down on docks amongst the ships and many other members of the organization that help educate and instruct upwards of 12,000 public school kids per year that come in from Kent County and various parts of the Eastern Shore.
"Our core mission—and we're coming up on our 30th anniversary—from the beginning, we have been laser focused on environmental literacy for kids. Getting kids out on the Chesapeake Bay; that's why we build the Sultana," said McMullen.
The schooner Sultana is a historically accurate replica of a Boston-built merchant vessel that served for four years as the smallest schooner ever commissioned in the British Royal Navy. This vessel now serves as a floating classroom that conveys not just a history, but experiences in team building, and a perspective on our regional waterways that they might not otherwise have.
The Foundation's mission, said McMullen, is reinforced in the sense that a child will experience an average of 35 days of environmental instruction as they progress from kindergarten through eighth grade. In addition to experiencing being aboard the Sultana, the organization provides all manner of programs and field trips that immerse kids in the ecosystem of the Chesapeake Bay and its inhabitants.
"And while their teachers are the real heroes, our job is to do all sorts of things that teachers can't do in the classroom."
This also could not be done, he said, without the help of an extensive network of volunteers; 137 in all, (85 who participate in the festival weekend alone) and the support of a wonderfully receptive and engaged community.
"A lot of this works because the whole community helps out, either by donation, or by donating a good or a service," he said. "For a small town like this to support an organization like ours, is not an easy thing."
Beyond the educational aspects, McMullen said, Downrigging is an event unlike any other, as it is the largest annual gathering of tall ships in the nation, and it helps bring together a specific group of enthusiasts who share a passion for the beauty and prestige of tall ships and the historical maritime aesthetic that embodies them.
"Some participants fly in from hundreds and hundreds of miles away just to be here every year."
Besides that, he added, the festival is a fitting way to close out the instructional year for them.
"This is a way to celebrate … we are almost to the end of the year. This is the Sultana's last sail of the year, and it's sort of a way for us to say, 'Yes, we took a lot of kids out, now let's celebrate and have some fun!'" 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily describes a festival featuring tall ships, live music, and cultural activities, and is labeled under the Entertainment section, making Entertainment the best fit.

title: Falconry demonstration wows at VFW
author: Tom McCall
content:
Falconry demonstration wows at VFW

 November 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 520
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Raptors can be taught behaviors with positive reinforcement, says Brian Bradley, the owner of Sky Hunters in Flight and a master falconer.Bradley drove all the way from the Hudson Valley to give a raptor demonstration at the VFW in Easton for this year's Waterfowl Festival. He has been doing falconry for 47 years and he brought 10 birds. Each bird was in a large box with its named taped to the top.
There was a crowd of about 50 people on bleachers. Families and bird lovers were beguiled by the raptors, which provided a thrilling display and highly educational experience. The kids' eyes followed the giant horn owl's every move.
Falconry is over 3,000 years old, and humans have used birds to catch rabbits and foxes for centuries. Bradley said the practice traveled with trade routes. From places like Medieval Europe, to the Middle East, to China. Mongolian horsemen use eagles for hunting to this day.
"As far as the Middle East goes, it is very embedded in their culture. It is a huge thing for them, and it involves a lot of time and a lot of money invested. They take it extremely seriously, but it is practiced around the world," Bradley said. "It was a practical way to bring home meat before firearms."
Being this into falcons is a full-time pursuit. They have to be fed every day, and Bradley weighs each bird down to the gram to know if they are hungry or not.
They come to him when calls out or when he uses a hand clicker.
He brought out a barred owl, a red tailed hawk and the fastest animal on Earth, the peregrine falcon. He described how their wing structure determines what kind of flying and killing they can do. He also explained how an owl's cone-like face helped them to pick up sound like a satellite dish picks up a radio signal.
Many of these birds were threatened by the insecticide DDT in the 1960s and 1970s. They ingested small birds that had eaten bugs who had been poisoned with DDT. The birds' eggs were affected. With shells that were too thin, the babies died.
"At one point there were almost no peregrine falcons recorded east of the Mississippi River. Without passionate falconers, there probably wouldn't be falcons today. They started to breed them in captivity. They got rid of the poison and now the falcons are rebounding. It is probably the greatest conservation success story in our history," Bradley said.
He loved the birds right from the beginning.
"I appreciate what they do in nature and the fact that they do it so dramatically and so athletically. It is just thrilling to watch," he said.
All of his birds were bred in captivity, with the exception is his hunting bird, the red tailed hawk.
He caught it with a net in the wild. He used a live pigeon during the hawk's migration season. It has to be the right age to keep legally. He will train the young hawk for five years and then let it go when it is sexually mature.
"It feels good to let a bird go." he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a falconry demonstration at a local festival, focusing on a public performance that entertains and engages the audience, making Entertainment the most fitting primary category.

title: There's plenty to eat in Easton: Fest-goers feast on food and drink
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
There's plenty to eat in Easton: Fest-goers feast on food and drink

 November 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: Local News 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The hordes of people converging on Easton on foot, some pushing strollers and others walking dogs, got enough exercise to work up a waterman's appetite Saturday.The Waterfowl Festival street vendors and those with stations under tents were ready for them.
"It's going great, it's a good turnout," Angie Tyler of Rusticana Pizza said of her business' first time at the 53-year-old fest. "We're a family business, we've been around for 40 years."
While the Waterfowl Festival is known for its seafood vendors, Tyler said Rusticana offered "a little something different" with New York-style pizza that's "always homemade."
RaR, a Cambridge-based brewery with an eclectic menu, attracted customers anxious to sample Eastern Shore comfort food. RaR (which stands for Real ale Revival) had location set up on Harrison Street. Marcy Harrison, RaR's catering director, said it was the first time the brewery has had such a location at the festival.
Among the menu items for sampling was venison chili. RaR chef Victoria Tanner said this is a "traditional chili" with black, kidney and pinto beans, using traditional spices and light tomato sauce. The venison is purchased from "local vendors."
"It's nice and traditional," Tanner said. The spicy chili was augmented by a slice of cornbread.
Whether looking to enjoy alcoholic beverages or something less spirited, fest-goers got samples of both at the tasting pavilion.
Monika Mraz of Doehrn Tea Company in Oxford said her products are imported from mostly Asia — China, India and Sri Lanka — where popular black and green teas are grown. Teas that are caffeine-free, grown in South Africa, are also part of the inventory.
"I'm discovering we have a great tea-drinking community," said Mraz, who noted she has customers who start their day with coffee "and then they move onto tea. It's a little less harsh on the stomach. Tea is a lot more like wine than coffee."
Wine lovers also had their favorite libation at the pavilion.
Candace Donahoe of Layton's Chance Vineyard and Winery had samplings of dry and sweet wines.
"We grow a great variety of grapes," Donahoe said. "We do lots of events."
The Layton family first planted grapes at their Dorchester County farm in 2007 and opened the winery three years later.
Some of the other Eastern Shore farm-to-food basket items available for sampling at the festival included Pepper's Pickles of Chestertown.
"We sell our products at farmers markets and through online shipping," co-owner Nikita Bocharv said.
Among the first-time food vendors was Experience Smith Island. While touting excursions on the classic deadrise workboat Circuit Rider, business owner Carole Ann Landon, a Smith Island Native, sold samples of the iconic Smith Island Cake.
"This is our four year of business and our first year at the Waterfowl Festival," Landon said.
The cake has been popular for centuries, and in 2008 the General Assembly designated it as Maryland's State Dessert.
The eight-to-nine-layer treat is no piece of cake to make, either. Fortunately, Landon does provide as part of her business' programs a Smith Island layer cake demonstration, available off island at a venue of customers' choice.
The cake and everything else consumable provided just another slice of good eating and thirst-quenching satisfaction at the annual Waterfowl Festival. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

It also mentions local businesses and farm-to-food items, giving secondary relevance to Business/Economy and Agriculture.

title: World Waterfowl Calling Championships echo through Easton High auditorium
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
World Waterfowl Calling Championships echo through Easton High auditorium

 November 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 373
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Quacks, squeals and honks reverberated through Easton High School's auditorium Saturday night.The World Waterfowl Calling Championships, the final event of the Waterfowl Festival's Saturday schedule, brought waves of camo to the school for the event's seven competitions: the Jr. World Live Duck Calling Championship, the Jr. World Goose Calling Championship, the World Team Live Goose Calling Championship, the World Team Live Duck Calling Championship, the World Live Duck Calling Championship, the World Live Goose Calling Championship and the World Goose Calling Championship.
Winners of the different competitions took home a variety of prizes including plaques, money and — of course — decoys.
Contestant John Walls took home the big title of the night, World Goose Calling champion, which came with a $5,000 check. This is Walls' third World Goose Calling Championship win.
After yelling for joy with his fists in the air, Walls told emcee Dave Bloodsworth, "It's the Super Bowl, man." He thanked his friends and family before talking about celebration plans.
"I'm going to have a lot of fun tonight," he said. "It's a bad night to be a Busch Light."
Other champions of the night include Logan Heibner, 16, named Jr. World Live Duck Calling champion; JT Johnson, 15, named Jr. World Goose Calling champion; Chandler Martin and Slayton Gearin, named World Team Live Duck Calling champions; brothers Bryan and Bobby Heim, named World Team Live Goose Calling champions; Seth Fields, named World Live Duck Calling champion and Chance Wadsworth, named World Live Goose Calling champion.
After his win, Fields thanked his wife.
"For listening to all my routines in the kitchen," he said.
Bloodsworth said five judges in the back of the auditorium graded contestants on their routine, flow and sound throughout the night.
Before the competition began, junior callers Carter Whaley, 14, and Peter Aul, 16, sat on the stage, feeling both nervous and excited for the final competitions of the night to begin.
For Aul, who traveled from Pennsylvania for the championships, it was his first time at the Waterfowl Festival. He said he found out about the festival through buddies.
As for how he got into calling: "I just got a call and started running it better than everybody in my area and decided, you know what? I'm going to throw my name in." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a local competition (World Waterfowl Calling Championships) that is a performance-based event and part of a festival, fitting best under Entertainment. It is not a traditional sport, nor does it focus on cultural arts like music or visual arts, though it has cultural aspects, making Entertainment the strongest match.

title: Virtual horse race goes to fund Christmas basket
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Virtual horse race goes to fund Christmas basket

 November 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 253
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BETTERTON — Two times a year, the stakes are plenty high at the Betterton Volunteer Firehouse.On Saturday night, almost 200 Kent County residents and nearby neighbors showed up, betting on the horse races as the Still Pond/Betterton Lions Club hosted their 46th Virtual Race Night.
On a large screen, horses raced while folks cheered in a rambunctious, enjoyable manner. On a large screen, they watched a DVD from the "Night at the Races," a gaming company that records real horse races.
Most races were close, some having photo finishes, and the jubilation of the winners watching was contagious.
This year's proceeds went to the Kent County Lions Christmas basket, and winner of the 50/50 raffle was Carol Calloway winning $776. She was congratulated by Emcee, Dick Story and new Lions member Jean Leverage.
During the races, patrons exchanged their regular money placing their bets, chatting with neighbors while they waited in line.
It was not an uncommon occurrence to see popcorn, red raffle tickets, white tickets, funny money, and the program strewn across the tables in a kind of organized, fun, frenzy.
That along with smiling, familiar faces.
There were 12 races, sponsored by local companies and also companies or individuals could sponsor the horses too.
This race is becoming a beloved Betterton tradition that is also a good recruiting tool for the Lions as well as an effective fundraiser.
Debi Cornelius Betterton/Still Pond Lions member thanked everyone for their continued support of the Bettertown/Still Pond Lions Club.
"I hope to see you at our next race on March 8," she added. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Waterfowl Festival draws crowd of over 25,000
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Waterfowl Festival draws crowd of over 25,000

 November 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 502
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Waterfowl Festival Executive Director Deena Kilmon said Easton's 53rd Waterfowl Festival was not just "spectacular," but record-breaking, too."We know we broke every record we've ever broken," Kilmon said on Monday.
The festival, a combination of wildlife, art, music, Eastern Shore history and more, attracted around 25,000 to 30,000 attendees to Talbot County this weekend, Kilmon said.
She said after talks with the Easton Police Department, it could be roughly estimated that there were 15,000 downtown Saturday and another 10,000 to 15,000 people at the Easton Elks Lodge for the Sportsmans' Pavilion and Dock Dogs competitions.
"We had the highest attendance ever," Kilmon said. "It's hard for us to gauge because not everyone buys a ticket. But we do know that every parking space was full and every bus had about 45 minutes to an hour-long wait, and we had to add three buses on Saturday to accommodate the people."
The executive director said multiple vendors — many of which are already asking about next year — sold out or had record days at the festival.
It all began Thursday evening with the Tidewater Inn's premiere party. Easton Mayor Megan Cook formally opened the festival by bringing down the duck-shaped gavel.
For the next three days, attendees enjoyed clear skies and great festival weather. During Saturday's attendance peak, attendees roamed downtown, many enjoying multiple musical performances that drew large crowds.
According to Kilmon, there were 38 musical performances in total, a focus of this year's festival.
"That made the festival have a different vibe this year, I think," Kilmon said. "Just made it more of a friendly family party on every corner."
On South Harrison Street, an expanded PNC Art Pavilion was a success, Kilmon said. While many artists were stationed inside of the Waterfowl Festival's main building, others had displays across the street in the pavilion's tent, including this year's featured artist, Ronnie Wells.
"You feel like you're in an art museum more than you feel like you're in a tent," Kilmon said. "It was just spectacular presentation."
Over on Bay Street, expanding children's activities and adding a "Beer Wetlands" area were focal points for organizers. Kilmon says she hopes the Bay Street area can grow in future festivals, as well as the Chesapeake Bay Pavilion at Easton VFW Post 5118 on Glebe Road.
"We want to make sure the Chesapeake Bay Pavilion has a little bit of love, because there were incredible educational exhibits out there that I think that some people may not have been able to enjoy," the executive director said.
Kilmon said organizers will work on improving the bus routes for next year, as well as adjusting signage and maps so that attendees, if able, are encouraged to walk to downtown venues for quicker commutes.
Overall, feedback has been "incredibly positive" and Kilmon is excited to begin work on continuing Easton's Waterfowl tradition.
"Fifty-three years of our community coming together just gets better every year," Kilmon said. "And we're already working on next year, believe it or not."
The 54th Waterfowl Festival will be held Nov. 14 through Nov. 16, 2025. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a community festival featuring music performances, art displays, and other attractions, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment topic. Arts & Culture is a close secondary fit due to the emphasis on art exhibits, while Local Government appears because the mayor opened the event, but it is less central.

title: Bringing global flavors to the table this Thanksgiving
author: Kristen Wood Food Drink Life
content:
Bringing global flavors to the table this Thanksgiving

 November 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Kristen Wood Food Drink Life | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1045
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Thanksgiving brings together family and friends over dishes like buttery mashed potatoes and sweet pumpkin pie. This year, add these international flavors to your Thanksgiving traditions and celebrate with diversity on your table.The popular story of the first Thanksgiving tells of Native Americans and Pilgrims coming together to share the bounty of harvest. Over a feast, people of different cultures and beliefs celebrated together.
In 1863, Abraham Lincoln proclaimed Thanksgiving a national holiday. According to State Representative, Wayne Rosenthal, this was the result of a campaign by Godey's Lady's Book to promote unity during the midst of the American Civil War.
Today, Thanksgiving remains a time to come together. It is the busiest travel week of the year, notes the United States Embassy, as families travel across the world to be together. Friendsgiving, feasts on college campuses and celebrations for members of the armed forces stationed abroad bring together those who may not be able to spend time with family over the holiday.
With more people celebrating Thanksgiving from several diverse cultures, new traditions are becoming more common at the holiday table. Turkey, stuffing and pie remain Thanksgiving favorites, but international dishes and flavors are also more at home on a modern Thanksgiving table. This year, bring these global twists to Thanksgiving dinner and celebrate coming together through food.
Thanksgiving traditions around the worldMany countries celebrate their own Thanksgiving holiday. Initially, these holidays began as harvest celebrations, says GoAbroad, giving thanks for a bountiful harvest much as America's first Thanksgiving did. In the years since, these celebrations have taken on their own unique traditions.
For example, in Germany, Austria and Switzerland, people celebrate Erntedankfest on the first Sunday of October. Religious services and lantern parades accompany this holiday. "Mohnstriezel" — a sweet bread with poppy seeds — is a popular treat during the festivities.
Malaysians celebrate Kadazan in May to honor the sacrifice of the goddess Huminodun, whose death provided for an abundant rice harvest. Their celebration is filled with feasting, rice wine, games and music.
Ghanaians celebrate "Homowo" — meaning hooting at hunger — to honor those who died in a historic famine, usher in a bountiful harvest and celebrate the arrival of the new year in Ghana. The people prepare "kpokpoi," a dish made of corn meal, palm oil and seasonings. In addition to eating kpokpoi, local chiefs sprinkle it around the town as an offering.
These traditions and dishes, as well as those from other countries, can be a fun addition to your own Thanksgiving celebrations. Adding African, Asian and European food, and other cuisines to your menu is a great way to learn more about other cultures or welcome an international guest with a taste of home.
Global twists on the main dishAt an American Thanksgiving, turkey is often the main dish of choice. Many traditional recipes call for baking, roasting, frying or even smoking the turkey, often with fresh herbs, salt, pepper and vegetables for flavor.
But turkey's mild taste also makes it a perfect dish for more adventurous flavors. Jamaican jerk turkey combines spices like cinnamon, nutmeg and cloves with herbs and chili for a warm and flavorful dish. Alternatively, a turkey marinade with Chinese five-spice powder — cinnamon, cloves, star anise, fennel and Sichuan peppers — infuses your turkey with fall flavors and a bit of heat.
These marinades are an exciting way to introduce global flavors, but they are only the beginning. Earthy za'atar seasoning from the Middle East, a warm berbere spice blend from Ethiopia or bright herbs de Provence from France can all be inventive additions to turkey.
Turkey mole combines mole, the national dish of Mexico, with your turkey for a rich, chili flavor. Make your own mole or purchase a high-quality sauce to add to roast turkey. You can also try pavo a la brasa, a twist on Peruvian roasted chicken, by marinating your turkey with a sauce with cumin, paprika and other aromatics.
Exotic sides and desserts to expand your Thanksgiving menuSide dishes and desserts are a great way to introduce global influences to a feast with plenty of room for experimenting. Try spicing up traditional sides with international ingredients. Adding shishito peppers to green beans gives the veggies a Japanese flair or you can switch out the sweet potatoes for a delicious yam casserole.
International sides can also bring a nice contrast to common Thanksgiving foods. A Korean cucumber salad is refreshing, spicy and tangy. With a mild heat from the gochugaru pepper flakes, the salad makes a great starter or palette cleanser between courses.
Vegetable korma is a flavorful way to serve veggies at your meal, infusing Thanksgiving with Indian spices. The creamy cashew, yogurt and coconut milk sauce with the korma goes great over turkey and potatoes.
For dessert, bring a twist to classics with pumpkin empanadas or baklava filled with walnuts for a nutty treat. Other exotic desserts, like Chinese moon cakes or melomakarona from Cyprus, both traditional holiday desserts, are great at an American Thanksgiving as well.
Flavorful condiments with international flairCranberry sauce and gravy are Thanksgiving staples. This year, add interest with a variety of condiments. Salsa Lizano, a sauce made with vegetables, cumin and pepper, is a Costa Rican condiment that is perfect on the table or in a rice and bean dish like gallo pinto.
Asian flavors like sriracha or gochujang give a delightful spice to meat and vegetables. Indian mango chutney or the Georgian plum sauce tkemali are sweet alternatives to cranberry sauce.
Serve these condiments alongside the Thanksgiving meal and let your guests tailor their plates to their liking. These are also a great way to spruce up your leftovers.
Bringing it all together at the tableWhether you look forward to visiting with family or enjoying your favorite foods at Thanksgiving, mixing up your menu with international flavors will make for a memorable holiday. Begin with these ideas or explore dishes from cultures that are meaningful to your guests. You might even start some new Thanksgiving traditions to celebrate for years to come.
Kristen Wood is a photographer, food writer, recipe developer and creator of MOON and spoon and yum. She is also the author of "Vegetarian Family Cookbook," "Fermented Hot Sauce Cookbook" and "Hot Sauce Cookbook for Beginners." Her work has been featured in various online and print publications, including NBC, Seattle Times, Elle, Martha Stewart, Forbes, Chicago Sun-Times and more. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Thanksgiving food traditions, recipes, and cultural twists, which aligns with lifestyle/food content typically placed in the Entertainment section. It also touches on cultural diversity, but the primary framing is a food/entertainment feature.

title: After exiting the Christian music industry, these artists engage religion on their terms
author: KATHRYN POST Religion News Service
content:
After exiting the Christian music industry, these artists engage religion on their terms

 November 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KATHRYN POST Religion News Service | Section: Ap Entertainment 
 
 1606
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When former Christian artist Michael Gungor first hosted a new spiritual community in Los Angeles this year, worship began not with an organ blast or sermon series video promo, but with blowing bubbles.Appropriately dubbed "Play," Gungor envisioned the event — which featured painting, dancing, corporate singing and meditation, but no religious creed — as a celebration that "redefines worship."
"I want to be in a room and see each other's eyes and smell each other and hear each other singing out of key. This is something we've always done as a species," Gungor said. "I think there's something important, really grounding and human about it."
Gungor's idea of worship wasn't always so experimental. In packed churches and concert venues, thousands once sang along to the band Gungor's 2010 hit "Beautiful Things," a song that became a permanent fixture on the setlists of youth group bands. But in 2014, Gungor's critiques of the Christian music industry — as well as his public musings on Genesis as a poem rather than historic fact — led to his exclusion from the Christian music business. Now, after a long process of wrestling with his inherited evangelical faith — documented on his podcast "The Liturgists" — Gungor says he's more interested in embracing the current lived moment than being tethered to a set of religious beliefs, though he describes Christianity as his "native tongue."
For those like him who have "deconstructed" — a popular term today for the process of questioning and sometimes letting go of the teachings of one's faith tradition — Gungor still sees a desire for ritual and for communal gathering. He recognizes the power of the collective — and aims to write non-dogmatic music for corporate, if not religious, worship.
"We've gotten rid of some of the shame-based stuff and some of the dogmas that were oppressing and hurting a lot of us, but now we're kind of just wandering around alone … What are we missing? Is there anything we can find back here?"
In the last two decades, several Contemporary Christian Music powerhouses — Audrey Assad, DC Talk's Kevin Max, Hawk Nelson's Jon Steingard, among several others — have publicly exited the CCM industry. For many of these musicians, questioning the industry's theological parameters meant becoming unwelcome in mainstream CCM spaces. Years later, after interrogating their beliefs, a handful of these onetime CCM artists are revisiting faith in some fashion, trying on elements they'd previously discarded and writing music for listeners who might be more spiritual than religious. In many ways, these artists' break from institutional Christianity and hunger for a broader form of belonging exemplifies national religious trends.
One of the earliest CCM artists to publicly depart the industry was Jennifer Knapp, who burst onto the Christian music scene with her debut album "Kansas" in 1998. But while Knapp was drawn to Christianity's teachings on human dignity and divine love, she soon realized that the Christianity promoted in the CCM world drew hard lines around who belonged, and who didn't. Her lyrics about the Christ's humanity and questions about the necessity of substitutionary atonement — the idea that Jesus died as a substitute for humanity — began to draw criticism.
"I was already getting critiqued at the time and being basically told you weren't a Christian anymore," said Knapp. "And then I was like, oh, well, I'm wondering what you guys are going to think about my sexual orientation."
In 2002, Knapp "pushed the eject button" on the Christian music scene and her faith. When she returned in 2010, it was as an openly gay musician no longer publishing music under the Christian banner.
For longtime Bethel Music recording artist William Matthews, it was in part the rigid homogeneity of the Christian Music industry that ultimately led him to walk away. Raised in a Black Church of God context, he came to Christian music by way of spontaneous worship models promoted by Morningstar Ministries in Charlotte, North Carolina, and the International House of Prayer in Kansas City, Missouri. Though skeptical about the existence of hell, Matthews, who spent his evenings watching Bill O'Reilly on Fox News, largely felt at home in the prophetic corner of the Christian music world. In the early 2010s, he led worship at the conferences of charismatic leader Lance Wallnau, now known for his pro-Trump prophecies.
But by 2015, Williams found non-violent Christian theology a more compelling approach. He watched as anti-immigrant rhetoric and opposition to the Black Lives Matter movement reached a fever pitch in evangelical circles and grew frustrated with what he saw as the Christian music industry's "conservative bias." After spending nearly 15 years thinking he'd been bridging cultures as one of the only Black people in white-majority evangelical spaces, he was shattered to discover that many of those he'd grown close to seemed ambivalent toward racism.
"That led me to really walk away from Christian music," said Matthews.
He attributes the CCM industry's apparent conservative slant to its target audience of "white, suburban, Midwest or Southern moms." In catering to that demographic, Christian radio executives and Christian bookstores are known to censor songs or albums that cross conservative theological or political boundaries.
"What the CCM industry, or Christian music, is selling is security," said musician Derek Webb, founding member of the Christian rock band Caedmon's Call. "The people who run or appear to be gatekeeping the CCM industry are not doing that as a means of holding some kind of moral plumb line." Webb believes the pushback usually has more to do with a company's bottom line than personal convictions.
Despite the Christian music industry's restrictions, exiting the industry often means leaving behind record labels, the Christian music festival circuit and radio play and requires promoting music to a market that's much less defined. While some boundary-pushing Christian artists like Semler and Flamy Grant, two queer artists who've scored top spots on the Itunes Christian charts, have found success via social media and streaming platforms, many onetime Christian artists are labeled "too Christian" for mainstream music spaces and "too secular" for explicitly religious ones.
"It's this kind of no man's land, algorithmically," said Gungor. "I still have more listeners of 'Beautiful Things,' than anything else I make."
Creating music for a more nebulous spiritual audience might not guarantee commercial success, but if it means creating music that feels authentic, for many former Christian artists, it's worth the tradeoff.
Known for his provocative approach to songwriting, Webb says his lyrics cause him to both "shed" about a quarter or third of his audience every 18 months and gain new listeners. After 30 years in the music industry, he's comfortable with the ebb and flow. In 2017, three years after his divorce from fellow Christian artist Sandra McCracken, Webb released "Fingers Crossed," an album documenting his departure from Christianity. But though he still considers himself an agnostic, his latest album, "The Jesus Hypothesis," grapples more explicitly with Christian themes.
"I wanted to go back into the rubble of where all this was pulled down and burned down, and where I was in here with an ax before, I want to come back in with a scalpel," he said of the album.
Webb's return to the debris of his Christian faith coincided with a return to Caedmon's Call, which recently produced a re-record of its self-titled debut album in honor of its 25th anniversary. The 2022 release is emblematic of the ways several former Christian artists have been coming back to reclaim elements of their religious heritage.
More than a decade since her return to the music world, in May, Knapp offered a re-release of her first album, "Kansas 25." She graduated from Vanderbilt Divinity School in 2018, and now views Christianity as a source of wisdom whose teachings on liberation have fueled her own LGBTQ+ advocacy. The outpouring of support for "Kansas 25," Knapp said, caused her to see her early music in a new light.
"If ever I had any bitterness about my role inside of evangelical Christianity, or concern that maybe I tied people down, exposed them to too much religious trauma because of the conservative evangelical space that I came from, this was a real joy to be able to witness, that our faith can teach us something, and it can expand beyond some of the harms sometimes that our smaller religious spaces offer to us," said Knapp.
Gungor's next project has emerged from his desire to see communal songs that trade religious lyrics for more universal themes, like love and unity. This fall, he gathered with over 20 other songwriters in Colorado for a songwriting retreat to begin writing and recording music for the project, called The Mystic Hymnal.
After a long hiatus from Christian music, William Matthews, too, is releasing new, honest songs about spirituality. Earlier this year, he was invited by the evangelical authors of a recent anti-culture war statement to write and produce a corresponding album intended to call the church out of political idolatry. Titled "Return to Love," the September album was recorded by artists from a range of theological and political perspectives and is designed for those who are "full of faith or struggling to believe."
"I'm always in the middle of wrestling. Does church even matter to my life?" said Matthews, who leads worship at a progressive LGBTQ-affirming church in Los Angeles where former evangelicals regularly attend. "I will say, in my life, I've somehow always managed to come back. Maybe it's cyclical. You're always returning home or to a sense of home or to a better expression of home."
___
This content is written and produced by Religion News Service and distributed by The Associated Press. RNS and AP partner on some religion news content. RNS is solely responsible for this story.
