title: Hollywood producer returning to Talbot roots for fresh perspective
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Hollywood producer returning to Talbot roots for fresh perspective

 November 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 377
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Chris Moore has many titles to his name: Harvard University Graduate, director, producer of "American Pie" and "Good Will Hunting," and one of his favorites: Talbot County native.Moore, after making his name in Hollywood, is coming back to the Eastern Shore to hear from the locals who helped him fall in love with film.
At the Oxford Community Center Thursday, Nov. 21, he will seek to engage in valuable dialogue with residents to better understand what movie lovers from across the country are wanting to see from the film industry.
"I could have been originally from somewhere else where, honestly, I wouldn't care what they had to say, but the thing about Talbot County, and what I love about coming back to it… is that it's a real slice of America," Moore said.
Moore said he grew up going to the Avalon and loving the world that TV and movies took him to.
After studying American history at Harvard, where he met and worked with Matt Damon and Ben Affleck, he left for California, where he worked in the mailroom at an agency and later got promoted to literary agent before selling several scripts, including "The Stoned Age," "PCU," "Airheads" and "My Girl."
He later went on to produce 1999 film classic "American Pie," a breakout hit that launched Moore's career as a Hollywood producer.
But for Moore, a lot has changed since the 1990s, including the way that people watch films. Subscription-based streaming services have changed audiences' consumption of content by "over producing" content and making it difficult to gauge what people actually want to see, he said.
Moore said he wants to take a step back and go back to his roots to better understand how to give audiences quality content. And for him there's no better sounding board than the people of the Eastern Shore.
For Moore, the event on Thursday will be interactive, funny and most importantly informative of what he believes best represents American culture and audiences.
"I don't want people to think this is like going to a college lecture," Moore said. "We're going to have some fun and talk about movies and talk about entertainment, talk about fun stuff and in a way that people laugh and can engage and it can be a lively night." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a Hollywood film producer returning to his hometown to discuss movies and audience preferences, which directly relates to the entertainment industry.

title: Hollywood producer hears from local moviegoers
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Hollywood producer hears from local moviegoers

 November 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 684
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — A wave of laughter erupted at the Oxford Community Center on Thursday evening as a crowd watched video clips of a young Ben Affleck imitating an Eastern Shore accent in an effort to act as Chris Moore, a Hollywood film producer and Talbot County native.That evening, Moore led a discussion of the challenges faced by the movie industry, particularly the shift to streaming services and the decline of traditional theater attendance. Throughout the speech, he sought audience engagement and gathered information to better understand American audiences.
In an interview earlier in the week, Moore called the people of Talbot County "a real slice of America" whose input he valued greatly in examining the state of his industry.
"I'm going to talk about the movie business, but what I really want to talk about is how it's falling apart at the moment, and I'm trying to learn a little bit more," Moore said Thursday.
Moore spoke on the concerns he has with the quality of produced films. He asked the audience what they would like to see in newly released films and what it would take to get them to watch a film in person.
An array of answers came from several people, but the message remained consistent: people want quality films with quality stories.
Cid Collins Walker, executive director for the Chesapeake Film Festival, said she looks at hundreds of films every year and she relies on her knowledge to pick out films that stand out against the rest.
"I think you have to continue to take risks and find the best writers," Walk said. "I get all tons of scripts now. They're very exciting to read. Some of them, once again, are still works in progress, but I think you just need to encourage the process."
At some point in the event, Moore presented a Netflix home page filled with recommendations and shared research on why audiences get frustrated when they are offered too many choices. When audiences are presented with more than 5-6 options, consumers start to feel uncomfortable and have difficulty deciding.
"I think that the other problem is somehow the algorithm the menu uses is actually creating more frustration," Moore said. "So most likely, you're going to watch something that was on here that you've already seen or you're going to wait for the person that is sitting next to you, who's going to say, 'I want to watch this.' You're going to decide how much you hate it."
Art Murr, an attendee of the event, said he and his wife love movies and said he figured that Hollywood was confused about the vapid changes going through the industry.
"He's confirming (Hollywood) is confused," Murr said. "They should be confused, but we're not helping. And I do totally agree that there's way too many choices that if you're given like, four things, you choose one of the four things. If you're given 65 things … you have no idea, and you walk away, and you don't watch anything."
Liza Ledford, executive director of the Oxford Community Center and sister to Moore, said she worked in the film industry and with new technology it has drastically changed the communication between audiences and filmmakers.
"We lost a lot of our tools to vote," Ledford said. "What things we like, what things we don't like, and with the new restructuring of Hollywood, it's hard not to be able to trust Sony Classics or Fox Searchlights. The branding of different things has all become mesh together. So it's harder to know where to find certain types of things."
Toward the end of the event, Moore took the time to thank attendees for their participation and said that though movies are not essential for living they are important and their feedback helps the way the industry moves forward.
"I know the choices you make for what you watch," Moore said. "…But I know Hollywood and movies are less (important) than how you pay bills, your health, your kids (and) mental health. …but I do think it is nice to be surprised and happy and sort of snuck up on by a story that you're surprised by." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a Hollywood film producer discussing the movie industry, streaming, and audience preferences, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment topic.

title: Holiday season kicks off on the Mid-Shore
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Holiday season kicks off on the Mid-Shore

 November 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Calendar 
 
 619
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The holiday season is here, and with it comes an array of events from ice skating to Christmas parades on the Eastern Shore. For those looking for a holiday adventure take a moment to preview upcoming events.Immediately following Thanksgiving is ice skating at Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay. Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay Golf Resort, Spa and Marina is debuting a synthetic ice-skating rink and winter village in celebration of the holidays and winter season. The rink will be available throughout the winter.
On Dec. 5 at 9 a.m., the Chesapeake Curling Club will be hosting 90-minute learn to curl sessions. During this event, attendees will learn proper technique in delivering a granite curling stone and sweeping techniques.
The 75th annual Cambridge-Dorchester County Christmas Parade, one of the largest nighttime Christmas parades in the state, kicks off at 5 p.m. on Saturday, Dec. 7. Pre-parade entertainment will be provided by artist Rebecca Bailey starting at 4:15 p.m. at the reviewing stand located at Craig's Drugstore parking area. The parade can be viewed on High Street, Poplar and Race streets, ending at Washington Street.
Also on Dec. 7 is the Easton Christmas Parade, which draws visitors to the town each year. Before the parade, Santa arrives in Thompson Park at 5:30 p.m., followed by a tree lighting at 6 p.m. Parade starts at 6:30 p.m. Street closures begin at 6 p.m. The Chamber of Commerce will have collection boxes at Thompson Park during the parade to collect for Toys for Tots.
In Ridgely, the Lions Club's annual Christmas Parade will light up downtown Dec. 7. Line-up for the parade begins at 6:15 p.m. at the Martin Sutton Park Fourth Street Parking Lot. The parade begins at 6:45 p.m. Santa will be at the train station after the parade for visits.
On Dec. 8, visitors can tour five gorgeous homes decorated for the holiday season in and around Cambridge, in addition to historic Waugh Chapel United Methodist Church and Sycamore Cottage. The Cambridge Holiday House Tour takes place from 1:30 to 4:30 p.m. Tickets are $35 and can be purchased day-of at 417 High St.
The annual Santa Chase will be held in Martin Sutton Park in Ridgely on Dec. 13. The dog- and family-friendly two-mile run or walk and costume contest (judged by Santa himself) costs $20 per person or $72 per group of four, plus $5 for each dog. The event is produced in partnership with Lions International and the Ridgely Lions Club.
Starting Dec. 13 to 15, the Oxford Holiday Market will be up and running. This event will take place in Oxford and will offer a weekend filled with unique artisan gifts, food and holiday music.
That weekend also marks the 38th annual Christmas in St. Michaels. From Dec. 13 to 15, St. Michaels will host a variety of holiday events including a gingerbread house contest, two parades and a tour of homes. More details and a schedule for the festivities can be found at christmasinstmichaels.org.
At noon on Dec. 14, Denton will host its first ever Wreaths Across America event at the Denton Cemetery. The event is being organized by local boy scout Billy Quick as his Eagle Scout service project. It will honor veterans by placing wreaths on their graves.
For those looking for family-friendly fun, Santa's Workshop will be open at Wharves of Choptank Visitor & Heritage Center in Denton on Saturdays, Dec. 7, 14 and 21. The event, where families can create toys with "elves" and meet Santa, has a suggested donation of $15 per child. Registrations can be made at carolinearts.org/events/santas-workshop-in-the-island-of-misfit-toys/.
For more information about these and other upcoming holiday events, see the calendar posted in every print edition of the Star Democrat.
To submit information about an upcoming holiday event, email community@stardem.com.

title: Easton gears up for 39th Festival of Trees
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Easton gears up for 39th Festival of Trees

 November 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 831
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The 39th Festival of Trees will take place in Easton on Nov. 29 through Dec. 3. Events include the Festival of Trees, which is held in the Tidewater Inn, as well as Carols by Candlelight, Santa's Workshop, Santa 5K Fun Run/Walk and a jewelry raffle.Every year, there is a theme for the festival, which is put on by the Friends of Talbot Hospice. This year's theme is "Holiday Traditions." The trees will be decorated based on that theme, festival chairman Karla Wieland-Cherry said.
"It takes a year to plan. It's a lot of work," Wieland-Cherry said. "It's all volunteer work, all volunteers. And this is our 39th year. The big thing is the trees, so we have the trees sponsored by various businesses, organizations and individuals. And they can either choose to decorate the tree, or we also have a list of volunteers who will come in and decorate the tree."
The festival raises funds for Talbot Hospice. Wieland-Cherry emphasized the work of volunteers in raising hospice funds, as well as the family aspect of the weekend-long event.
"My children are involved, my son comes and volunteers, my daughter used to sing, my husband, he's the music chairman," Wieland-Cherry said.
" ... It's just a wonderful way to kick off the holiday season," she continued. "I have such a blessed team of volunteers that work so hard to make this such a success."
On Friday night, the Preview Gala will kick off the festivities. From 6 to 8 p.m., guests will have the first opportunity to view 100 exquisitely trimmed trees of varying sizes. Tickets to the gala are available in advance for $125 per person or $200 per couple.
While the larger trees are sponsored in advance, gala guests get the first opportunity to purchase the smaller trees, from 12 inches to three feet and in varying price ranges.
The Gold Ballroom at the Tidewater Inn opens to the public Saturday morning and remains open through Tuesday. As always, local performers will be cycling throughout the event to provide music and singing.
Also Saturday morning, participants will hit the pavement at 9 a.m. for the Santa 5K Fun Run/Walk. There will be on-site registration starting at 8 a.m. at Idlewild Park in Easton and advance sign-ups will be available online.
Later in the day, Santa's Workshop opens. From 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. on both Saturday and Sunday in the Tidewater Inn's Ballroom Garden, children will rotate through stations after being greeted by Santa and posing for photographs.
Children can write letters to Santa, participate at craft stations, play games and enjoy a selfie station with props for photo opportunities. Santa's Workshop is no additional charge to those that pay for admission to the Festival of Trees.
Returning for the fifth year, Carols by Candlelight is an event free for all families. On Saturday from 5 to 7 p.m. Families can sing along with choral groups, bell ringers and musicians while enjoying hot cocoa and holiday treats.
Santa will be located on the grounds of The Bullitt House at the corner of Washington Street and Dover Street in downtown Easton. Other visitors include The Grinch, Elsa and Buddy the Elf.
This year, the Festival of Trees introduces a Fine Jewelry Raffle, courtesy of Kyle Edward Fine Jewelry of Easton. A pair of satin ball earrings and a diamond bezel necklace will be offered in the raffle to benefit Talbot Hospice. One raffle ticket costs $25 and is available online at and at Kyle Edward Fine Jewelry on 27 South Harrison St. The raffle will be drawn at 5:30 p.m. on Dec. 3 at the conclusion of Festival of Trees.
New this year is the debut of one-of-a-kind, keepsake luminaries in honor of a loved one. Designed and created by Pat and Eric Harvey, a limited number of the metal luminaries will be sold online, then displayed in the Gold Ballroom. At the conclusion of the Festival of Trees, the luminaries will be available for pickup in time to enjoy for the holiday season.
As Christmas is a season for remembering, friends and family remember their loved ones in a very special way by purchasing a poinsettia. The name of someone dear is placed on a Memory Scroll next to a stunning 12-foot poinsettia "tree" in the Tidewater Inn's Gold Ballroom.
Friends of Hospice was formed in 1984 and began hosting the Festival of Trees in 1986 to raise money for the Talbot Hospice Foundation. To date, close to $4 million has been raised by the Festival of Trees to assist with Talbot Hospice's operating budget.
As a celebration of life for those who have received Hospice care during the past year, the continued success of Festival of Trees is made possible by the generous financial contributions from local individuals and various businesses. To get involved in any capacity, or to inquire about a sponsorship, contact Festival of Trees Co-Chairmen Karla Wieland-Cherry at dkcherry4@aol.com or 410-310-8421 and Denise Haddaway at 443-995-4431 or denise.haddaway@gmail.com.
To learn more about Talbot Hospice, visit talbothospice.org. Festival information can be found at festival-of-trees.org/. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Greensboro kicks off Whoville, 2 weekends still to come
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Greensboro kicks off Whoville, 2 weekends still to come

 December 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 296
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — A popular holiday attraction for families and children of all ages kicked off last weekend in Greensboro. The town's sixth annual Whoville Village Holiday Park opened Friday at the Greensboro Volunteer Fire Company Fair Grounds.The annual event, inspired by Dr. Seuss' fictional town, features activities for all ages, decorations, light displays and photo opportunities with the Grinch.
Whoville continues during the next two weekends, open Dec. 6-7 and Dec. 13-14. Admission is free.
The town requests $5 parking donations, though donations are not required. Parking revenue is split between the Greensboro Volunteer Fire Company and next year's Whoville efforts.
Amanda Weaver, Greensboro's community programs coordinator, said around 1,500 people attended Whoville last weekend.
"The first weekend was slower than (it has been) historically," Weaver said. She said that's partly due to the town opening the attraction in November for the first time ever.
Sunday was a special night for Greensboro residents, in which 150 town residents enjoyed Whoville without the usual "commotion" and packed crowd.
"We loved that," Weaver said. "They all had a great time."
Typically, there are 2,000 to 3,000 attendees per day, according to Weaver. She said the town is expecting a similar turnout looking toward this weekend.
Around 12 student volunteers from the local schools chipped in to make opening weekend a success, Weaver said. They will continue helping throughout the upcoming weekends.
This Friday, Saint Paul's United Methodist Church Pastor Bonnie Shively will accept her nomination as Whoville's honorary mayor.
Weaver said on Dec. 11, Whoville will have its sensory night. Loud music and flashing lights will be minimized to accommodate visitors with sensory sensitivities, and the trails will be designed for accessibility.
Reservations for sensory night can be made by calling Greensboro Town Hall at 410-482-6222. The Whoville attraction runs 5 p.m. to 8 p.m. on all nights. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland author pens latest thriller
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maryland author pens latest thriller

 December 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 495
 Words 

 Read News Document

 R.J. Hinkemeyer recently published his latest book "False Trespass" on Nov. 18 on Amazon.The Dunkirk native writes mysteries that take place in his native state of Minnesota and his home state of Maryland and some of his previous books include "Confessions of the Soul: A Maryland Mystery," "Sins of Stone: A Marylan Mystery," "Shadows on the Soul: A Maryland Mystery" and "Snow Cover."
His books have won several literary contests sponsored by writing associations and his most recent novel — "False Trespass" — was a finalist for best mystery in the Pacific Northwest Writers Association's awards.
Hinkemeyer is a U.S. Army veteran and former federal official is a graduate of St. John's University in Minnesota and completed his graduate studies at George Washington University in Washington, D.C.
He grew up on a farm in Minnesota and enjoys the outdoors, his small garden, many pets and living in Southern Maryland. He is also an avid Baltimore Ravens, Baltimore Orioles, Bowie Bay Sox and U.S. Naval Academy sports fan.
The 223-page book is available at www.amazon.com.
How long have you been writing, and how did you get started?
I was an English major in college who did a lot of writing during my career with the federal government. However, I didn't begin writing fiction seriously until after I retired several years ago. I had an older brother, Michael, who was a published author who encouraged me.
What inspires you to write?
I am interested in portraying principled individuals who confront the challenges and mysteries that life presents them.
Do you consider writing to be a career?
I'm not sure I would call it a career, but it is definitely more than a hobby.
What kind of writing process do you use?
I primarily use a computer to write, although I do edit my work on paper. Mornings are the best time for me to write when my mind is clear.
Who are some of your favorite authors and why?
As a former English major, I have a lot of favorite authors. Over the holidays, I am looking forward to reading several new releases including "Grey Wolf" by Louise Penny and "The Mighty Red" by Louise Erdrich.
What are you working on now?
A thriller that takes place in the wetlands sanctuary of Jug Bay.
Please include a description of your book
A former county sheriff comes out of retirement when his grandson is suspected of shooting his own father.
Please include an excerpt from the book
"Drew shivered. He felt the cold deep in his bones. A lone snowflake brushed his cheek. Winter was coming. He wondered if Fletcher would stop by to see what he remembered. He wasn't certain what he could tell him. He was afraid he might have missed some signs over the years.
Maybe it would be best if he let things be, go home and start a fire in the fireplace. He didn't have all the answers and never had. Maybe it would be best if he let Fletcher solve his part of the puzzle. He was certain he had solved his." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Frosty’s Holiday Village brings holiday cheer to Easton
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Frosty’s Holiday Village brings holiday cheer to Easton

 December 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 369
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Frosty's Holiday Village came back Friday evening at the Anchor Church bringing with it holiday cheer, family friendly activities and community engagement.Hosted by For All Seasons, a community behavioral health center, Frosty's Holiday Village is in its fourth year of providing winter festivities to the residents of the Eastern Shore.
Katie Theeke, vice president of marketing and communications at For All Seasons, said the event's mission goes beyond bringing holiday cheer to residents. The event is also meant to help lift spirits throughout the community during a time when mental health concerns grow.
"We know that the holidays can be like a really lonely time of year for many people, and we also know that for many folks too, it can be expensive to take your family out, and we wanted to just have a really fun, festive evening of connection in the community that was free for everyone and that brought people together to just enjoy a night out," Theeke said.
Theeke said the attendance of the event over the years has grown significantly. Last year there was an estimated 1,000 people in attendance. This year, the For All Season team anticipated a bigger turnout of 1,500 people.
Similar to previous years, there was a line of excited children waiting for their turn to have a professional photo with the famous Frosty and friends. They enjoyed complimentary cocoa, cider and additional winter treats as "Frosty's Winter Wonderland" played on a big screen.
Nearby, a crowd of enthusiastic families in awe of Cascading Carlos the Juggler. Adored in his iconic black shirt with flames, the award-winning juggler and Guinness World Record holder engaged with children and parents alike to take part in his performance. Sharing his love for juggling with attendees of all ages.
This year, included with the wide variety of activities, there was an additional 20 new inflatables and a second holiday movie for all to enjoy.
Presenting sponsors include The St. John Foundation and Willow Construction. Additional sponsors include Willow Construction, St. John's Foundation, Jacob Sloan Foundation, Tri Gas and Oil/Pep, Parker Counts, Hearthstone, Talbot County Health Department, Construction Services & Supply, Inc., Chesapeake Building Components, La De Da!, Grauls Market, Julianne Rosela Foundation, Mid-South Audio, and Creative Training Solutions. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community holiday event with performances, activities, and festive entertainment, making Entertainment the most fitting category, with Arts & Culture as a close secondary match.

title: Giving The Edge Foundation bounces into winter
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Giving The Edge Foundation bounces into winter

 December 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 212
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Giving The Edge Foundation jumped for joy with its third annual Bounce into Winter event Nov. 30. Partnering with Shore Party Rentals to fill The Edge Arena in Stevensville with bounce castles, inflatable slides as well as crafts and face painting, the event welcomed hundreds of children and their families to bounce out energy and have fun.Giving The Edge Foundation founder Robert "Bobby" Woolley said the annual Bounce into Winter event is a great quick way for kids to blow off some steam before the cold sets in as they be with others as a community.
Started in 2013, Giving The Edge Foundation supports advancing opportunities and building a strong community of youth. More than just sports, Giving The Edge has greatly expanded over the years, helping kids of all walks in the community be the best version of themselves, Woolley said.
Programs and incentives to engage kids include monthly acts of kindness, essay contests, as well as an enormous Field Day for all 12 county elementary schools, he said.
Entrance admission for the free community event was gently used toys for the Tides of Grace Christmas Magic Toy Drive.
More information about Giving the Edge Foundation can be found at theedge360.net. More information about Tides of Grace can be found at tidesofgraceinc.org.

title: Residents brave the cold for Denton Holiday Parade
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Residents brave the cold for Denton Holiday Parade

 December 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 461
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Bundled up in coats, gloves, hats, scarves — and even blankets — Caroline County residents braved the cold and the wind to watch the town's annual holiday parade.At the start of the parade on Thursday, the weather was 31 degrees Fahrenheit but felt like 12 degrees.
As the wind put a sway to the colorful string lights above Market Street, John Bell and Linda Allen-Bell waited for the parade to begin. The two, wrapped in blankets, didn't want to miss the parade after missing it last year. Allen-Bell said they love small town parades.
Down the street, Rachel Tull stood with her family, trying to stay warm. She said that the kids were most excited for the candy that would soon be tossed from parade floats. Tull, on the other hand, was most excited for the meatloaf she had waiting for them at home.
As attendees waited for floats to glide down the street, some checked out the vendors at the corner of Market and Third streets.
It was Ridgely resident Haley Wondrash's first year selling the cups she makes at the parade. She said she makes her cups, which have different designs on them, for different people to express themselves. There's a cup for everyone, she explained, from sports lovers to Taylor Swift fans.
"I make a lot of Taylor Swift cups for all the Taylor Swift girlies out there," she said.
JP Morris, who attended the parade with his two sisters and his parents, was most excited for the candy that parade participants toss to the crowds. He, along with other children at the parade, cleaned up the candy from the sidewalks as floats made their way down Market Street.
Morris said he wasn't too cold. His mom, Meagan Morris, said the family of five has spent their last couple Christmases in Maine, "so this ain't nothing," she said, laughing.
Once the parade began, attendees heard local marching bands play Christmas music, watched bright red firetrucks and pickup trucks decorated in lights make their way down the street, and kept their eyes open for Santa and Mrs. Claus, who closed out the parade.
A variety of creative floats were in attendance this year, from the 4-H float blasting fake snow into the air to the Caroline County GOP float toting a cardboard cutout of President-elect Donald Trump standing next to a decorated Christmas tree.
Kyra Ringgold took her son Kyro, 3, to the parade for the first time this year. Seeing Santa and getting candy and chocolate was Kryo's favorite part of the experience.
After Santa and Mrs. Claus made their way down the street, people gathered in front of the courthouse for the Lighting of the Green. A drumroll slowly ushered in the turning on of green and red lights on the trees outside the courthouse. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community holiday parade with floats, marching bands, and festive activities, which are primarily a form of local entertainment rather than a governmental, educational, or health-related matter.

title: Easton's Holiday Parade brings bright lights and candy downtown
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Easton's Holiday Parade brings bright lights and candy downtown

 December 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 366
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Downtown Easton buzzed with anticipation Saturday evening as people — some decked out in Christmas-themed gear — waited for the town's annual holiday parade to begin.Although it was dark out, colorful lights shaped like candy canes and candles helped light up the night before the vibrant, festive floats arrived. The parade, which brought music and candy to Harrison and Washington streets, was preceded by a visit from Santa and a tree lighting at Thompson Park.
This year, 5-year-old Makena Dickerson lit the tree, helping to kick off the holiday season in Easton.
Mayor Megan Cook said that one of the best parts of living in a small town is events like these that bring the community together.
"The parade, to me, is one of the highlights of the whole year," she said.
Cynthia Spence has been coming to the parade for a about five years now with her daughter Sofia, 7, and now her daughter Nevaeh, 4. She said they return because her children like watching the parade.
"They like seeing different floats and ..."
"Don't forget the candy," Sofia jumped in as her mother spoke.
"And apparently the candy they throw out," Spence finished.
Josie Taylor, who sat with her family on Washington Street, said she was most excited to see her sister, Ella, who was in the parade with the Avalon Theatre.
Their mother Jess Taylor said that although they normally attend St. Michaels' parade every year, they came to Easton's parade to support Ella this year.
From Easton school marching bands to a kazoo choir, music filled the air at Easton's Holiday Parade. Floats, vintage cars and firetrucks traveled slowly along the parade route as parade participants on foot weaved in between them, handing out candy and other small items.
Bethany Shair, a Preston resident who had not been to Easton's Holiday Parade before, said she wished that she and her family had brought chairs.
"Next year we'll learn," she said.
This year, Midshore Veterinary Service was named the best commercial float in the parade. Partway through the parade, Vivienne, 6, and Drew Sperandeo said it was their favorite float.
The Eastern Shore Hockey Association was named the best nonprofit float in the parade. Easton Middle School took home the best marching band title. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community holiday parade featuring music, floats, and festive activities, which is primarily an entertainment event, with cultural elements also present.

title: Embracing the spirit of Christmas
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Embracing the spirit of Christmas

 December 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 622
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It was a cold few days earlier this month but Chestertown was armed with hot cider, mulled wine, beer, cocoa, music, an athletic activity, and all the Victorian-style costumes you could imagine to keep the chill at bay.Top hats, overcoats, bonnets and scarfs abounded.
The fashion of the Victorian era was once again adopted by Chestertown, as Mainstreet Chestertown put on the annual Dickens of a Christmas Festival Dec. 6 and 7 inspired by Charles Dickens beloved 1843 novella, "A Christmas Carol". The festival was sponsored by Main Street Chestertown, Rosin Creek Collaborative, 114 High and Molly's Place to name a few.
During the two-day event, couches were placed on High Street facing the music stage, in a homey atmosphere where one could meet friends and visitors of Chestertown, warming up by the fire barrels just a brisk walk away.
The event began Dec. 6 with the opening ceremony courtesy of Jimmy Kinstle portraying Dickens.
Kinstle introduced Queen Victoria who read off every child's name from Santa's nice list, courtesy of Santa's House next to Fountain Park.
Following, the audience was entertained by the Kent County High School Jazz Band, Garnet Elementary Chorus, River Voices and finally, The Devil's Brigade, formerly known as The American Rouges ending the night in a rowdy fashion.
Bonfires were lit, oysters and beer were served and food vendors were on hand. The new executive director for Main Street Chestertown, Sonny Huntzinger described the night as magical.
On Dec.7, 113 racers, contested the morning chill in the 5-K, Run/Walk and Kids' Fun Run, "Run like the Dickens" commentated by Kinstle, never breaking character.
Race coordinator Renee Bench and vice chair of the Board for Mainstreet Chestertown, pointed out there were not as many people as last year due to the weather, but was pleased to see the turnout all the same.
Finishing first for men's was Joshua Dorsey, winner for female's was Jamie Hicks, and Ethan McIntire, age 15, and C. Mann, age 8 finished first in their age range.
Over the day, the sun warmed the street and alcohol and food vendors opened up at noon. Music was performed throughout the day, traditional Irish songs to classic rock, and folk.
For kids, a petting zoo was situated over by Fountain Park as well as a puppet show performed by, Horns Punch and Judy Show.
For shoppers, the farmer's market was open, and further down was Heritage Village in the Bank, featuring a native flower farm, River Arts, WAC Women's League, Museum of Kent and Tarot readings.
For history buffs, the Holiday House tour afforded ticket buyers a journey to "festively decorated homes on Queen, Maple, High, Cannon and Water Street," as stated on the Chestertown website.
People could navigate the busy streets, seeing the homes in any order they wished.
Chestertown Police Chief Dixon, his crew in bobby hats, said over the two days there was an estimated 1,500-2,000 attendees and reported there were no incidents.
Huntzinger was thrilled by the efficiency in the planning process, having 25 years of experience in community development and other related fields. She noted that Main Street Chestertown Assistant Director Kelly Reed and a few volunteers planned the entire thing, while partnering with the Town of Chestertown.
She appreciated the hard work of them all, especially the Town's Streets and Public Works Department for setting up the stage among the many other tasks.
Huntzinger said all revenue, goes toward advancing Main Street's mission to promote and support a diverse range of educational, cultural entertainment and recreational activities.
Planning is a long process for such an event like this, Huntzinger acknowledged, and as much as they are looking forward to the next Dickens festival, she said they need more volunteers to sit in on committees and get involved.
If you have an interest in volunteering, contact the offices at 410-778-2991. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community Christmas festival featuring music, performances, a fun run, vendors, and cultural activities, and it is published in the Entertainment section, making Entertainment the most fitting primary topic.

title: Galena lights up for the.holidays
author: Staff Writer
content:
Galena lights up for the.holidays

 December 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 307
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It was a festive night at Galena Town Park, Dec. 7. When the sun sank low, lights were plugged in, and the many decorations in the park were evident for all to enjoy throughout the holiday season. The town held their annual Christmas event, Light up the Park, sponsored by Molly's and Dixon Valve, drawing nearly 100 people this year.Through the archway made of colorful gifts with ribbons creatively put together, attendees were treated to a Santa wearing floaties, next to a boat of Christmas lights, some reindeer, a gingerbread man, multiple light displays, a fire to stave off that winter chill, and plenty of family activities.
In addition to lighting up a 20-foot Christmas tree, Council member Sarah Merrell noted they had Santa escorted by the Galena Volunteer Fire Department, children's coloring activities and a few vendors, all while the Galena Lions Club offered hot chocolate and cookies.
At 7 p.m., under the tent, they had their fourth movie night of the year, playing the 2000 family/comedy "How the Grinch Stole Christmas," starring Jim Carey.
Mayor John Carroll said movie night has been growing in popularity, and the screen they purchased with American Rescue Funds money, has turned out to be a good community investment.
And he was pleased with the annual Christmas event overall, growing too big to contain at their previous location.
Over the years, they held the event at Town Hall, he noted, but after 100 kids showed up, they felt the park was the best way to expand it and allow the kids to have space enough to play.
Next year, Carroll said, they are going to try to develop squares around the whole park for families to decorate.
"Hopefully we can grow each year and make this a nice tradition," Carroll said, thanking volunteers, the community, the fire department and their sponsors for making all this possible. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community holiday lights festival, movie night, and family activities, which are primarily entertainment events, even though local officials are mentioned.

author: Staff Writer

Rhythm Xpress to perform at Church Hill Theatre

 December 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 RhythmXpress will be bringing dance magic to the Churchill Theatre as they show that "All the World's a Stage" at 7 p.m., Wednesday, Dec. 18.The performance. will include solo, partner and group choreography set to a variety of favorite songs from famous stage productions, including "Wicked", "Aladdin", "The Sound of Music", "Hairspray", and other musicals.

The company has provided support and entertainment for numerous charitable organizations, including GiGi's Playhouse and the Special Olympics Maryland Polar Bear Plunge. Dancers will include International Special Olympic DanceSport champion and 2024 Chesapeake Classic Top Pro-Am Male, Robert Wallop, as well as Certified Special Olympic Athlete Leaders Abby Gibbons and Alicia Gogue. There will be raffle tickets available (cash only) for some great prize baskets, as well as some Church Hill theatre concessions for sale. The dancers are excited to showcase their talents and look forward to sharing this fun evening with you," the announcement continued.

title: Uncork the perfect holiday feast with these wine-pairing secrets
author: Anne Jolly Food Drink Life
content:
Uncork the perfect holiday feast with these wine-pairing secrets

 December 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Anne Jolly Food Drink Life | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1030
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The holiday season is here, bringing festive gatherings and delicious meals. As you plan your celebrations, choosing the perfect wines to accompany your dishes can enhance the entire experience. Whether you're a wine novice or a seasoned enthusiast, these holiday wine pairing tips will make your celebrations unforgettable.With a few simple tips and secrets, you'll confidently pick winners every time. From classic turkey to creative desserts, there's a match for every course.
Tips for perfect holiday wine pairings
Here are the top tips for choosing wines to complement your holiday dishes and delight your guests. Understanding basic pairing principles will help you confidently navigate the world of holiday wines.
Create balance
One of the most important concepts in wine pairing is to create balance in flavor and intensity. Pair delicate foods with light and subtle wines, and rich and hearty dishes with robust, full-bodied wines.
Sweetness is another area where balance is an important consideration.To avoid flavor clashes, choose a wine that's as sweet or slightly sweeter than your dish.
Acidity is another important factor.Many holiday foods, like buttery mashed potatoes or juicy prime rib, are rich and fatty. High-acid wines can cut through these dishes, so you can taste each bite of food as if it were your first.
Finally, select wines that go with the herbs and spices in your dish rather than overpower them. When selecting a wine, focus on your dish's most prominent spices or herbs.
Add variety to your holiday wines
Don't forget sparkling wines - they're not just for toasts. They're versatile and can pair well with everything from appetizers to main courses to desserts.
Using regional wines is another way to add variety. Wines often pair well with foods from the same region. For example, serve Italian wines with Italian dishes.
When it comes to holiday wine pairing, there are tried and true favorites that you can count on. If you are in doubt, choose crowd-pleasing wines like pinot noir or sauvignon blanc. These classic wines pair well with a variety of holiday dishes.
Make sure you offer various non-alcoholic alternatives for your guests.Provide high-quality grape juices or non-alcoholic wines for those who don't drink alcohol.
Serving and enjoying holiday wine
Make sure you serve your wines at the right temperature. Serve white wines chilled and serve red wines slightly below room temperature. The correct temperature can significantly affect the taste and enjoyment of your wine.
Lastly, trust yourself and don't worry too much about the rules. If you enjoy a particular wine with a certain dish, then that's the perfect pairing for you.
Perfect wines for your holiday feast
Now that we've covered the essential tips for holiday wine pairing, let's review some specific recommendations for your holiday table. Whether you're serving a traditional roast turkey, a succulent ham or vegetarian options, there is a wine that will make your meal even better.
These are suggestions meant to inspire you, not strict rules. Experiment and choose the wine pairing that seems right for you and your guests.
Turkey or chicken
When serving roast turkey, choose a versatile chardonnay. Oaked, full-bodied chardonnays offer a richness that pairs well with white meat and many side dishes.
If you prefer red wine, a medium-bodied pinot noir goes well with the delicate poultry flavors. The wine's light to medium body and bright acidity pair well with both white and dark meat.
Ham
Holiday ham 's saltiness and subtle sweetness make for interesting wine pairings. A slightly sweet riesling is a fabulous choice. The wine's natural sweetness balances the ham's saltiness, while its crisp acidity cuts through the richness of the meat.
For red wine enthusiasts, a fruity zinfandel is a perfect match. Its bold berry flavors and hints of spice stand up well to the strong flavors of ham, especially if it's glazed or honey baked.
Beef
Bold red wines truly shine when it comes to beef. A full-bodied cabernet sauvignon is a classic choice for a beef roast like prime rib. The tannins in the wine help cut through the beef's richness.
Another outstanding option is a rich malbec. Malbec has a smooth texture that goes well with a tender, well-prepared roast. The wine's moderate acidity helps balance the richness of the meat.
Lamb
Lamb's rich, slightly gamey flavors are best paired with robust wines. Medium or full-bodied reds are ideal companions for this flavorful meat. A syrah's dark fruit and smoky character pair beautifully with grilled or roasted lamb.
Bordeaux blends, typically consisting of cabernet sauvignon, merlot and cabernet franc, are another fantastic choice. These wines provide a complex flavor and go especially well with lamb cooked with herbs like rosemary or thyme.
Pork
Pork's versatility allows for a range of wine pairings. Choose a medium-bodied red like merlot, which offers plum flavors that complement pork's lean meat.
Alternatively, a fuller-bodied white like viognier is the perfect choice for enhancing pork's subtle flavors. For pork dishes with fruity sauces or glazes, a pinot gris is an excellent choice, as its crisp acidity balances the sauce's sweetness.
Vegetarian dishes
Focus on the meal's dominant flavors, textures and cooking methods rather than defaulting to white wines. Mushrooms, with their earthy, umami flavors, pair well with light to medium-bodied red wines like pinot noir.
Crisp white wines work well with green vegetables and salads. A sauvignon blanc beautifully enhances the flavors of asparagus, bell peppers or zucchini dishes. Try a fuller-bodied white like a viognier or an unoaked chardonnay for roasted root vegetables.
Dessert
Pairing wines with desserts can be a delightful way to end a meal. The wine should be as sweet or sweeter as the dessert so it doesn't taste bitter or sour in comparison. Sauternes, a sweet white wine from Bordeaux, France, goes well with fruit-based desserts.
Ruby port is a classic choice for chocolate desserts. The wine's sweetness and body stand up to dark chocolate's intensity. Moscato d'Asti, a light, sweet and slightly sparkling wine, is perfect for lighter desserts. It pairs wonderfully with fresh fruit, light pastries or sorbet.
Toast to perfect pairings
Wine pairing is both an art and a science. These tips provide a foundation but trust your palate and experiment. After all, the most important part of any holiday gathering is the joy of sharing good food and drink with loved ones.
Anne Jolly is the creator of the food blog Upstate Ramblings. She loves cooking, especially for the holidays

title: Garden Club 'decks the halls' in Centreville
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Garden Club 'decks the halls' in Centreville

 December 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 429
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The festive scents of seasonal pine and holly filled American Legion Jeff Davis Post 18 as the Queen Anne's County Garden Club Members prepared the town with festive cheer Dec. 5.The long-standing annual decorating is traditionally the Thursday before the Centreville Christmas parade, according to club president Laura Blaylock.
"This is the highlight of the year," she said, and is a favorite among all members who, with a potluck breakfast and lunch, and many of whom in yuletide sweaters, spend all day together preparing.
Throughout the hall, stations were set up for wreaths, swag, garland, bows, and putting the final touches on holiday magic to decorate Centreville in a glow of greenery.
Members also designed over 100 floral arrangements to be hand delivered to hospice care and home bodies in need of Christmas cheer.
"It is our way of getting in the Christmas spirit and getting others in the Christmas spirit as well, " Blaylock said.
Member Jane Chambers, of Kent Island, has been a garden club member for about 50 years and said her favorite part is seeing the finished product displayed throughout the season "and it's a fun group that does good for the community," she said.
With help from local department staff, wreaths, garland, and long lines of blooming swag adorned historic aspects all through town, including the Queen Anne's County Library, Shore United Bank, the Tucker House, the Historic Courthouse, and Chesterfield Cemetery.
From wreath decoration design to floral arraignments, "It never ceases to amaze me the amount of creativity from everyone," Club Vice President Robin Lanham said.
During Arbor Day, the club celebrated its 90th anniversary with a tree planting honoring first responders at the Fallen Heroes Memorial at Route 18 Park in Centreville.
The club recently decorated crab pots to create a crab tree unique to Queen Anne's County and pay tribute to the watermen and preside over the Annapolis state house.
"It made quite a splash, people loved it," club treasurer Paula Kumar.
The object of the garden club is to stimulate the love of gardening, to aid in the protection of native plants and birds, to encourage civic planting and beautification, and to teach children to love and care for all growing things, according to Blaylock
Covering a wide spectrum of horticulture topics including guest speakers and field trips, the club is always seeking new members and anyone interested in not just gardening but local pollinators, native plants, floral design or seeking to enhance their green thumb.
Queen Anne's County Garden Club is part of the Federated Garden Clubs of Maryland Inc. District 1.
More information can be found by contacting Blaylock at laura.blaylock804@gmail.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot Street Parade brings festive cheer to St. Michaels
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Talbot Street Parade brings festive cheer to St. Michaels

 December 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Holiday 
 
 229
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — On Saturday morning, the streets were filled with families in holiday getup as dozens of floats made their ways through the center of the town for the Talbot Street Parade.The Talbot Street Parade is a time-honored holiday tradition in St. Michaels that includes marching bands, antique cars and boats, horses and representatives of the town's vibrant business and nonprofit community.
Ashley Russ, a parade attendee and St. Michaels native, said as a child her family would take her to the parade every year. Now as an adult with her own family, she is happy to pass down the tradition to her son.
Russ said her son most loved the fire trucks, which opened the parade, and the horses that decorated with festive tinsel, vines and reindeer horns.
Maydeen Merino, an attendee of the parade, said she enjoyed the motorcycle Santas that made an appearance and the Chesapeake Bay Retrievers and their well-dressed dogs who adorned sweaters, scarves and bandanas.
"It's a really cute community event, and I love how enthusiastic the whole town was for this parade," Merino said.
The parade is a part of a weekend-long fundraiser event known as Christmas in St. Michaels. Beginning in 1987, Christmas in St. Michaels has raised more than $1.7 million for local nonprofit organizations including Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers, St. Michaels site, St. Michaels Community Center and the St. Michaels Fire Department. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Thousands attend Christmas in Ridgely Winter Festival
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Thousands attend Christmas in Ridgely Winter Festival

 December 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 495
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — Thousands braved frigid temperatures to stroll the streets of the Ridgely Saturday for its annual, award-winning Christmas in Ridgely Winter Festival.Attendees walked up and down W. Railroad Street and W. Belle Street, enjoying vendors, massive displays of holiday lights, and a wide array of activities for families and children.
Many children ice skated — some for the first time — outside of the Ridgely Town Hall, while couples young and old posed for photos underneath the town's mistletoe sign. At the other end of the festival, kids enjoyed an area full of inflatable slides, bounce houses and games.
In between the town hall and inflatables, the historic Ridgely Train Station welcomed visitors in for pictures with Santa and a Christmas tree display from the students and parent-teacher association at Ridgely Elementary School.
Garret and Pat Falcone, a couple from Chestertown, were enjoying their second trip to the festival. There was no doubt in their minds that they would come back for another year after last year's experience.
"The people. Everyone is so nice," Garret Falcone said of why he loves the event.
"I love the decorations. They're really cool," Pat Falcone said.
Ridgely Clerk-Treasurer and event organizer Stephanie Berkey said the town stuck to its usual strong suits this year, namely horse-drawn carriage rides and train rides for attendees. She said holiday characters, such as Elsa, Olaf and Buddy the Elf, were new additions to the event.
People from as far away as New Jersey and southern Virginia made the trip to Caroline County, she said. As always, Berkey's favorite aspect of the event was the smiles it brought to children.
"Seeing kids try to ice skate for the very first time, it's so much fun to see," she said. "And when you see all the parents that are taking the pictures of them having such a good time, that makes it all worth it. It's the happiness that it brings to everybody."
Around $50,000 was raised to make the Winter Festival a go, Berkey said. Keeping it a non-ticketed venture is the town's aim.
"The big thing that we've always said is that if we ever get in a position where we can't cover those costs and would have to charge, we don't want to do it any longer," Berkey said. "We want to be able to give the people of this area something they can bring their whole family to, where they can make a Christmas memory and they don't have to bring any money."
Planning for the town's marquee event in 2025 has already begun. Berkey said there may be some new offerings to keep things fresh for loyal festivalgoers.
"We are thinking that next year, we would like to try and maybe add something new, some kind of a new attraction, just to keep people interested in it," she said. "We don't want it to be stale next year. We want to still have all the charm and have everything that we have, but maybe add another attraction to it." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community winter festival with lights, performances, and family activities, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category, while also touching on cultural aspects and local government organization.

title: Full steam ahead: Festival of Trains awes visitors
author: Staff Writer
content:
Full steam ahead: Festival of Trains awes visitors

 December 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 324
 Words 

 Read News Document

 KENT NARROWS — The old outlets on Kent Island came to life with the lights and sounds of locomotives as train lovers young and old once again flocked to this year's Queen Anne's Railroad Society's Festival of Trains Dec. 3,4 and Dec 14 and 15.A favorite of enthusiasts for decades, the free annual festival had well over 1,000 people a day pack rooms to view the indoor train displays of various gauges and creative backdrops while learning information on the local history of railroads in the county.
A train display used to be part of an informational section of Queen Anne's Museum of Eastern Shore Life at the 4-H Park, but has since erupted to take on a life of its own, Queen Anne's Rail Road Society President Dan Worth said.
Queen Anne's County and the Eastern Shore of Maryland has a rich railroad history, connecting towns and major shipping areas. And are a tradition in every sense of the word, representing local history as well as being a fond memory to usher in the Christmas spirit for all ages, according to Worth.
Set up for the skillfully crafted displays begins in November.
An interactive scavenger hunt encouraged kids to explore the venue and note intrinsic details found within the train sets.
With a silent auction of historic train memorabilia and train kits for sale, all proceeds went toward the society's efforts to keep the spirit of local railroads alive and preserve the Centreville Station Freight Depot.
New this year, the Festival of Trains was also part of the 2024 Tour the Shore, a family oriented scavenger hunt for collectible stickers presented by local railroad clubs including Delmarva Model Railroad Club, Eagle Line Railroad, Rescue Fire Company, First State Model Railroad Club and Sudlersville Train Station Museum. This interactive partnership seeks to bring attention to the other clubs, layouts and historic stations on the Eastern Shore.
More information about the Queen Anne's County Railroad Society can be found at https://www.qarrs.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: How long is too long for Christmas decorations
author: Michele Brosius Food Drink Life
content:
How long is too long for Christmas decorations

 December 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michele Brosius Food Drink Life | Section: Entertainment 
 
 869
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The holiday season sparks lively discussions about traditions and preferences — from pumpkin spice to candy corn and the timing of Christmas decorations. Once the tree is up and the halls are decked, the question becomes how long holiday decorations should stay — is there a perfect timeline, or is it all about personal choice and sentimental value?For some, clearing the decorations right after New Year's symbolizes a fresh start. Others follow tradition and keep the festive spirit alive until the Twelfth Night on Jan. 5. Then, some stretch the season further — leaving lights aglow months after the holiday ends — prompting the age-old question: When to take down Christmas decorations?
Christmas decor through the ages
Once central to winter solstice celebrations, evergreen trees symbolized life during the darkest days. By the 16th century, candles were added to represent Christ's light, and the tradition spread through Europe and America, evolving with tinsel, glass ornaments and electric lights.
Today, Christmas decor reflects diverse styles, from traditional red and green to minimalist or trendy themes like pink Christmas. Whether rustic, glamorous or nature inspired, modern decorations allow for a personalized festive atmosphere.
Holiday decor: Tradition vs. personal preference
In some families, tradition dictates that all decorations come down on Epiphany, Jan. 6, marking the Twelfth Night when the Wise Men visited baby Jesus. Others prefer not to wait that long, taking down the tree the morning after Christmas and cleaning the house in time for New Year's Eve festivities.
You might be one of those people who would appreciate a year-round tree if you love Christmas, the holiday candies that come with it and the warm and cozy feeling of having a glowing tree in the corner of your room. The internet is full of year-round Christmas tree decor ideas like a sparkly heart-themed Valentine's Day tree or a pretty pastel tree to welcome spring.
According to a 2023 poll on Bob Vila, 16% of respondents said they take their Christmas decor down immediately following the holiday. Just over 60% of respondents said they typically leave decorations up until the conclusion of Epiphany — and the remainder — 21% of poll participants — indicated that they enjoy keeping their decorations in place at least until the end of January.
Multiple factors at play
For many, deciding when to take holiday decor down results from several factors. These include whether or not they need to get their closets or garage storage space back in order, the types of decor and if it's fragile or a family heirloom that requires greater care.
The availability of community recycling and environmental waste disposal can also be a factor for those opting for a real tree over an artificial one. The National Fire Protection Association reports that most Christmas tree fires occur in January, often due to dried-out trees that pose a heightened fire risk. Safety is key if you plan to keep your real tree up for an extended period.
Christmas tree safety
Proper care and precautions can help ensure Christmas tree safety throughout the holiday season. Water your tree daily to keep it from drying out and becoming a fire hazard. Position the tree away from heat sources like radiators or fireplaces, which can accelerate drying and increase risk. Check that all lights are in good condition, avoid any frayed cords or broken bulbs and always turn off the lights before leaving the house or going to bed.
Energy efficiency
Another important consideration is the higher energy bills in keeping Christmas tree lights and outdoor holiday lighting running throughout the day. While there are energy-efficient LED lights on the market, given the additional expenses acquired during the holiday season, keeping electricity bills down during this time can be a priority for some.
Caring for your Christmas decorations
When you finally put your decorations away, making them last will require proper care and storage. Wrap fragile decorations individually in tissue paper or bubble wrap, and store them in sturdy, divided containers to prevent breakage. Wrap string lights around cardboard or a spool to avoid tangling, and check for any damaged bulbs before storage.
Artificial trees should be disassembled and stored in their original box or a tree bag to protect against dust and moisture. Keep all decorations in a cool, dry space, away from extreme temperatures or humidity. Proper storage ensures your decorations stay in great condition for many holiday seasons to come.
When to take Christmas decorations down
Deciding when to take down Christmas decorations is a personal choice shaped by tradition, practicality and lifestyle. Whether you follow a historical timeline like Epiphany, embrace a New Year's refresh or extend the festive spirit, the key is finding what suits your home and schedule.
Your lifestyle and preferences will dictate the best answer to how long Christmas decorations should stay up, and when it comes down to it, if someone isn't contributing to the household or paying your energy bill, then their opinion on the topic shouldn't matter. Do what makes you and your family happy and let the grinches of the world scowl from afar.
Michele Brosius is the creator of Midlife Healthy Living where she expertly combines her love for cooking with budget-conscious nutrition strategies. Through her blog, she encourages women to embrace a healthier lifestyle with simple recipes and wellness tips. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses holiday decoration traditions, safety tips, and lifestyle choices, fitting the Entertainment section's focus on seasonal lifestyle content rather than news, business, or public safety.

title: Holidays on the Shore First Night Talbot, Ocean City fireworks and First Day Hikes highlight New Year’s events
author: Staff Writer
content:
Holidays on the Shore First Night Talbot, Ocean City fireworks and First Day Hikes highlight New Year’s events

 December 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 537
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We've already seen plenty of cool and fun events this holiday season.Christmas in St. Michaels (including the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum's Winter on the Chesapeake event) along with the Bluepoint Holiday Market at the Ebenezer Theater and the Avalon Theatre's production of "The Sound of Music" in Easton have already rung in the holidays.
But we are not done yet.
Christmas lights are still adorned throughout the Shore and New Year's Eve and New Year's Day events await.
Here are some of the upcoming events.
First Night Talbot in EastonThe Easton Economic Development Corp. and Union Baptist Church are putting on the free, family event to ring in the New Year.
The New Year's Eve event runs 6 p.m. through midnight.
First Night Talbot will also feature a Gospel Music Extravaganza at the Avalon Theatre from 10 p.m. to midnight. There will also be crab drops to ring in 2025 at 9 p.m. and midnight as well kids events and arts and craft.
A number of restaurants and hotels throughout the area have New Year's Eve special menus and events to celebrate 2024 and welcome 2025.
Those include the Ruse Restaurant at The Wildset Hotel and Bistro St. Michaels in St. Michaels.
For more: https://discovereaston.com/first-night-talbot/
Fireworks and fun in Ocean CityThere will also be plenty of New Year's Eve parties and events in Ocean City.
That includes two fireworks shows to ring in 2025 and celebrate Ocean City's 150th anniversary.
There will be fireworks downtown at the beach and Northside Park
"The downtown fireworks on the beach near Dorchester Street will be bigger and better than ever to usher in the 150th anniversary of the Town. A smaller fireworks display will be available uptown at Northside Park," the city said in an announcement.
"We can't think of a better way to ring in the new year and the Town's 150th anniversary than offering our residents and visitors two great fireworks shows," said Ocean City Mayor Rick Meehan. "Families can enjoy counting down to the new year with fireworks at midnight, whether you catch the large-scale show downtown on the beach or choose to enjoy the northern show from the perimeter of Northside Park."
There will be games at Fun City Arcade and live country music from the Dwayne Wilson Band at The Purple Moose on Ocean City's famed boardwalk.
The town will offer free bus service on New Year's Eve and into New Year's Day.
OC's Winterfest and its holiday lights run through Dec. 31 until 9:30 p.m and the Winterfest Model Train Display at OC's convention center is on display Wednesdays through Sundays until December 31, 5:30 — 9:00 p.m.
For more: https://www.ococean.com/
First Day HikesState parks across Maryland will host First Day Hikes from Dec. 31 through Jan. 2. They are part of national efforts to encourage hikes, walks and enjoying the outdoors to kick off the New Year.
On the Eastern Shore, there will be First Day hikes hosted at Martinak State Park in Denton, Tuckahoe State Park in Ridgley, Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad State Park in Church Creek, Cypress Branch State Park in Millington, Janes Island State Park in Crisfield, Assateague State Park in Berlin and the Bill Burton Fishing Pier State Park in Trappe.
Some of the hikes are self-guided and some include guided walks with rangers.
For more information check out https://dnr.maryland.gov/publiclands/pages/firstdayhikes.aspx

title: Upcoming shows at the Avalon

Upcoming shows at the Avalon

 Upcoming shows at the Avalon Theatre in Easton include an acoustic nod to to Southern Rock, a leading bluegrass and American roots group and a singer-songwriter duo.Here are some of the details.
CHESAPEAKE SONSThe Chesapeake Sons will perform an acoustic set at the Avalon Theatre in Easton on Friday, Jan. 3.
The show starts at 7 p.m. Tickets are $30 and $40.
"Chesapeake Sons owe their geographical roots to the Atlantic seaboard, but its sonic heritage connects the band firmly to The Black Crowes, the Allman Brothers Band, Lynyrd Skynyrd, and the Marshall Tucker Band," according to a show announcement from the Avalon.
"The Chesapeake Sons four-piece ensemble blends effusive melodies, fierce musicianship, convicted vocals, and smart lyrics in a diverse song stew that dips — in Southern-rock fashion — into rock, blues, country, gospel, and even psychedelia."
KEN & BRAD KOLODER QUARTETThe Ken & Brad Kolodner Quartet will perform Saturday, Jan, 4 at the Avalon. The show starts at 7 p.m. Tickets are $30.
"The dynamic father-son team Ken & Brad Kolodner weave together a captivating soundscape on hammered dulcimer and clawhammer banjo blurring the lines of Old-Time, Bluegrass and American Roots music," the Avalon said in an announcement.
"Regarded as one of the most influential hammered dulcimer players in North America, Baltimore's Ken Kolodner joined forces in 2009 with his son Brad Kolodner, a renowned clawhammer banjo player. They've sculpted their own brand of driving, innovative, tasteful acoustic roots music with a "creative curiosity that lets all listeners know that a passion for traditional music yet thrives in every generation."
The quartet won 1st place in the Neo-Traditional Band Contest at the Appalachian Stringband Festival in the summer of 2019 and they're still going strong!
GOLDPINEGoldpine will have a performance at the Stoltz LIstening Room at 7 p.m. on Thursday, Jan. 9.
Tickets are $25
"From festivals like 30A Songwriting Festival and Bristol Rhythm & Roots Reunion, to listening rooms throughout the United States, Ben and Kassie have been offering their own brand of raw Americana to audiences large and small. Winner of the 2022 Rocky Mountain Songwriter Contest and Finalists in the Kerrville Folk Fest 2021 New Folk Competition, the duo's bold harmonies are clearly a channel for their highly charged songwriting," according to a show announcement.

title: Heavy rain did not stop the 31st First Night Talbot
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Heavy rain did not stop the 31st First Night Talbot

 January 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 348
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Although there were thunderstorms and heavy rain poured, First Night Talbot was a success.Around 6:15 p.m. Dec. 31, heavy rain and some light hail began to pour over downtown Easton, leading locals to seek shelter inside the Waterfowl building, where the festivities took place.
According to Union Baptist Church officials, who helped organize this year's event, there were 300 to 400 people who came out to celebrate the new year at the 9 p.m. crab drop, one of two held that evening.
Many locals enjoyed First Night Talbot for the very first time and archived some fun family memories.
"It was fun stuff for kids to do and just a good time listening to the music," said Kent Sadler, father of a local family. "We waited a little while because of the rain, then we decided to come, and then my wife fell down and got wet."
Kids ran around to get their face painted and played with inflated basketball hoops and football goals. Music bingo was a success, and everyone moved their heads enjoying the music while kids played and enjoyed the night.
Event organizers had to pivot for the 9 p.m. crab drop with rain and lightning near the area. The crab drop was moved back until 9:15 p.m., which some longtime locals had never seen before.
Although some locals voiced their dismay at the delay, everyone stayed until the new time, even when it started to rain. Due to technical difficulties, the 2025 sign did not light up until 9:16 p.m., but attendees enjoyed the event despite the hiccup.
Local couple Dan Helfgott and Kim Helfgott have been married for 38 years, and they just moved to Easton last year and they enjoyed all the festivities and the crab drop.
"We moved here a year ago," new local Kim said. "Last year we were unpacking, and we missed the crab drop last year, so we really wanted to see it this year."
"It's just like Times Square, but with a crab," Dan said. "I've been in Times Square. I saw the ball drop in Times Square. This is just as festive." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
