title: 'Ziggy's World': Rock Hall artist keeps wheels turning on train display
author: BOB FORD Special to the Kent County News
content:
'Ziggy's World': Rock Hall artist keeps wheels turning on train display

 January 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BOB FORD Special to the Kent County News | Section: Entertainment 
 
 712
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When Ziggy Carter immigrated to the United States from Germany in 1960 at the age of 14, he carried with him two suitcases."In one suitcase were my clothes," Carter says. "In the other, smaller but somewhat heavier, were my electric trains."
A fascination with model trains has, obviously, been a lifelong obsession for Carter, and, until recently, finding a place to create a holiday display for his treasures was stretching into what seemed like a lifelong quest as well.
"For the last five years, I was always looking for a store window to use, but everyone was worried about liability or insurance," Carter says. "Then I asked Fresh Start and they said I could have their whole greenhouse. It's wonderful."
Carter, a multi-talented artist and builder, who has become a quaint, if quirky symbol of a town sometimes described the same way, finally found a place to unpack.
"He came to us in October with the train show idea and it was great timing," said Nina Flynn, the manager of Fresh Start, a produce-centric grocery near the central crossroads of Main and Sharp Streets. "Rich (owner Rich Seewald) and I did a little train set thing last year around the holidays and we underestimated how difficult it was. Ziggy said he could definitely do a better train show."
Well, yes. Carter's huge collection of trains and assorted paraphernalia now fill the 30-foot by 40-foot greenhouse at the rear of Fresh Start, a space that was available at this time of year. As many as eight trains whir around the intricate series of tracks; over bridges, around bends, and through Henry's Mountain, a large plaster eminence built at the request of local photographer JP Henry.
"He said he would like to see a mountain, so I had to build a mountain," Carter says.
The trains, which began operating the weekend after Thanksgiving, ran from noon to 4 p.m. on Saturdays and Sundays, through Sunday, Jan. 5. The expansive display itself can be seen during all regular store hours. More than 100 local businesses and individuals contributed funds to help Carter build the incredible show. He also invested more than $1,000 of his own money.
"Saturdays are a big day. We get a lot of kids and a lot of older people reminiscing about the old days and the trains they had around the Christmas tree," Carter says. "The kids like to chase the trains around the table, following them as they go."
Carter is best-known around Rock Hall for his artistic installations. He built the six-foot blue heron metal sculpture displayed outside Harbor Shack, and executed the whimsical storefront sign above the That Place On Main restaurant, and created the more-than-life-size depictions of Snoopy and Woodstock at the American Rock Hall Garage. Carter was also the featured artist for the 2024 Rock Hall FallFest promotional poster that was on display all over Kent County.
Rock Hall was not necessarily a destination for Carter when his sailboat broke down here 25 years ago, but he eventually made it his home.
"I was shipwrecked," he says. "I was only planning to stay for one night. I was sailing south from Maine on a 40-foot Hinckley, having come down through the canal, and was having engine problems, and some other problems as well."
After sorting those out, he decided to stay, and somehow the trains got here, too. Carter, who turned 78 last month, has been battling health problems as he worked to pull together the holiday display. He receives a chemotherapy treatment every two weeks, a course that will last through most of February. It is the main reason for the limited hours he is able to run the trains.
"It really knocks you, and I've lost 60 pounds," Carter says. "The doctors just say, 'We'll see how it goes.' What can you do? I'm enjoying what I'm doing here, and I've had a wonderful life with great adventures. No regrets at all."
The only regret might have been if his holiday train display, something he imagined in his fertile mind's eye for so long, had not become a reality. But here it is, chugging along literally the same way Carter is chugging along metaphorically. The layout is loud, and colorful, and full of action, surprises, and the delights for the season. Pretty much the same as him. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article profiles a local artist's holiday train display, a community entertainment event, and is published in the Entertainment section, making Entertainment the strongest fit, with Arts & Culture as a close secondary.

title: January events: Oysters & Ice Festival, movie night, murder mystery event
author: Staff Writer
content:
January events: Oysters & Ice Festival, movie night, murder mystery event

 January 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 409
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There are a number of fun, local happening this month, according to a January rundown from Discover Easton — which puts on and promotes local events.Here's some of January's top events, according to Discover Easton (https://discovereaston.com/).
Cambridge Oysters & Ice Festival
Friday Jan. 17 and Saturday, Jan. 18
Icelab and the Dorchester Chamber of Commerce are putting on the Cambridge Oysters & Ice Festival with events throughout downtown Cambridge. That includes interactive ice sculptures, oysters, live music and free family fun as well as an ice skating rink at the Hyatt Regency.
For more: https://iceoysterfest.com/
Movie Night at The Ebenezer: Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy
Friday, Jan. 10 — 7:30 pm
Enjoy movie night at the Ebenezer Theatre for the 1975 spy novel by John Le Carre. Venture back to the days of intrigue in the bleak days of the Cold War, as espionage veteran George Smiley is forced from semi-retirement to uncover a Soviet Agent within M16.
The.movie event at the Prager Family Center for the Arts features tables for two with beverages and pizza slices from Roma Alla Pala.
For more: https://www.pragerarts.com/
Murder Mystery Dinner
Saturday, Jan. 18 — 5:30 p.m.
Join the Tidewater Inn for a Murder Mystery Event on Saturday, Jan. 18 at 5:30 p.m.. The Mardi Gras-themed mystery, features The Mystery Krewe, where not everyone survives the ball. Enjoy a 4-course paired menu crafted to complement the intrigue. Tickets are $120 per person, including the experience, menu, gratuity, and tax. The Tidewater Inn is also offering Murder Mystery Hotel Package, featuring discounted accommodations and two tickets.
For more: https://tidewaterinn.com/
Bugatti: Reaching for Perfection
Exhibit at Academy Art Museum
An exhibit at the Academy Art Museum features five rare Bugatti cars from an Eastern Shore collection: two grand prix race cars, two Type 57 touring cars, and a miniature "Baby." and eight bronze sculptures from the Arsidi-Scuderi Collection of Lugano, Switzerland. The two collections have never been displayed together before. The exhibit runs through April 13.
For more: https://academyartmuseum.org/
Call Me Dancer
Friday, Jan. 17
The Chesapeake Film Festival and Maryland State Arts Council are presenting a free back-by-popular-demand screening of the critically acclaimed film "Call Me Dancer" at the Talbot County Free Library in Easton,n Friday, January 17, at 4:00 PM. Call Me Dancer tells the story of a young street dancer from Mumbai whose passion and determination lead him on a transformative journey to pursue his dreams of becoming a professional dancer against all odds. This movie is suggested for adults.
For more: https://chesapeakefilmfestival.com/

title: Casting call: Tred Avon Players holding auditions for ‘The Man from Earth’
author: Staff Writer
content:
Casting call: Tred Avon Players holding auditions for ‘The Man from Earth’

 January 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 394
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Tred Avon Players theatrical company in Oxford is looking for actors "of all experience levels" to audition for roles in its upcoming production of the drama "The Man from Earth."The drama by Richard Schenman is based on a book by Jerome Bixby.
The Oxford production will be directed by Cecile Storm. It will run April 17 to 27 at the Oxford Community Center.
Auditions will be held at the Avalon Theatre in Easton at 6:30 p.m. on Tuesday, Jan. 14, and Wednesday, Jan. 15.
Play summary:After history professor John Oldman unexpectedly resigns from the University, his startled colleagues impulsively invite themselves to his home, pressing him for an explanation. But they're shocked to hear his reason for premature retirement: John claims he must move on because he is immortal, and cannot stay in one place for more than ten years without his secret being discovered. Tempers rise and emotions flow as John's fellow professors attempt to poke holes in his story, but it soon becomes clear that his tale is as impossible to disprove as it is to verify. What starts out as a friendly gathering soon builds to an unexpected and shattering climax. Acclaimed science fiction writer Jerome Bixby, writer of the original 'Star Trek' and 'The Twilight Zone', originally conceived this story back in the early 1960's. It would become his last great work.
"TAP will be casting 10 roles. All ages, genders, ethnicities, body types, abilities, and skill levels are welcome to audition and will be considered for roles," the drama group said in a press release.
Here are the roles:John: A history professor who resigns from his job to move to a new home. He claims to be immortal and must move every ten years to avoid being discovered.
Harry: A biology professor.
Edith: An art history professor.
Dan: An anthropologist.
Sandy: A historian who is in love with John.
Art: An archaeology professor.
Linda: A young student.
Will: A psychiatrist and physician.
Two Movers that will double as our orchestra.
Readings will be selected scenes from the script provided during the audition. You can reach director Cecile Storm by emailing hello@cecilestorm.com for any special accommodations.
Production crewTAP also needs a production crew for sets, lights, sound, costumes well as a stage crew. If you are interested, come to any audition to find out more information or send an email to hello@cecilestorm.com.
The nonprofit Tred Avon Players were founded in 1982. For more: www.tredavonplayers.org 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge Ice & Oyster Fest to return for fourth year
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge Ice & Oyster Fest to return for fourth year

 January 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 565
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Ice sculptures and ice games are coming back to Cambridge — and will be served up with a side of oysters — for the fourth annual Cambridge Ice & Oyster Festival on Jan. 17 and 18.Put on by the Dorchester Chamber of Commerce and Ice Lab, with help from Cambridge Main Street and Dorchester County Tourism, the festival will bring ice sculptures carved from more than 400,000 pounds of ice, live ice sculpting demonstrations, a slide made of ice and more frozen fun to Cambridge.
There will also be frozen versions of classic games such as corn hole and tic-tac-toe, an '80s-themed ice bar and two stages featuring live music.
Dorchester Chamber of Commerce President Bill Christopher said the family-friendly festival is "always a blast." This year, there will be some new ice sculptures, including a Jersey skiff you can pose inside of and a target you can shoot at with paintballs, he said.
"We have a lot of interactive ice, which I think is different than some of the other festivals," Christopher said.
According to a news release about the event, some of the festival's featured ice sculptures include an ice hockey table, locomotive engine, flock of geese and tractor and trailer. The more than 40 sculptures have been or are being carved by Ice Lab.
Ricky Fitzhugh, chief ice officer of Ice Lab, said the time it takes to carve each sculpture depends on the detail of the sculpture.
"But it could (be) anywhere from an hour to five or six hours of carving," he said.
Sponsored by the Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay Golf Resort, Spa and Marina and a variety of other Mid-Shore businesses and organizations, the event will be held in downtown Cambridge, at the Packing House and at the Hyatt. Shuttles will provide transportation between locations.
For the oyster part of the festival, the watermen of Dorchester County and some of the region's top oyster farms will be selling oysters. Christopher said that along with raw oysters, there will be oysters prepared in different ways, like roasted oysters.
"The Dorchester Seafood Heritage Association will be serving wild caught oysters," Christopher said. "And then we will have five other aquaculture guys that are all local that grow the oysters local. Each of those oysters are slightly different. They've got different salinity, different taste."
According to the news release, local oyster farms that will be at the event include Choptank Terrapin Oyster Co., Farm Creek Oyster Co., Madhouse Oysters and Madison Bay Seafood.
With all the ice, festival-goers will be able to warm up at fire pits and make s'mores.
The festival will also have beverages to keep everyone — including those who are 21 and older — warm. From coffee to hot chocolate to craft beer and cocktails, attendees will be able to take their pick.
The event will kick off at the Packing House on the evening of Friday, Jan. 17. That night, there will be ice skating at the Hyatt Winter Village and interactive ice sculptures in downtown Cambridge. On Saturday, Jan. 18, events will be held throughout the day in downtown Cambridge and at the Hyatt Winter Village. There is no cost for admission to the festival.
The Rescue Fire Company Train Garden will be open during the festival.
More information about the Cambridge Ice & Oyster Festival can be found on the festival's website at iceoysterfest.com. Entertainment schedules and weather updates will be posted on the festival's Facebook page. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a local festival featuring ice sculptures, live music, games, and food, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category, while also touching on arts (ice art) and local oyster (aquaculture) vendors.

title: Spreading the love: Centreville welcomes Eastern Shore’s first romance-only bookstore
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Spreading the love: Centreville welcomes Eastern Shore’s first romance-only bookstore

 January 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 608
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTERVILLE — Providing a community for romance readers, indie writers, and all those who love books, a small bookstore in a small town is supporting small authors for all those with a big heart as Romance-Landia Bookstore held a grand opening in Centreville Jan. 4.The niche store fills a need, supporting self-published authors and offering a community for romance book readers, according to owner Staci Hicks who considered romance books to be her escape outlet and was excited to share that passion with the community.
Hicks has a background in promoting self-published authors, and noted romance novels are no longer a genre that one has to be ashamed of enjoying and now has its own entire community backing, she said.
Romance books come in an eclectic variety of subgenres from westerns to sports to paranormal.
"Anybody can find something if they open themselves up to it," she said.
In addition to a wide variety of romance books, the store stocks everything a bookworm needs, including stickers, pens, bookmarks, tote bags, and gifts for the bibliophile in your life.
With a degree in graphic design, Hicks designed a number of bookmarks and stickers herself.
Highlighting the importance of a good book, the store is also complete with a sitting lounge and a small self-serve coffee bar to curl up with a new favorite find.
The intimate location is perfect for connecting with others who feel passionate about books.
"We needed this," said Cristi Bruce, of Crumpton, with an armful of indie writings, who noted there was nothing like it in the area and was thrilled by the opportunity of a brick and mortar bookstore in Centreville. The stigma used to be that you never told anyone you read romance, she said, now the genre is becoming more and more popular by readers of all types.
To have a physical bookstore and in-person book clubs that romance book lovers can flock to is nothing short of a dream come true, said Amanda Parsons, of Chestertown.
Romance is a rapidly expanding genre, according to indie author Kristie Wolf, of Bel Air who came out to the ribbon cutting in support of local businesses and fellow authors.
The best part of romance novels, both writing and reading, is the guaranteed happy ending, Wolf said, which fills her days with much needed hope.
Indie author Sarah Blue provided signings and promotions of her latest page turners last Saturday. From paranormal to contemporary, Blue writes a little bit of everything in the genre of romance,"I can't stay in one lane," she said.
The great part of writing romance books is there aren't too many rules to follow and Blue loves the opportunity to write stories that she wants to read.
Local authors supporting a local woman-owned businesses in a small town, "is a match made in heaven," said indie author B.R. Goodwin performing book signings.
Being a self-published author is similar to owning your own businesses and indie authors are always supportive of each other, according to Goodwin.
Indie authors are always sharing, supporting and encouraging each other and readers are vicarious who love devouring anything, author Claire Cain said.
Hicks has been delighted in the new people she has met through connecting over books and as the flocks of the opening day's crowd gathered, community support has been extremely receptive and supportive of the store.
The best thing about romance books is sharing a sense of escapism with other readers, which in this day and age is needed more than ever, Hicks said.
Romance-Landia has a schedule of regular indie author visits and book clubs are held Thursdays once a month
Located at 204 Banjo Lane, more information about Romance-Landia Bookstore, including upcoming author visits and bookclubs can be found at https://www.romance-landia.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the opening of a romance‑only bookstore, author events, and community reading activities, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category (bookstore and genre promotion). It also touches on cultural aspects of literature, making Arts & Culture a secondary fit, while business aspects are present but less central.

title: The secret world of fancy butter: Is the hype worth your buck?
author: Jennifer Allen Food Drink Life
content:
The secret world of fancy butter: Is the hype worth your buck?

 January 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jennifer Allen Food Drink Life | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1200
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Enter the secret world of fancy butter, where class and sophistication define every dish they're added to. While high-end butters like Bordier and Kerrygold offer richer flavors and a smoother texture, the question remains: Is it worth splurging $20 or more for the indulgence?What is fancy butter?Fancy butter is a high-quality butter with unique characteristics that you just don't get in your supermarket brands. These distinct qualities can include higher butterfat content, a complex taste or a softer texture. They can also be made from the milk of grass-fed cows or select breeds that have more flavorful milk, or even from goat's milk.
If you're wondering why butter usually tastes better in restaurants, gourmet butters might be the reason. In 2021, The Guardian discussed the growing restaurant trend of using fancy, handmade butter, such as those flavored with herbs, spices or even smoked bone marrow, to deliver a different flavor experience.
Is a stick of fancy butter worth it?An article in HuffPost states that fancy butters contain higher butterfat than ordinary butter, especially those from Europe which can go up to 87% versus your store brand which hovers around 80%. This higher butterfat content gives the butter a richer flavor and lower moisture content, which improves mouthfeel, taste and texture. "What's the point of having good bread if you don't use good butter," is a sentiment shared by many, including Amanda Luhn from Knoxville Backyard & Beyond.
Statista has projected the price of butter to rise even more in 2025, and with increased demand, is gourmet butter better? From French butter that could range up to $82 per pound to Irish grass-fed butter like Kerrygold, are these pricey spreads worth every buck, or are they just a modern fad?
Bordier butter: Justifying the French crazeFrench butter is revered worldwide for its rich flavor and texture, which elevates everyday dishes from soups to pastries. Ashley Wali, creator of Wanderlux, recommends visiting creameries and grocery stores in France to experience true French butter craftmanship. "They pass airport security and will stay cold until you get home. It's the perfect edible souvenir you can't get anywhere else," she says.
One of the most famous French butter is Bordier butter, a handcrafted butter made with high-quality organic milk from small local French farms in regions like Brittany, Normandy and Pays de la Loire. Starting at $12 for a 4-ounce stick, this premium butter will give you a unique creamy, silky texture and complex flavors, which change with the seasons due to the varying cow diets.
Bordier butter is made using traditional methods, including churning, kneading and salting by hand. With meticulous attention to detail in its production, this luxurious butter is a beloved ingredient in professional kitchens and among food enthusiasts, making every penny you spend worth it.
"Sure, it's not always cheap — hello, sticker shock — but there's no comparison when you're spreading it on warm bread or swirling it into a sauce," says Bitty of Eighty Recipes who's been stashing specialty butters in their freezer. "Flavored ones, like Bordier, are incredible and hold up perfectly for months. When you treat butter as more than just an ingredient, it can make a meal sing," she adds.
Grass-fed butter: Healthy and fancyGrass-fed butter is made from the milk of cows that eat a diet of 100% grass without grain or corn supplementation. This means the color of grass-fed butter is deeper due to the carotene and chlorophyll in the grass, making it richer than grain-fed cows. Because of the diverse grasses and herbs the cows consume, grass-fed butter offers a rich, creamy taste with nutty undertones.
Angus Dalton explains in the TastingTable that grass-fed butter contains higher levels of omega-3 fatty acids which are essential for brain and heart health and could help manage depression. It's also rich in conjugated linoleic acid which can aid in weight loss.
Grass-fed butter is a healthier option than traditional grain-fed butter that are high in saturated fats. This premium butter can cost $5-12 per pound based on brand and whether it's organic or specialty butter.
Is Irish butter just better?An 8-ounce slab of Irish butter for $4-7 will give you a sweeter and more flavorful alternative due to its higher butterfat content and the cows' grass-fed diet. According to Real Simple, it contains 82% butterfat, which makes it creamier, spreadable and more flavorful than American butter. Lovers of Irish butter, like Glenda from Glenda Embree Blog, reserve this pricy butter for special occasions.
Real Simple states that the sweeter taste comes from the beta-carotene in Ireland's lush, nutrient-rich pastures the cows graze on. This also contributes to the butter's distinctive bright yellow color. Irish butter is mostly uncultured and unsalted, unlike most European butter, making it smoother and milder in taste.
The most famous brand of Irish butter is Kerrygold which launched in the United States in 1990 with its first product, Kerrygold cheese. The Irish Co-operative Organisation Society reports Kerrygold holds the number one position in the U.S. market for imported butter, and Wirecutter has named it one of the best butters of 2024, describing its texture as "luxuriously creamy, dense and silky, without any mouth-coating greasiness."
The creative spreads of flavored butterIf you want to go fancy without spending a fortune, try making flavored or compound butter at home. Compound butter is butter mixed with other ingredients, like herbs, spices or even alcohol, to enhance its taste. It's another method of adding flavor to your dishes and improving your butter's flavor profile. Here are some notable examples you can whip up to make you feel like a five-star chef in your kitchen.
Herb compound butterIf you're looking for butter that adds a luxurious aroma to your dishes, herb compound butter might be for you. This flavored butter ranges from combining shallot, rosemary asiago or lemon herb for that rich, savory flavor to your recipes.
Garlic compound butterA popular staple in restaurants and home kitchens, garlic compound butter, such as roasted garlic, lemon garlic, garlic powder and black garlic, offers various savory, aromatic flavors for bread, meats, seafood, vegetables, pasta and even vegetarian meals. This makes this fancy butter a versatile ingredient that will help you invent that signature dish you've been planning ever since.
Sweet compound butterUse sweet compound butter, such as apple herb, cinnamon honey and maple brown sugar, to combine sweet and savory flavors in your dishes. Flavored butter of this variety works wonders in baked goods, breakfast items and meats.
Savory compound butterTo introduce bold and rich flavors, incorporate savory compound butter into your dishes, such as blue cheese, bacon, four cheese and pesto basil. This flavored butter is ideal for meats, vegetables and baked goods.
Final words on fancy butterAdding fancy butter to your arsenal of ingredients should be based on your preference and budget, not primarily on social status. With several options to choose from, gourmet butter should not only be used for sophistication but to also create mouthwatering dishes that will have your guests asking for seconds.
Jennifer Allen, retired chef turned cookbook author, blogger and traveler, shares her adventures and travel tips at All The Best Spots. Living at home with her family — and the cats that rule them all — her work has been featured in The Washington Post, Seattle Times, MSN and more. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on gourmet butter as a lifestyle and food trend, discussing taste, price, and consumer choices. It is published in the Entertainment section and reads like a food‑culture feature rather than a health report or economic analysis, making Entertainment the best match.

title: Musical prodigies will perform at Chesapeake Music’s Interlude Concert
author: Staff Writer
content:
Musical prodigies will perform at Chesapeake Music’s Interlude Concert

 January 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Chesapeake Music will hold an Interlude Concert on Sunday, Feb. 16 featuring pianist Janice Carissa, and violinist Stella Chen.The concert is at the Ebenezer Theater in Easton. Tickets are $50.
Chesapeake Music also offers free tickets for students and music educators, as well as a "buy-one-get-one" option for those who are new to Chesapeake Music and want to bring a friend, the local group said in an announcement.
Carissa began studying piano in Indonesia at the age of five with her self-taught pianist mother, according to the announcement.
She entered the Curtis Institute of Music at age 15, debuted with the Philadelphia Orchestra at age 16, and with the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra at age 19. Carissa studied under professors Gary Graffman and Robert McDonald and went on to receive her master's degree from the Juilliard School. She was recently named a Gilmore Young Artist and has won the Salon de Virtuosi Award and the American Protégé Star Performer Award.
She has performed Sydney Opera House to the Kennedy Center and Carnegie Hall.
Chen grew up in Silicon Valley and began playing the violin at age seven. She was Gramophone's 2023 Young Artist of the Year,
Chen won at the 2019 Queen Elisabeth International Violin Competition followed by the 2020 Avery Fisher Career Grant and the 2020 Lincoln Center Emerging Artist Award. She is the Inaugural recipient of the Robert Levin Award from Harvard University. Her mentors include Levin, Donald Weilerstein, Itzhak Perlman, Miriam Fried, and Catherine Cho.
Chen has performed as a soloist with the New York Philharmonic and the Chicago Symphony and appeared in venues such as Carnegie Hall, Lincoln Center, Vienna's Musikverein, and Berliner Philharmonie. She plays chamber music with Perlman, Weilerstein, and Levin.
In March of 2023, Chen produced a debut album called Stella X Schubert. Her instruments include the 1700 "ex-Petri" Stradivari and the 1708 "Huggins" Stradivari.
There will be solo and combined performances at the Feb. 16 concert.
To purchase tickets, visit Chesapeakemusic.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

"Debbie Wojciechowski is a self-proclaimed 'normal person' who possesses an extraordinary ability…the ability to communicate with your loved ones on the 'other side',:" the Avalon said in an announcement on the event.
"Born and raised in Baltimore, Debbie's metaphysical journey began at the age of 13 with a near-death experience. Although she was aware of some of her metaphysical abilities from that point forward, she did not fully understand what was happening until experiencing actual losses when she was about 21. From that point forward, Debbie began a personal journey to study and learn more about her metaphysical gift," the announcement continued.
"For years, she worked and studied extensively with local and international mediums and spiritual mentors. She trained with British mediums and learned the traditions of the Spiritualist Churches of Great Britain. Although accreditation is not required in the U.S., Debbie has studied extensively with internationally known and respected professionals in this field and has obtained formal certification from the Lisa Williams International School of Spiritual Development."

title: Ice & Oyster Festival brings crowd to downtown Cambridge
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Ice & Oyster Festival brings crowd to downtown Cambridge

 January 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 488
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Although Friday's comparatively warmer temperatures kept the more than 40 ice sculptures off the streets of downtown Cambridge for the first day of the Cambridge Ice and Oyster Festival, they didn't stop festival-goers from having a good time.As Caleb Stine strummed his guitar at the Packing House Friday, people mingled and filled their stomachs with everything from grilled oysters with cheese, bacon and salsa to steaming hot gumbo.
Cambridge resident Kathy Ridgely said she loves the live entertainment, variety of vendors and seafood the event offers every year.
"It's just a great opportunity for community," she said.
Along with the Packing House, the two-day, admission-free festival was held at the Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay Golf Resort, Spa and Marina and in downtown Cambridge. Shuttles offered festival-goers easy transport between locations.
Dorchester Chamber of Commerce President Bill Christopher said although it was too warm to set up the ice sculptures until about 9:30 p.m. Friday night, the Packing House was "packed."
"And the shuttle was full, running people around up to the ice skating rink at the Hyatt," he said. "So people had plenty to do even though we didn't have the sculptures for them to look at downtown. The restaurants were still open, shops were still open."
Gayle Quillin, a Cambridge resident who arrived at the Packing House Friday evening with a group of friends and family, said they first went downtown Friday, but nothing was going on yet.
"So we came over here," she said.
Quillin said she always looks forward to the people at the festival every year.
"We just love all the people down there and getting to see our neighbors," she said.
Sponsored by the Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay and a variety of other Mid-Shore businesses and organizations, the event was put on by the Dorchester Chamber of Commerce and Ice Lab with help from Cambridge Main Street and Dorchester County Tourism.
Christopher said he wanted to thank the numerous sponsors of the event, whose sponsorship supports downtown Cambridge businesses.
"Because that's what this is all about," he said. "Bringing people into downtown to get folks into the restaurants and the shops in the January timeframe, which is normally very slow. And I think we were successful at making that happen again."
Ice sculptures, once they were set up, remained up for attendees to marvel over and interact with all of Saturday.
"I mean, the temperature was probably better for humans than ice," Christopher said. "But the fact that it was overcast helped the sculptures hold up really well for the day."
Last year, weather also had an affect on the festival. The event's first day was canceled because of warm weather.
Christopher said the Chamber has received overwhelmingly positive feedback about the fourth annual event. He said the Chamber estimates the festival brought in as many people as last year. He said Saturday was busy and he thinks the restaurants and shops got a lot of business.
"It's nice to see Cambridge alive and breathing," Ridgely said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community festival featuring live music, ice sculptures, and food vendors, focusing on the entertainment and cultural aspects of the event.

title: Maryland author releases new historical mystery
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maryland author releases new historical mystery

 January 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 834
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Author Carol McCabe Booker recently released her latest book "The Farmer's Wife" through New Bay Books.The book details the 1877 mystery of why a woman who had just picked a basket of cabbage leaves for dinner was murdered in a field in the village of Friendship in Anne Arundel County.
According to the New Bay Books website, "The Farmer's Wife" is the third in the Lusby resident's nonfiction series exploring historic events in 19th- and early 20th- century Southern Maryland.
It follows 2021's "Cove Point on the Chesapeake" and her 2023 best-selling "The Waterman's Widow," which was one of the Top-10 nonfiction books checked out of the Calvert Library in 2024.
The 129-page mystery is available for $17 at www.newbaybooks.com.
How long have you been writing, and how did you get started?
I started writing as a pre-teen, always focusing on nonfiction. I liked reporting on events either in school or the community. Then, one day I learned of the upcoming scrapping of a luxury cruise ship, the SS Ile de France, and it inspired me to write an essay on the great lady's history on the high seas. It was published by the New York Daily News, and it convinced me that a career as a journalist was indeed possible. A summer internship at the Voice of America while I was in college made it happen.
What inspires you to write?
I am inspired by the discovery of information that seems too fascinating or important not to share with others.
Do you consider writing to be a career?
It was my first career, starting in radio with the Voice of America, covering civil rights. I reported for Westinghouse Broadcasting from the Nigerian civil warfront, and on other stories throughout Africa while freelancing for magazines such as Reader's Digest, Ebony, and Jet. It was a wonderful career, but I also had a fascination with the law. I went to Georgetown Law School with the idea of combining the two.
What kind of writing process do you use?
I think it might best be described as a journalistic approach.
Who are some of your favorite authors and why?
Two of my favorites are historical nonfiction writers, Timothy Egan and Eric Larson. Egan's recent release, "A Fever in the Heartland: The Ku Klux Klan's Plot to Take Over America, and the Woman Who Stopped Them," is a jaw-dropper. Larson's "A Devil in the White City" and "Isaac's Storm" are both unforgettable. And coincidentally, they are both journalists.
What are you working on now?
I'm working on another book about Southern Maryland in the 1870s. It was quite a decade.
What do you want readers to know about you?
I want readers to know that whichever of my books they pick up, they will find within it something they never knew, but which merits some thought in the context of the famous quote carved into stone in front of the National Archives: "The Past is Prologue. Study the Past."
Please include a brief description of the book
In one of the wildest years in the post-Civil War period in Southern Maryland, one story in 1877 captured headlines across the country from May through December.
The press called it "one of the most revolting murders in the annals of crime," and spared no details in their reporting on the arrest and trial of a young tenant farmer for the cold-blooded murder of his wife, the mother of his three children, in the tiny hamlet of Friendship in Anne Arundel county.
Southern Maryland, like much of the country at the time, was recovering not only from the Civil War, but also from the previous November's U.S. presidential election, which had resulted in no winner until a couple of days before Inauguration Day on March 4, 1877.
Perhaps a harbinger of things to come, the year had begun with a frozen Chesapeake Bay imprisoning oyster boats, and leaving frostbitten watermen facing possible starvation until a thaw sent ice floes ripping into some of their hulls, cutting them in half. The Farmer's Wife follows the murder trial and the events that must have left many Southern Marylanders wondering "what next?
Please include an excerpt from the book
"These were tumultuous times, from a contested presidential election to deadly weather extremes, a bloody railroad strike and the actions of national and local legislatures. Reporters in every state covered the news for avid readers, and Maryland historically had several very popular newspapers.
Yet, a single story first reported in The Baltimore Sun captured headlines throughout most of the year across the country. It was a tale of betrayal. Some called it an atrocious breach of faith; a fiendish, brutal violation of trust. Others even called it "inhuman," with hints of demonic possession. It began in May with "one of the most revolting murders in the annals of crime." The victim was a young mother who went to her grave never knowing why, and perhaps not even seeing her cowardly executioner.
Steadily and in excruciating detail, nationally syndicated reports illuminated a cold-blooded crime more chilling than the past winter's paralyzing frosts on the Chesapeake Bay. No detail was spared." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article announces a new book release by a local author and is placed in the Entertainment section, focusing on cultural content rather than sports, business, or public safety.

title: Maryland stories: Filmmaker's new movie aims to scare
author: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland stories: Filmmaker's new movie aims to scare

 January 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ted Black tblack@somdnews.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 555
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In the two decades since she graduated from Patuxent High School in southern Maryland, local actress, producer and writer Victoria (Fratz) Fradkin has developed a reputation among those familiar with horror films, and recently the newly christened mother unveiled her second such film in that genre.Fradkin, 37, a Maryland native who attended The Calverton School in Huntingtown as an eighth and ninth grader before transferring to Patuxent High, vaulted onto the scene nearly 10 years ago when her debut film, "Electric Love" (2018) won for best world premiere at the San Diego International Film Festival, followed three years later by her first horror film "Val" in 2021.
Last November, Fradkin and her husband, Aaron Fradkin, a Los Angeles-based writer and director originally from Massachusetts, collaborated on yet another foray into the horror genre with "Beezel," which was released last fall. Months later, only a week before Christmas, they welcomed their first child, a daughter, and the tandem has remained busy.
Her newest film was released on streaming services nationwide last fall.
"When we first started to make 'Beezel' I wanted to be able to tell the story in three parts and then weave it together through one thread," Fradkin, who now lives on the West Coast in California, said. "Of course, even after it's finished you never know how it's going to be received by the audience until you see it during the premiere. What I found most enjoyable was seeing and hearing the audience react in different scenes. It was pretty much the reactions that we were hoping for."
"Beezel" covers six tumultuous decades as three unwitting guests of a cursed New England home stumble upon a sinister secret dwelling beneath its floors — an eternal witch with an insatiable thirst for the souls of the living. In actuality, the film was set inside the crawl space of the very home in which Aaron Fradkin was raised and his parents made no changes to the eery setting.
Although she is trying to carve her own niche in the industry, especially among horror film makers, Fradkin admits there have been several influences along the way, including independent director Damien McCarthy known for "Oddity" and actress Naomi Watts, who has emerged as one of the leading ladies in the fright film set.
"I've tried my hand in acting, but I really feel more at home writing and producing," Fradkin said. "A lot of the success from horror movies stems from the setting. We filmed much of 'Beezel' in my husband's parents' old house in the crawl space. It was really creepy, but it wasn't a set, it was just that way. His parents have since sold that house, but the new owners kept the crawl space the same way. They always wanted to live in a haunted house."
"Beezel" follows on the heels of "Val," co-written by Fradkin and her husband, produced by Victoria Fradkin, who also played the role of "Jenny" while Misha Reeves played the title character. Zachary Mooren, Erik Griffin, Sufe Bradshaw and Kyle Howard also play primary roles in the Patuxent graduate's first foray into the horror genre.
"I want people to know that movie was an escape to go back into the movies of the 2000s," Fradkin said. "It doesn't take itself too seriously. We pretty much wrote the entire script with all of these actors in mind." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article profiles a local filmmaker and her new horror movie, focusing on the film's production, release, and creative aspects, which aligns directly with the Entertainment topic.

title: Travel experts share top bucket list destinations for 2025
author: Caitriona Maria Wealth of Geeks
content:
Travel experts share top bucket list destinations for 2025

 January 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Caitriona Maria Wealth of Geeks | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1235
 Words 

 Read News Document

 'Overtourism' is swallowing major destinations alive, with countries like Japan, Spain, Italy, and Indonesia suffering the effects. This is not surprising, considering that 80% of travelers visit just 10% of the world's tourist destinations, according to a McKinsey report.As travelers gear up for 2025, a growing emphasis is being placed on taking the road less traveled. In Expedia's Unpack '25 travel trends report, travelers are looking to take detours to less well-known and less crowded destinations, with 63% of consumers saying they are likely to visit a detour destination on their next trip.
A Shift Toward Experiential TravelTechnavio predicts the travel market size is set to increase by $5,506.7 billion between 2023 and 2028, with experiential travel being a key driver of the market. Experiential travel allows modern travelers to connect to local cultures and traditions, and captivating content on social media sites like Instagram and TikTok fuels this trend.
"2025 is the year to leave your comfort zone and chase experiences that will truly take your breath away," says Ellen Flowers, travel editor at The Perennial Style. "Travel is about pushing your boundaries, discovering new worlds, and connecting deeply with the places and people you encounter. For 2025, make it your goal to fill your bucket list with experiences that will shape your memories for a lifetime."
Highlights of Bucket List DestinationsWe asked travel experts to discuss destinations and activities that go beyond the typical tourist trail, emphasizing adventure, cultural immersion, and sustainability. Travel experts singled out the following destinations and activities for their uniqueness and appeal:
Svalbard, NorwayLocated in the Arctic Circle, Svalbard offers pristine wilderness and the chance to spot polar bears while experiencing some of the harshest and most stunning landscapes on Earth.
"Camping under the midnight sun in Svalbard, Norway," says Andrea Affinati, founder and travel expert at Voyaged Magazine. "There's no dark sky to signal bedtime; you're wide awake at 2 a.m., basking in sunlight while surrounded by Arctic landscapes. It's surreal, and it forces you to disconnect from any concept of time. Add in the occasional visit from a curious reindeer, and it's something you'll talk about forever."
Lake Bled, SloveniaKnown for its emerald-green waters and fairy-tale setting, this European gem combines natural beauty with opportunities for hiking and local culinary indulgence.
"For a more serene yet equally memorable experience, head to Lake Bled, Slovenia, where you can row a traditional wooden boat across crystal-clear waters to reach the iconic Bled Castle — perfect for an Instagram-worthy moment and a peaceful escape," Flowers remarks.
Kanazawa, JapanKanazawa, Ishikawa Prefecture's capital, might be less crowded than other parts of Japan but just as impressive, with the entire city classed as a UNESCO site for crafts and folk art.
"I always recommend Japan, and beyond the usual cities, Kanazawa should be on your list. This city is known for its Edo-period architecture, beautiful Kenrokuen Garden, and an up-and-coming art scene," says Affinati. "It's also famous for its gold-leaf crafts — you can even try your hand at applying gold leaf to souvenirs or desserts."
Cultural Immersion and ConnectionCultural tourism and authentic experiences are leading to the exploitation of new paths. Destinations like Sri Lanka's Ceylon tea region and Oaxaca, Mexico, offer travelers the chance to connect deeply with local cultures and nature. Experts say these interactions can be a very rewarding aspect of travel.
"For a cultural experience, I suggest celebrating the Day of the Dead in Oaxaca, Mexico," Affinati says. "This festival draws you in completely. Families invite you to see their altars, you can join them in the cemetery, and you [can] share traditional foods. It's a beautiful mix of joy and remembrance that really stays with you."
Flowers says Sri Lanka's Resplendent Tea Trails offers the perfect cultural retreat. "Nestled in the hills, it's the ideal place to sip tea while soaking in the serenity of tea plantations. It's a journey of both personal growth and cultural immersion, where each destination challenges you to step outside the ordinary and embrace the extraordinary."
Adventure and Personal GrowthFor travelers seeking physical challenges, trekking the Annapurna Circuit in Nepal provides a unique opportunity to connect with the majestic Himalayan landscape while pushing personal limits.
"I would suggest trekking the Annapurna Circuit in Nepal," says Affinati. "It's tough, but the views are worth it, and the connections you make with local communities along the way are deeply rewarding. Plus, you'll come back with a renewed sense of what you're capable of."
Similarly, Namibia's Sossusvlei dunes and Oman's wild camping experiences promise an exciting escapade alongside breathtaking scenery.
"Namibia is pure adventure. The landscapes here are epic, from the towering dunes of Sossusvlei to the shipwrecks along the Skeleton Coast, not to mention the incredible opportunities for spotting wildlife," Affinati says.
As for Oman, "You'll feel like the last person on Earth with an incredible night sky. You might even see camels and nomads roaming around," Oberman says.
Oberman also puts in a good word for Erbil, the capital of Iraqi Kurdistan in Iraq, for someone looking for a real adventure.
"I lived there for two years, and while it's in an 'orange' area, the region offers beautiful and unexpected nature: snow-capped mountains — even glaciers — waterfalls, gorges, canyons, and lush valleys," he says. "One of the most stunning spots is Rawanduz, a small town built on a cliff edge. However, always go with a guide familiar with the area."
While Oberman provides an interesting insight, the current Level Four "Do Not Travel" advisory for Iraq suggests that potential visitors may need to reconsider their plans or explore safer alternatives until conditions improve.
Sustainable Travel Takes Center StageTrip.com Group, a leading global travel service provider, reviewed 9,867 survey samples from 109 countries and territories for their Sustainable Travel Consumer Report 2024. They found that while an overwhelming 92% of travelers may consider sustainable travel, only 56.9% say they have actually practiced it. Travelers are on the lookout for more transparency around sustainable options, but a gap between awareness and action is still present.
As environmental awareness grows, travel experts we interviewed encourage travelers to plan trips responsibly. They recommend traveling off-season when there are fewer crowds, supporting sustainable, locally-owned businesses, and opting for eco-friendly accommodations.
Affinati recommends taking it slow. "Instead of hopping from city to city every couple of days, stay longer in one place. It reduces your transportation footprint and lets you experience a destination on a deeper level."
"Another practical tip is to choose eco-certified accommodations. These aren't just hotels with a 'save your towels' sign but places that actively work to reduce waste, conserve water, and support local ecosystems. I suggest looking for certifications like Green Key or EarthCheck when booking," she adds.
Affinati also points to low-impact activities such as electric-powered boat tours, which "allow you to explore without disturbing wildlife or polluting the water." In addition, you can cut down on single-use plastics, which are "a huge problem in many popular destinations." Instead, opt for reusable items such as water bottles, utensils, and shopping bags.
Looking Ahead to 2025With the lingering effects of pandemic-era restrictions, experts predict that 2025 will continue to see a surge in bucket-list trips as people make up for lost time. The McKinsey survey reports that 66% of travelers are more interested in travel now than before the COVID-19 pandemic. Travelers are highly influenced by the stories behind the destination, with 92% of young travelers taking inspiration from social media for their last trip.
The expectations for meaningful and experiential travel destinations are high for 2025 and beyond. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on travel trends, bucket‑list destinations, and experiential tourism, which aligns with lifestyle and leisure content typically classified under Entertainment rather than the other listed categories.

title: Local author asks, does a kitten belong in school?
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Local author asks, does a kitten belong in school?

 January 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 477
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Growing up in Massachusetts, in the mid-80's, second-grader Nancy Mugele, now Head of Kent School, a private day school in Chestertown, had an adorable and stubborn gray kitten that followed her to class.The affectionate feline was called Jingles. Her unique personality left a big impression because years later, the kitten would be the subject of Mugele's first children's book, "Jingles Goes to School."
Late October, Bumble Bee Books, the children's publishing department of Olympia Publishers, put out the book and can now be purchased at Bumblebee Books website, on Amazon, and locally here at the Book Plate, in downtown Chestertown.
Mugele based her book off her childhood, even mentioning her home, the house with the red shutters at 19 Bonney Lane. That was where Jingles escaped from back then, braving the New England winters to follow Mugele to school. Mugele's mother had to place her infant son in a stroller to come pick up Jingles.
"That's not normal behavior for a cat," Mugele said laughing.
This amusing anecdote is the plot of the book.
In between the colorful illustrated pages, Jingles displays to Nancy's teacher, Miss Bevivino, her class, and the principal, Mr. Willett, her love of learning. At one point, Jingles even plays the piano, "learning to trill in all the right places," at the school concert.
Will Jingles earn the affection of some of her harshest critics, like the principal?
One thing is for sure, Jingles loves school, and so does her creator, the Head of Kent School of nine years with a career in education over 20 years.
"It's really remarkable, the transformative power of books," Mugele expressed.
She witnesses this on a weekly basis, reading Jingles' adventures to her pre-k, kindergarten, and first graders, seeing their reactions.
"They absolutely love it. They ask a lot of questions. It's such a thrill when I show them actual pictures of Jingles, and see how their imaginations expand."
From her enjoyment of reading aloud to her students, she pitched her story to eight publishers, and heard back from three of them — no small feat for a new author.
Olympia Publishers appreciated that Mugele drew from her own experiences. They took care of the artwork and distribution, leaving Mugele to dream up future stories for Jingles.
In the meantime, "Jingles Goes to School," will be coming out in hardback Jan. 30, and in the near future the author plans to do local book tours. She will also be doing one for a friend at Farley's Bookshop in Pennsylvania.
Her passion however is to visit schools, reading to the kids.
"It is one of my most important meetings throughout the week," Mugele said.
She hones her writing skills on her blog site nancymugele.com, while envisioning new adventures to pen.
And as she looks for more inspiration from her life, nobody is safe, especially her lovable black lab, "River."
"He won't mind one bit if I make him the star," Mugele said with a smile. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Country Cooking: Super Bowl snacks
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Super Bowl snacks

 February 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1218
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Super Bowl LIX will be held at the Caesars Superdome in New Orleans, Louisiana kicking off at 6:30 p.m. on Feb. 9.This will be the 11th time that New Orleans has hosted the Super Bowl, tying with Miami for the most Super Bowl hosts.
Some Super Bowl facts: the Super Bowl decides which team becomes the National Football League champions. Since 2022, the games are played on the second Sunday in February. The Super Bowl is the final game of every NFL Season since 1966. The Super Bowl was supposedly named after a children's toy.
There are many gatherings and parties held on Super Bowl Sunday, and everyone has a favorite food they serve — from finger foods to snacks, pizzas, chili, soups, sandwiches and subs to wings.
No matter whether you prepare them at home, pick up a carry out or order home delivery, enjoy the gathering. May the best team win.
The Kansas City Chiefs
KANSAS CITY BRISKET BURNT ENDS
BEEF: 3-4 lb Chuck Roast, 2 tbsp favorite barbecue seasoning, 1 tbsp canola oil.
SAUCE: ¾ cup ketchup, ½ cup apple cider vinegar, 1.5 tbsp hot sauce, 1 tbsp brown sugar, ½ tbsp garlic paste, ½ tbsp Worcestershire sauce, salt to taste.
Cube your chuck roast into 1-inch cubes and place in a bowl. Lather with canola oil and then season with barbecue seasoning. Place the cubes onto a baking tray with about half an inch separation between each cube. Place in the fridge for 1 hour to set, then let come to room temperature 15 minutes before cooking. Preheat a grill or smoker using a two zone fire with Charcoal to 275 degrees. Two-zone fire: Coals spread along either side of the grill, with an empty space down the center, ideal for smoking and low-temperature cooking. Add some hickory chunks or chips for added smoke flavor. Place the beef onto the smoker to cook for about 1.5 hours until they begin to soften. As the beef smokes, heat up a medium high fire for the barbecue sauce. Add a skillet with the ingredients for the barbecue sauce and let simmer until thickened. Once warm and well incorporated, pull the barbecue sauce off the heat to cool. After 1.5 hours on the smoker, pull the beef off and place into a medium size foil bin. Top the burnt ends with the barbecue sauce and mix around. Cover the bin with aluminum foil and place back on the smoker to cook for another 2.5 hours. Add more barbecue sauce if needed so that there is a decent amount of liquid in order to break down the burnt ends. Once the burnt ends are tender and can easily break apart, pull them off and let cool for 10 minutes. Toss the cooled burnt ends in some of the foil bins sauce, season with a little more barbecue seasoning. To make the most authentic burnt ends at home, you will need a smoker but you can make them on a gas or charcoal grill.
The Philadelphia Eagles
PHILLY CHEESECAKE
1 1/2 cups Honey Maid graham cracker crumbs, ⅓ cup butter or margarine (melted), 4 (8-oz) packages Philadelphia cream cheese (softened), 1 cup and 3 tbsps sugar, 1 tsp vanilla, 4 eggs.
Preheat the oven to 325 degrees. Mix crumbs, butter and 3 tbsps sugar until combined; press firmly onto the bottom of a 9-inch springform pan. Beat cream cheese, 1 cup sugar, and vanilla in a mixing bowl until smooth. Add eggs, one at a time, mixing on low speed until just blended. Pour over the crust. Bake in the preheated oven until the center is almost set, about 55 minutes. Loosen cake from the pan rim; cool before removing rim. Refrigerate for 4 hours before serving.
New Orleans
For the next two recipes, we are going to have a game of our own, Gumbo vs. Jambalaya.
Jambalaya is primarily a rice dish, while gumbo is more of a stew. Both are made with chicken, sausage and/or seafood.
GUMBO
ROUX: 1 cup all-purpose flour, 2/3 cup oil (vegetable or canola oil).
GUMBO: 1 bunch celery (diced, leaves and all), 1 green bell pepper (diced), 1 large yellow onion (diced), 1 bunch green onions (finely chopped), 1 bunch fresh chopped parsley, 2-3 cloves garlic, 1-2 tbsps Cajun seasoning, 6-8 cups chicken broth, 12 ounce package andouille sausages (sliced into coins), meat from 1 rotisserie chicken, 2 cups shrimp (pre-cooked), hot cooked rice for serving.
In a large, heavy bottom stock pot combine flour and oil. Cook on medium-low heat, stirring constantly for 30-45 minutes. This part takes patience — when it's finished it should be as dark as chocolate and have a soft, "cookie dough" consistency. Be careful not to let it burn. Feel free to add a little more flour or oil as needed to reach this consistency.In a separate skillet on medium-high heat, place the sausage slices in one layer in the pan. Brown them well on one side (2-3 minutes) and then use a fork to flip each over onto the other side to brown. Remove to a plate. Add ½ cup of the chicken broth to the hot skillet that had the sausage to deglaze the pan. Pour the broth and drippings into your large soup pot. Add remaining 5 ½ cups of chicken broth. Add veggies, parsley, garlic and roux to the pot and stir well. Bring to a boil over medium heat and boil for 5-7 minutes, or until the vegetables are slightly tender. Stir in Cajun seasoning to taste. Add chicken, sausage and shrimp. Taste and serve. At this point taste it and add more seasonings to your liking —salt, pepper, chicken bouillon paste, garlic, more Joe's stuff or more chicken broth — until you reach the perfect flavor. Serve warm over rice. (Tastes even better the next day).
JAMBALAYA
1 tbsp oil (vegetable or canola oil), 1 lb andouille sausage (cut into ¼ inch thick slices), 1 1/2 lbs boneless skinless chicken breasts (cut into bite-size pieces), 2 tbsps all-purpose flour, 2 tbsps butter, 1 yellow or white onion (chopped), 4 green onions (chopped), 4 cloves garlic (finely minced), 3 ribs celery (chopped), 1 green bell pepper (chopped), 1 1/2 tsps dried basil, 1 1/2 tsps Cajun seasoning, 1 tsp kosher salt, ½ tsp fresh ground black pepper, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper (optional add more for spice), 14.5-oz can diced tomatoes, 2 1/2 cups low-sodium chicken broth, 1 1/4 cup long-grain white rice.
In a large skillet with a fitted lid, add the oil over medium high heat. Once hot, add the chicken and cook, flipping once or twice to brown on all sides (don't cook chicken through). Remove to a bowl. Add sausage and cook until browned on both sides. Add to the bowl with the chicken. Reduce heat to medium and add butter and flour to the pan and stir well, scraping up any leftover browned bits from the pan. Add onion, garlic, celery, and bell peppers and sauté for 3 minutes. Add basil, cajun seasoning, diced tomatoes, salt and pepper and stir well to combine. Add chicken broth and rice and bring mixture to a gentle boil. Add reserved meat to the pan. Reduce heat, cover pan with fitted lid and cook for 20 minutes.Remove from heat, and rest with the lid on for 10 minutes. Then gently fluff with a fork and rest again for 5 minutes before serving. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'Make Muskrat Great Again': Maggie’s Coleman Tavern in Rock Hall hosts annual cook-off
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
'Make Muskrat Great Again': Maggie’s Coleman Tavern in Rock Hall hosts annual cook-off

 February 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 539
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Earlier this month, Maggie's Coleman Tavern on Sharp Street in Rock Hall was once again celebrated the mighty muskrat, that is — by way of savory muskrat meat served in all kinds of unique ways. Maggie's threw their annual Muskrat Cook-Off, in its 10th year, where savory recipes featuring the web-footed critter were sampled and voted on.Around the table, muskrat meat was served alongside oysters by a man affectionately nicknamed as Capt. Jack Sparrow, next to him, Phat Daddy's served up barbecue for anyone not digging muskrat.
In the competition, muskrat meat, supplied by trapper Robert Smith, was sampled in quesadillas, mixed into stew, added to jalapeño and cheese, fried up on the grill with onions, or placed inside an egg roll.
"The meat's a little bit of an acquired taste, like beef, only if cows ate from the swamp," said one jovial man, sampling each station.
Owner of Maggie's Carolyn Jones presented first place to the all-female team declaring "Make muskrat great again!" with their swamp rat slider. Jones provided the red-capped team with a trophy created by Greg Jetton from Dirty Cat Garage.
Visiting friends with a bubbly, energetic spirit, Heather VanDerbeek, from Westchester, Pennsylvania, commended the women's set-up. "This is awesome! I tried all the samples, and this is the best. The food, the presentation and the energy is all there," she said.
Also receiving awards from Dirty Cat and coming in second were George Parker and Alex Cooper, with their muskrat cheesesteak egg rolls. In third, with their Hawaiian slider, was the team of Ben Hicks, Darrold Smith and Chuck Woodfield.
Although the weather was windy, with a chill in the air, camaraderie among competitors and tasters alike was warmly felt.
Friends, family, neighbors and quite a few tourists, sampled muskrat, listened to live music courtesy of The Everafter, and thrilled to watch their neighbors and friends receive awards.
"We work hard to play hard," Rock Hall Mayor James Cook said, counting around 150 to 200 people in attendance.
Jones was pleased with the turnout, noting this year they had a few less contestants than last, but enthusiasm for the event remained.
The festival, Jones said, came out of a bored day with the idea this would be a fun, creative way to escape the cabin fever of winter months.
But why muskrat? Why not oysters, crabs, or even white tailed deer?
Because muskrat, spotted along Maryland's lakes, ponds, swamps, marshes rivers and streams, was once a thriving industry on the Eastern Shore. During the Great Depression era, muskrat pelts were the mainstay of the winter economy after blue crab season ended, as stated in an article in Smithsonian Magazine titled "Muskrat Love."
Smith, known as "Trapper Bob" follows that time-honored tradition. In winter, when he cannot work his concrete business, he enjoys the extremely challenging work of trapping muskrat, coyote, fox, otter, possum, and other animals.
Although his muskrat meat has been sampled in the past cook-offs, this was his first year attending in person and he brought with him those pelts, drawing in many admirers. In only about two hours, he sold half of them, he said.
And will there be an 11th muskrat cook-off?
"As long as we can trap 'em," a resident holding a beer in one hand and a muskrat quesadilla in the other remarked. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a local muskrat cook‑off festival featuring food, live music, and community celebration, which fits the Entertainment category best, while also touching on cultural (Arts & Culture) and economic (muskrat industry) aspects.

title: National Outdoors Show slated for Feb. 21, 22
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
National Outdoors Show slated for Feb. 21, 22

 February 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 310
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The National Outdoor Show in Dorchester County is coming back for its 78th year.The show — which celebrates wildlife, as well as the trappers, watermen and sportsmen of Dorchester County — will be held Friday, Feb. 21, and Saturday, Feb. 22, at South Dorchester School in Church Creek. Bringing residents together to celebrate the county's culture, the show has it all, from a live auction to pageants to exhibits to demos and competitions that include calling, trap setting, skinning and oyster shucking.
This year, 13 young women will vie for the title of Miss Outdoors, with the pageant to take place Friday night. On Saturday, 22 girls and three boys will vie for the respective titles of Little Miss Outdoors and Little Mister Outdoors.
The National Outdoor Show also hosts the World Champion Muskrat Skinning Competition, where competitors race to skin a muskrat fastest.
During a Dorchester County Council meeting Feb. 4, the council proclaimed the month of February to be National Outdoor Show month in the county.
"And we hope that in doing so, the people of Dorchester County will see the beauty of our wildlife and gain a new appreciation of our natural resources," Council Vice President Mike Detmer read from the proclamation during the meeting.
The proclamation was received by the show's 2024 royalty, which includes Miss Outdoors Laila Insley, Little Miss Outdoors Rose Bloodsworth and Little Mister Outdoors Edwin Bramble.
"We want to thank you for being representatives of our beautiful county," Council President Lenny Pfeffer said to the three before the council handed them Dorchester County pins for their muskrat pelt sashes.
Doors to the 2025 National Outdoor Show will open at 5 p.m. on Friday, Feb. 21, with the show beginning at 7 p.m.
On Saturday, Feb. 22, doors will open at 9 a.m. At 6 p.m., the 2025 pageant winners will be introduced and a live auction will be held. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
