title: Seniors show unbridled joy in Kentucky Derby-themed party
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Seniors show unbridled joy in Kentucky Derby-themed party

 May 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 770
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Last Friday, the horse races came a day early when the Amy Lynn Ferris Adult Activity Center was transformed into Churchill Downs for its very first Kentucky Derby Party."There are some amazing artwork and displays," said Susan Higgs the Kent County Project director for the Retired and Senior Volunteer Program of Upper Shore Aging Inc.
Around 50, maybe more, came out to partake in the festivities, wearing giant, elaborate hats, jamming out to a variety music from DJ Pres Jacobs — sharing laughs with friends.
From 10:30 a.m. to 1 p.m. they had finger foods, snacks, cookies and sipped non-alcoholic mint juleps. Each table was adorned with a wooden centerpiece representing the race complete with turf, jockey silks, helmet and stirrups.
But nobody sat at the table for long.
There were exciting things to do, ideas thought up by Activity Coordinator Colleen Upp. Since she has been in her role, many can attest she has breathed new life into the center with creative activities planned daily.
The origin of this idea, she exclaimed, stemmed from her love of horses. Thinking of a horse-themed event, she saw the costumes and pageantry behind the biggest national races as inspiring.
"It was a fun idea and so original," Higgs pointed out.
And like all of Upp's ideas, her enthusiasm in the project was contagious. Soon it was all hands-on-deck to transform the center into a racing hub. In every corner there is something created that adds authenticity to the event and fun.
Starting on the outside of the building, styrofoam containers once used for storing chemicals were airbrushed and made into a brick wall. Wildlife artist John Elburn used his creativity to fashion a unique gateway into the party, complete with plywood horse and jockeys.
His innovation did not stop there. In the doorway, greeting party-goers, was a five-foot, 350 lb. horse head he sculpted from a chainsaw, rotary and chisel tools. The maple sculpture took him 350 hours and was glad to do it for the center.
"Colleen had the idea, and we ran with it," Elburn said.
Past the horse head, going into the dining area, the red rosed archway was designed with the idea of the flower blankets draped over the horses at the competition.
Inside the dining area, every inch seemed decorated...including the party goers, who donned hats of ribbons, feathers and flowers. There was a display of red roses symbolic of the Kentucky Derby, Upp's daughter's exercise saddle, horse figurines arranged in orderly fashion, and of course, the winner's circle perfect for photo ops after the competitions.
Because what's a party without party games, Upp said, including toilet paper horse races.
A total of eight participants (jockeys) held a roll of slightly unrolled toilet paper. At the end of the table, setting on the toilet paper strip was a plastic horse, ready for the race. At the mark, set, go, the jockeys had to roll up the toilet paper keeping the horse on the strip while moving it towards the finish line.
Carol Elburn and Marie Spray had a heated competition in the finals. Elburn edged her out, and both received award winning plates.
In the morning, they held their hat competition, many wearing their creations from the hat-making class held by Brenda Foehrkolb on April 29 with over 20 in attendance.
DJ Pres Jacobs put on a huge Smirnoff Ice Vodka hat and went home the winner of three of the six categories: most comical, most eventful and most outrageous, Upp said laughing.
As they were cleaning up, they had line dancing headed by the boundless activity coordinator. Upp likes to put her own spin on the line dancing, making it adaptable for seniors. She said that dancing promotes coordination, balance, memory and it is just plain fun.
She's named her group of dancers the Vintage Vibes. They dance two times a week, learning different genres and styles from Mark Rice's 1965 song "Ride Around Sally" to hits by American rapper and singer, Pitbull.
"Their grandkids would be amazed to see grandma dancing to Pitbull," said Pam Holland, a friend of Upp.
The horse race parties will continue for two more big races, the Preakness and then the Belmont Stakes. With each change of race, comes new decorations added on to the centerpiece and the wreath; for Preakness, Black-eyed Susans, and for Belmont, white carnations.
It is these little details to add to the experience.
For a list of activities at the center, contact the front desk at 410-778-2564 or stop in at 200 Schauber Rd. Monday through Friday from 8 a.m. to 3 p.m.
"We're having so much fun here! You never know what to expect from our members," Upp said with a "winning" smile... pun intended. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a themed party and recreational activities for seniors, focusing on fun, performances, and decorative arts, which aligns best with the Entertainment category, with Arts & Culture as a close secondary fit.

title: Nicholas Ray aint country? Could have fooled us!
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Nicholas Ray aint country? Could have fooled us!

 May 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 872
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BETTERTON — On a 12-day music tour, local musician/songwriter Nicholas Ray's plans to reach California were thrown off by a snowstorm. Alone, two hours from the Grand Canyon, the snow fell so heavy it froze his headlights. Driving in the dark, fighting to keep visibility, unbeknownst to him, the nearest civilization was two hours away.Ray explained it was a Sioux Indian reservation, where they told him it had not snowed there yet until that very day. "Lucky me," Ray said, laughing, as he talked to the Kent County News inside his garage/band practice room.
He had slept in his car in the parking lot of their gas station and was awoken to coyotes rooting in the trashcans and a mountain of snow on his car. He swept it off with a broom, gave those who let him stay, a copy of his album and moved on, heading southward following the Gulf Coast to warmer weather.
Ray returned home to the farm in Still Pond, to his wife and family with even greater resolve to follow his dreams.
On his visit to major cities from Ohio, Colorado, New Mexico, Texas, Louisiana, Georgia, South and North Carolina, he collected 220 new subscribers to his Spotify and Apple Music accounts, while greeting friends on his journey.
Busking, (playing in the streets for money) was a great experience for him he said, and although he was nervous to start performing original songs in a strange city, everybody was supportive of his dreams of earning a living performing on stage.
These dreams began when he was a soldier in the Maryland National Guard deployed to Kosovo as a mechanic on Black Hawk helicopters. Hard work but during down time, he played the guitar until his hands bled, writing and singing songs.
Now he is ready for the next adventure. In October, Ray and his wife, Brandy Dorey, his biggest cheerleader and hype person, are Nashville-bound — moving on from the county to pursue his music goals.
"If you don't take chances, you never know," Ray said.
Kent County will certainly miss him, but live music lovers have an entire summer to hear him and band members, drummer Steve Toth, Rob McFarlane on bass, and Ray on guitar singing his original southern country style songs.
The 26-year-old Ray has been everywhere. He is a regular performer at Open Mic night at the Betterton Legion, the Back 50 Tavern, The Double Tap Tavern, Ram's Head Tavern, the Chancery in Wilmington Delaware, and the Kent County Fair to name a few.
He will be performing at Riley's Mill Ale Works May 17, and the next day at The Shanty Beach Bar, singing songs about battling depression, transcending love, venting frustrations, talking to God and drinking whiskey with friends.
Inspired by outlaw country greats, Waylon Jennings, Merle Haggard and the like and modern country star Luke Coombs, Ray described his music.
"It's nothing superficial. It's just the three chords of truth."
His album "Built for Leaving," certainly showcases his ability to capture his vision. He writes for those who appreciate lyrics but also provides a catchy tune for audiences to have fun with.
The crowd favorite, "Marlboro Man," is about a guy who relies on cigarettes and booze to mask his sadness. What is a somber theme becomes an excellent crowd sing-a-long with the chorus: "Light em up boys! Smoke em if you got em! I won't stop till I reach the bottom."
"Built for Leaving," laments a woman who left him. The singer is calling her back to remember who she once was. "Hold On" is a tune encouraging the subject to maintain hope through the storms of life, when there seems to be no answer. "Way Too Young" increases the tempo and calls for an escape from a mundane life.
The transforming power of love is a residing theme in Ray's album as well.
He likens his wife's love to a "Knotted Oak" a poetic song that describes her love as tough, resilient, able to bear the wind and waves. Ray expresses his gratitude for that love when he sings, "he is grateful," for her, and she is "an angel."
"Antiquity" is also a song dedicated to his love. Accompanied by clear and powerful chords, Ray sings about how she completes him, giving her a supernatural quality. "You are my antiquity, the past and the present — the air I breathe."
The album ends in an ironic, comic country song in the style of Hank Williams Jr. or David Allen Coe, in "I Ain't Country." With a growl to his voice, Ray sings, country isn't a location; it is a lifestyle. Ray, who when he is not performing, is hunting turkey, sport shooting, fishing, playing pool, drinking whiskey and riding horses, gives a brash answer to detractors who may think country music only resides in the typical southern states.
Anybody visiting Kent County for a few seconds can see it's as country as they are and Ray notes that.
In addition to his album, Ray released two singles and June 5 is releasing "That Ain't Today," a song he performed in Kent Got's Talent. That night, he dedicated it to a close friend suffering with cancer.
Ray has got big dreams, and is leaving Maryland to pursue them, but "that ain't today" so see him while you got a chance. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article profiles a local musician, his tour, album releases, and upcoming performances, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category.

title: 44th Strawberry Festival draws thousands
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
44th Strawberry Festival draws thousands

 May 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 321
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — The Ridgley Lions Club hosted the Strawberry Festival for the 44th year at Martin Sutton Park in Ridgley on Sunday. Thousands of people attended.Unofficial co-chairman for Strawberry Festival and Ridgley Lions Club member Brett Meyers credits the turnout and the overwhelming support for driving him to plan the festival each year.
"Every year, I say, 'this is the last one I'm gonna do,' and then every year we get done and we have such an amazing group of people that support us and that are in the Lions Club here in Ridgley, that I go, 'it wasn't that bad,' and so then we start planning not quite immediately, but almost immediately after the festival for next year," Meyers said.
According to Meyers, the Strawberry Festival has become "part of the fabric of the community here in Ridgley."
"Because I think people come out to see old friends, to get our wonderful strawberry and shortcake and to just be underneath the trees for a day," Meyers said.
While the festival highlights strawberries in the name, the event has turned away from its early route. According to Meyers, now the festival is community based.
The festival featured 82 vendors from the Caroline County Sheriffs Office to venders who sell floral arrangements.
Vicki Marquess, who sold floral arrangement and fake bakes at the Strawberry Festival this year, has came out a total of six years because of the people.
"It feels good, its nice, a nice atmosphere good family thing for people to come too," Marquess said.
Ridgley Commissioner and Lions Club member Brad Sears commends the festival's ability to bring people into the town.
"It's the kind of event that we like to see here in Ridgley because we'd like to bring people into the town because there is so much we have to offer to the public," Sears said.
Sears' favorite part of the festival is meeting people, being of service and being able to do things for others. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community strawberry festival with vendors, performances, and family activities, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category.

title: Tea time: Historical fun draws revelers near and far
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Tea time: Historical fun draws revelers near and far

 May 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The historic district of 18th century Chestertown was bustling with enjoyable activities Memorial Day weekend, highlighting the proud, colonial roots in the area.Residents and out of towners summoned their inner rebel and patriotism to celebrate the Chestertown Tea Party. The annual event honors a day in May 1774 when Maryland set forth "Resolves" forbidding importing, selling, or consuming British tea in Chestertown.
According to legend, residents gathered at the local town center, marched down High Street to the brigantine Geddes anchored in the Chester River, and tossed her cargo overboard against British mandates.
The current tea-tossing festivities began Friday night with a block party with music from Chesapeake Sons, food trucks and vendors, beverages, and fun for all ages.
Saturday morning, a festival staple, the Tea Party Distance Classic Run, a 10-mile run and 5k fun walk "kicked" things off. Organizer was Laura Livingston Marketing and Events coordinator from Radcliffe Creek School. She was pleased to report that 518 participants competed with 88 medals and awards handed out including 81-year old Lou Dwyer with a Young at Heart medal; he placed second in his age division.
All race proceeds went to the School's scholarship fund.
The race was followed by the Colonial Parade with Grand Marshal, Charlie Joiner. His vehicle was followed by first responders vehicles, colonial militia, costume-garbed children, marching bands and floats, greeting residents and guests on a warm, windy day.
Shortly after, along the water's edge, the reenactment started — the centerpiece of the festival. The reenactment team encouraged the crowd to join them in rebellion against the British government, harkening back to days ushering in the War for Independence.
Barefoot, standing on a barrel, Reenactor Jacob Robert Swane cried out, "Let us commit ourselves to liberty, freedom, without disguise, without the cloak of darkness, and dump the tea in the river!" and received applause for his performance.
On Sunday, the fun moved to Wilmer Park with a raft race, live music from, children's activities and artisan craft vendors, available until 4 p.m. The raft race was a great time with creative rafts galore pointed out organizers.
Winners for the humorous categories were as follows.
Frank Floater —Congressional
Waterfull Wizards of Oars —Van Gogh
Peace Bus —DaVinci
Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles on a Log —Family Award
Fury Rowed —Tea Cup
Beer Knights of the Boys —Fabulous Flotsam
Caps Revenge —Flop
Throughout the weekend, everyone had a great time with temperature around 70 degrees.
Chestertown Police Chief Ron Dixon said the event was safe estimating upwards to 10,000 attendees this year and having only one issue with some juveniles which was quickly handled by officers.
"The beautiful weather certainly helped bring people out," he said, thanking Kent County Sheriff's Office and Volunteer Fire Company Police for lending their support.
Chestertown Tea Party Festival President Steve Meehan was thrilled with the turnout this year.
"We had a record number of artisan craft vendors, Saturday and Sunday, the Heritage Village was full of families, food and music was great all three days, the weather was perfect. And we threw the tea overboard! We thank the Town of Chestertown residents, street crew, security and police for their invaluable support and look forward to 2026 and celebrating the country's 250th anniversary." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community festival with music, parades, reenactments, and crafts, and is published in the Entertainment section, making Entertainment the best fit.

title: Recipes for graduation celebrations
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Recipes for graduation celebrations

 June 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1269
 Words 

 Read News Document

 What an exciting time of the year — graduation has once again arrived. From graduates from nursery school, to grade school, to middle school, to high school, to night school, to college, to trade school, to graduate school to just any kind of school, congratulations.As I sit here and write this column and gather materials, my mind travels back in time to when my mother went to a one-room schoolhouse outside of Selbyville, Delaware. The outhouse being behind the school was no problem, as most of the homes had the same.
There were only 11 grades, and mom was a member of the Class of 1928. She always told me there was no celebration as she was running a farm with her stepfather and had to get back home to work in the fields. She said that her church group celebrated all school children the previous Sunday.
The next graduation I remember was in June 1954, when my sister graduated from Buckingham High School in Berlin. I remember going to the graduation was a formal affair. The boys wore suits, and the girls wore "dressy' dresses with high heels. This attire included dark graduation robes for the guys and white robes for the girls.
A big dinner was held at our house on Sunday to celebrate, and the house was full... and so was the kitchen sink with dirty dishes waiting for "little sister."
I graduated from Stephen Decatur High School in Berlin in 1963 with a "large class" of 72 students. As was the norm, my parents held a large family dinner, and guess who didn't do the dishes. I went to the beach with some of my classmates.
The years go by, and my youngest son graduated in 1996 from Colonel Richardson High School. We had a gathering of family and friends at home with "BBQ and Picnic" foods. Betty Lofland, my neighbor, made a garden flag with CRHS Class of 1996 in the school colors to fly on my pole. I still have the flag.
In 2022, my grandson, Mason Emory Williamson, is a member of the graduating class of Parkside High School in Salisbury. The ceremony was held at the Wicomico Civic Center due to such a large class — 800 kids. Times may have changed in the past 94 years of my family's graduations, but the message is and has always been the same — "The world is at your feet. Take it and keep going. If you fall get right back up".
Now I am hungry so let us fix some food for graduation celebrations.
FRUIT KABOBS
My only tip here is try not to use fruits that will brown, such as bananas, apples or peaches. Think about a variety of color.
Prep the fruit by cutting it into slices, wedges or chunks. Thread fruit onto skewers and refrigerate until eating. Make fruit kabobs ahead of time so they'll be well chilled before serving. They'll keep in the refrigerator for up to 12 hours. For an extra twist, add some whipped cream with shredded coconut as a dip. Mix however many cups of whipped topping with 2 tbsps of shredded sweetened coconut per each cup.
GARLIC BREAD PIZZA DIPPERS
1 can biscuit, 1/4 cup olive oil, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 cup ricotta, 4 oz cream cheese (softened), 2 cups mozzarella cheese (shredded), 1 tsp Italian seasoning, 1/4 tsp red pepper flakes, 1/3 cup marinara, 6-8 pepperoni, 3 tbsp parmesan.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Cut each biscuit in half and roll into a ball. Place each biscuit ball around the edge of an 8-inch skillet. In a small mixing bowl, combine olive oil and garlic powder. Mix and then brush onto biscuits. In a large mixing bowl, combine cream cheese, half of the mozzarella, Italian seasoning and red pepper flakes. Mix until well combined. Pour in the middle of the skillet, spreading evenly to the edge of the biscuits. Pour marinara on top of the cheese mixture and spread it evenly across the top of it. Sprinkle the remaining mozzarella on top of the marinara and place pepperoni on top. Place in oven and bake for 30 minutes. Remove from oven and sprinkle parmesan on top. Serve hot. This recipe makes eight. Adjust accordingly to how ever many guests you are having.
SLOW COOKER BBQ PULLED PORK SANDWHICHES
1 lemon-garlic pork loin filet (about 1-1/3 pounds), 1 can (12 ounces) Dr Pepper, 1 bottle of your favorite barbecue sauce, 6 hamburger buns (split).
Place pork in a 3-qt slow cooker. Pour Dr Pepper over top. Cover and cook on low for 7-9 hours or until meat is tender. Remove meat; cool slightly. Discard cooking juices. Shred meat with 2 forks and return to the slow cooker. Stir in barbecue sauce; heat through. Serve on buns. You can also make this with chicken for a pulled chicken variation.
CHEESEBURGER SLIDERS
1/2 cup mayonnaise, 2 tbsps ketchup, 1 tbsp yellow mustard, 24 slider rolls (I use King's Hawaiian), 2 tbsps olive oil, 1 medium onion, (small diced), 2 pounds lean ground beef, 1 (1 ounce) package dry French Onion Soup Mix, 1 tbsp steak seasoning (I used Montreal), 10 slices American cheese, 24 pickle slices, 2 tbsps butter (melted), 1 tbsp sesame seeds.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Line an 11-by-15-inch baking dish with foil and coat lightly with nonstick spray. Set aside. Slice the slider rolls in half, and place the bottoms evenly into the prepared pan, setting the tops aside. In a small bowl, whisk together the mayonnaise, ketchup and mustard. Set aside. In a large skillet, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the diced onions and cook, until soft and golden, stirring frequently. Add the ground beef to the skillet and cook until no pink remains, breaking the meat while cooking. Drain any excess fat from the skillet. Add in the onion soup mix and the steak seasoning, stirring to combine. Remove the skillet from the heat. Stir in the mayonnaise mixture and coat the meat evenly. Spread the meat mixture evenly on top of the slider rolls. Top with cheese slices, cutting to fit, if necessary. Top each with a pickle slice. Place the slider roll tops on top and press down slightly. Brush the melted butter on top of the sliders, and sprinkle with sesame seeds. Cover the pan tightly with foil. Place the pan on a large cookie sheet and bake for 15-20 minutes, until the cheese is melted. Remove the pan from the oven and keep covered for 5-10 minutes before uncovering and serving. Store airtight in the refrigerator until serving, no longer than 24 hours to preserve taste and freshness of rolls.
ANTIPASTO KABOBS
1 package (9 ounces) refrigerated cheese tortellini, 40 pimiento-stuffed olives, 40 large pitted ripe olives, 3/4 cup Italian salad dressing, 40 thin slices pepperoni, 20 thin slices hard salami (halved).
Cook tortellini according to package directions; drain and rinse in cold water. In a large bowl, combine the tortellini, olives and salad dressing. Toss to coat; cover and refrigerate for 4 hours or overnight. Drain mixture, discarding marinade. For each appetizer, thread a stuffed olive, a folded pepperoni slice, tortellini, a folded salami piece and a ripe olive on a toothpick or short skewer.
RAINBOW SHERBET PUNCH
1 gallon Breyers brand sherbet (rainbow flavored if you can find) 1 liter 7UP/Sprite/ginger ale, 1 liter of Hawaiian punch or a favorite juice of your choice, Whipped cream (optional).
In a large punch bowl scoop in your ice cream. Pour soda over the ice cream and break ice cream apart gently while pouring slowly then add in your juice and mix slightly to incorporate. Serve in tall glasses with a dollop of whipped cream. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: MusicLife spring recital and scholarship honors Sam Scalzo
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
MusicLife spring recital and scholarship honors Sam Scalzo

 June 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 451
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — On May 28, at their spring musical showcase, MusicLife at 241 High Street, awarded the Sam Scalzo scholarship to young, local musician Ben Gilbert and a second scholarship to Kylie Griffith.Gilbert has been accepted to the Blackbird Academy in Nashville, Tennessee where he plans to study music production.
Griffith, a skilled pianist, performed "Lord I Need You" that night; she plans to have music play an integral part of her life.
MusicLife offers instrument rentals and sales, lessons, sheet music and more.
This year's recital was emotional since it is the first year Scalzo, an accomplished musician offering his time, energy and talents to area schools, has not been there personally to deliver the award to recipients. Scalzo is in hospice care and a tearful playing of "Shall We Gather" ended Wednesday night's program reflecting on his many contributions.
Owner of MusicLife Bill Drazga played the piano and delivered the heartfelt vocals portraying a distant land beyond pain, suffering and death.
"Yes, we'll gather at the river," he sang. "The beautiful, the beautiful river. Gather with the saints at the river, that flows by the throne of God."
The recital reflected Scalzo's passion for music by showcasing musicians of all ages and styles singing and performing numbers in rock, classical and everything in between.
To some students such as Auden Unsworth this was their first recital, encouraged by the teachers, performing in a creative and fun environment while proud instructors looked on.
Scalzo too, would have been pleased.
Better known as "Sam, the Italian Music Man" in Rock Hall, he spent his entire life in music, beginning at a young age and learning from the First Clarinet Player at the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra. When he was not performing, he was fostering young musicians in Kent County High School Jazz Band, tutoring elementary students, practicing weekly with general band students or cheering on the marching band.
Drazga said in the 25 years of knowing Scalzo, "I think he is the only person on earth that loves music more than I do."
Drazga came up with the idea of the scholarship to honor the many contributions Scalzo has made to music education in Kent and Queen Anne's counties over the years.
"Mr. Scalzo has shown his dedication to cultivating young people's musical education through his countless years of work in Kent County schools and beyond."
The scholarship was established in 2019 by MusicLife, in partnership with family and friends and awarded annually to a local graduating high school senior.
Past recipients are Sarah Parker (2019), Jane Godfrey (2020), Claire O'Brien and Isabella Williams (2021), Corrina Boyd (2022), Jade Lee (2023) and Aaron Saunders (2024).
Anyone wishing to make a donation to future scholarship awards can find more information at musiclifedelmarva.com or by calling at 410-778-7010. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a local music recital, scholarship awards, and performances, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category, while also touching on arts and music education.

title: Country Cooking: Steaks for Father's Day
author: Staff Writer
content:
Country Cooking: Steaks for Father's Day

 June 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 958
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Father's Day was introduced in the United States in the early 20th century to complement Mother's Day.Father's Day was founded in Spokane, Washington at the YMCA by Sonora Dodd, who was born in Arkansas. Her father was a Civil War veteran and a single parent who raised six children. After hearing a sermon about Anna Jarvis' Mother's Day in 1909, Dodd told her pastor that fathers should be celebrated as well. Beginning in 1915, Father's Day has been celebrated on the third Sunday in June.
Hats off to all fathers on this special day. My own father was a proud father of nine sons and two daughters. There were many of our friends included in our family functions that had no father figures in their lives, and "Pop" treated us all the same.
His famous saying was "You put your feet under our table, then your hands were put on farm work like my own kids'." Needless to say, it did not deter anyone from coming to the table.
Today, I am turning the column to my son John. Proud father to three boys — Mason, Colin and Braxton. Enjoy your day with some wonderful grilled steaks.
Grilling Steak
I prefer not to freeze my steak. It is not always convenient, but I try to get my steak the day of or day before I plan to grill it. I think steak that is not frozen and then thawed out tastes better. Could just be me.
However you do it, whether from the freezer or out of the refrigerator, take that steak out and let it sit. Steak right out of the fridge will cook unevenly. Set yours out at room temperature for 30 minutes before grilling.
Here are a few ways to grill various cuts of steak as well as the various temperatures for getting the grill you want.
Rare: 120 to 130 degrees.Medium Rare: 130 to 135 degrees.Medium: 135 to 145 degrees.Medium Well: 145 to 155 degrees.Well Done: 155+ degrees.
SIRLOIN
Preheat the grill over high heat. Season steak generously with salt and pepper. Grill steak over direct heat 4 to 5 minutes per side for medium-rare.
SKIRT STEAK
Preheat the grill over high heat. Season steak generously with salt and pepper. Grill steak over direct heat 3 to 5 minutes per side for medium-rare.
RIBEYE
Preheat the grill over high heat. Season steak generously with salt and pepper. Grill steak over direct heat 4 to 6 minutes per side for medium-rare.
FILET MIGNON
Preheat the grill over high heat. Season steak generously with salt and pepper. Grill steak over direct heat 5 to 6 minutes per side for medium-rare.
T-BONE STEAK
There is something magic about a nice, fat T-bone. That piece of bone gives this steak so much flavor that you'll want to pick it up and eat steak right off the bone when your plate is clean. I like my T-bones to be at least 1 inch to 1 ¼ thick. This is so you can get a good crust but still have nice tender meat. Thaw your T bone out and let it sit at room temperature for at least 30 minutes. If your grill doesn't have a thermometer, you can try to use a meat thermometer to check the surface heat, but it is not always accurate.
Here is what you'll need: 2 T-bone steaks at least 1 1/2 inches thick, 1 teaspoon salt, 1 teaspoon ground black pepper, 1 stick unsalted butter, 1 tablespoon fresh rosemary (chopped), 2 cloves garlic (finely minced), ¼ teaspoon ground black pepper.
Turn on your grill and let it warm up to medium-high heat. Clean the grill grates and oil them. Pat the steaks dry with paper towels, then generously season with salt and pepper from all sides including the edges. Make the garlic butter, in a small saucepan, melt the butter with rosemary, garlic, and pepper. When the butter starts bubbling, cook for 1 minute then remove from heat so you don't burn the garlic. Allow the herb and garlic to steep in the butter as you grill the steaks. Add the steaks to the grill and reduce the heat to medium and cook for 4-5 minutes per side. Check the temperature. For a medium rare steak, grill the steaks for about 4 minutes on each side until the internal temperature reaches 130 degrees.When the steaks are done, remove from the grill onto a plate and pour the butter all over the steaks and cover with foil. Allow to rest for 5 minutes before slicing and serving.
NEW YORK STRIP
New York strip is my second favorite cut of steak that is much prepared the same way with a few adjustments. After letting steaks sit out for maybe 20 minutes, pat them dry. You want to try to get the same thickness of at least 1 inch thick. Pat dry to absorb any extra fluid or moisture.
Here is what you'll need: 2 New York strip steaks at least 1 inch thick, 1 teaspoon salt, 1 teaspoon ground black pepper, 1 stick unsalted butter.
I preheat the grill to high heat. Heat the butter in a microwave safe bowl and then when ready I coat each steak on all sides as well as edges. I sprinkle the Kinder's Prime Steak seasoning on both sides of the steak. When you are ready to grill the steak turn the heat down to medium then place the steaks on the grill. Let sit for about 4 minutes a side then flip. At this point I coat with butter and sprinkle more seasoning on each side after I flip. About 5 minutes a side and I check the temperature using a meat thermometer. I like my steak medium rare so I pull them off when they hit 130 to 135 degrees. I slice immediately and eat while hot off the grill. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a lifestyle piece offering cooking tips and a recipe for grilling steaks in celebration of Father's Day, which aligns best with the Entertainment category (food/recipe content). It is not primarily about health, arts, or any other listed topics.

title: Betterton Legion welcomes families for day of fun
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Betterton Legion welcomes families for day of fun

 June 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 286
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BETTERTON — An overcast morning did not prevent families from experiencing the fun on June 14 at the C. Henry Price Betterton American Legion during their second annual American Legion Family Day.From 11 a.m. until 3 p.m. they held face painting, a moon bounce house, corn hole games, a petting zoo with goats, donkeys and cows, with popcorn, drinks and hotdogs.
Marcellus Black Jr. organized the music and each Legion station offered smiles and camaraderie.
For some added excitement, kids got to experience what it's like behind the wheel of Engine 4 courtesy of the Kennedyville Volunteer Fire House.
This event was part of the national American Legion Family Day, which is held on the last Saturday of April to recognize and celebrate the accomplishments of Legionnaires, Sons of The American Legion members, Legion Riders and American Legion Auxiliary, and to bring awareness to the organization's "Be the One" initiative to reduce the rate of veteran suicide.
Betterton held its pool tournament on that date, so the family fun event was pushed back to Saturday, said Legion Auxiliary President Patti Bone.
Since it was also Flag Day, the Legion retired many old American Flags, holding a ceremony then burning them to dispose of them — the proper way to do it.
Post Cmdr. Jacob Matthews said since there was a lot going on Saturday, especially in Chestertown, he was pleased with the turnout, and looks forward as the post plans more events that bring the community together.
Every Thursday at 7 p.m., open mic night is hosted by Gerry Werner featuring a 50-50 drawing, music, comedy and trivia. The post meal will be pulled pork barbecue with drinks served by your favorite bartender. Come out and play or sing your favorite tunes. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community family day with games, music, petting zoo, and open‑mic events, which are primarily recreational and entertainment‑focused rather than sports, government, or other categories.

title: 'Artists inspire other artists' at the Academy Art Museum
author: BROOKE ENSMINGER
content:
'Artists inspire other artists' at the Academy Art Museum

 July 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BROOKE ENSMINGER | Section: Entertainment 
 
 535
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Local musician Kentavius Jones broke the barrier between performer and audience member with an intimate public recording session in the Academy Art Museum on Saturday.Taking inspiration from an exhibit in the museum, Jones and his band gathered in the Performing Arts Room to record material that would go on his second album. The Academy invited several artists, from painters to pastel artists, to set up their canvases and let the music guide them to their creative destination.
Jones said he did something similar with the art museum for his first album, "Bohemian Beatbox." However, that session was not in collaboration with other artists.
"For this one, I was like, 'man, we should add a component where there are actual people, where there are actual artists there creating too,'" Jones said. "Artists inspire other artists."
Jones took inspiration from Richard Estes' exhibit "Urban Landscapes," which is featured in the museum until Aug. 3. A photorealist painter, Estes' work showcases the reflective surfaces of the city. The exhibit's focus on reflections serves as a reminder that artists are reflections of their lived experiences and of each other, according to Jones.
Ellie Christiansen, of St. Michaels, was one of the painters at the recording session. She decided not to arrive with an idea of what she wanted to paint. Rather, she took a walk around the gallery and viewed other pieces of art to get color inspiration. Upon returning to the room, she said she let the music inform her painting decisions.
"I think that it's a beautiful, inspiring event that can bring together community members and artists who can be inspired by the music," Christiansen said. "I don't think you get a chance to do that very often."
Painting during a live music recording session was not an opportunity she's had before, she said, but she enjoyed it.
"If I could do this every Saturday, I think I would because it's always nice to be around fellow artists, especially listening to amazing, inspirational music," Christiansen said.
The quiet, dimly lit room created a relaxing environment. Guests could walk around freely and engage with the performers and artists.
"Good scenery, good visuals and good sounds," said Kentavius's mother, Lois McCoy, describing the ambiance of the event. McCoy said she was excited to experience her son's recording process, something she's only heard about.
Throughout the session, Kentavius and the band switched between improvising and recording, allowing audience members to experience the raw recording process.
"The musicians, they were somewhat familiar with some of the songs, but some of the songs they never heard before," Jones said. "I wanted people to see it unfold live."
Jones said the experience felt organic for him, and he was grateful for the opportunity to make his art even more collaborative. He often took breaks from performing to engage with audience members. At one point, he individually greeted and introduced himself to each person in attendance.
"To have folks there a part of the recording process, it just further builds that relationship, that connection between me as the creator and folks as the audience," Jones said. "It was magical for me."
Some of the music recorded at this session will be performed at Jones' public outdoor concert at the Academy Art Museum on Aug. 2. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a live music recording event and collaboration with visual artists at an art museum, fitting the Entertainment section and focusing on cultural arts activities.

title: Easton carnival returns for July 4
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Easton carnival returns for July 4

 July 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 202
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Families began lining the ticket booth at 6 p.m. to ride rides, eat a funnel cake, drink lemonade or to play one of the many games offered at Easton's annual Fourth of July Carnival.The carnival began on June 20 and goes through July 4. The Independence Day celebration will include all of the same carnival festivities from the days prior with an addition of live music beginning at 6 p.m. and fireworks after dusk.
For St. Michaels Elementary School teacher Kelly Coutts, the carnival has become a tradition for her two kids, Millie and Teddy. "They look forward to this every year," she said.
Coutts had been in Peru for the past week after receiving a Fulbright Teacher Exchange Award last year. Her children waited for her to return to go to the carnival Tuesday. "When I got back last night, they were like oh we have to go," Coutts said.
It cost $5 to park near the carnival, and wristbands for unlimited rides cost $23 with a $5 off coupon, according to Discover Easton. Every evening, the event goes until 11 p.m. On July 3, the carnival opens at 6 p.m., and on July 4, the event begins at 4 p.m.

title: Celebrating the Fourth
author: JIM JOHNSON jjohnson@chespub.com
content:
Celebrating the Fourth

 July 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JIM JOHNSON jjohnson@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 257
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Three hundred-plus people crowded the streets of St. Michaels on the Fourth of July painting the town red, white and blue.The annual Children's Parade stepped off at 10 a.m. led by Police Chief Jeffrey Oswald, an antique fire engine and the color guard from Scout Troop 741 carrying the flag.
The highlight of the parade was the children — most sporting red, white and blue attire — who marched the parade route that started and ended at the St. Michaels Historical Museum and looped through downtown where the streets were lined with cheering paradegoers. The parade took just over 20 minutes, which seemed like a long time for many of the children as temperatures reached the mid-80s.
Brian Collison and his 14-year-old daughter, Constance, stood on a downtown corner, Brian playing patriotic songs on his trumpet with Constance accompanying him on the drums. The Collisons came from Denver, Colorado, to visit relatives in St. Michaels over the holiday weekend.
Four friends from Crofton came to St. Michaels, the third time they marched in the parade. The four — Megan Elias, Ellie Cockrell, Taylor Sundick and Ella Davis — painted their faces red, white and blue.
"We love being patriotic," Sundick said.
Following the parade a traditional Fourth of July program was held on the museum lawn starting with the Scout troop raising the flag and reciting the Pledge of Allegiance. The program included patriotic and folk songs.
The Fourth of July weekend in St. Michaels concluded Saturday with Big Band Night at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum followed by fireworks at dusk. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community Fourth of July parade, music performances, and fireworks—an event focused on local entertainment and cultural celebration rather than policy, safety, or economic issues.

title: Big bands, big booms: Big Band Night and fireworks cap St. Michaels Fourth of July
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Big bands, big booms: Big Band Night and fireworks cap St. Michaels Fourth of July

 July 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 421
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — More than 1,700 people from around the Eastern Shore and beyond showed up to the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum on Saturday night to celebrate the July 4 weekend, enjoy the 18-piece big band and watch St. Michaels fireworks display.The Shades of Blue Orchestra provided entertainment for the whole family, spanning genres and generations through their tunes. The father-daughter duo Tony and Gia Liberto joined the band for multiple songs, belting out ballads alongside the instrumentalists.
"The talent must run in the family," said Michael Walker, conductor of the Shades of Blue Orchestra.
According to Shannon Mitchell, vice president of engagement for the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, the Shades of Blue Orchestra has been playing at Big Band Night for at least the past decade.
Between songs, Walker thanked and honored the veterans who attended, gushed over how honored he was to be a part of this and spoke about the importance of music education.
"It has real value to the human brain," he said.
Walker guided the band into "Fly Me To The Moon" by Frank Sinatra, which Tony Liberto sang with grace and ease. The dance floor filled with couples of all ages and a sister duo wearing matching American flag dresses who maybe stopped dancing one time throughout the night.
Delawareans Renee Goolday and Mitch Greene said they always wanted to visit St. Michaels and saw Big Band Night as the perfect opportunity.
"I saw the fireworks were going to happen tonight, and I thought this was perfect weather so we drove the Jeep down," Goolday said.
Mitchell said Big Band Night is unique compared to other festivals and events in the area with the focus being on music and fireworks, having a bring-your-own beverage model, there being few food vendors and cheaper tickets making it more accessible.
This year, the space next to the museum's welcome center was used for inflatables like slides and a bouncy house with a speaker playing the big band, so parents didn't miss out. According to Mitchell, in previous years this area was extra viewing space for the fireworks.
The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum is situated in front of where the firework display is set, making it a premier destination for the show. As the sun began setting, the museum's lighthouse and gazebo glimmered in red, white and blue.
By 9:30 p.m. all eyes were fixed on the show in the sky. Bursts of colors reflected on the Bay as the Star Wars theme song played in the background.
"Wow, Mommy!" a little boy said emphatically after each firework went off. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a local big band concert and fireworks celebration, which are primarily entertainment events rather than news about education, health, or other categories.

title: Great Mills resident wins Miss Maryland pageant
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Great Mills resident wins Miss Maryland pageant

 July 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 364
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maria Derisavi has a community service initiative titled Seize Your Opportunities, and June 21 in Hagerstown she did exactly that when she was selected as Miss Maryland.The 22-year-old is the first Iranian-American Miss Maryland in the organization's 104 year history, and the first from St. Mary's County to win the award.
"I competed against 18 of some of Maryland's [most] accomplished, community-driven young women, so it was really an honor to be selected among those really incredible girls," said Derisavi, who also won Miss Teen Maryland USA in 2021. "I was shocked when I won, but of course so grateful. You definitely go into these competitions to win, but at least for me you never expect to win, you just hope for it but I prepared my best."
She will represent Maryland when she competes in the Miss America competition which will be held in September in Orlando, Fla.
The Great Mills resident won the crown following a week of competition which included interview, fitness, on-stage question, talent and evening gown.
"Each contestant worked extremely hard and put their best foot forward at the Miss Maryland Competition," 2023 Miss Maryland and board member Kennedy Taylor said, adding that Derisavi "captured the judges' hearts in all categories."
For the talent portion, Derisavi performed a speech about her story of immigration to the United States from Kuwait at the age of 9.
The first runner-up was Alaysia Bookal (Miss Potomac), followed by Jaclyn Davis (Miss Northern Maryland), Allie Wolfe (Miss Montgomery County) and Elle Miles (Miss Baltimore).
"We are always blown away by the level of talent at the Miss Maryland competition," Taylor said.
Since 2021, Derisavi has championed her community service initiative titled SeizeYourOpportunities, a research-backed resilience development program that has already reached thousands of students across the state of Maryland through school seminars that empower students through goal setting and self-efficacy workshops.
"Coming from a low-income background myself, I know how important it is to have some sense of resilience, especially when you go through adverse experiences," she said. "What my programming does is it's research and educator-informed, so I work with social worker professionals and educators to create a workbook that talks about resiliency and teaches skills like goal-setting and perseverance." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cow chip toss defining moment for reporter
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Cow chip toss defining moment for reporter

 July 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1056
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FAIR HILL — I never gave a crap about cow chip tosses until I competed in one at the Cecil County Fair on Sunday evening.My editor assigned me the story. And it was consistent with the other George-Plimpton-style assignments he had doled out to me for our fair (the event, not the quality of work) coverage in the past.
He is the reason why I plunged my face into a miniature peach cobbler topped with a cumulus cloud of whipped cream during the annual pie-eating contest two years ago, as one example.
The contest is simple. Contestants competing by gender and in various age brackets attempt to toss a "cow chip" into a metal bucket, which is about 15 feet away. Those who sink the cow chip advance to Round 2, when the toss-line is moved back to approximately 20 feet away from the target, and those who miss are eliminated.
This process is repeated until every competitor is sidelined except for the most accurate tosser, who smiles moments later as a fair representative presents him or her with the 1st Place Ribbon.
Then, that elated cow-chip-toss winner looks straight into the lens and gushes, "I'm going to Disney World," after the off-camera reporter asks what will be the champion's next conquest . . . OK, OK, I made up that last part.
Before I continue with my slightly embellished account, it's important to clear up some misleading cow-chip-toss terms, the first of which is the term "cow chip." For the record, I and my fellow contestants did not toss cow chips.
Instead, we tossed clay pigeons, the kind that hunters use for target practice. Those clay pigeons are normally propelled high into the air by a machine or by a guy with a really, really strong throwing arm to simulate the flight of pheasants, geese, ducks and other winged prey and hunters shoot them down with their shotguns.
I hate to quibble, but the clay pigeons we tossed Sunday evening looked nothing like pigeons — or any other type of bird, reptile or mammal, including humans. What we cow-chip-toss gladiators tossed were orangey, palm-sized discs.
Furthermore, I feel compelled to be a stickler about this: clay pigeons aren't made of clay, but they actually are comprised of limestone and petroleum pitch — based on my extensive AI and Wikipedia research . . . Yeah, it's starting to dawn on me now that I don't hate to quibble after all.
So why is the contest called a cow chip toss?
Well, this is where it gets repulsively interesting. It seems that, up until an estimated two decades ago, according to some unofficial Cecil County Fair historians, cow chip toss competitors tossed actual cow chips.
What is a cow chip, some may ask. Sure, I'll field this one. A cow chip is manure that has been dropped in a field by — you guessed it, a cow — and then has been dried out by the sun into a hardened, disc-like shape.
It should not be confused with the terms "cow patties" or "cow pies," however, if I'm comprehending my AI/Wikipedia research information correctly.
Cow patties and cow pies are fresh (Oxymoron Alert), wet cow dung, before they've been petrified by the sun. Speaking of petrified, the AI Overview included a photo of a fresh, wet cow patty and it scared me to death. Some things in life you truly cannot unsee.
So where was I? Oh yeah, petrified cow crap and how it was once used in the cow chip toss contests.
I assumed, naturally, that Cecil County Fair officials overseeing the cow chip toss competition 20-some years ago pooh-pooh'ed the practice of using real dry dung discs and replaced them with clay pigeons — or discs masquerading as clay and as pigeons — because it would be more sanitary.
But that is not the reason, according to local farmer and fellow contestant Mark Crouse, who chatted with me Sunday evening during the competition. He explained that fair planners in the Cow Chip Toss Department opted for clay pigeons (ahem) at some point because of a supply-and-demand problem encountered when doing things the organic, old-fashioned way.
Turns out, Crouse, who is 48, traipsed through the fields on the Miller Family dairy farm near North East when he was a teenager and gathered cow chips for the annual fair contest. Al Miller, who has served on the Cecil County Fair Board for 47 years, also served on that cow chip collection crew.
"It's harder to collect suitable cow chips than you would think," Crouse emphasized.
Then Crouse outlined, "The cow had to go in the pasture. You couldn't have rain the day before or even two days before, either, because it had to be completely dried out. You hope it's dry before you pick it up, but that isn't always the case."
It's noteworthy here that, according to my AI research, a fresh cow patty consists of approximately 83 percent water. Yes, it actually cited "about" 83 percent. I'm assuming a more precise cow-manure-moisture reading would involve a decimal point followed by lots more numbers, all of which compiled by scientists in white lab coats and buoyed by government grants.
Miller further explained that changes in the dairy farming field (no pun intended) created the supply problem. "The cows used to go out in the pasture, but the cows are more confined now," Miller said, agreeing that the change leading to the paucity of perfect cow poo occurred about 20 to 30 years ago.
So where was I? Oh yeah, Sunday evening's cow chip toss contest and my participation in it.
Well, we're running out of space now because, apparently, I digressed for quite a bit back there. So I'll finally cut to the chase. I competed in the class for men who are 26 and older and sunk my first "cow chip." During Round 2, I missed slightly to the right of the bucket, with my clay pigeon crashing onto the ground and exploding into tiny pieces like it had been shot by a target-practicing hunter.
After Round 3, which I watched from the sidelines, it was determined that I tied for 2nd Place. And I, quite surprised, received a ribbon indicating that feat.
But I must say this: Knowing that I could have been tossing real cow chips if that supply-and-demand problem hadn't happened, I left the fair Sunday evening feeling like I took home a 1st Place Ribbon. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a light‑hearted fair competition (cow chip toss) and the reporter's personal experience, fitting the Entertainment category. While it mentions farming practices and fair board officials, the primary focus is on the event as a local amusement rather than agricultural policy or government business.

title: Trappe fire company hopes to recoup lost day of Old Tyme Fair revenue
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Trappe fire company hopes to recoup lost day of Old Tyme Fair revenue

 August 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 352
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — The Trappe Volunteer Fire Company is holding its annual Old Tyme Fair this weekend. Due to inclement weather, Thursday's festivities were cancelled.Thursday was one of the strongest days for turnout at last year's event, Fire Company officials said. With cooler weather for the next two days, the Fire Company hoped attendance would be high to make up for lost revenues.
The annual fair brings in about 30% of the Fire Company's revenue for the year.
"There's always a risk of losing a day, and hopefully you only lose one day," said Cheryl Lewis, secretary for the Trappe Volunteer Fire Company. "We just hope that the public shows up on Friday and Saturday to help us recoup what we potentially could have made on Thursday."
The fair will be open on Friday and Saturday from 6 p.m. to 10 p.m.
Every year, the Fire Company offers cheap prices for games and food. This year will be no different.
"One of the things that we do at our fair that really does kind of set us apart is we work really hard to keep the cost extremely low, so it's family-oriented," Lewis said. "So, our games are about $2, and I don't think we have anything that's more than $2. Our rides are a dollar, our food is $2 for a hot dog, $5 for a hamburger. So, we work really hard at making it possible for for families to come out and be able to participate. We just really hope that we make the money in volume and support."
In addition to the low cost of food, rides and games, the Fire Company holds a silent auction with gifts and gift baskets donated by community members and businesses.
Some prices featured in the silent auction are a cub cadet lawn mower, Traeger smoker and an antique fishing rod.
A parade will be held on Saturday at 6 p.m. staring on Route 50 at Main Street and coming back to the fair grounds on 4001 Powell Ave in Trappe. Shelly Abbott will perform music and will allow some karaoke.
For more information, Visit the Trappe Volunteer Fire Company Facebook Page. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Fair season is here with affordable fun for the whole family

 It's fair season, and there are multiple fairs happening for the next couple of weeks on the Mid-Shore.I personally enjoy fairs for the prizes and the food.
Trappe Volunteer Fire Company is holding its annual Old Tyme Fair this weekend. Unfortunately, the first day of the fair was cancelled due to inclement weather.

Fair season is the best, and if you're looking for a fair this weekend, the Old Tyme Fair is a perfect option. You can read more about it in my story below.

title: 'One for the books' — Betterton Day draws families for a day of suds and fun
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
'One for the books' — Betterton Day draws families for a day of suds and fun

 August 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 407
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BETTERTON — The weather was gorgeous and the beach was well-attended for Betterton Appreciation Day on Friday night into Saturday afternoon."Betterton Day was perfect with amazing weather, the parade was awesome. The band had people dancing. The magic show had the kids and adults laughing. It was a great time," replied a representative for Betterton Day.
Fireworks on Friday night on the boardwalk bedazzled audiences.
The next morning, Ryann Marchetti sang the "Star Spangled Banner". The parade followed, featuring Kent's first responders, marching bands and fun floats before beachside vendors sold everything from bookmarks to baked goods.
Betterton vendor, Nina's Baked Goods sold great tasting items including their bacon cheddar scones, said Nina and Sienna Fahrman, residents of Betterton.
The Union United Methodist Church in Worton offered savory trout, said volunteer George Johnson.
Jim DeCaro of Still Pond Creations sold paintings of journeys to the Outer Banks in North Carolina, a double rainbow in an azure sky, a sunset on the Sassafras and many other works.
Everyone seemed to participate in the fun. Dave LeClair from his residence on the hill, shot off tiny plastic soldiers on parachutes down to expectant kids. Residents from Rigby Bluff II condominiums threw beachballs down to the kids simultaneously as the Willy Woo Woo Productions float operated a bubble machine spreading suds.
Toys, bubbles and candy surrounded scurrying kids, having fun while their parents froze those fond moments on their cell phones.
New this year was the magic show by magician of 50 years, Michael Cox and family, Jennifer, Hailey and Caidyn Cox of Willy Woo Woo Productions.
The show drew around 150 adults and kids near the pavilion steps such as little Layanna Johnson. Her aunt Akilah Johnson-Downes complimented the show.
"We definitely enjoyed this. This year's Betterton Day was one for the books."
That was followed up by the crowd favorite at the park, Cow Plop Bingo, and while Rosa the cow did not "plop", money went to Fred Zink, noted volunteer for the fire company, as his number was drawn at random from approximately 500 plots.
Representatives for Betterton Day extended their thanks to organizers.
"Thank you so much to the Betterton Community Development Corporation, Betterton American Legion, Betterton Volunteer Fire Company and the Betterton Still Pond Lions Club, especially volunteers, Gerry and Linda Werner for pouring countless hours bringing this event to life."
For more information and pictures of Betterton Day, find them on Facebook and do not forget to attend next year's beach party, Gerry and Linda Werner reminded. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Arts & Culture is a close secondary fit due to the inclusion of performances and local art, while Local Government is less central.

title: Country Cooking: Cooking for The King
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Cooking for The King

 August 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1061
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Today's column is being written from the heart. The month of August is always a busy month, but not too busy for me to reflect on the past.Those of you who know me also know this is the month I usually travel to Memphis and meet with worldwide friends to gather at Graceland and pay respects to Elvis.
Aug. 16, 1977 was the day we teenagers of the late 1950s and '60s lost one of our favorite idols. Hard to believe it's been 48 years since I heard the news that morning. As goes with all our idols, Elvis is just as popular today with fans of all ages.
My answer to those who ask why I liked him so much is easy to explain: My older siblings loved the late 1940s through the mid-1950s music, and when I became a preteen, my generation needed a change of dance styles and rock 'n' roll music. And we got it — to the horror of our elders. That is true for all generations.
When I meet fans from Germany, some are my age, but some are 30 and 40 years old and remembering their grandparents and parents talking about Elvis serving in the Army in Germany.
Let's explore some of the King's favorite foods. Elvis loved his mother's meatloaf, and I occasionally make this recipe.
MEATLOAF
2 lbs ground beef, one chopped onion, one chopped green pepper, two minced cloves garlic, 4 oz crushed saltines, 8-oz can crushed tomatoes, 8-oz can tomato sauce, 1/2 cup ketchup.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Mix together ground beef with onion, green pepper, garlic, crushed saltines and crushed tomatoes. Mix well and form into a loaf and place in a baking pan. Bake covered, for 45 minutes. In the meantime, mix tomato sauce and ketchup and set aside. After 45 minutes of baking, remove the meatloaf and pour the ketchup on top and return to the oven. Bake for another 15 minutes and serve with mashed potatoes.
ROAST BEEF
2 tbsps black pepper, 1 1/2 tbsps salt, 2 tbsps garlic, 6 lb beef, 1 1/2 cups water.
Mix pepper, salt and garlic to form a paste and rub on this mixture on the beef. Place this roast in a baking pan, add water and place in a 350-degree oven. Bake for about 4 hours or until tender. You can steam some fresh vegetables to serve with the roast.
SPANISH OMELETTE
4 eggs, 1/2 cup chopped green bell pepper, 1/2 cup chopped onion, 1/2 cup shredded cheese, salt and pepper.
Beat eggs well and mix in bell pepper and onion. Fold in 1/2 cup shredded cheese of your choice with salt and pepper to taste. Cook in a greased skillet for about 4 minutes.
HAMBURGER STEAK ELVIS
2 1/2 pounds ground beef, 1/2 cup chopped onion, 1/2 cup chopped green pepper, 1 tbsp garlic, 1 tbsp salt, 1 tbsp black pepper, 2 cups mushroom soup, 2 eggs (beaten).
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. In a large bowl mix together ground beef, chopped onions, chopped green pepper, garlic, salt, black pepper, mushroom soup and eggs. Mix well Shape into mini steaks and fry in a skillet with 2 tablespoons Crisco. Cook for about 12 to 15 minutes, making sure steaks are cooked inside well. Drain on paper towels and proceed to make gravy with grease left in the pan.
ELVIS BANANA BREAD
2 cups all-purpose flour, 1 cup sugar, 1 tsp baking powder, 1 tsp baking soda, 1 tsp salt, 1 tsp pumpkin pie spice, 4 medium ripe bananas (mashed), 2 large eggs (room temperature), 1/2 cup creamy peanut butter, 1/4 cup unsweetened applesauce, 1/4 cup canola oil, 2 tsps vanilla extract, 2/3 cup semisweet chocolate chips
Preheat oven to 350 degrees. In a large bowl, whisk the first six ingredients. In another bowl, whisk bananas, eggs, peanut butter, applesauce, oil and vanilla until blended. Add to flour mixture; stir just until moistened. Fold in chocolate chips. Transfer to three loaf pans coated with cooking spray. Bake for 45-50 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Cool in pans 10 minutes before removing to a wire rack to cool. If you make multiple loaves like Mary Jenkins Langston would make for his plane rides to Las Vegas, you can freeze them and reheat. Securely wrap the cooled loaves and freeze. To use, thaw at room temperature or, if desired, microwave each loaf on high for 60-75 seconds or until heated through.
FRIED PEANUT BUTTER AND BANANA SANDWICHES
Smear peanut butter on one slice of bread, and on the other slice smear the bread with mashed banana. Put the slices together, smear each outside slice with bacon grease and fry in a hot skillet.
FRIED DILL PICKLES
1 jar (32 oz) whole dill pickles, 1 cup buttermilk, 2 tbsps Louisiana-style hot sauce, 1 cup all-purpose flour, 1 cup cornmeal, 2 tbsps garlic salt, 2 tbsps paprika, 1 tbsp cayenne pepper, 1 tsp pepper, oil for deep-fat frying, ranch salad dressing.
Drain pickles, discarding liquid. Cut pickles into 1/2-inch-thick slices. Drain on paper towels; blot with additional paper towels until dry. In a shallow bowl, mix buttermilk and hot sauce. In another shallow bowl, mix flour, cornmeal, garlic salt, paprika, cayenne pepper and pepper. Dip pickles in buttermilk mixture, then in flour mixture. In a Dutch oven, heat one inch of oil to 375 degrees. Working in batches, fry pickles for 2-3 minutes on each side, or until golden brown. Drain on paper towels. Serve immediately with ranch dressing, if desired.
Before I close the column today, I need to honor my late brother, Staff Sgt. (E6) Ollie L. Hitchens Jr., who would be celebrating his 78th birthday on Aug. 15. Ollie served 20 years in the U.S. Army and pulled three tours of duty in Vietnam.
Ollie and I had a lot in common — our likes, dislikes, love for Chevy cars, love of family, patriotic responsibilities, personalities and love for Elvis.
Ollie loved our mom's old-fashioned cooking and often wrote home about how he missed it. While on his many trips home Mom would make sure to have those foods ready — fried chicken, pot roast, pork chops, mashed potatoes, fried liver with gravy, chicken and dumplings, fresh lima beans with tomatoes, corn and potatoes and of course homemade biscuits. I have shared many of these recipes with you in previous columns.
Rest in peace, brother — as I always say, "All gave some, and some gave all." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on Elvis Presley, a major entertainment figure, and shares recipes inspired by his favorite foods, making it primarily an entertainment piece with cultural (arts) elements.

title: Caroline Dorchester County Fair kicks off with ribbon cutting
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Dorchester County Fair kicks off with ribbon cutting

 August 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 428
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On Wednesday, the Caroline Dorchester County Fair begin with a ribbon cutting ceremony.Commonly known as "the fair too big for one county," this annual fair will be hosted at the Caroline County 4-H Park through Saturday. During the ribbon cutting, multiple county officials spoke on how important 4-H Park is to the community and how important the fair is to the park.
"4-H and these county fairs are just such an essential part of keeping our future going," Dorchester County Council member Mike Detmer said.
"...I love coming here with my family. I love coming here and enjoying all the families and kids that are here. I just want them to know we just are cheering for them so much and we're counting on them. We're so appreciative for the the opportunity this gives to 4-H and other students here that are doing such a great job. We're so proud of you."
Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) spoke on behalf of the Eastern Shore legislative delegation.
"We always look forward to this wonderful tradition," Mautz said. "It is Americana in person right here in Caroline County. It's an honor to be a part of it, and especially we want to salute our 4-H'ers. We always like to come out here seeing everything you guys put into those animals every year. Its a great thing, so God bless the 4-H and God bless the fair."
The fair includes family fun for all ages with different events and themes and attractions each day.
One particular exhibit that drew a crowd at the fair was Lumberjack Ray.
Ray Geist, a Talbot County native, is a former Timber Sports professional. He was able to put his skills on display for Caroline and Dorchester residents at the fair Wednesday.
Geist started Timber Sports, a lumberjack-style sport, in 2011. He participated in all four years of college and then got a job at the Great Alaskan Lumberjack Show in Ketchikan, Alaska.
"I did that for 10 years off and on and then came back here and been back in Maryland, which is home sweet home," he said.
Geist performed axe throwing, log rolling, underhand chop and more on Wednesday. He said it was amazing to perform for his hometown because people don't get a chance to see Timber Sports in person.
"People haven't seen it in real life, TV here and there, but to be able to have the demonstration here and to have my local family and friends here to see it, it's a lot of fun," Geist said.
For more information on the schedule for the fair, visit carolinedorchestercountyfair.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
