title: Country Cooking: Treats from carnivals and fairs
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Treats from carnivals and fairs

 August 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: News 
 
 1278
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Carnivals and fairs — what a welcome treat each year for folks of all ages.Growing up on the farm, we always looked forward to traveling to those adventures. Even though we lived just a few miles from the boardwalks in Ocean City and Rehoboth Beach, we always attended the carnivals and the Delaware State Fair in Harrington.
The local carnivals had the usual rides — smaller Ferris wheels, small train rides on short tracks, tilt-a-wheels and swings. The state fair would have much more active rides on a larger scale.
Of course, the boardwalks had the famous bumper cars, a giant Ferris wheel, small boat rides, a merry-go-round and that laughing lady — I was always scared of her.
Let's check out the food at the local carnivals. Most of the carnival foods are cooked on the grounds by the local volunteer firefighters and their families, along with other local volunteers.
Some of the best oyster fritter sandwiches and fried soft crab sandwiches on the Shore can be found here — did I mention clam strips and fries. Some other fair and carnival foods and treats include: corn dogs, deep fried onions, fried pickles, funnel cakes, caramel apples, cotton candy, popcorn balls, hot dogs, hamburgers, fried alligator and snow cones, and the list goes on.
Enjoy all these foods, and try some of them at home.
DEEP FRIED OREO COOKIES
2 quarts vegetable oil for frying, 1 cup milk, 1 large egg, 2 tsps vegetable oil, 1 cup pancake mix, 1 18-oz package cream-filled chocolate sandwich cookies.
Gather all ingredients. Heat oil in a deep fryer or large saucepan to 375 degrees. Whisk milk, egg and 2 tsps of vegetable oil in a large bowl until smooth. Stir in the pancake mix until no dry lumps remain. Dip cookies into batter, one at a time, and carefully place into hot oil. Fry in batches, 4 or 5 at a time, until cookies are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Drain on a paper towel-lined plate before serving.
STATE FAIR CORNDOG
1 cup yellow cornmeal, 1 cup all-purpose flour, ¼ cup white sugar, 4 tsps baking powder, ¼ tsp salt, ⅛ tsp black pepper, 1 cup milk, 1 large egg, 1 quart vegetable oil for frying, 2 16-oz packages beef hot dogs, wooden skewers.
Combine cornmeal, flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and pepper in a medium bowl; stir in milk and egg to make a batter. Heat oil in a deep fryer or large saucepan to 375 degrees. Meanwhile, pat hot dogs dry and insert a skewer into each one. Roll hot dogs in batter until well coated. Fry 2 or 3 corn dogs at a time in preheated oil until lightly browned, about 3 minutes. Drain on paper towels.
FUNNEL CAKES
3 ⅔ cups all-purpose flour (divided), 2 tsps baking powder, ½ tsp salt, 2 cups milk, 3 large eggs, ¼ cup white sugar, 1 quart vegetable oil for frying, 2 tbsps confectioners' sugar.
Mix together half of the flour, baking powder and salt in a medium bowl. Set aside. Beat together milk, eggs, and sugar in a large bowl. Add flour mixture and beat until smooth. Add remaining flour, using only enough to achieve a runny batter thin enough to flow through a funnel. Heat 1 inch oil in an 8-inch skillet to 375 degrees. Put your finger over the bottom opening of a funnel and fill with a generous 1/2 cup batter. Release batter close to the surface of hot oil while making a circular motion and fry until the bottom is golden brown, 1 to 2 minutes. Use tongs and a wide spatula to carefully turn cake over and fry until the other side is golden brown, about 1 minute more. Drain cake on a paper towel-lined plate and sprinkle with confectioners' sugar. Repeat with remaining batter.
TURKEY LEGS
1 2-liter bottle lemon-lime flavored carbonated beverage, 2 tbsps sugar, 2 tbsps hot sauce, 1 tbsp crushed red pepper flakes, 1 tbsp black pepper, 1 large sweet onion (sliced), 4 turkey legs, 2 tbsps honey, 1 tbsp steak seasoning.
Preheat an outdoor grill for high heat, and lightly oil grate. In a large pot, mix the lemon-lime flavored carbonated beverage, sugar, hot sauce, red pepper, pepper and onion. Place the turkey legs in the mixture and bring to a boil. Cook 30 to 45 minutes until the turkey has reached an internal temperature of 180 degrees. Remove onion slices from the mixture, and arrange on the prepared grill. Place turkey legs over the onions. Drizzle with honey and season with steak seasoning. Cook, tuning once, 20 minutes, or until a crisp browned crust has formed on the turkey legs.
DEEP FRIED PICKLES
2 eggs, 1 cup buttermilk, 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce, ½ tsp vinegar-based hot pepper sauce, ¾ tsp cayenne pepper, ¼ tsp seasoning salt, ¼ tsp garlic powder, 1 cup cornmeal, 2 ¼ cups all-purpose flour, 1 tsp salt, ¾ tsp ground black pepper, 1 32-oz jar dill pickle slices, 1 cup vegetable oil for deep frying, salt and pepper to taste.
In a large bowl, combine eggs, 1/4 cup of the flour, buttermilk, Worcestershire sauce, hot sauce, cayenne pepper, seasoning salt and garlic powder. In a separate mixing bowl, combine cornmeal, 2 cups flour, salt and 3/4 tsp black pepper. Preheat oil in a deep fryer or pot to 365 degrees. Dip drained pickles into milk mixture and then dredge them in the flour mixture. Deep fry until golden brown. Drain on paper towels. Salt and pepper to taste
STATE FAIR SWEET TEA
2 cups water, 6 black tea bags, 1/8 tsp baking soda, 2/3 cup sugar, 6 cups cold water.
In a small saucepan, bring water to a boil. Remove from the heat; add tea bags. Cover and steep for 10 minutes. Discard tea bags. Sprinkle baking soda into a 2-quart pitcher. Transfer tea to pitcher; stir in sugar. Add cold water. Refrigerate until chilled.
CARNIVAL CHURROS
6 tbsps unsalted butter, 2 tbsps plus 1 cup granulated sugar (divided), 1 tsp pure vanilla extract, 1 cup all-purpose flour, 1 tsp kosher salt, 1/4 cup ground cinnamon, 2 large eggs, vegetable oil for frying.
In a large saucepan over medium heat, bring butter, 2 tbsps sugar and 1 cup water to a boil, then stir in vanilla. Remove from heat and add flour and salt. Stir with a wooden spoon until thickened, about 30 seconds. Let cool 10 minutes. Meanwhile, on a rimmed baking sheet or large plate, mix cinnamon and remaining 1 cup sugar. Using a handheld mixer on medium speed, add eggs one at a time, beating to blend after each addition. Transfer mixture to a piping bag fitted with a large open star tip. Into a large pot fitted with a deep-fry thermometer, pour oil to come halfway up sides. Heat over medium-high heat until the thermometer registers 375 degrees. Holding a piping bag a few inches above oil, carefully pipe churros into 6-inch ropes. Using kitchen scissors, cut off dough from the piping bag. Working in batches, fry churros, turning as needed, until golden brown, 4 to 5 minutes; make sure oil registers 375 degrees between batches. Using a slotted spoon or tongs, immediately roll churros in cinnamon sugar, then transfer to a wire rack.
CARAMEL POPCORN
6 quarts popped popcorn, 2 cups packed brown sugar, 1 cup butter (cubed), 1/2 cup corn syrup, 1 tsp salt, 3 tsps vanilla extract, 1/2 tsp baking soda.
Place popcorn in a large bowl and set aside. In a large saucepan, combine the brown sugar, butter, corn syrup and salt; bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly. Boil for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally. Remove from the heat. Stir in vanilla and baking soda; mix well. Pour over popcorn and stir until well coated. Pour into 2 greased 13-by-9-inch baking pans. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on carnival and fair foods, providing recipes and describing the festive atmosphere, which aligns best with the Entertainment category. It also touches on cultural food traditions (Arts & Culture) and the fair economy, but entertainment is the primary theme.

title: Rock Hall Bull Roast returns for 70th season
author: BOB FORD Special contribution to the Star Democrat
content:
Rock Hall Bull Roast returns for 70th season

 August 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BOB FORD Special contribution to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 625
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — When St. John Catholic Church parish members in Rock Hall first planned a fundraising bull roast to help build a new church for the congregation, they probably couldn't imagine the event would one day be celebrating its 70th renewal.That is the case, however, and the 2025 edition of the event that began in 1954 — missing only two years during the COVID pandemic — will return for the 70th time on Sunday, Aug. 17 from 1 to 5 p.m. at the Rock Hall Volunteer Fire Company.
"This event is kind of the mountaintop for the community every year," said Deacon John L. Davis, who has been with the Sacred Heart/St. John parish for more than 20 years. "It's humbling to see how many people give their time and their talent to always make it a success. There have been times when you are tempted to say, 'Well, this year might not work,' but it always does and it's always great."
The first bull roast and several thereafter were held on the Eastern Neck farm property of Dr. Norbert Nitsch, and was organized by Nitsch, his wife, Ethel Nitsch, and neighbors Ernest "Tot" Willson and his wife, Mary Willson. The groundbreaking for the new church took place soon after and the brick church still in use today was dedicated in November, 1955.
The Bull Roast moved in 1960 to the open lawn between the new church and the original 1890 parish church, before moving one more time to the Rock Hall Volunteer Fire Company building in 2022.
One thing that hasn't changed is the quality of the food served, which starts at 6:30 a.m. behind the firehouse with a roast beef-grilling crew overseen by Ernest "Tot" Strong, the grandson of one of the founders. His wife, Millie Strong, is co-chair of the 2025 Bull Roast, along with Beth Dunn.
"It runs very smoothly. We start having meetings in April and there are probably about 25 people on the committee," Millie Strong said "Last year we served 337 dinners and there were also 85 takeout dinners. This is the most important fundraiser of the year for Sacred Heart and St. John. We're able to maintain the buildings and make improvements. We recently had all the stained glass removed to clean and repair. But the Bull Roast is also a part of our history. When you think of St. John and Rock Hall, you think of the Bull Roast. It's synonymous."
The traditional menu, aside from the sliced beef, includes grilled hot dogs and sausage with peppers and onions, french fries, potato salad, sliced tomatoes, baked beans, corn on the cob, and an extensive dessert table. The food is locally sourced from Redman's Farm and Bayside Market. Included with admission are beer and soft drinks. There is also a silent auction, music, and games.
"We're thrilled to be able to help out a community partner like this," said Andy Glenn, president of the fire company. "I grew up down the street from the church. To me, the Bull Roast is a town institution. We do a little setup to make sure they have what they need, but they do all the work and we're more than happy that we have the space for them."
The indoor event is rain or shine, and tickets can be purchased in advance for $25 for adults, $12 for youngsters 7-12 years old, by visiting sacredparish.org. On the day of the Roast, admission is $30 for adults and remains $12 for the youngsters.
What started out as merely a way to build a new church has become over the years the means to build old traditions and continuing community alliances. That's worth celebrating, and on Sunday, Aug. 17, St. John will do just that for the 70th time. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community fundraising bull roast with food, music, games, and a silent auction, which fits best under Entertainment as a local cultural event.

title: Caroline Summerfest slated for Aug. 15 and 16
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Summerfest slated for Aug. 15 and 16

 August 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 269
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline Summerfest is on the horizon. The two-day event is scheduled for Aug. 15 and 16 from 5 to 9 p.m.According to Caroline County Recreation and Parks Director Jamie Beechey, nonprofit organization in the county benefit the most from Caroline Summerfest.
"It is one of their biggest, if not biggest, fundraisers of the year," Beechey said. "So, by virtue of the sales that they do have, they're able to provide for the residents of Caroline County the services that they they can provide and because of that fundraising during Summerfest."
Summerfest is a free family entertainment festival featuring two stages of regional and local entertainment hosted on the Caroline County courthouse lawn and parts of Main Street in Denton.
On Friday, there will be a car show and multiple groups and soloists singing on the Courthouse Stage and the West Lawn Stage.
Saturday will feature a fireworks show, strolling performers, artisans, free activities, games and food vendors.
Also on Saturday, Summerfest includes the Rivah Run, a 2-mile paddling event including kayaking, paddle boarding and canoeing for people of all ages. Children must be accompanied by an adult.
Caroline County Recreation and Parks holds 100 slots for the Rivah Run, and each year the 100 slots are filled. Pre-registration is at 8 a.m., and launch is at 9 a.m. at Martainak State Park.
Each paddler stops at a series of five dealer checkpoints to receive a playing card. At the finish, the best five-card poker hand wins the first pick of prize options with a cash value of $750. Local businesses contribute prizes for other winning hands.
For more information on Caroline Summerfest, visit carolinesummerfest.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community summer festival featuring performances, fireworks, car shows, artisans, and other entertainment activities, making Entertainment the most fitting category.

title: Pirates raid Rock Hall for annual festival
author: WILL BONTRAGER wontrager@chespub.com
content:
Pirates raid Rock Hall for annual festival

 August 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 826
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — Avast me hearties! Buccaneers and landlubbers of all ages flooded to Rock Hall for their annual Pirates and Wenches festival over the weekend sponsored by Main Street Rock Hall.They took to Main Street, Sharp Street, Ferry Park Beach and Watermen's Crab House meshing fun with history and entertainment.
Voted Best Tourist Attraction by local media, the festival celebrated its 18th year.
Co-organizer, Suzanne Einstein originally dreamed up the pirates concept, happy to see it expand.
"We came up with the idea while at Waterman's Crab House on Halloween after seeing so many people dressed up as pirates! We thought, how fun would it be to have a Caribbean style party on our public beach, a decorated dinghy flotilla in the harbor, and a Buccaneer's Ball! It was clear to us that our little waterfront town on the Chesapeake was the perfect location to host such an event!"
She was right. Eighteen years later the party is in full effect, drawing people of all ages.
Jim Rich, chairperson for Pirates and Wenches Committee noted the weather was absolutely perfect to bring people out.
He said that for two days restaurants, bars, shops, hotels and Airbnb's were filled. Business in the area thrived, including some new businesses that just opened: Rock Hall Brewing Company, The Green Heron and Nauti Blu Cottage to name a few.
Down the street and avenues, joyous pirates and charming wenches peddled their wares to locals and visitors alike while music played along Sharp Street and kids' laughter and joy filled the air.
In typical pirate fashion, much could be experienced from deer-antler weapons, to spicy pirate blend pickles to wooden pints as big as a giant's fist to artwork and beautiful jewelry. Some vendors were local or nearby, but others came as far as Florida like author historian, Robert Jacob.
With four buses shuttling people to and fro, it made for a safe, relaxing weekend with no incidents, reported Brian Jones of Rock Hall Volunteer Fire Company.
The party kicked off Friday night with rum tasting at Haven Harbour South and sea shanty sing-alongs at American Legion Post 228 at 7 p.m.
On Saturday, a Lions Club sponsored kids treasure dig at the Ferry Park public beach at 10 a.m uncovered fun followed by a rolling flotilla low speed vehicle parade at 11 a.m. along with pirate poker run from noon to 2 p.m.
After that, pirates and wenches took to the coast for a beach party with live music from noon to 4 p.m.; and Buccaneers Ball from 7 to 11 p.m. at Waterman's Crab House where winners of the raffle were announced.
Also on Saturday, mysterious mermaids waved to audiences from their watery chambers, stilted individuals stalked merrily through the crowd and planners of the pirate events had a ball showing people how to participate in the multitude of activities.
As of last year, cannon fire shot off at intervals throughout the weekend from the Skullduggery Crew based out of Baltimore. The group stayed two days in tents, truly roughing it.
Music from The Brigands and other bands got people toe-tapping and twirling.
Rich said everyone has fun at Pirates, especially kids, with even more activities for them than last year.
The HoCo Pirate Adventure Treasure was a hit with families, participating in a treasure hunt that encompassed the entire festival area.
Another activity, kids could hunt down the "most wanted pirates" and be rewarded with prizes as well as a chance to win a movie party at Flagship Premium Cinemas.
Fortune's Folly Pirate Show got kids laughing and watching in wonder.
Near Gunpowder Cove, the dunk machine drew a big crowd said mom and PTA member, Laura Wirth. Her daughter Lina Wirth happily volunteered to be dunked. All proceeds went to Rock Hall Elementary School.
A new attraction from Master Ship builders Lisa Sasser and George Barnett guided kids to make their own sailboats, testing them on the rough waters of the kiddie pool. Sasser was pleased to see so many children enjoying it.
History buffs were entertained as well.
The author, Robert Jacob regaled the crowd, knocking down some past prejudices of Black Beard and conducted a lecture about pirates in the Chesapeake.
The street was open for creative swashbucklers and maidens greeting people with warmth and cheer.
Woody McKay better known as Captain Gray Fox handed out good doubloons.
"I love this! Every year I meet such interesting people," he said.
As he said that, award winning actress, Smithsonian scholar Mary Ann Jung introduced herself as her character, Grace O' Malley the Pirate Queen.
Good grub was to be had as well from pizza, burgers, barbecue to smoked meat on a stick. And if the sun was too much for people, they even had a mist tent cooling people down.
Rich lauded Pirates a success, estimating the event drew 4,000 people to the town.
He thanked everyone on the committee who started planning around February.
"From my view we pulled off what can be a complicated event with a lot of moving parts. We showed people Pirates in Rock Hall is a friendly, family-oriented weekend."

title: Caroline Summerfest 2025 brings large crowd to Denton
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Summerfest 2025 brings large crowd to Denton

 August 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 302
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Last weekend, Caroline Summerfest drew one its biggest Friday night crowds in recent years."I would say this has been a busier Friday night than the past few years," Caroline County Recreations and Parks Executive Director Jamie Beechey said. "The weather's a little less humid than it has been. I think that people have been really excited about coming out."
Attendees visited more than 150 nonprofit organizations' tents and learned new information while enjoying food for sale, proceeds from which benefited the nonprofits.
"It's our biggest event of the year," said Victor Reynolds, a communication representative for CASA of Caroline. "We're very lucky in particular to have our booth directly in front of our office."
Outside CASA's office on Main Street, Reynolds said how important the event was for exposure for all nonprofits in Caroline County.
"It's a vital day for them as well, including just the overall exposure for people that, maybe the resources that are traveling through or that are in the county, that might not be aware of certain resources available to them," Reynolds said.
For entertainment, attendees rode on a fire truck courtesy of the Denton Volunteer Fire Company, enjoyed cars in the car show, listened to singing from multiple artists and groups, and ate food from multiple different vendors.
The "Back to the 80's" theme gave attendees a chance to pull out their 1980s-style outfits.
"It feels really good because this is what I remember in these areas when I was growing up, big festivals, carnivals and stuff like that, so it kind of like brings everybody together," said Alex Green, owner of Harriet Tubman Tours in Cambridge said the '80s theme.
Organizers said this summer's event was a success. Caroline County Recreations and Park said in a Facebook post Sunday, "Thank you all for the love this weekend we had a blast." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

content:

 There were giggles and laughter all along North East's Main Street Saturday, August 23. as children of all ages took part in Unicorn Quest, the annual celebration of all things magical.Children waited for their turn to get face painting or to meet a real unicorn that came from Fairwinds Farm in North East. The North East Rotary Club handed out free snow cones and McCormick Orthodontics offered several themed crafts included slap bracelets and masks. Cecil County Public Library also took part in Unicorn Quest as did Dolly Parton Imagination Library. Many of the stores that call Main Street home also offered unicorn-themed fun including Treats By Zeets and Maryland Cruzin' For A Cause.

title: Singing Captains to lead Buffett celebration at The Mainstay
author: BOB FORD Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Singing Captains to lead Buffett celebration at The Mainstay

 August 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BOB FORD Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 552
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — Jimmy Buffett was a musical legend with a phenomenal career and a unique following, but on the Chesapeake Bay, he was just another boater looking for good fishing, good food and good times.Well, maybe not just another boater. When Last Mango, his 42-foot custom sportfisher, made its way north to Sag Harbor in the spring, or south in the fall to the tropical climes that inspired many of his songs, Buffett delighted in exploring the bay from the ocean to the C&D Canal. He even filmed a music video at Thomas Point Light on one of the trips.
Boaters, beach bums and backyard pool drifters all lost a friend when Buffett died at 76 on Sept. 1, 2023, due to complications from a rare form of skin cancer.
To honor the Labor Day weekend anniversary of his passing, and to celebrate his musical legacy, the Singing Captains are performing a Buffett-only concert of his hits on Sunday, Aug. 31, from 4 to 6 p.m. at the outdoor amphitheater of Rock Hall's iconic music venue, The Mainstay.
It will be a "family-friendly celebration of music, memories and Margaritaville vibes, with special musical guests and good company," according to Mark Einstein, a member of the Singing Captains and a day-job charter boat captain in his own right.
The event is ticketless and free to the public, with a suggested donation of $10 to help The Mainstay continue its mission of providing a wide variety of musical offerings for the community. The Mainstay cash bar will be operating, with margaritas and more. Ice cream will be available for purchase from Get the Scoop, and That Place on Main will have Cheeseburgers in Paradise on the menu at the show.
Opening for the Singing Captains, and joining them on a number of Buffett songs that follow, will be steel pan virtuoso Trevor Stubbs. He is a native of Trinidad, where the instrument was first fashioned out of industrial steel drums. Stubbs, who is one half of the duo Island Vibes, has played at The Mainstay previously. Beginning with the song "One Particular Harbor," a 1983 release from the album of the same name, Buffett often used steel pannists on his Caribbean-flavored songs.
"What connects Rock Hall to the Jimmy Buffett thing is that this is a premier sailing and boating town. We've all got Hawaiian shirts, and we like to emulate that laid-back lifestyle that his music captured," Einstein said. "His music, when it burst on the scene, influenced the whole boating world. You would hear it walking down literally any dock."
Buffett, originally from Pascagoula, Mississippi, made his way to New Orleans and Nashville before discovering that Key West was just the right latitude for his attitude, and the tropical-tinged hits followed quickly. Over the course of his career, Buffett sold more than 20 million records, and 17 of his albums were either gold or platinum in sales. He was posthumously inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2024.
Those attending the Buffett celebration at The Mainstay will find plenty of seating at the open-air amphitheater, but if so inclined, there is room on the lawn for beach chairs, too. Visitors can bring those, wiggle their toes in the grass and pretend it is sand.
"Wear your loudest shirt and come help us toast Jimmy," Einstein said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a live music concert celebrating Jimmy Buffett, which is a cultural event focused on performance and audience enjoyment, fitting the Entertainment category best, with Arts & Culture as a close secondary fit.

title: Autumn Block Party brings community together
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett!@chespub.com
content:
Autumn Block Party brings community together

 September 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett!@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — On Saturday, the Second Annual Autumn Block Party brought together hundreds of Caroline County residents for a day of free fun at Martin Sutton Park in Ridgely.The block party committee was able to bring in more than 30 vendors with food, service information and attractions. In just its second year, the block party has become a community favorite, organizers said.
"I'm overwhelmed because I'm getting a lot of good feedback," Holly Justice said on behalf of the committee Saturday. "So, it feels great. As a organizer, you never know how people are going to receive your event. So, to hear that people are enjoying themselves and the kids are happy, I think it turned out better than we expected."
The Town of Ridgely, which provided hot dogs and juices for the event, said that town officials served over 250 hot dogs during the first half of the event.
At the end of the block party last year, the committee put out a community poll to see what could be improved. Extending the time was the biggest item the residents raised.
This year, the block party didn't end until 7 p.m., which allowed attendees to come in waves while doing multiple things with their Saturday.
The event featured performances from The Cayer Band and Monkee Paw, as well as belly dancer Caitlyn Poole and DJ Tony VIBEZ. The committee also had a raffle and handed out multiple prizes.
The goal for the committee is to continue to allow free fun with the event, which they hope to grow in years to come.
"My heart is so happy," Justice said. "My only hope is that we continue to grow and people continue to share the word and talk about the block party and how it is really for the community. Money is wonderful, but it's about those faces being out there dancing and winning the prizes and bouncing on the bouncy houses. So, I'm happy." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community block party featuring music, performances, and activities, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category, while also touching on cultural aspects and town involvement.

title: Winestock Festival returns to Dove Valley Winery on Sept. 27
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Winestock Festival returns to Dove Valley Winery on Sept. 27

 September 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 365
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RISING SUN — Hey, all you hippies out there!It's almost time to put flowers in your hair. Yes, it's almost time to don your favorite tie-dyed T-shirts, denim bellbottoms, mini-skirts, granny sunglasses and peace symbol necklaces. And if you're really feeling that Wavy Gravy vibe, it's almost time to to dab your neck with patchouli and burn some lavender incense.
In other words, it's time to let your freak-flag fly at Dove Valley Winery's 13th annual Winestock Festival, a rain-or-shine event set to run from 11 a.m to 7 p.m. Saturday, Sept. 27, on the vineyard grounds at 645 Harrington Road, off Joseph Biggs Highway (Route 274), a short distance south of downtown Rising Sun.
The annual event typically draws 800 to 1,000 people. As evidenced by the previous Winestock events, many attendees wear groovy threads and outwardly immerse themselves in the counter-culture celebration associated with Woodstock, the three-day-long rock music festival that was held in Upper State New York in August 1969.
And what's a Woodstock tribute festival without music?
On the bill for Winestock 2025 are Max & Denise "Acoustic with an Edge" (11 a.m. to 1 p.m.), Old Skool & The Edge (1 p.m. to 3 p.m.), Smokin' Guns (3 p.m. to 5 p.m.) and the finale act, Olivia Reynolds (5 p.m. to 7 p.m.) Those bands will perform on the winery's pavilion stages.
Beer will be for sale on the premises. Chesapeake-City-based Bayheads Brewing Company and Perryville-based 5th Company Brewing Company will be selling their various craft beers. And, of course, Dove Valley Winery will be selling its array of wines during the festival.
The list of food trucks includes Kacey's Kitchen, Rolling Grub, Dine 'N' Dash Delights, Wing Paradise and The Pit Shack BBQ and Pizza. Non-alcoholic drinks also will be available for purchase.
In addition, numerous local art and craft vendors will be displaying and selling their merchandise during the eight-hour-long event.
Admission for Winestock 2025 is $10 per person in advance and $20 per head at the gate. There is no charge for attendees under 21 years old. The admission fee for the 21 and older crowd also covers wine tasting and a complimentary keepsake wine glass.
Outside food, beverages and coolers will not be allowed. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article announces a local music festival with live performances, food trucks, and craft vendors, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category, while also touching on Arts & Culture through local artisans.

title: A clown named Crickett 'stands out' at Port Deposit festival
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
A clown named Crickett 'stands out' at Port Deposit festival

 September 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1049
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PORT DEPOSIT — Hundreds of people attended the fourth annual Pirate Takeover in Port Deposit last weekend, but one person stood out in the crowd — quite literally.Head and shoulders above all the rest was "Crickett," a professional clown who ambled throughout the Marina Park grounds on stilts that were hidden by his tuxedo-style pants and boosted his natural six-foot height to somewhere around eight feet.
"Crickett," whose real name is James McGrath, turned heads — upward, as well as sideways — wherever he roamed Saturday during the seven-hour event.
Many people stopped in their tracks and tilted their heads skyward to confirm that there was, indeed, a face attached to the top of that human mountain in their midst. Clearly amazed, giggling kids ran up to Crickett to get a closer look. Several of the youngsters went airborne, giving it their best Jordan jump, as they high-fived with this spectacle that bent forward accommodatingly.
"Some people actually get startled when they see me," McGrath said. "You get the usual jokes from people, too, like, 'How's the weather up there?' and, 'Hey, Shorty,'" stuff like that.
Of course, folks ask him how tall he is on those stilts. And they ask if he has ever fallen.
The answer to that last question: Only once in approximately 20 years of practicing and performing on stilts. And after that tumble, Crickett got back on his feet — unscathed — because learning how to fall safely on stilts is as important as learning how to walk on stilts.
The trick is to never extend your arms to break your fall because, instead, you will break your wrists, humerus and other nearby bones, he emphasized. Tucking your extremities, balling up your body and rolling when you hit the ground are the ingredients for a safe fall.
As it turns out, Crickett takes his clowning very seriously. A 44-year-old Washington, D.C. resident, McGrath performs as Crickett in the region about 100 times a year under his enterprises of Shows by Crickett, Block Party Bubbles and Clown Cabaret.
"I performed at the Pirate Takeover event in Port Deposit for the past few years, and it is easily one of my favorite gigs," McGrath commented.
Those 100 or so annual gigs are the sole source of income for McGrath, who married for the first time in 2024 after spending many years on the road as a professional clown, including a long stint with the renowned Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus.
That clowning job with The Greatest Show on Earth took him to every state in the continental United States, save for Wyoming, the Dakotas and perhaps one or two others. McGrath performed as "Crickett" with Ringling Brothers in some major arenas, including the legendary Madison Square Garden.
"Back stage, there was a bunch of pictures of Billy Joel because he had performed there so many times. I think he holds the record," McGrath said of that famous New York City venue.
So how did McGrath morph into a professional clown?
Born in Massachusetts and raised in Virginia, McGrath went to the circus with his family as a kid and was drawn to all of its attractions, particularly juggling. While attending Christopher Newport University in Newport News, Va., where he graduated in 2005 with a psychology degree, McGrath learned to juggle.
"I always liked juggling as a hobby. I got a book, something like, 'The Complete Klutz Guide to Juggling' and taught myself how to juggle," he recalled.
Perhaps the main lesson that McGrath learned while majoring in psychology was this: Live an adventurous life and see new places while you are still young and able.
After attending a clowning camp in New York City, a few years post graduation, McGrath joined the Big Apple Circus as a concessions worker — just to get his big, goofy clown foot in the door.
As did many of the 150 other circus employees, McGrath lived in a renovated room in the back of a trailer while the show traveled to places in Georgia, Vermont, New Hampshire, Virginia and New York.
"I was a cotton candy twister," he said, before explaining, "I was just hoping to meet some people, make the right connections."
That pay-your-dues gig made a huge difference, too, because McGrath then got a performance job with Ringling Brothers. He performed under the Big Top as Crickett with the Blue Unit of that outfit from 2006 through 2011, juggling and executing all manners of jokes, including sight gags.
"I was very lucky. I just happened to be submitting a resume at the time when one of the clowns jumped ship — so I was available and got the job," McGrath remembered.
It was common for Ringling Brothers to stay in the cities and towns on the tour and perform nine to 15 shows per week, before moving on to the next stop. It was a demanding way of life that was tempered by the fun and adventure it provided.
"We traveled by train and pretty much lived on that train. We each had a 6'-by-6' room. We were paid a salary that was just enough to live on, just enough to meet expenses. We got one month off every two years," McGrath reviewed.
It was a passion project. "I'd work with the other clowns and we'd come up with our own gags. We'd also work with writers and a team of prop builders," McGrath said.
There was no need, however, for McGrath's talent on two-foot stilts at the Ringling Brothers level. "They had Caribbean stilt-walkers who walked smoothly on 6-foot stilts," McGrath noted.
The secret to walking on stilts, according to McGrath: "You have to get over your reptilian mindset and feel comfortable walking higher above ground than normal. And you have to know how to fall safely. It took me about 20 hours total of walking on stilts before it felt natural to me."
He added, "Most gigs are one to two hours long. Some, though, are four to five hours long and you feel pretty achy after walking on stilts all that time."
After he left Ringling Brothers and transitioned into a more domesticated life that still allowed him to clown and perform regionally, McGrath incorporated more stilts-walking into his act. He has been performing solo as Crickett, mostly on weekends, for approximately the past 15 years.
"It is an abnormal job, but I have a pretty normal life," he summarized.

title: Chefs showcase local flavors at 17th annual Taste of Cambridge
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Chefs showcase local flavors at 17th annual Taste of Cambridge

 September 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 418
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Residents came out to support the sold-out 17th annual Taste of Cambridge on Saturday, Sept. 27, donned in rain jackets and ponchos and clutching their umbrellas alongside the delicious dishes given out by vendors.The event featured 20 dishes across five categories made by 10 local chefs.
"We were very happy with today's turnout, despite the overcast weather," Executive Director of Cambridge Main Street Christina Wingate-Spence said.
Crab cakes, hush puppies, tacos and seafood soup were among some of the dishes available Saturday.
GMK Catering Company won first place for the people's choice award this year, with participants commenting that the stew dish was "fantastic." The vote was incredibly close with GMK Catering Co winning by just four votes.
Head Chef and Owner of GMK Catering Company Christopher Branch brought his predecessors, who also happen to be brothers, Ramello and Cordell Whittaker, to compete in the seafood stew category. The stew included blackened rockfish, lump crab, black-eyed peas and a tomato-based curry sauce with mirepoix and chickpeas.
The event also had four guest judges who picked the 2025 best of dishes in five categories: best seafood soup or stew, best crab cake, best crab specialty, best Eastern Shore fare and best dessert.
Guest judges included radio host Jessica Dutra from Mix 106.5 Baltimore, Chef and Owner of Hamilton House Events and Catering and Executive Chef of Great Oak Manor Jordan Lloyd, Cambridge Mayor Lajan Cephas and Andrea Elgin with Coastal Style Magazine.
"I was invited to be on the panel of this amazing event. I'm honored to be here, and it's so fun to watch all these brilliant chefs really put their whole heart on the plate," Lloyd said.
"Some of these dishes, I can't put them down. I feel like it's not a taste of Cambridge. I feel like this is a meal of Cambridge, so I'm trying to be conservative, save some room," Cephas said after tasting eight of the 20 dishes.
The judges' picks for the 2025 awards were:
For best seafood soup or stew, the award went to Blue Ruin.For best crab cake, the award went to Blue Ruin.For best crab specialty, the award went to RaR Brewing.For best Eastern Shore fare, the award went to the Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay.For best dessert, the award went to Black Water Bakery.
"We could not be happier for the turnout. It's a great opportunity for literally hundreds of people to come to downtown Cambridge and support our restaurants and our shops and just kind of see the revitalization that's going on down here," Wingate-Spence said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a local food festival featuring chefs, dishes, and community participation, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category (a public event for enjoyment). Arts & Culture is a close second due to the culinary arts aspect, and Business/Economy is relevant because local businesses and vendors are highlighted.

title: A trek through the Eastern Shore on a rainy Saturday
author: Lily Tierney
content:
A trek through the Eastern Shore on a rainy Saturday

 September 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester Star 
 
 212
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Most Saturdays, I take my dog to the Bay to swim, catch up on some television, do some chores and hang out with friends. This Saturday, I traversed the Eastern Shore to cover three events at three separate locations from noon to 9 p.m.I started my day of reporting with the 17th annual Taste of Cambridge, which lit up all of my senses. The aroma was salty and crisp from the rain. I didn't know where to look because there was so much excitement. I was overcome with nostalgia when the band played "Float On" by Modest Mouse, and my taste buds danced with joy through every bite.
My next stop was Old Trinity Church's 350th anniversary. By this point in the day, it was pouring. I tucked myself under the tent where the Hammer Creek bluegrass band played "Rain Please Go Away."
It didn't. But no one seemed to mind.
My third and final stop was the Avalon Theatre for Bailando con las Estrellas, a local Dancing with the Stars event hosted by Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center. The local celebrities blew me away with their salsa and mambo numbers, and I can't wait to see who they choose for season three.
Check out these stories below, thanks for reading and have a great day. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes attending local festivals, a church anniversary, and a dancing‑the‑stars style event, focusing on performances, music, and leisure activities, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment topic, with Arts & Culture as a close secondary fit.

title: Hit fundraising competition Bailando con las Estrellas returns for season 2
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Hit fundraising competition Bailando con las Estrellas returns for season 2

 September 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 574
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The second annual Bailando con las Estrellas took place Saturday evening at the Avalon Theatre, where local stars danced their hearts out to raise money for the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center.The event, a dance competition modeled after popular TV show Dancing with the Stars, is part of the center's Hispanic Heritage Month programming and aims to celebrate Hispanic culture while raising funds to meet yearly goals.
The fiscal goal of the event was to raise $80,000. Each dancer raised their own set of funds prior to the event and through the voting process during. By the end of the night, 86% of the goal was reached, coming in at just over $69,000.
"The first one was last year. We didn't know what we were doing, and it ended up going so well. We knew we had to go bigger and better this year. So we just went as big as we could possibly go," Executive Director of ChesMRC Matthew Peters said.
The team at ChesMRC balances uplifting success stories with difficult day-to-day challenges. The event provides a needed break to highlight the good, Peters said.
There were three judges: Liza Ledford with the Oxford Community Center; Jeremy Hillyard, Talbot County Public School 2024-25 teacher of the year; and Sharon Pepukayi, Talbot County Public Schools superintendent.
Hillyard and Pepukayi fully understood what each star was going through, as the two performed the previous year.
This year, Victoria Gomez Lozano performed with Tori Gomez, Joe Petro performed with Maya Robinson, John Marrah performed with Rebecca Wales, Brenda Fike performed with Samantha Martinez, James Redmen performed with Christine Redmen, Angel Perez performed with Maddie Megahan, and Milton Orellana performed with Berenice Orellana.
Choreographer Erinne Lewis spent two weeks with the stars learning routines, but when the amateur dancers took the stage, it appeared as if they'd been training for months. Each set of dancers brought their own unique flair to the stage — some silly, some serious and some downright impressive.
Hillyard said there was noticeable improvement from season one to season two, saying the dancers "stepped it up" this year. He was impressed by the amount of money raised and compared it to a yearly salary.
He said being a judge this year felt like less pressure than performing and he could enjoy and appreciate the dancers' hard work more.
Owner of the nonprofit consulting firm What's Good LLC Jayme Dingler was the evening's master of ceremonies. She attributed this year's success to multiple changes from last year's event.
"Matthew had the great idea of inviting star sponsors, so every team had a company that sponsored them, which is really fun," Dingler said.
In addition, they had a big opening number with all the stars, text voting, voting during the show and allowing ticket and sponsorship purchases to be allocated to a specific team.
Dingler said this led to a significant increase from the estimated $35,000 raised last year.
The big winners of the evening were Angel Perez and Maddie Megahan with the Dancing Stars (Estrellas de Baile) award, James and Christine Redmen with the Heart (Corazon) award, and Victoria Gomez Lozano and Tori Gozem with the Make it Rain (lluvia de Dinero) award.
"Thank you to everybody, all the sponsors this year, all everyone that's stepped up, and then, yeah, get ready for that phone call when I call you next year and ask you, you know, do you can you dance and do you want to, what are you doing on this Saturday night," Peters said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a local dance competition fundraiser, highlighting performances, judges, and awards, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category despite its fundraising aspect.

title: Dove Valley's groovy, wayout Winestock festival draws 1,000 'hippies'
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Dove Valley's groovy, wayout Winestock festival draws 1,000 'hippies'

 October 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 447
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Dan Moore has seen The Grateful Dead in concert about 50 times, including three consecutive shows in San Francisco in August.Suffice it to say, he is quite familiar with the hippie culture. So it speaks volumes when the veteran Deadhead from Pennsylvania gave his tie-dye seal of approval to Dove Valley Winery's 13th annual Winestock, which he and approximately 1,000 other folks attended Saturday at the vineyard near Rising Sun.
"I am loving this. It is quite a happening," marveled Moore, who came to the eight-hour-long event with Sandi, whom he described as "the love of my life," and their friend, Monique Pietrzyk, who proudly proclaimed that she is a "South Philly" resident.
Many of the festival goers got into the spirit and let their freaks flags fly by wearing attire featuring peace signs, psychedelic colors and such. Accessories included round-rimmed granny sunglasses and flowers in the hair. There was plenty of denim clothing, too, including bell bottoms. A few pairs of colorful Go-Go boots were spotted, as well.
It's quite possible, though, that Moore was the most authentically-dressed hippie on the grounds that day.
"This is from 40 years ago," Moore said, gesturing to his floppy hat with a subdued Rastafarian vibe and his quilted top. "I bought it at a Grateful Dead show in Philadelphia. They didn't have merch tents back then. This stuff was on a blanket on the pavement. That's how the person who sold it to me had all of the stuff displayed."
So, yes, if Moore says Dove Valley Winery's 13th annual Winestock was close to the genuine groovy article, then it must be true.
(It's comically noteworthy that Moore, 62, patted the front of the Grateful Dead top that he bought sometime in the mid-1980s, smiled and remarked with obvious satisfaction in his voice, "And it still fits me.")
The event provided non-stop live music performed by Max & Denise "Acoustic with an Edge," Old Skool & The Edge, Smokin' Guns and the finale act, Olivia Reynolds. Taking turns, those bands performed on the winery's two pavilion stages.
Vendors sold beer, an array of local arts and crafts and plenty of food. Workers and volunteers at Dove Valley Winery's bustling tent were busy throughout the day, selling the numerous varieties of wines created at that vineyard.
Winestock, by the way, is Dove Valley Winery's vino-infused nod to the counter-culture celebration that was Woodstock — the three-day-long rock music festival that was held in Upper State New York in August 1969.
For those who are not citizens of Deadhead Nation and might be asking themselves . . . Yes, the Grateful Dead performed at Woodstock. Moore missed that show, however, because he was only about six years old back then. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a local music festival with live performances, vendors, and cultural activities, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment topic, while also touching on Arts & Culture.

title: New acts, old favorites to highlight Rock Hall FallFest live music
author: BOB FORD Special to the Kent County News
content:
New acts, old favorites to highlight Rock Hall FallFest live music

 October 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BOB FORD Special to the Kent County News | Section: Music 
 
 675
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Rock Hall FallFest returns Saturday, Oct. 11, for the 28th edition of the annual one-day festival that celebrates the opening of the commercial oyster season along with the bayside town's tradition of presenting and supporting live music.The "return" of the oyster will be honored, as always, with thousands of hand-shucked oysters on the half shell, complemented by street-fair food and assorted drink offerings.
As for the music, which will play continuously on alternating Main Street stages during the 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. event, two newcomers will join the performance schedule in addition to some old favorites, including the always-popular Catonsville High School Steel Band.
Leading off the lineup on the Mainstay Stage will be Austin, Texas, singer-songwriter Andrea Magee, making her FallFest debut. She will be followed by The Llama Dalis, an eclectic, innovative art-rock quartet that also will perform at FallFest for the first time.
The oysters and the music are just the start. Main Street, transformed into a pedestrian-safe thoroughfare, will be lined with craft and artisan vendors and Rock Hall's array of quaint shops. A food truck convention will set up near the base of Main Street, and a Kids Kourt will feature games, prizes and entertainment for children.
Admission is free, as is the plentiful parking near the festivities. The nonprofit event donates all proceeds to Rock Hall organizations and projects. The main beneficiaries over the years have been the Kent County Waterman's Association scholarship fund and The Mainstay, the iconic music venue that books acts year-round on the Tom McHugh Stage.
The Llama Dalis, founded more than 30 years ago by brothers Michael and Dave Biddison, are a Pennsylvania-based band that reunites for festivals. Michael Biddison, on acoustic guitar, handles most of the lead vocals, while Dave plays drums and sings on the rest of their mostly original repertoire. Bob Taylor plays bass, and Steve Wheelock is the lead guitarist.
Taylor played FallFest last year with Philip Dutton's band, The Good Stuff, a classic country cover unit, and encouraged the Dalis to join the lineup this year.
"We play a high-energy show for all the dancing fools," Taylor said, "but a lot of our pieces are dreamy, thoughtful stuff. My daughter calls us jam band funk."
The Llama Dalis members have all performed in other bands over the years, but they always reunite to play fresh tunes written by the Biddison brothers and to revive a catalog influenced by the full spectrum of rock music. As for the name?
"Well, the Dalai Lama was a good guy, and Salvador Dali was an interesting character," Taylor said. "We have a song called 'Hair on Fire' that comes from a Zen teacher back in the day who said you have to seek enlightenment like a man with his hair on fire. That's us — a little Zen, a little absurdist."
Magee, a multi-instrumentalist, was born and raised in Belfast before pursuing her musical dreams in the United States in 2014. Her music blends folk, rock and Celtic styles, and she has toured with legendary artists including Brian Wilson, Brian Setzer and Jeff Bridges.
Magee is the festival director for She Rises Fest, an annual event that celebrates women in music and the arts. Her nonprofit, Music Helps, provides workshops for children at Helping Hand Home for Children in Austin, a support and housing service for children who have experienced abuse and neglect.
"Music is about community, connection and giving back," Magee said. "It's the threads that weave us together, and I'm honored to be part of that tapestry."
Other acts taking the stage at FallFest include the Catonsville High School Steel Band, returning for its 25th anniversary appearance; Pat Wictor and Bob Beach, blending acoustic guitar and blues harmonica; Kent County's own hard-rocking guitarist Blake Thompson and his Family Band; and the hometown favorites, The Singing Captains, who will close the show with classic pop songs.
Rock Hall FallFest is a feast for the ears, for good appetites and honest thirsts, and for those who enjoy a throwback day of music, oysters and small-town charm.
For more information, directions and a full lineup, visit www.rockhallfallfest.org

title: Chesapeake Film Festival showcases artists' perspectives for record-breaking crowds
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Chesapeake Film Festival showcases artists' perspectives for record-breaking crowds

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Headlines 
 
 506
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — While the Chesapeake Film Festival's focus this year largely dealt with environment and women's empowerment, the "rhythm, motion and meaning" section shown at the Academy Art Museum on Saturday afternoon veered into something different.There were two screenings: a documentary feature called "Lives Beyond Motion," directed by Keith Glassman, and a documentary short called "100 Foot Photo," directed by Matt Kresling.
The festival's Executive Director Cid Collins Walker said she chose to show these films together to balance the festival's commitment to films about women's empowerment with stories about men.
Walker said this was the best attended year in the festival's 18-year history.
"Every year, we see an increase in the amount of support we receive for all the programming," Walker said.
Committing life to art
After the showings Saturday, there was a Q&A with the director and producer of "Lives Beyond Motion."
The film explored Glassman's existential question of why he and other men committed their lives to dance.
The film began as a low-budget, long-term project around 2008 with major progress starting in 2015 after bringing producer The Angel on board. Glassman interviewed around 20 dancers who, without knowing it, shared common loves, struggles and difficulties.
Glassman's own career as a dancer ended 30 years ago after being diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. This prompted his quest to understand why dancers commit their lives to the artform for such a long time.
"I decided their answers should be heard by a wider audience, which was the impetus for the interviews," Glassman said. "Their specific answers about their experiences adjusted my perspective beyond my own, bringing in topics relevant to the whole dance community over the years, like the HIV epidemic."
"Lives Beyond Motion" is Glassman's first documentary, and he said he's been submitting it to every film festival possible.
Audience members went around the room describing what about the film resonated with them most. Multiple people spoke of the authenticity and vulnerability of the interviewees, which they said made this film personal and emotional.
An Eastern Shore connection
Matt Kreslings short film follows the journey of 20th century American artist Robert Rauschenberg's trip to China in the 1980s, his creative relationship with long-time Eastern Shore resident Donald Saff and, ultimately, his creation of a long, scroll-like photograph he named "Chinese Summerfall."
The 10-minute film explored the painstaking process of printmaking at a time when artists were physically cutting negative images and didn't know if they were done properly until the images were processed.
"I want my work to make you care because I care," Rauschenberg said in the film.
The Academy Art Museum will celebrate Rauschenberg's 100th birthday with the exhibit "Rauschenberg 100: New Connections" opening Dec. 11 and running through May 3, 2026.
The exhibit will include "Chinese Summerfall," which is rarely exhibited due to its size and fragility, according to the Academy Art Museums website. It will also feature showings of Kresling's short film, "100 Foot Photo."
"Receiving the support that we do from the community, from our sponsors, our partners, our patrons, makes such a huge difference for us," Walker said. "We simply couldn't do it without you." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

 I'll be on vacation next week, and while I'm excited to spend time with family, I have to admit — I'm a little bummed to miss out on some of the fun stories our newsroom has planned.Halloween is in full swing across the Mid-Shore, and local communities are embracing the spooky season in creative ways.  330
 Words

 EASTON — Halloween is right around the corner, and communities around the Mid-Shore are getting ready to host events.Here are some of the Halloween events going on around Mid-Shore.
Talbot County
The Talbot County Community Center will host its Halloween BOOnanza event from 6 to 8 p.m on Oct. 22. The event will feature ice skating, trick-or-treating, face painting, photo opportunities and more. It is for all ages, and no pre-registration is required. The event costs $10 per child at the door, with children aged 2 and under free.The St. Michaels Community Center is hosting a Pumpkin Pie Baking Contest on Oct. 18 at 9 a.m. with judging at 11 a.m. While sign ups are closed, residents are welcome to attend and sample some of the entries. The community center is also hosting a Pumpkin and Face Painting event on Oct. 18 from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m.
Caroline County
The Chesapeake Culinary Center will host the Spooktacular Fall Fest on Oct. 17 from 5 to 8 p.m. The free event features music, bounce houses, tent or treat, a costume contest, vendors and community resources.The Caroline County Council of the Arts will host a Halloween Sip-N-Paint: Spooky Night on Oct. 22 from 5:30 to 7:30 p.m. at the Foundry in Denton. The event will cost $35, and all ages can attend.
Dorchester County
Downtown Cambridge will be hosting Trick or Treating in the Cambridge Main Street District on Oct. 24 from 5 to 8 p.m.East New Market Events is hosting Trunk or Treat with the Sanderson sisters on Oct. 24 from 6 to 8 p.m. in the fields by the Historic Train Station on 10 Murphys Alley.Dorchester County Recreation & Parks is hosting a Spooktacular Trunk or Treat Bash on Oct. 27 from 5 to 6:30 p.m. at the Dorchester Athletic Complex. The event will feature free candy and treats and a meet and greet with the local Sheriff's Office, Cambridge Police Department and Emergency & Medical Services. The event is free for all ages.

title: As it has for generations before, Rocky Horror still astounds
author: Lily Tierney
content:
As it has for generations before, Rocky Horror still astounds

 October 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 315
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Inside the Waterfowl building on Thursday evening, Janet, Brad, Riff Raff, Eddie Ex and Magenta could be found doing the time warp again.Woohoo Productions put on its first-ever Rocky Horror Picture Show with bags of props for each attendee, a buffet themed alongside the film and games galore before the show began.
The games included a costume contest, a raunchy fill-in-the-blank game for first timers and a chaotic "find the item" game where guests scrambled to find items ranging from red lipstick to a high heel.
The master of ceremonies sprayed water guns at guests to mimic the rain scene, encouraged audience participation with cues from the film that have endured for decades and by the end of the night, no one was a stranger.
"It brings people together who are so similar and you can just sit together and you see them dancing together and throwing all the ridiculous stuff around. It's so fun," said Woohoo Productions founder Angel Perez. "And at the end of the day, that's what really matters, is just bring the community together in some way to have a good time and Who knows? Some people may leave the building today and create some new friendships."
Perez founded Woohoo Productions three months ago, and this was the company's first major event.
For Perez who has been doing community and family events in Caroline County as CEO of Caroline Pride, program manager at Chesapeake Culinary Center, board member of Shore Legal and more, he's excited to pivot to adult-focused events.
"I thought now it's time for me to try to make some money out of here and do the fun stuff, something I've been doing for free for the last 10 years," Perez said.
He was happy with the turnout of the event considering it was a Thursday evening and the first time they've hosted this event, but he hopes to grow attendance next year. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community screening of the Rocky Horror Picture Show, a performance‑based event focused on fun, costumes, and audience participation, which aligns best with the Entertainment category.

YOGA WITH PATTY, 8 to 9 a.m., Dorchester Chamber of Commerce, second floor conference room, 306 High St., Cambridge. Designed for all skill levels, this class offers a harmonious blend of postures and breathing techniques to rejuvenate both mind and body. Call/text 410-463-8393 for reservations.

title: Colorful kites mark 20 years of Cambridge fest
author: JIM JOHNSON jjohnson@chespub.com
content:
Colorful kites mark 20 years of Cambridge fest

 October 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JIM JOHNSON jjohnson@chespub.com | Section: Dorchester 
 
 236
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Colorful kites dipped and darted in the skies above Sailwinds Park Sunday during the 20th annual Kitefest.A stiff breeze ranging from 15 to 17 mph provided enough wind to keep the kites airborne but was not strong enough to cause problems, particularly for some of the larger inflatables.
"You need a steady breeze," said Kitefest organizer Chad Malkas who added that the event was expected to draw between 500 and 1,000 kite fliers and spectators.
The event drew people from across the Delmarva region and featured carnival rides and RAR burgers. Volunteers from Baywater Animal Rescue brought a couple of puppies.
But the big draw was the kites.
Wings Over Washington brought a half dozen people who were flying small kites synchronized to music.
"We are a very active club," said Paul Dugard, who headed the Wings Over Washington team at Sailwinds on Sunday.
Dugard and three other kite fliers stood side-by-side and flew their four kites in tightly choreographed moves with Dugard barking commands into a headset much the way a square dance caller shouts moves to dancers.
"We've been fliying together for many years," he said, adding the group first started flying together in the 1980s.
Their years of experience showed as their kites crossed lines and then uncrossed. The four kites would climb into the sky together and then circle one another before reforming in a line, much like the precision flying of the Blue Angels or Thunderbirds. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community kite festival with performances, music, and rides, which aligns most closely with an entertainment event rather than other categories.

title: Spooktacular Fest in Denton brings family fun energy to start spooky season
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Spooktacular Fest in Denton brings family fun energy to start spooky season

 October 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 256
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On Friday evening, hundreds of Caroline County residents attend Spooktacular Fest in Denton, hosted by the Chesapeake Culinary Center.According to project manager Angel Perez, the major Halloween event is one of the biggest in Caroline County because the preparation starts in the summer to come up with new ideas to improve from the previous year's event.
"It takes a couple months to plan this this event, you always trying to show or provide something different than the previous year," Perez said.
Perez also mentioned new this year were more vendors and community resources.
According to Perez, the event saw more than 750 people this year with the new and improved haunted house inside the Chesapeake Culinary Center being the main attraction.
"We have a different haunted house this year, it's a little more like spooky than friendly," Perez said about new things at Spooktacular Fest this year. "We had venders this year, we had a DJ, we had an MC, we had a trivia game."
With vendors at the Spooktacular Fest, the hope was to give families an opportunity to have fun but also learn about community resources.
For growing and new families in Caroline County, the Spooktacular Fest allows for a fun place to enjoy the town besides the normal trick or treat day.
"We've lived in Denton for like five or six years, and I think it's just nice to have other than trick or treating like a party that our family can get dressed up and go to, and it has everything," said Denton resident Jennifer Reilby. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community Halloween festival with vendors, a haunted house, DJ, and trivia, which aligns most closely with the Entertainment category.
